Subnautica: Below Zero is a masterpiece of survival and exploration. The game takes you to a frozen alien planet, where you have to craft, build, and survive in a hostile environment. The game is full of stunning visuals, immersive sound effects, and captivating storylines. You will encounter new creatures, biomes, and mysteries as you dive deeper into the icy waters. The game also has a lot of replay value, as you can choose different paths, customize your base, and discover secrets. Subnautica: Below Zero is a must-play for fans of the original Subnautica and anyone who loves adventure and sci-fi games.

I first got this game during the Early Access period in 2019, and watched it take shape into it's fully released form. Below Zero is a worthy successor to the original, taking what made the original so great and expanding upon it. All the new environments are varied and interesting, and undeniably gorgeous. The larger emphasis on surface exploration was a really nice change of pace as well, which I thought was treated with just as much care and thoughtfulness as the underwater world. The story felt a bit weak, but it was still interesting enough to pull you through the game. If you liked Subnautica, chances are you'll like Below Zero.

Tbh would rather play this then the original, this is because it has better more colorful lighting then the previous game. 
The story is more interesting.

While having a peppy voiced protag is definitely a step down compared to the prior game pretty much everything else is a major step up. Which given Subnautica 1 was already quite the great little game this one blows it out of the water and right back into the water.

[h3] Achievement Hunting Rating 4/5 [/h3]
If you are familiar with the original Subnautica, Below Zero will be a fun continuation to scratch that itch. I would say it falls short of the original but it's not a bad game by any means. At some points I was confused on where the story was trying to take me and had to look up what my next objectives were. For achievements, you should be able to get them all in one play through if you are paying attention to the parallel stories at hand.

Fell short of the original, and kind of killed the vibe with a voiced MC. Much of the story is out of wack due to the amount of times it's been rewritten. otherwise it plays much the same as the original, save for the on-foot segments which the game was clearly not made for. Still a beautiful OST and world however.

I had a good time with this game but admittedly Subnautica (the first one) is one of my favorite games of all time. It does feel like a DLC or something for the first one but still had a good time with it. I do think it could have had some improvements to make it a bit more engaging but worth a playthrough if you enjoyed the first one.

First 30 min or so. A weaker game than Subnautica 1. The graphics are not improved from the color pallet to the lighting. They may have increased the resolution, but nothing else. I feel like everything is lit-up for me and there's significantly less mystery. The game is kidified without the gameplay being better, at least from the start.

[b] Pros; [/b] [list] 
[*] There's more to build.
[/list]
[b] Cons; [/b] [list]
[*] Story is more geared toward elementary school kids.
[*] Environment is too bright because there's no longer a dark, poorly lit ocean. Every area is instantly seen without a flashlight.
[*] They copied roughly 95% of plant and animal life and simply changed the color pallet to something less aesthetically pleasing.
[*] This game is supposed to be in the arctic, but virtually everything underwater shows almost no sign of an arctic ocean. In the first Subnautica, you could watch the discovery channel in a tropical ocean and play this game feeling as if they copied that real-life environment. In Subnautica 2, the conversation made no since. There's just as many plants, if not more in an arctic environment than the tropical.
[/list]

the game has long since come out.

but in short, honestly its just mediocre.

theres no single thing i can point at and go 'this is bad' but everything except for the textures feels like original subnautica but worse.

its just... lesser.


the game is less dangerous, like you arent surviving anymore, and reuses hostile wildlife more.

it has far less 'fear of the ocean', the moments where you gotta go down but you cant see the bottom so you descend into the inky blackness.

the map is smaller (by 60% aprox). 

the map is less deep (by 30% aprox). 

the map has less biomes.

oxygen is far too lenient considering how shallow the waters are. 

i kept waiting and waiting and waiting to find "the drop", like how once you reach the red grass area near the jelly cave in the original game everything starts getting much deeper.

the new writer scrapped the whole story midway in production and it show. the writing is not great, the plot we got was the worst of both worlds and full of nonsense.



conclusion: buy the original if you dont already own it.

Lets be upfront. This will never top Subnautica proper for immersion, dread, and experience. That said right there, this is WORTH the buy.

-The story is not as gripping as the environmental story telling from the first game but it has its moments. Seeing things the previous game only hinted at was really rewarding!
-Gameplay is great! A lot of improvements over the previous with pinned recipes, new upgrades, new items etc. Some minor issues like the small bug here and there or resources being annoying to farm but it kept my attention the entire 23 hours it took me to complete the game!
-The sounds and soundtrack are *Chef kiss*! Simple as that.

Some of the most noteworthy downsides for those hesitant to buy include glitching creatures, slow points in the story, and ANNOYING leviathans however the pros far outweigh the cons. I got this game to relive some OG subnautica gameplay as well as to get me out of a slump in my life. It worked! Held my attention and felt rewarding to complete after much set up! Its worth the price in my book.

Subnautica Below Zero is a very good game. In comparison to Subnautica its a massive visual upgrade. The biomes are varied and the fauna is unique. The biggest difference by far is the fact it has a speaking protagonist, whereas the first game only had the ai guide for the most part. Subnautica was a true survival craft, Below Zero is a linear story with an optional side story. 

Depending on how good you are at time and inventory management I'm sad to say this will not be a long play through. My one hundred percent all scans and all achievements save file only took 14 hours. This will not be the gauntlet that was the first game for most people. I found this to be a relaxing and fun return to the alien seas that stole my heart and mind in 2018.

Subnautica: Going Woke

In the real world most people struggle to make the best product possible. Most fail and you never notice them.
Here you have a company that created a masterpiece (original Subnautica) but instead of continuing to take their craft seriously they release this.

The core is still visible and don't get me wrong ... there are parts that are even better than in the first game. For example I really enjoyed exploring some caves where you need to refill your O2 while diving. The original version had this mechanic too but it was not utilised in like you never had to use that.

The negative parts include the story riddled with woke identity politics, a colored "body type 2" bad-ass main protagonist, children acting as scientists on a harsh ice planet, a PDA with an Indian text-to-speech accent, the stupid Spy Pengling that is needed to harvest fur, a vegetarian game option, ... The list goes on and on.
Unfortunately ... and this is the frustrating part ... these things are per choice. These are no accident or a lack of resources/skill. They are intentionally put there like a dick that is painted over a masterpiece.

This is a good game - Subnautica as a series has a wonderful survival core, but be warned that this isn't nearly as tight as the original.  It isn't a death blow, but the developers did some brave things, and not all of them paid off.  The original was quiet - the character didn't speak at all, and any recording or evidence of another human being was precious.  The player felt alone, and I found myself hording odd items just to make my base feel "lived in" - but, there was also a strange peacefulness to the silence.  In Sub-Zero, you're a can-do woman with things to say, but she was given some pretty substandard lines by the writers.  Her voice acting is passable, but there is an ongoing dialogue between her and another character (the ancient alien) which is so foolish and flat, it's genuinely bad for the game. The conversation comes through often enough that you lack that feeling of quietude that made the original so special. 

The overall "quest", however, is interesting - you're on a mission to discover what happened to your sister, who was assigned to a corporate scientific team on a frozen planet, but all communication went dark.  It's good stuff.  Yet, it can be challenging to know where to go next, and this game doesn't guide the player as neatly as the original.  Pacing isn't really a thing, and it can be all too easy to miss something small, but critical, especially when first getting the lay of the land.  Still, this could be a feature instead of a bug if you don't like having your hand held by the designers.  No matter your preference, though, the original should be played first.  This shouldn't be anybody's introduction to Subnautica.

The additional items and structures added to the game are only sometimes an improvement on the original - I'm sad but understanding of the omission of the full-base-sized submarine from the original, but the sea-truck cannot hold a candle to the Seamoth (the single seat submarine from Subnautica I) in terms of appeal.  On the other hand, the recent inclusion of a new base structure that allows a truck with multiple modules to dock completely is VERY well done.  Whoever designed that?  Hats off to you.

In summary, Sub-Zero was an attempt by the designers to add some fresh ideas to the original, but not everything was an improvement - the dialogue was poorly executed, and navigating some of the three-dimensional mazes are a clinic in frustration, but despite these painful hurdles, Subnautica as well as Sub-Zero are deeply evocative, stirring experiences, and should be explored.  Just, for this title, maybe wait for a sale.

Game was glitchy as hell. It started off small with a few lighting issues. No big deal. Then all of the plants and stuff that lays on the ground just stopped appearing, meaning the entire ground was just a flat empty pile of sand and rocks. The plants would randomly pop back into existence for a while then leave again. Then it got worse when all the fish and mineral rocks stopped spawning, meaning literally the entire ocean was empty and I couldn't collect anything. 
Then because it somehow could get worse, one of the biomes just didn't render right, and it was just pure white. Like I was swimming around in a grayish rocky area, then BOOM, hard line dividing the biome I'm in and the next one and it's just pure white. I thought "wow this is pretty bad" as I then started literally swimming through the land. It just didn't even exist and I stared swimming straight down through all the land. I eventually came up for air and kept going wondering how it could get worse. 
I thought "maybe it's a setting I have turned on that's causing problem." But instead of going into the setting I accidentally hit "save", to which it then proceeded to freeze up on the save screen and I had to force quit the game. Upon reloading I was right back at the start, losing all my progress. Maybe I'll give it another shot some time down the road, but damn, that was horrible.

[code]TL;DR: this game is by no means bad, but compared to the original, it is very short-sighted and not worth the price they charge for this game in my opinion.[/code]

while it definitely isn't as vast and as captivating as the original subnautica, i would still recommend it once it goes on sale. it is a new experience for returning subnautica players and offers some truly beautiful environments and excellent creatures. although...

i can't deny that the on-land game mechanics feel undeveloped. it still genuinely feels like a chore to climb up land and get over ledges, and once you play the game for long enough, you wonder why the snowfox even exists when you can just use the prawn suit with the grappling hook upgrade. the freezing mechanics don't help with the fact that land exploration in subnautica is already far less dynamic compared to sea exploration, which only makes the game feel more like a chore than an adventure. additionally, some of the animations outright look unfinished and overall weak.

as for the storytelling aspects of this game; i overall felt underwhelmed by them. by far my favorite part has to be the exploration of the architect race and ALAN, as it only further develops the intricacies of the species and dives deeper into the unknown universe of subnautica. not to mention, there are a few well written interactions between the characters which i found pretty entertaining. as for the rest of the story, though? it feels like a weak rehash of the original, being told in a far less interesting way. in the original subnautica, a major focus was put on the player themselves, the mystery of the universe, and naturally piecing together the story by observing and interacting with the environment. in subnautica: below zero, it feels like you are just listening to a voice actor do their job in the studio due to how the game presents itself, and when you add the fact that the environmental storytelling is far less subtle than the original, these elements really remove the sense of wonder and mystery that the original game had.

if you have never played a subnautica game before, definitely play and finish the first before playing this one. by no means is this game awful, but the first game simply delivers a better experience for players than this one does in my opinion.

This and it's predecessor share a ranking as my all time favorite video games. The atmosphere is incredibly, you really feel immersed in the world.  The ecology feels unique but still grounded in some reality, with many of the creatures having unique behaviors that keep the game interesting. The story line is captivating and the voice acting really helps that. The only main thing I'd really criticize is that leviathans are much to easy to avoid and don't have as many unique ways of attacking or getting in your way then I'd like. As well, I think this game has less of a sense of wonder then the first. Idk if that's just because the player is used to this world by the second game or if it's because the environments aren't as awe-inspiring. Do appreciate that  there's no more clunky Cyclops game play in this one though. Overall I still absolutely adore this game, it and Subnautica 1 offer something unique that I don't think any other game truly captures as well.

After only 3 hours it is clear to me, that this game lost everything that made the first part great: The underwater world is way to constructed and artifically colourful to unfold any kind of lasting atmosphere. The constant droning of way to frequent, annoyingly long and quite frankly uninteresting audiologs contributes to the same factor as well as making sure you never feel alone, while the feeling of being alone was to me one of the factors that really drove said lasting atmosphere of the first game home. The first game was a masterclass in how reduced design makes a world feel natural & believable - after all reality isn't constructed to be visually entertaining either - just to be all the more intense when you break that scheme at the end to slowly lead the player into very otherwordly setpieces. This game on the other hand is a perfect negative example of how turning up everything to eleven constantly nets you a sum of enjoyability below zero.
I absolutely love both the original and this sequel and cannot wait for the third one!

It's just okay. Hard to believe this is the sequel since a lot of features are a downgrade from the first one. I have accepted I am never going to finish this game. The map design is irritating and difficult to navigate. The land areas in particular are labyrinthine with winding paths and multiple levels of elevation and are very annoying to deal with, especially during the scavenger hunt the game sends you on. (Way too much time spent on land for a series originally centered around deep sea exploration.) The flora & fauna are pretty similar to the first game but the hostile creature designs were lackluster and are rarely seen in the game, especially compared to the first one where reapers are a frequent threat. There are some very minor improvements to the base building system (basically just a larger room option) but it feels like this game is riding on the coattails of a successful standalone game. There is very little in this game that I consider successful that wasn't imported from the first game.

I became entirely dependent on walkthroughs to progress the story because after a while I wasn't getting dialogue triggers or objectives telling me what to do. Not sure if this is a bug, related to me accidentally finding a plot point out of order, or if the game really does leave you dead in the water later in the story. I put a decent number of hours into this game but most of them were not fun - lots of time backtracking for specific resources, traveling back and forth across the map looking for objectives the game wasn't marking for me,  and carefully following walkthroughs to try and figure out what I missed.

The story is great, but suddenly having a talking protagonist could be immersion breaking for some people, and the fear factor from the first game is almost non-existent here until maybe the late game, due to the familiarity of biomes from having played the first game.

Subnautica: Below Zero is a good game.

"But why do so many people who enjoyed the original also enjoy hating Below Zero?" You may ask.

Because there's a certain expectation with a new game in a series to follow things exactly as they are done in the previous games of the series. Innovation tends to be punished when a developer deviates from an original formula.

I think BZ is better than Subnautica in many ways, but that's just my opinion. I'll try to outline why I think that way though.

The first is obviously narrative. Subnautica had little to no story, with only a silent protagonist and drop pod messages probing you to explore deeper to uncover what happened. That's fine, the focus of the games is different (and this is why I think so many people hate BZ, but I'll explain that in a bit). While the original focused more on exploration and the fear of the unknown, the sequel wants to tell a story within the world that was built in Subnautica. The voice actors are good, the story is decently written (imo), and the way it unfolds is similar to the original in that you will receive clues at certain intervals (this time from a character that the MC interacts with instead of because of dead drop pod messages). Overall the story is better (imo), and it's given life with just a few characters. A few of the people (not all of them) I've seen complain about the story generally seemed to hate the characters as people rather than giving any legitimate complaints about story. It boils down to insults including vague things like "boring" and "annoying", then going to the weird like "too many women" or "too g@y" (Yeah, some people actually wanted to make those complaints). It's fine not to like the characters and judge the game based on that, everyone is entitled to their opinions (and this is just mine). Just know that there are certain biases tainting those opinions (everyone has biases, including me).

The second is the world. Subnautica was about the fear of the unknown, unexplored areas, and mysterious dangers. The world was vast, sometimes dark, and often incredibly scary. This worked well when you first play the game, but after that it's incredibly predictable. On a second play through of the game I found myself jumping out of vehicles and knifing leviathans until they died after I stunned them. You can do this in BZ too, it's just not as interesting to do so because the world is more interesting than the fear (imo). You see, with the original the biomes eventually became large open spaces (for a specific reason that I'll get into next) that didn't hold much more than a few resources and one or two leviathans to keep you away from the borders. In BZ each biome has lots of interesting creatures, plants, and resources. Things are more abundant and the world feels alive. I always thought it was a little weird in the first game that a MASSIVE space conglomerate like Alterra came to a planet to strip mine it while I'm struggling to find enough resources to build a SINGLE base under water. The story in Subnautica tried to hand wave that away, but it was only vaguely successful in doing so. The original felt too *dead* to me for the story it wanted to tell. BZ is tightly packed with tidbits of info everywhere, and the environments are better at telling that story too (imo).

Finally there's the vehicles. I don't know if people are romanticizing the Seamoth and the Cyclops from the first game but this is where I adamantly disagree with a lot of people who don't like BZ. The Seamoth, while useful in the original, actually only had one purpose: faster exploration. Well, two if you count "getting away from leviathans" as another. Because aside from arriving somewhere quicker without running out of oxygen, it was essentially useless. In the beginning bumping into a small fish could cause you to lose 10 percent of your hull, never mind bumping into a spire or getting grabbed by a leviathan. I found myself repairing my Seamoth more than actually travelling in my first play through until I found the hull upgrade. Which is just a waste of an upgrade slot honestly. The Cyclops... Oh, the Cyclops. An unwieldy and even more annoying "vehicle." The open and dead spaces I mentioned earlier were probably meant to allow you to traverse them using the Cyclops... Because if it wasn't as open it would be an even bigger nightmare to maneuver that thing than it already was. Not to mention that if you're using the cyclops it's to get somewhere really dangerous... but you'll have to be jumping out to knock off fish hiding on the hull and sucking your power or to repair the Cyclops hull... or even putting out fires if it's your first time piloting it without a specific upgrade. Less fun, more micromanaging, much more annoying. The Sea-Truck is a good cross between the Seamoth and the Cyclops. You have more speed if you detach the modules, a sturdier hull than the Seamoth, more maneuverability than the Cyclops (which also works better in the tighter and more focused environments), and finally, it's not annoying to drive it.

Below Zero isn't trying to be Subnautica 1.5, which is what I see a lot of people wanting. It would be impossible to reclaim that success, especially with how Subnautica relied on the fear of the unknown. I think the developers understood that many second time players were going to find it predictable thanks to how things worked in Subnautica so they wouldn't be as afraid as they were in the first game. People probably would have complained about that as well, and I think they knew that. It's a "d**ned if you do, d**ned if you don't" scenario honestly.

If you think a game that's set in the same world as Subnautica but *isn't* exactly like Subnautica doesn't appeal to you, then the first game still exists. You can definitely replay that, and it would probably make you happier than this game.

Below Zero is a different flavor of subnautica than the original, but it is just as engaging in its own way. Below Zero is far more character-driven, and with a smaller but very much denser world to explore. The survival crafting pipeline has changed somewhat in the particulars of how you advance and what's available, with some new tools to aid you. The story is strong, if a little bumpy on a couple beats, and the ending wraps things up in a satisfying way.

Where Subnautica gave a very open experience as a whole, Below Zero's denseness doesn't detract and offers a unique adventure; I highly recommend it!

I'm going to cry.

I loved the first Subnautica.  It was the ocean exploration game I'd always dreamed of.  The creatures were beautiful in sound and in design.  The story unfolded through your exploration.  The world felt so big and alive.  It was an immersive (lol) experience near perfection, especially for an aquatic science nerd like me.

Then they decided to make Below Zero.  And somehow - either through incompetence or spite, because there's no way this was done through ignorance - they took everything that people loved and replaced it with the parts that people hated.

Namely, the biggest change: instead of exploration driving the story, story drives the exploration.  This sounds great on paper, but is terrible in execution.  Mainly because the game utilizes Forspoken-style dialogue long before Forspoken made it noticeable.  You know the reveal in Subnautica when [spoiler]you try to deactivate the gun, only to be told you are infected and the planet is in quarantine[/spoiler]?  How the player is given that much information and then gives them time to realize the situation?  If it were this game's writers, [spoiler]Robin would have shouted "Quarantine?  Infected?  Oh, this isn't good.  I need to find a cure and fast!" and Alan might have chimed in with a "I concur.  Time is of the essence, for the infection spreads quickly."[/spoiler]  That's the game.  [i]You[/i] don't get to decide how you feel about the situation you are in.  The game will tell you what you need to feel.  It will tell you where to go next.  And it will rip you out of your immersion every time.  [spoiler]Also I [i]hate[/i] that they brought back Margeruite.  Ruins the Degasi storyline just to give people fanservice, because people decided that people who kill wildlife indiscriminately are cool.  I never liked Marge.  And I don't like that she's here.  Especially since her presence amounts to NOTHING.[/spoiler]

Creature design is a step down.  They don't look or act like beings adapted to their environment, as the critters in the first game did.  They look and act like beings adapted to be in a videogame.  The predators have looks and sounds that demand the audience be scared of them.  Its the same effect as a man in costume chasing you in a haunted house screaming "OOGA BOOGA BOOGA."  The Leviathans don't deliver the same awe or terror as the ones in the first game; again, the designs try to hard to be spooky.  Honestly, the only design I encountered that I liked were the sea monkeys.  And even then, they're overanimated to the point of parody.  

The only thing this game did better than the first was base building options.  You can build a huge underwater house with rooms, rather than a bunch of circular modules.  These options lead to a much more homier base that looks more refined.  But they added a lot of that back to Subnautica, so there is really absolutely no reason to get this game.

If I sound unusually harsh, its because this is a franchise I care about.  I bought this game day one of Early Access.  I remember when Robin was a researcher sending samples to her sister Sam up on a satellite [spoiler]which would lead to Robin accidentally sending a live Kharaa sample, needing to find and befriend Sea Emperors to save the research station (or at least, that was the theory)[/spoiler], and when [spoiler]Alan[/spoiler] was a prick who warmed up to life [spoiler]and was heavily implied to end up getting put in a Warper body[/spoiler].  It was cozy and a great base line for an unfolding story set in a growing frozen world.  It was all about research and exploration, just like what I wanted.  And they THREW IT ALL OUT THE WINDOW BECAUSE I DONT KNOW.  I genuinely do NOT know what they were going for.  And the final result is such an obnoxious, hand-holdy, unimmersive experience.

Here's hoping the true Subnautica 2 will be a return to form.  I shudder to think of the result if they decide to do the whole "throw out the parts people liked and buckle down on what they didnt" cycle again.

Visually, this is one of the most beautiful games I've ever played. There is something about jumping into the ocean for the first time that just brings me sheer joy with this game, and has pulled me back many times.

That said, however, this game does lack with its story. The story is a bit bland, doesn't make much sense, and has too much direction. The original Subnautica was a masterpiece, you were thrown into the deep end (literally) and had to figure everything out yourself. This is the opposite, and in that regard, it fails. Subnautica is renowned for its "Leviathans", the scariest aspect of the game, but Below Zero offers very little with regards to this. Only 1 real 'true' leviathan within the waters, and only 1 real 'deep' location to explore.

I can only hope that with the sequel that is coming, they take the visual aspects of Below Zero but return to their roots of Subnautica... No dialogue, No direction, a vast open ocean, and depths that really challenge your decision making. With new and spine chilling leviathans.

All said though, I would recommend picking this game up on sale, as it does offer some hours of fun. And even if the story does lack, exploring the beautiful sea is very calming.

If steam had one of those "maybe" instead of a "yes" "no", i would have chosen that... This game is more meant to attract mainstream users than to offer a sequel to what fans of the 1st game loved.

Like: the MC is voiced!... you know what I realised? MC voice was a mistake. Why? Well if MC was voiceless = they could add the option to create your own character, regardless of gender, race, colour, it doesn't matter. Why? because all of this elements Don't even matter in this game.

If you look on the "cut out content" wiki and similar stuff that where not added in the 1st game, you will realise this game, is much smaller exactly to add as many of those cut stuff as possible. In the 1st game, iirc, they wanted 2 glacier ares, but wasn't added.... so now you have a game featuring the whole events in an arctic ocean... ruining already the "explore the deep ocean" because: you are to focused on the weather (another added cut out), so above it's not a safe space. You go under? it's just caves and caves and more caves, you get claustrophobic at most, but you feel no sense of deep since the caves are small, so you go down and instantly get to "bottom", like a "L" tunnel....  Anyone who finished the 1st game, know what I mean since the end game areas ruing the atmosphere of "going down in the deep dark endless ocean" as well You even forget you are in the ocean.... or fish.... well this game is fairly similar

Copy paste for so many elements that where not added in the 1st game that where added here (like weather), so of course this game is much smaller.



Exploring: You get very annoyed that there are tons and tons of small equipment, the same one, over and over again. Aka to create a use for the scanner since there isn't as much in this game

Now, the best part this game did: Seatruck. Why? it's small so you can go into the caves, like very small. And being a truck, you can add more units..... except... whoever decided the storage unit should never be in charge of game decisions ever again.... Once thing I hated even with the 1st game: Fasting time to go back and forth since inventory is full. So getting said truck extension for storage was my #1 priority. I needed to explore everywhere to get items and more, and of course, need to go back and forth since inventory is full. Finally I found where to find the blueprints but aggressive and dangerous enemy and traps. Due to again, the whole, going back and forth due to inventory, missing equipment, new ways to protecting and more, it took like what? 1 -2 hours? to get all of them while trying to not die. Finally got the blueprints.... they need resources that I had no clue where they are.... finally got all of them.... what do I get? One of the most horrible storage units ever. It's like the devs are trying to punish you for wanting this. Imagine there are 3 different shape and types inside. so instead of using 100% of the wall, they just trowed different size for reasons only they know. And all of them have very small storage... one of them has only 12 space... it actually makes me wish that unit was a wall, so i could add a wall storage that gives me 30 space. And of course, because it's such a little space, you need to go back and forth between them when moving stuff, only all of them having the "naming" screen so you will end up pressing that one to many times. I don't know how far I am in the game, but I honestly wish there is something better because this storage unit would be the most perfect think for this game to allow player to collect as much resources as they need without wasting real life going back and forth. But hey! if you collect more materials you can create and attach more! how wonderful, if it was not for the speed penalty so you ending up wasting as much real life time driving the long with tons of important storage space, as you would going back and forth full speed (and this with a non stocking module to increase speed). So you guessed it, the dev themselves ruined one of the best aspects of this game but punishing players to actually try and use new features. Then they wonder why no one touch most of the stuff in this game (look at global %), after all, you need tons of space to transport all the needed resourced and equipment.... something that would NOT be an issue if a certain green storage box had a massive storage size, or connected to a warehouse or similar, but nope, small storage, to make some people happy that the game is realistic instead of enjoyable

End of story question: why are every last game developers obsessed with limited inventory? guess what, it makes us NOT use a lot of the stuff you add in the game exactly because we have no space to carry them for when we could use them and no one will go back just to get them. Even games that have stacked, the always put 99 max. Regardless what SIFI in game explanation, if everything collected, would go in an infinity inventory, accessible any time if you need to use something, create or build, games like this one would get rid of a lot of unnecessary game element that just ruins the idea of exploring, collecting and utilising everything game has to offer.
It is so immersive it really makes you feel like you are in an alien world.

This game is more Subnautica, which is great. 

I definitely recommend playing the first game first. This game has some slight improvements in gameplay but still has the same core. It also came with some of Subnautica's flaws. The game has a small hotbar, clunky inventory and there are some parts of the story where I feel like its easy to get lost. 

The world is still beautiful, deep and interactive. There are very interesting creatures that make up the world and their lives and interactions give the world life and interesting gameplay interactions. I do find the large predators less interesting then the Original but there are many more interesting small and medium creatures. 

The world building of the first game really helps with setting up the story for this game. The story is a little more direct and I feel like it was done well. There are good characters and interesting twists. 

There are several base additions that are really fun. Making your base a home with comforts and some fun stuff really helps balance out from the exploration.

Sum: Subnautica is awesome. Play it. Then take a breather and when you want more Subnautica Below Zero will scratch that itch.

This will be a tough one... (spoiler warning)
[h3] On the surface [/h3]
Generally speaking, it's good.
The general gameplay feels nice and exploration feels mostly rewarding with many things to discover.
While in the first few hours of gameplay it might feel like a copy of Subnautica with some ice slapped on top of it, one will soon discover, that the game does indeed have it's own charm and feel to it, wich is mostly due to the fact, that this time [spoiler] you're not alone on 4546B.[/spoiler]
This is where the game goes it's own way, and not necessarily only downhill.
From here on out I'll no longer censor spoilers, since it'll just be too much censorship.
[h3] Positive aspects [/h3]
- The game gives you an objective from the very beginning
- The progression regarding ressources and technology is (mostly) steady
- There are [b] almost [/b] no instances, where you truly have no idea what you are supposed to do next.
- Story has an interesting concept
- Many new customization options for your base
- Non-linear story progression and exploration
[h3] Negative aspects [/h3]
   [u] Map Design [/u]
  The Map not only became [b] significantly [/b] smaller, but also a lot more barren and repetetive. The biomes don't feel 
  very unique (except the cave biomes) and large areas are completely empty, especially the eastern and western arctic 
  regions.
  Additionally, a large portion (roughly one third of the map) is now dry land / Ice. The ice areas are not only very empty   
  and difficult to traverse, but also extremely annoying because of the unkillable ice worms.
  [u] Gameplay [/u]
  Whilst i have mentioned earlier that the gameplay feels nice, there are some major flaws in the progression mechanics.
-My most dominant issue is that you unlock the Prawn Suit way too early. Once you have built it, there is absolutely no 
  need for the cold suit or the Snow Fox. There is not a single cold area that you cannot enter with the Prawn Suit, which is 
  also more resistant against Ice Worm attacks and can mine the ressources, which are scattered around the areas.
-Due to the small size of the map there is no need for a Seatruck functioning as a mobile base and you have no 
  encouragement to build secondary bases like in Subnautica.
-It's very unlikely that you will ever have shortages of ressources in this game. There are way too many large ressource 
  nodes placed on the map, many of which are also mostly unguarded, which brings me to my next point.
  [u] Danger [/u]
-In comparison to Subnautica you feel way too safe in this game. Enemies other then leviathans can barely harm your 
  Seatruck, since you get a free defence system early on and all enemies simply flee whenever they take damage, so that 
  you can easily repair your vehicle back up to 100%.
 -Leviathans are nowhere near as scary as in Subnautica and are very easy to fight using the Prawn Suit. Additionally they 
  are rare and easily avoidable, since they are not very aggressive.
 -The lack of danger takes away a lot of the original feelings.
 [u] Story [/u]
 -While the story is indeed interesting, if feels not nearly as well thought out as Subnautica's story, since there are many 
  unanswered questions, so many that i can only 
  [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/subnautica/comments/nmbqvr/spoilers_some_remaining_questions_after_below/] Link a 
  reddit post [/url] about them.
  [h2] Conclusion [/h2]
  Subnautica: Below zero is, despite my seemingly endless negative points, in my opinion still a great and worthwhile game 
  to play, especially if you liked Subnautica. This game however, doesn't shine nearly as bright as Subnautica does and has 
  many flaws, which made it difficult for me to decide wether or not I should give a positive or a negative review.

  Map design: 6/10
  Gameplay: 7/10
  Story: 4/10

  Despite this somewhat disapointing sequel, I have very high hopes for the third installment of the series, and am eager to 
  recieve news about it!
FISH

[h1]6/10 - More of a Subnautica DLC expansion. Still pretty good but doesn't have the magic of the original game[/h1]

✅ Review does not contain spoilers. TL;DR at the bottom
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

[b]• STORY: 4/10[/b]
Not even comparable to the original game, the story in Below Zero is "Meh", it's not terrible but I finished playing it two days ago and can barely remember it. It's basically just a [i]"go here and find this thing, then go there and find that, and go over there to find those, bring them here and put X, Y, and Z together... then profit??[/i]

[b]• DIFFICULTY: 3/10[/b]
Just as easy as the original game, there is no real challenge at all. Everything has a big glowing map marker, and there is not a huge amount to explore in this game. This game could really do with a bunch of mods to increase the difficulty.

[b]• GRAPHICS: 5/10[/b]
Pretty much exactly the same as the original, very brightly colored and pretty but one of the first things I did was create a ReShade preset to reduce the color saturation, make the game darker so it was better on an HDR monitor, and also add a lot of underwater blurring/water effect so I can't see nearly 1km underwater.
With a dark and water blur shader it did make it a little challenging, plus I had to enable mod to change the recipes for crafting to make them much more grindy and challenging.

[b]• MAP / EXPLORATION: 4/10[/b]
The map feels a fraction of the size, The distance between one story objective and the next one can be as little as two minutes of swimming, it really does hurt the game. There are estimations that the map is 1/4th (25%) of the size of the original game's map, but not only from one side to the other it's also the depth, it's 1/3rd (30%) of the map depth in the original game. 
There are around 40 biomes in the original game and they mostly all feel different, whereas there are only 12-15 in Below Zero and I would argue a few of them are the same.

[b]• MOD SUPPORTt: 7/10[/b]
It doesn't have anywhere near as many mods or as much support as the original game but it does still have a decent number of mods and it uses the same tools as the original game so it's fairly easy to create mods for it.
Installing them is super easy, drag and drop, click play.

[b]• Replayability & Game length: 4/10[/b]
The main story is very bland and you could probably complete it in 5 hours if you weren't bothered about going off and exploring. I don't think it has much replayability because there just isn't the exploration that there is in the original game.

[b]• BUGS: 8/10[/b]
This was one very good thing, I only encountered a couple of minor bugs, a few of the large leviathans still clip through walls, and you can occasionally get snagged on something you should easily be able to walk or jump over, but overall, nothing game breaking at all.

[b]• PERFORMANCE & FPS: 8/10[/b]
Another good thing, running at 4k (2160p) resolution on maximum graphical settings I was able to comfortably run at 100+fps even with a heavy ReShade preset enabled on a 3080Ti.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
[b]TL;DR (Conclusion):[/b]

Below Zero started off scratching the Subnautica itch and gave me those same feelings from the original game... but that only lasted about an hour until I realised it was a shallow puddle.
When I saw how rinse and repeat it is, and how tiny the map is, it spoiled the game right at the beginning when I knew it wasn't going to be a shadow of the original game.

It's not a [b]bad[/b] game, if Below Zero was a standalone title in a world where the original Subnautica didn't exist then I would say Below Zero was a pretty decent game, but it's not, it's a sequel to [b]Subnautica[/b]... one of the best games that has been released in the past 20 years, and Below Zero is not Terminator 2 or Aliens, it's not an amazing sequel that many would even argue is even better than the original... Below Zero is Robocop 3 or Dumb and Dumber Too... it's a slightly embarrassing far cry from capturing the original's magic.

Not as good as the original but really enjoyable in VR none the less.  I wasn't expecting it to be as short as it was with so few biomes so I way over farmed materials. I'd give the original a 10/10 and rthis a 7.5/10.

The game is not bad, but I'd like to remind the developers of two important definitions: 

Sub: Prefix, from the Latin "sub"-, under, expressing a lower position in space.
 
Nautică: Feminine singular or neuter plural form of the Latin word "nauticus", meaning "sailor" or "naval", and in a broader sense related to the sea.

I have the impression that the developers forgot these definitions halfway through the game's development.

The predecessor of the masterpiece game Subnautica doesn't follow the same formula the first game does. In Below Zero you have a lot more walking and land creatures. In my opinion the story does follow up quite nicely and this game is worth buying.

As others have said, frequently, this game is no Subnautica. It's good, but it just feels limited. One thing that stands out and really contributes to the feeling others have described of this feeling like a Subnautica DLC rather than it's own game is that you are basically spoon fed the blueprints. If you played Subnautica, you'll remember scouring the ocean for tech fragments, taking you to new and exciting areas of the map. In Below Zero, there are many times where you'll scan one thing and get between 2 and 6 blueprints out of it. Very little fragment hunting. The progression was extremely fast. Where I had no less than four bases in the original game to take advantage of things only found in those areas, or to help with exploration there, in Below Zero it was one and done. 

I never felt the sense of apprehension or downright terror I did in the first game. The new leviathans were cool, and I did like them, but the overall sense of "Oh God what's down there" never really hit me here. 

The map is very small, and to go deeper you'll be looking for quite small caves leading down. I felt like most of the biomes, while still unique and striking, were too small to really develop the kind of personality you found in the first game. And the land portions, taking up probably about 1/5 of the explorable areas, were frankly miserable to slog through. Without spoiling too much, one major contributor to the first game being as great as it was, was your ability to see that there's something spoopy up ahead, and move around it carefully. Or, if you did get ambushed, you could usually run away to safety with your heart in your throat. These land sections on the other hand have enemies that pop out of nowhere and are very hard to avoid, meaning you're running into them every two minutes, and you aren't afraid of them as much as you're annoyed. 

However, I have to give props to the Twisty Bridges biome. That place was just stunning in every way.

Overall, if you haven't played the first one, go play that instead. Below Zero would be an ok game on it's own, but honestly I feel like I only enjoyed it as much as I did because I was trying to fill the Subnautica shaped hole in my heart after finishing the first one.

Would have been better as a maybe 10 hour DLC for the original Subnautica. The map was big and without crafting/leaving location coordinate markers all over the map at key locations it was easy to get turned around and lost. The main strengths are the beauty of the biomes/creatures and the detailed (very much alive) underwater world the devs created here. Would recommend only if a big fan of the first one.

It's not as good as the original but it's still a good game. If you haven't played the original Subnautica, treat yourself and go do that since it's one of the greatest survival games of all time. Below Zero, not so much. I'm just going to talk about differences and what I did and/or didn't like about them.

- The map feels much smaller than the original. I'm not sure if it actually is or if it's just so cluttered that it feels more confined so I didn't have that feeling of exploration that I had in the original.

- The story is kind of bland and completely removes the atmosphere of complete isolation that the original did so well.

- The Seatruck is an obvious attempt to combine the Seamoth and the Cyclops from the original. But it lacks the maneuverability  of the Seamoth and the customization of the Cyclops so it ends up feeling inferior to both.

- The land elements are a little rough but nowhere near as bad as they were in the original Subnautica. It's like people forget that the few land elements in the first game were terrible. In Below Zero, the land elements are passable.

- The Prawn Suit still exists but I never built it. I didn't need it. There was nowhere I needed to go that the Seatruck couldn't reach and no reason to mine resource nodes.

- I don't know why people say it lacks the feeling of threat from the first game. There are still monsters ranging from small biting fish to absolute giants that will straight up try to wreck your Seatruck and end you. There are even predators on land. Much like the first game, none of them are difficult to deal with once you learn their attacks.

- In the first Subnautica, I built multiple bases around the map and enjoyed doing so. In Below Zero, I built one small three-room base and two one-room outposts. With there being a pretty linear story that's constantly giving you goals to follow and finish, building elaborate bases felt like a waste of time so I didn't.

- There were so many things that I didn't bother building or gathering blueprints for because they were not needed. There were also things that I used one time then never again. I feels like many of the new additions in Below Zero weren't very well thought out before being implemented. 

So that's it. It's not a bad survival game but it doesn't expand upon what made the original Subnautica so amazing.

Subnautica was one of the best games of the last two decades. The atmosphere, the sound design, the sense of impending danger and of actually [i]being[/i] there.

Below Zero is basically a fan mod made by someone who completely failed to understand what made the original game great.

On its own, it's a mediocre and almost instantly forgettable game, with annoying cookie-cutter characters and a cheesy, predictable, checkbox-ticking (and ultimately nonsensical) "plot" (or rather, two separate plots that don't even mesh together, and actually contradict each other at several points). Compared to the original, it's probably the biggest [i]disappointment[/i] of the last two decades.

I thoroughly loved the first Subnautica, and this one had potential. However there is one major problem that is preventing me from finishing the game. There is a bug where I have to keep remaking ALL my prawn suit attachments and upgrades. After the first time I submitted several bug reports, waited a couple of months, remade everything, and then it happened again. I have to uninstall as I cannot finish the game.

Great game. The ambience is awesome, the amount of things to do are pretty insane, and the overall feel of it is good. There's some glitchy stuff that crops up every once in a while (for example, saw a Snow Stalker literally hovering off a cliff once just walking around a bit), but overall everything is smooth... and a good amount of scary without like completely terrifying me. Also, does a good job of guiding the player along a path with the story while still leaving it completely up to them as to what they want to do and providing plenty to do off the main storyline.

After white-knuckling through the first game, I'm sadly not at all motivated to finish this one. I wish I could give a *Mixed Review* because this isn't without it's merits.

It's got a lot carried over from subnautica, but enough is missing to make this a very unflattering comparison--

There is little sense of mystery, isolation, danger unlike in Sub1.  The VAs did well with what they were given, but the addition of SO MUCH conversation, including the protag's constant commentary on everything, makes you feel like you're being led by the nose on what to do.  Even with that much handholding, a lot of changes leave us with less of a game.

Land travel is a large part of this game, very odd diversion from the prior installment and feeling very clunky.

The Alien passenger in your brain-- I am sure this could have been an interesting idea in some game, but part of the wonder from Sub1 was that the precursor aliens were a total mystery.  Everything we knew of them was through environmental storytelling.  Having 1st hand interaction just feels... wrong.

And the seatruck is a terrible trade for the seamoth.  The seamoth was so fun to use, and while the seatruck has some utility, it's boring as heck to drive.  I hated having to use it.  The prawn suit seemed clunkier than in Sub1.  I mainly was using the seaglide for everything because the other options were so darn cumbersome.

If I am playing Sub1 or its follow-ups, I would hope for that feeling of total isolation, mystery I have to unravel, freedom to fail, and danger that isn't totally able to be ignored. I just am too spoiled from the first game to enjoy this one.

What Below Zero does well the original game did better, and everything else is either a downgrade or lacks significant improvements. Exploration no longer has the streamlined metroidvania style of Subnautica, but is much more open-world. This means that if you are the kind of player who likes to explore every corner of a newly discovered area, you can easily end up accidentally sequence-breaking the already questionable progression. This risk is further exacerbated by the strange decision to give the player a map of the entire playable area very early on. 
And without taking sequence-breaking into account, it also gives you things that trivialize certain elements of the game before they get to be relevant.
All of that without mentioning the resource balance, which is all over the place now.


In terms of world design there are some areas with good visuals, but a significant portion of what you will see underwater looks so similarly empty to the dead zone that you may end up in it accidentally, with barely any detail or interesting features in the terrain. 
Even the more detailed biomes have little purpose beyond a few "points of interest" (or even a single one) which are lackluster more often than not. Just scan or grab this one thing that is randomly scattered on the ground and you're done with the zone, time to move on to the next one. Most of them feel pretty much identical to each other from the scenarios to the writing.

Land sections are not really any better despite the fact they were a major focus in the marketing of the game. They basically consist of massive empty areas, enemies that can be easily ignored and a weather system that is more of an annoyance than a challenge, with storms that greatly reduce visibility happening way too often.

There's also a very excessive amount of loops and dead ends that make exploration feel like a chore.


I really missed the horror elements Subnautica had too, which Below Zero does not really expand upon. It's a survival game, yet you never really feel like your life is actually in danger.
The music has some great tracks, but like the rest of the game lacks the spooky atmosphere I was hoping for in supposedly tense situations.

This game is quite focused in its characters and has plenty of dialogue, but it's generally not for the better. It's full of cheesy lines, stereotypical characters with one-dimensional personalities, repetitive scenes, pointless additions and sanctimonious philosophy that sometimes contradicts other elements of the story. I am also not a fan of the direction the overall narrative took.

After learning the original writer left during development and the new one was asked to remake the story, it seems the reason it appears to be rushed is because it was.


When it comes to vehicles, the Seatruck introduces interesting ideas with its modularity, but being somewhere in-between what the Seamoth and the Cyclops could accomplish, it ends up underwhelming in comparison. Modules either add things that could be done with the builder tool in the Cyclops in a less annoying and more customizable way or niche functions you don't really need, a common theme for the new tools. 
In addition, the Prawn Suit feels much less agile than I remember, although I'd still rather use it on land than bother with the Snowfox's awful camera and controls.


There are a lot of bugs too. Subnautica already had its fair share, but Below Zero took it to the next level for me, with multiple game-breaking bugs including freezes, crashes, water disappearing and causing me to fall into the void, an NPC clipping inside the Seatruck making it unusable, the Seatruck getting stuck both in the Moonpool and the Docking Module (the latter of which could only be fixed by destroying it), weird audio volume changes on and near the surface, NPCs getting stuck or floating in the air, foundations and water filtration machines being impossible to remove right after being placed without destroying half the base because of things they weren't even touching being close by... 

I also accidentally went out of bounds multiple times on land, which is as simple as jumping on the wrong spot with the Prawn Suit. That and how good it is at dealing with enemies there makes me think it wasn't taken into account at all when designing the land sections.


Overall, the game does have a few enjoyable moments (particularly at the start), but it could have been so much better it's hard to recommend.

Its not bad to me but the first game set the standard higher so it pales in comparison. Creature designs don't feel that memorable save for a few handful best left to be discovered by yourself. Environments didn't feel quite right with the convenience of air plants so the risk/danger feeling was lost exploring some places. Building felt even less necessary as i beat the game with nothing but a tube since the sea truck has almost everything you need early/mid game. If anything this game felt like a testing ground for the devs to try new things and see what works to set up for the next game. Regardless, if you like the world of subnautica, this second installment will most definitely satisfy you for the time being.

It's not Subnautica -- the map is much smaller and less diverse, the creatures aren't nearly as diverse or scary, and the plot is more linear -- but it's fun.  It captures the base-building aspect of Subnautica well, along with a few tiny improvements and slightly better graphics.  Robyn's constant voice narration (something many players complain about) was reassuring to me -- it was better than our original completely silent protagonist -- and I appreciate that there is a clear story here.  Base building is fine.  Devices are so-so -- the SeaTruck is not a one-for-one replacement for the Cyclops in Subnautica.  The above-water elements are...meh...but the underwater adventures are engaging and interesting.

- Is it scary or scarier than the previous one? Not at all, but do not take it easy.
- 38hrs played, why? Full engagement and completition 100% achievement.

- Is the overall gameplay good? Yes, indeed. It is very fluid, good-looking, immersive, enviromental deep sounded video game.
- Quality of the game? 10/10
-Bugs/glitches counted: none so far, unless you considered few cosmetic resources not fair.

Buy anytime. It deserves its full price.

TL:DR
Easier than the original, for good and bad.
Not as fun to explore but still rewarding
Some bugs but not game breaking
Not nearly as visually striking as the original
Land sections were slow but still fun to explore

[b]I genuinely had fun with this game and I will very likely play it again some day[/b]

[h1]THE LONG REVIEW[/h1]

After finishing the absolutely incredible Subnautica I was excited to play Subnautica: Below Zero but I feel like I should highlight what I didn't like about this game compared to the first.

[h3]LESS OCEAN, MORE LAND[/h3]

I understand why the game had so much more land exploration but it never felt like it fit and the extended section of exploring the area around Phi Robotics just dragged on. The Snowfox is hard to control and I ended up using the Prawn Suit on land until I hit the Snow Worms section. 

What I loved about Subnautica was the beauty of it's undersea world with massive mushroom caves, lava vents, the trenches and so on. While there is diversity in Below Zero it pales in comparison to the original. The Mercury II was fun to dive into.

[h3]MUCH EASIER[/h3]

I spent a week of constantly dying and restarting in the first game trying to complete it in Hardcore. I did do it and I felt very satisfied with the challenge, every death was my mistake and I learned from them. In Below Zero I completed the game in Hardcore mode on my second attempt and I didn't even die stupidly the first time because my cat unpaused the game when he stood on the escape button and I starved to death while I was busy IRL. Not my fault...Okay!

The biggest reason this game is so easy is the abundance of oxygen you can get from plants or even some fish. While these crutches weren't available in deeper portions it still makes the game very easy. I never felt worried about drowning so while it made exploration easier it also ruined the tension. I didn't even die to the cold because of how easy it was to mitigate.

[h3]ANNOYING BUGS[/h3]

Because of some annoying bugs I had to resort to opening and using the console. This had locked me out of getting achievements but I hours into my second run and didn't want to restart, Here's a a couple of things that made me have to use the commands.

1. A hatch door made me fall out my base and I was walking along the sea floor. I fixed this using the fly command
2. On two occasions my Snowfox fell through the ground. I had to use the Ghost command to retrieve it.
3. The Propulsion cannon wouldn't grab a box that was blocking a passageway. It grabbed it once then bugged out and couldn't grab it again. I had to use Ghost to get past it.
4. A certain item near the end after three, 22 second items, wasn't able to be interacted with. I had to save/quit and reopen the game just to begin the end of the game.
5. Some Sea Truck compartments got stuck as I was moving them. Partly my own fault I suppose but it bugged me.

Aside from the 4th bug, none of these were game breaking.

[h2]WHY DO I RECOMMEND IT?[/h2]

If you enjoyed Subnautica and want more then Below Zero is a worthy successor. Here's why.

[h3]ROBIN AYOU[/h3]

After playing as Riley in Subnautica 1, a mute protagonist, I can easily understand why Robin isn't as well liked. A voiced player in a first person game is risky since it can remove a ton of immersion from the player. I don't think Robin has that issue. From the start her goals are very in line with how the game is played.

She's a scientist looking for answers on the mysterious death of her sister but she's also a survivor who has previous experience in a hostile environment. That explains why she's here and why she's confident she can survive. She wants to explore the planet, scan everything and unlock the mysteries of 4546B. This is also what the player wants. Instead of her personality conflicting with the game it actively compliments the playstyle the game encourages.

Don't open this spoiler if you want to play blind!

[spoiler][h3]AL:AN[/h3]

I loved AL:AN. Him being in your head and trying to solve the mystery of the differences in Humanity compared to his species provided some insightful conversations that also deepened our understanding of the games lore in a natural way that didn't interfere with exploration. He can seem rude at times, such as calling Robin's body inadequate and inferior but Robin almost takes a motherly role in their relationship. He was superbly acted as well.[/spoiler]

[h3]THE STORY[/h3]

No spoilers here. In Subnautica I found myself lost more often than not which was a little annoying but in Below Zero the objectives are quite a bit clearer. You find some maps that tell you key locations but without a world map to reference, you still need to explore to fully understand where to go. This was fine for me. I liked having a vague direction.

Most of the backstory is told through PDA voice logs and I enjoyed listening to the logs left by the crew of the crashed Mercury II vessel. Whoever wrote their story did so wonderfully.

[h2]FINAL VERDICT[/h2]

Below Zero isn't as good as Subnautica but it is still good in it's own ways. I wouldn't have played it in Hardcore if I thought it was painful to potentially restart over and over. Now that I've finished it I do hope we get more.
Below Zero

This was a strange one.

I loved Subnautica dearly.

I was aware that Below Zero (BZ) was a shorter/smaller game, but whatever. What I didn't realize was how pervasive that was. There's less biomes, and they're smaller. There's less vehicles, and they're not as good. There's less story, and it's not as good.

And I think the story part is what drove me from "BZ has its flaws but is still great" to "wait shit I think I hate it now?!?"

The story is, in a word, too short. It seems like things are picking up and then that's it. Right when the middle part of a story should be hitting you're instead hitting the end. The quality is...not the best but on the higher side of "fine".

That's not the horrible part, though.

The horrible part is that BZ is much, much worse at guiding you through the story than original Subnautica. It is very possible to miss absolutely massive story related things in BZ. Some of which are so important and plot critical that they should have been mandatory rather than letting it be something you can completely miss until you're almost done with the game. Which is what I did. I missed out on meeting a certain character who is allegedly a main character. 

I say allegedly because I was able to completely miss what was supposed to be a companion.  A companion that would have allegedly made the story and progression flow better. Instead I got a story that just felt...disjointed? Almost like there was supposed to be someone feeding me information this whole time but the devs made this character an optional encounter.

There are other completely optional story elements as well. It doesn't feel rewarding to find them so much as it feels infuriating that something so big was hidden. This hurts even more when the original Subnautica was so good about pointing you in the right directions and feeding you story breadcrumbs. 

In short, I thought the game was good but it turns out that you can accidentally skip large parts of the story and completely break the narrative experience.

Any (slight) improvements to gameplay get overridden by that.

Having never played 1, I think I will have a more unbiased view. On the face of it. it's a very atmospheric game. The level details are great. The tight locations and narrow passages are just what you should expect in an ocean floor. Some cases I would search for a corridor to a item and  get turned around. Get ninja'd by a predator behind me. The base building is simplistic compared to other survivor games. Once you have all you need the rest feels like a waste of resources to build, but it is really not the focus of this game. The animals and large predators are localized to certain biospheres and you know there is a risk/reward going in. If you are well equipped with later game tech then you are certainly the peak predator and can hunt for all the treasures without much worry. The story line itself I had a difficult time following. Like most people I would skip some dialogue (sorry developers) when possible as I find it pretty predictable passed the initial plot point. With that if you are not a person who has played the 1st you will apparently enjoy this one and is a good game. 8/10

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Played and loved Subnautica. Was an Early access player. stuck with it through the years of development.
was happy to see a new Subnautica game come out.

But this game feels more like a shorter DLC and a bit rushed near the end.

The first Subnautica had a nice even progress curve that felt like an unfolding adventure.
Sub Zero however had that for the first half of the game then suddenly everything gets thrown at you, huge tech advances and story discoveries and then suddenly you're in the end game and its feels rushed and unsatisfactory.

The game goes on land near the end and while this sounds like a good idea it ultimately doesn't feel that way and i found myself at the end feeling less and less interested in playing.

Subnautica is a Submarine game and should stay that way, the wonder and fear of the deep was its main draw and the great sense of progression and awe sold in the original is missing somewhat in this title and subsequently falls a little flat.

A shame.

If you want more Subnautica.. give it a go. but in a sale.

Let me explain, Subnautica: Below Zero is not TECHNICALLY a bad game. The good aspects of the game are all copied exactly as they were from the first game. The streamlined crafting, interesting resource management, and pristine base building are all exactly as they were from the first game.

But EVERY SINGLE new thing that isnt in the original Subnautica is mediocre, at best. So if all the good parts of this game are ripped from its predecessor, and everything else is pure garbage...is this game really worthy of the praise it's receiving?

The perfect conclusion to planet 4546B.

I know that for many this game didn't quite live up to the experience of playing Subnautica 1 for the first time. But let's be honest, nothing possibly could.

Instead though we got a game that has plenty of fresh offerings to pull the series in a new direction. Some of the highlights include:
- Some of the most beautiful/unsettling environments I've seen in any game ever
- An amazing soundtrack by the legendary Ben Prunty
- Some unique new items/vehicles that change up some of the gameplay
- Some terrifying new creatures to encounter
- An entire new realm of gameplay with [spoiler]an above-ground section[/spoiler]

The biggest negative I've seen mentioned is the inclusion of more dialogue, including having a voice protag. But for me it felt like it took only 10min before not only did I become acustomed to the change, but I realized how there is no way the story of 4546B could ever progress without one.

I sat on waiting to complete the last task for this game for nearly a year, same as I did for the original game. And just like the original I'm left with the feeling of wishing it never had to end. I think that alone is telling enough that this was a huge contender to matching the original game, which has become one of my favorite gaming experiences of nearly 30 years.

As much as i love the subnautica franchise, i cannot recommend this game to a fan of the original, this game pretty much takes everything that was good aboutt subnautica and throws it away. First of all, its hilariously easy, you will likely die once or twice total and it will just be something goofy like forgetting to eat or surface. Its pretty much just one big fetch quest, going from one place to another grabbing mcguffins as you go, the main story progression is infact mcguffin based. Directions on where to go can be vague at times even with a beacon, its like the game is forcing us to explore in a world that offers nothing to explore. This new story kind of ruins the intrigue and the fun of the first game. Robin has some of the worst written dialogue ive seen. The map is tiny with only 2 of the new biomes really giving subnautica vibes, the twisty bridges and tree spires. To much back tracking. No seamoth or cyclops, only a lame seatruck, you will probably only really use your prawn suit as its so much better and can be used to just somewhat skip parts of the game with its grapples. However the building improvements are welcome, while most creatures are downgrades and dont feel very subnautica, there are some cool ones like the shadow leviathan(game overuses it and uses it wrong however) snow stalkers, and pengwings were also very welcome, most of the creatures brought back from scrapped concept art were fine but you can see why they were scrapped. AL AN was a rather fun character, pretty well written IMO and behaves how you would expect.

I think this game should have been a DLC. For a standalone game, the story is too flat I think (not finished yet). But I could live with this since I played Subnautica back then without any story at all. I somehow miss the improvements in the game. It starts with basics like having a fuckin' clock to know when it becomes dark. Or a map, which still does not exist.

Also using sonar with integrated chip to show found items is a mess. All items are shown in your ui with same size of icon and same color. My whole screen was orange. I also posted this somewhere to the devs to maybe change it. Who knows. But this is one of the things which really annoyed me in the original game too. And yet, they did not change it.

Also in you underwater vehicles you have no possibility to see if you are horizontally aligned or not. Nothing.

The german translation is also somehow crappy. Seatruck is translated as "Seebahn". I don't know who came up with this. But "Bahn" is either used for trains in Germany or for the "road". So Seatruck is like "Searoad" ... but it is not a road, it is a truck. But still can live with this. Next time they maybe can provide the sources for the community to mod etc.

Caves are a pain in the ass. I hate caves. The navigation in there is so shitty. I never know where I go down and if I can reach the end without drowning. There are also not that many "dark water" moments where you shit yourself ... but still good.

I don't know if I really like the ice terrain. It is somehow interesting. But on the other hand ... it is a little bit of waste, since you do not really build up there and there is nothing for you. Subnautica is about water ... and it should stay that way.

I also somehow don't like the main character ... too positive ... everyone is an "individual" ... everyone has it's own "life" (can't explain that using my shitty english). When the AI (or Alien) told about its kind and their knowledge ... it was more or less all blocked by the main character ... like being human is superior to everything. There is no real discussion about what is better etc.

Inventory is okay for the character but way too small for the seatruck and crab. I don't know who decided it, but why is the storage module for the seatruck so small? I have like 4 modules to collect shit on the ground ... but the first problem is: I cannot really reach the ground very well since the seatruck is too long to be maneuaverable in the depths and caves and using crab on the other hand again lets you go back and forth all the time. Collecting materials is still somehow shitty.

But in the end the materials are also not that important ... you can basically build everything in short period of time. I also recommend only to collect materials you really need. My base is full of crap which is not even used anywhere.

This time I liked that you have a story and it somehow leads you through it ... although I had some problems finding some locations. The crab is as always top. The seatruck is a really good idea. But it is missing some basic features or enhancements to be really cool. Base building is as always, I think they didn't change anything in there.

Environment is also nearly the same as before, but the caves are a pain for me. i just hate them.
The pinning of materials required for construction is pretty nice, but I am not sure if this already existed in the previous game. If not: super enhancement.

Placing stuff inside the base is still crappy. There is no grid or snap function to place stuff in same distance at same hight etc.

Ps, I am playing without mods to get the real game feeling.
I think the game does not really provide enough enahncements to be a standalone game ... but still good.
I like the setting and this more or less "easy" going ... no monsters hunting you etc.

What I would like to see in a new Subnautica:
Better bases, maybe also more NPCs in their own bases where you can get jobs etc.. A better graphic would be nice. A map.
