OK, first off- a disclaimer: I am not done with this game yet even after a little over 20 hours of playtime. Also, it won't show up on my list since I don't own the game through Steam, but I have maybe 30 hours in original Subnautica as well. 

As a more or less casual player, I have some notes I wanted to share my Below Zero experience.

Personally, I have greatly enjoyed Subnautica: Below Zero in particular and I might even go to say that I prefer it to the original. Having read other reviews, I can definitely see where the criticisms are coming from. BZ is a fully featured game that feels complete to me, but the maps are not as large as in the original. There's potentially more time spent out of the water in BZ which can be awkward but I didn't have a huge problem with. Sometimes getting out and walking could be a nice change from being underwater all the time, though it is a weaker part of the game. 

Map-wise, I personally found myself getting lost quite often in the first game and feeling overwhelmed by the sheer size of everything. Instead of wanting to explore, sometimes I'd want to stay too close to my base and not go anywhere. Sometimes I'd go explore for awhile, but It either felt too empty or too hostile. Less so in Below Zero. I've gotten lost in BZ, too, but I admit it does feel more contained. You're less likely to explore for hours and not find anything. There's also way more twisty passages and caverns, so you might get lost in a different way in BZ. I guess it's a matter of what you prefer.

If you liked the first game, and you wanted a straight-up 1:1 continuation of what you got before, then this one is probably not gonna satisfy you. From the first, what you were probably expecting is a whole lot more horrifying creatures waiting to eat you, existential dread, loneliness, and an overall difficult time. You'll get some of that in this one, but despite nearly identical play styles, the tone in BZ is quite different. You'll still explore old shipwrecks, listen to transmissions from people who are probably long dead, meet strange lifeforms, and explore a vast alien ocean world. 

While I wouldn't exactly call BZ lighthearted, it doesn't have quite the negative psychological pressure or weight of the first one. It's different. You're not left alone to your devices as much in BZ. It's a bit less free form, with BZ preferring to guide you through things more. Below Zero is more story driven, with the focus being on Robin and her quest to find out more about what happened to her sister. Instead of pure survival with a small side of corrupt corporation and ancient alien intrigue, you get more corrupt corporation shenanigans combined with amateur detective, and a dash of ancient alien weirdness. In the first one I felt like a survivor in way over their head. In this one, I felt more like I had more agency in the role of xenobiologist / investigator. It was right up my alley, but I can see where the shift might not work for everyone. 

On the relative scale of things, I'd say that Below Zero is a more friendly game overall, with a lot of general quality of life fixes. Where things always felt stacked against me in the original, BZ felt more doable. I felt like there's more options for dealing with trouble when it arises, and for me that works. I like a challenge as much as the next person, but sometimes it's nice just to be able to get further in the story. An interesting game difference I noticed is that some recipes/blueprints become available sooner in BZ, though others that were available quickly in Subnuatica remain elusive. It's an interesting design decision but I approve. It spices things up as you can't just cookie cutter everything from a tropical world to an arctic one. That said, some of the tools were 'universal'. The changes were enough for me to feel like I was exploring the world differently. 

Honestly, the sheer variety of underwater life in both Subnautica games is amazing. I love the cell shaded cartoon-y aspect of the graphics from both, and it's fun seeing just how much there is to see and discover. The sunsets and sunrises and weather events are gorgeous. The ocean itself is beautiful and teeming with life (in most places). Everything about these games is so imaginative that even despite the horrifying moments there's a lot of joy and wonder. Those details alone are worth me coming back again and again, but it's also cool to think of some of the stuff being not that out of the range of possibility. There's a long-ish documentary style video on YouTube by creator Curious Archive that was fun to see that explored some of the real life biological inspiration that the Subnautica series might have drawn from. Highly recommended if you are like me interested in speculative alien biology:

https://youtu.be/1xBrxWzKzDQ

Anyway, do I recommend the game? I do!!

I've been playing for hours and I still want to keep coming back. I'm still discovering new secrets and new aspects to the game I didn't notice. There's still mysteries to be solved. I've loved the writing and the story so far. I really want to meet Potato some day. It's a charming game! 

TLDR; If you were someone who was too intimidated to try the original Subnautica or were having too much trouble with excess loneliness/existential dread but still want to explore an alien water world (or perhaps you just want a more directed experience), then Below Zero may be a great fit for you. There's aspects of the story that you'll understand more of if you finish the first one first, but it's more or less a standalone experience. I hope that you'll give these games a go!

If you loved Subnautica for its immersion, mystery, silence, its feeling of hopelessness and abandonment, don't come looking for it in this game. Almost everything that made Subnautica great was butchered in this "sequel" in a way that it honestly makes me sad, maybe because I had high expectations just having finished the prequel.
You can tell that the devs tried to make it [i]better[/i] by just adding more stuff to it, ranging from a more diverse flora and fauna, different tools and vehicles to adding an excess of voice lines and, simply put, unnecessary storyline elements. I get that they're trying to paint a picture and tell a story, but please don't force it down everyone's throat [b]this hard[/b].

Imagine you're playing the prequel, but all of a sudden you are Dora the Explorer on psychedelics and your PDA environment becomes a dumbed-down corpocratic burden that tells you exactly what to do and how to react to things every step of the way. That is what Below Zero feels like. You are [b]clearly[/b] not the only human on this planet. In fact, you have landed some place that could best be described as a mediocre sitcom. There's way too much emphasis on the characters' personal little discrepancies and funny little stories, as opposed to figuring out how to survive on a strange planet.

Maybe when I come back to Below Zero one day, I will add more things that are good or bad about it, but right now I'm very annoyed and disappointed. Thanks for coming to my TED talk

Subnautica's sequel has the unenviable task of perfecting an already-perfect game, and it did it, largely by introducing a new mechanic: weather. In addition to Subnautica’s survival gauges of health, hunger, thirst and oxygen, Below Zero adds temperature. Whereas the skies of the original game were always fair and sunny, now the planet is intermittently pummeled by blizzards that will send you scurrying from the freezing winds and pelting hail. Out of all the excellent moments this game delivers, few beat the sublime pleasure of diving under the water during a hailstorm and watching the turmoil above from the sanctuary of the world below. I do wish it had changed more about Subnautica's systems - it largely reprises the same tools, structures and materials, and I would love a co-op mode, but this is still a worthwhile experience if you loved the original.

Inadvertently because of the success and innovation of the original title, this game gets compared to it with no escape. Subnautica: Below Zero is a game in a different direction from the original. Whilst Subnautica had an atmosphere of complete lonesomeness, danger and wonder, its successor is lacking in most of these things. However it is more Subnautica, and good fans of the original may get a kick out of it just for that much. If that is the case for you, stop reading here.

Story wise, the plot is unfortunately all over the place. Knowing that there was a change in responsible writer, this is understandable. But that does not excuse the fact that a great amount of plot points are left unexplained, motivations are unclear, and the overall story is mediocre at best. The original Subnautica admittedly had a simple, easy to follow story with not much of a mature theme to think about. But seeing that Below Zero apparently tried to go for a more character driven approach with a non-silent protagonist it hurts the more how much it fails in that regard. Characters are introduced in text and forgotten. Characters are introduced and hint at a questline that immediately is done after one mission. Bits and pieces of one writer's vision appear and are discarded for another's.

Gameplay wise, it is Subnautica with extra buildings, no cyclops and no seamoth but a seatruck and a winter bike. Said truck is fun to interact with but becomes tedious with time as too slow for seamoth's purpose and too clunky for cyclops's. The overall size of the map is significantly smaller from the original, with more claustrophobic spaces and frankly less wondrous content in them. The biggest problem of the game is, and dare not read this if you plan on playing the game, [spoiler] a lack of tension and danger in the map. Whilst the original had impressive giant sealife that was capable of ripping the player apart randomly, Below Zero is either too easy to navigate to allow unpredictable predators, said predators are too disinterested in the player or too weak to pose real harm, or they downright don't work properly.[/spoiler]

The game features a land section in a winter tundra, but that section appears lacking in thought and polish. These land sections different from the free-romaing seascapes appear in the form of semi-linear corridors with leading hints placed. Some effort has been done to distinguish the land sections from the sea sections such as a temperature mechanic but it fails to deter from the tedium of wading through seemingly padded long stretches of land and gadgets that don't motivate or entice the player enough to do what the developer wanted them to. The wildlife to be found is meant to serve as a threat but fails partly due to exploitable bad path-finding as well as glitch like failure to harm the player for his mistakes. The tundra overall feels like a neat idea that might have had an impact if properly executed, but you end up wishing more effort was put into the sea parts.

Ultimately, Below Zero changes direction unprompted and falls flat for reasons of bad direction, insufficient content or bad execution overall. Whilst fans of the original can still get enjoyment out of it as they re-immerse themselves in the world, broadly speaking the title does not live up to its legacy unfortunately. Play Subnautica instead if you do not know that game, and otherwise think twice about buying this one.

If your like me you bought this because you wanted more subnautica, BUT this isn't like the original game. It lacks depth, isolation, danger  and all around fun. In the original game i use to fear going 10m from my pod, this one I can go with my glide from one end of the map to the other and have no fear- map is small btw. What made the original so unique was that it didn't hold your hand, it literally just said to you 'hey, go explore, you ain't getting shit from me' and out you went straight into the unknown getting the occasional signal for a pod. BZ literally tells you to go here, here and here, even your character will tell you to go there. No No No, I want the isolation.
They got rid of the seamoth and the cyclops, why God WHY. Seamoth was the best, they gave us a seatruck instead which I didn't even bother building anything after the first section. Its just not necessary and there isn't really enough space to fully utilize it.
There are larger land sections in BZ for you to explore..... which you will go once to and that's it. Even then you are gonna feel rushed because of the temperature gauge.
The leviathans--- practically non-existent. The sea felt empty without all those reapers roaming around. There are 2-3 dangerous levi's above ground and 6 deep down, I fell there should of been at least 1-2 more. The sea just feels so not threatening. The deep down leviathans were the best imo.
This game should of been a DLC story- like another pod that came out of the aurora when you were entering the atmosphere and it made its way to the ice part were our player then has his own adventure. This would of fit this game better than having it as a standalone with half of its life missing.

Achievements: Practically all story and unmissable except for the achievement regarding the 'infection'. Important Note: Do not spawn anything in with the developer console, you will void all other achievements in that save- do that in a casual run.

Bugs/Glitches: Same as the first game, there still there and don't really impact anything. At most there a reminder you are playing subnautica. No crashes either.

7/10 Not as good as the first, hopefully just a learning experience for the team and that they make Subnautica 3 bigger, better and full of beautiful things for me to FEAR.

Best survival game I have ever played! From its immersive gameplay mechanics to the captivating storyline, this game truly takes you on an unforgettable journey. What makes it even more remarkable is the seamless crafting system that strikes the perfect balance between accessibility and depth. Every time I dive into the crafting menu, it feels like I'm embarking on a creative adventure, bringing my visions to life. And speaking of diving, as someone who has always been terrified of the ocean, this game has been my ultimate therapy. It has helped me face my fears head on, as I explore the depths of the virtual underwater world. Yes, it can be terrifying at times, but that's precisely what keeps me hooked and unable to put the game down. The ability to upgrade and witness the progress of my vehicles adds a layer of satisfaction, fueling my desire to keep pushing forward. I must confess, I initially had doubts about buying this game, but I decided to give it a shot, and it has become an unexpected love affair. I genuinely believe that once you conquer this game, you will undoubtedly feel a sense of accomplishment and fulfillment like no other. So, dive in, embrace the thrill, and prepare yourself for an adventure that will leave you yearning for more!

[SPOILERS] Great Game, I'm Not Sure Why People Dislike It So Much.

- The Map Is Amazing, People Say All of The Good Biomes Are At The Start Which Makes You Not Want To Research New Diving Gear And Go Deeper, But That Is Simply Not True.

Also People Say The Caves Are Confusing But You Can Use That As An Opportunity To Build Bases Near The Caves, Use Scanner Rooms And Their Cameras To Explore Beforehand. No One Is Forcing You To Instantly Rush Into The Cave And Get Lost.

At The Start Is All of The Regular Biomes You Would Normally Find In The Subnautica Universe For Example The Shallows And Kelp Forest.

But Once You Start Going Deeper You Find The Crystal Caverns, Fabricator Caverns With The Shadow Leviathans.

Tree Spires With The Chelicerate And Vent Gardens.The Lilly Pad Islands With The Glow Whale And The Squid Sharks.

Not To Mention The Arctic Zones With The Snow Stalkers, The Ice Worm Leviathan And Those Cute Penguins.


- The Leviathans, In My Opinion The Leviathans Are Amazingly Made. Their Models Are Very Creative And They Give The Player A Sense of Terror.

Most Notably With The Shadow Leviathan. They Sneak Up On You While You're Distracted And Only When They've Grabbed You Do They Roar Making Them Terrifying When First Encountered.

The Ice Worm Leviathans Too, When You're Exploring The Arctic They Suddenly Come Out Of The Ice And Quickly Snag A Snow Stalker Just Knowing Its Coming For You Next.

- The Story, I Somewhat Dislike The Story As It Wasn't Very Thought Out. The Story Just Consists Of You Exploring Alterra Bases Around Sector 0 Trying To Find Out What Happened To Your Sister.

 But The Best Part Of The Story For Me Was Having To Make Alan A New Body. It Was Fun Exploring New Precursor Locations To Help Alan Make A New Body.


- Conclusion, The Game Is Pretty Good, The Things I Disliked Most Were Parts Of The Story And The New Voice For The PDA.

I finally finished this game. I had purchased this game in the first releases of early access and as they kept changing the story of how things would go, I decided to shelve it till it finished or I remembered it again. This morning I finally finished this game. I wouldn't say its better than Subnautica. In comparison, this game is rather small compared to what Subnautica was. Though I know that in the first one, the vastness of the ocean was an illusion, the placed looked bigger than it was, but the depth was amazing. Area's that I hadn't explored seemed very dangerous and blew up in my mind how big the area was where it was much smaller than intended, especially in a sea moth. You can change biomes so quickly in a sea moth. This game was like that, but without the illusion. There were lots of times where I was thinking there was something at the edge of the cliff only to find the dead zone. Lots of times where I was facing wall after wall. Depth seemed deep but only from the surface level. Once you got into the caves it didn't seem to go as deep as Subnautica. There was no illusion on how small this map was to convince me the map was bigger than I would realize. Other than that, I rather enjoyed the final story they settled on. The end of the game sent shivers up my spine but I felt that getting the final pieces of the end game way too easily. Shadow Leviathins didn't seen very dangerous once I picked up an upgrade but thats another problem. The fact that I had to pick up an upgrade. The only real upgrade slot you can really upgrade is depth modules, others you have to find and there aren't many. 

In regards to the land portion of the game, it seemed too vast. I'm not saying I enjoyed it but I'm also not saying I don't enjoy it. Apparently your supposed to make thumpers to avoid the ice worms, but I kinda skipped that part, then wandered around till I found what I was looking for. Did it make it more difficult? I died once. Wasn't too terrible. I did have to look up where to find certain things though, like where the greenhouse was, or where the medicine was hidden. I know Subnautica is a collectathon type of game but it was too tedious to find where these things were. 

All in all, this game doesn't feel like a sequel but an extended DLC for Subnautica, although I did enjoy it, atleast in the first one I built multiple bases in different biomes. One base for everything here. I did enjoy the story. I won't spoil anything but meeting the ending scenes were amazing since we heard about them all in the first one. All the new fish and such were also really cool. Land travel was interesting though I wished they did less so of Land and more so of water but all in all it was an enjoyable experience, besides my own experience with the game. 4/5 recommend to play but only after beating Subnautica with the thought going into it that it isn't ment to be a full fledged sequel.

While I am ultimately giving this game a positive review, its not as good as the first one and I think plenty of mistakes were made.

-No replenishable source of Ion cubes
-No good reason for a base on the Glacial area of the map (or really more then 1 for that matter)
-Cannot use tether to teleport between teleport modules. Why? By the time most people get to this point they'll have already beat the game and be messing around
-Quantum locker only usable floating in water, no quantum locker available to be used in base, again, why? Very silly
-World feels much smaller than the first game
-World too tight for cyclops, no cyclops at all, cyclops was great, again, why? Want to add the truck? Wouldn't have been that hard to design the world around having both
-Cant change ladder position (seriously, why is this still a thing?)
-Story wise, the antidote? Very stupid, really spits on the story of the first game.
-Did not feel like a sequel as much as a DLC

This is what comes to mind at the moment, ultimately the game is enjoyable enough going through the story and getting enough of the Subnautica feel but enough mistakes were made create some disillusionment by the end of the game.

After looking back on this game and replaying the original has given me a new look at this game. I played this during early access and was very impressed with the game but found that it had become somewhat dull when fully released. For starters the features cut from the game, knowing how much theyve cut from the game like the supply rockets, the sea emperror juvenile and the original way the story played out is so disappointing. its dissapointing because they added in nothing to substitute the substance the cut content would've added to the game. Secondly, the story is worse off in release than before the change of writers. Before it felt like you had motivation because you needed to get a cure for the space station for the kaharaa. that cure being obtained through the cut sea emperor juvenile. you had motivation to get the cure to the people on the station but also at the same time find the person sabotaging the mission and stop whatever they are seaking to do. this original story idea gives you all the motivation to continue throughout sector zero. with the new story you are looking for your sister who supposedly died due to her own negligence. they try to make alterra out to seem shady and like the bad guy but in reality with how they present things it really does feel like Ssm did die to her own negligence and the payoff to curing the frozen leviathan is non existent because Alan doesnt even seem to have any care for doing it, even though its his fault the bacteria got out. thirdly the map is a lot smaller than the original game, which wouldnt be an issue if a majority was so bland and uninteresting. theres so few threats in the game like leviathans that my only deaths were because i was reckless and stupid like not bothering to bring cold weather stuff or eating food or drinking water. there are little to no threats in the game and the ones that do exist are more annoying than actually scary. especially the ice worm leviathans, when originally showed off they actually looked threatening but when playing in the actual game all they do is knock you off your snow fox briefly and you just get bat on it. a small nitpick as well is that all the PDA data you get on animals and plants seems so lackluster and almost lazy. In the original I actually liked to read up on pretty much every animal and even plant but in below zero it feels like they just put down stuff as placeholders but forgot to actually change the placeholders to actually say something thats interesting. People say this game gets trashed on because it doesnt live up to the original but i just dont think thats true because plenty of these issues are with the game itself and not it being compared to the first game. I honestly believe if they had kept the original vision for this game when it was in early access it wouldve been much much better in quality especially the story as I feel like the original idea for the story was much more polished and put together than what they shipped out as the story on full release feels rushed and unpolished and is full of plotholes. like how the hell did a advanced precursor alien race not figure out how to make a cure for Kharaa yet humans can suddenly manufacture the cure that an advanced civilization crumbled to? If you are into Subnautica for the gameplay this game is still fun to play but this game feels more like it's a DLC to Subnautica than an actual sequel given its size. overall I recommend just playing the original first game as it is overall better than this sequel.

Despite what most people seem to think about this game, I still firmly believe Below Zero is an incredible experience. Is it as good as the first game? No, maybe not. Is it still worth playing? Absolutely. Sure, the story is questionable and navigating the caves and the glacial basin is a monotonous chore, but in my opinion the game's flaws are vastly outweighed by its strengths. The base building and customization aspect are SO fun to mess around with. Being able to color and name your base is such a nice addition. The Seatruck is by FAR my favorite vehicle in all of Subnautica. It has the maneuverability and speed of the Seamoth, while also having the ability of item storage, on-board fabricator, and docking your Prawn Suit like the cyclops had. The new biomes are very fun to explore, and the new mobs are equal parts intriguing and terrifying.
Overall, you're going to enjoy this game more if you treat it as an expansion rather than a sequel to the original Subnautica, because that's essentially what it is. It may not have the same feel as the first game but I still think it's worth picking up on sale.

Such utter garbage compared to the original, which even that had it's flaws. How do you iterate on your first success by smoothing none of the rough edges, adding poorly thought out mechanics, an uninspiring story, and call it a day? There isn't even a submarine in this one! They should've named it Nautica: Below Zero Fun.

Allow me to elaborate.

Let's begin with the first vehicle, the SeaTruck, or as you'll come to know it: the SeaCuck. It's purpose is to ricochet off of every single edge of geometry like an oblong pinball, spewing your precious cargo every which way because you had to eject a segment of the vehicle to escape that crevice you thought you'd be able to make it through, all while the Sea Monkeys make sweet love to your wife in front of you. The silver lining in all of is the the developers knew it was a SeaCuck and allow you to park your SeaCuck in a faithfully recreated prefab building that resembles a Swedish Penis Enlarger Pump™.

Let's talk about those poorly thought-out mechanics. What's new in Below Zero is a thermal mechanic, essentially, you have to keep warm. However, this really only applies to when you are on land. In a game where you're primarily underwater, this mechanic goes largely unused except for a handful of segments. When you do need to worry about this mechanic, it is absolutely dreadful. I found myself sprinting from geyser to geyser waiting and praying that 
it would erupt with warmth and save my character from death. I came to find out later in the game that you uncover schematics for winter clothing all at once which trivializes this mechanic but you wouldn't discover it organically on your own until you are basically done with the terra firma portions of the game. The same can be said for the Snowfox vehicle. At the end of the day it feels like a punishment for not spending hours reading the fandom wiki to spoil the game with requirements and locations of the technology that should be rewarded naturally for progressing through the content.

The Pengling robot fetch quests are obtuse to control and have no danger or interesting aspects, a missed opportunity. If the developers had only put in a Pengling Rock 'Em Sock 'Em robots mini game, it would've easily been a 10/10 "It's Okay" by IGN. 

Doing my best to avoid spoilers, the part of the story where you try to complete your sister's mission brought no closure. It felt like a hollow victory because it's really hard to form an emotional bond with your dead sister through non-sequitur audio logs you listen to while busy trying not to die yourself. I can tell they tried establishing this fraternal connection through the recordings but this implementation just doesn't work.

Lastly, when it's time to finally delve into the crushing depths of the Arctic seas, you will be enjoying the Oops! All Leviathans part of an incomplete gaming experience, since there is no variation in the type of leviathans here. As you make your way through the confined space of lower areas, you will encounter multiple patrolling leviathans who've acquired a connoisseur's taste in titanium submersibles. Your life down here consists of a 4 step rinse-and-repeat process: 1. Your vehicle gets spotted and munched on by a leviathan, even though your lights are off. 2. The leviathan, conscious of its figure and not wanting to gain too much weight from binge-eating saturated titanium fats, leaves you alone for now. 3. You exit the vehicle equipped with your repair tool and patch up the damage. 4. You swim around a little bit with your swim-charge fins to recharge your repair tool. Just enough time has passed as you enter your vehicle that the leviathan is doubling back on its patrol to start this fresh hell all over again.

The game feels like a lazy rehash of the original and that's because it quite clearly is.

Итак, всё-таки не выдержал!! сравнение с оригинальной сабнавтикой: (eng below)
(и после релиза то же самое)

1. Размах мира.
Мне было страшно в тёмной пропасти оригинальной игры. Почему? напишу ниже. Там было столько биомов....ух! Можно было исследовать часами. В почти каждом биоме были свои животные и растения. Большая глубина Резко отличалась от мелководья. Я искал именно  загадки, разгадки. А не продолжение сюжета! Заброшеная база Дегази вынудила искать объяснения без принуждения со стороны сюжета. Не сравнивал размер карты, но до сих пор оригинальная  сабнавтика кажется интереснее из-за огромного мира. Надводный мир ледяных пустынь мне неинтересен. Если в оригинале я не замечал отсутствия карты, то как только я начал ходить по льдинам(блуждать и теряться!) мне в голову начало лезть какого чёрта нет мини-карты или просто карты"

2. AI.  в прежней игре я поставил базу возле кораллового леса. Не без опасений - мне мог приплыть и навалять люлей левиафан!  В SBZ скриптам AI будто бы подрезали крылышки / радиус действия, они стали тупее, безопаснее. Погружаться в темноту стало уже не страшно. Такое впечатление, что игре понизили возрастной рейтинг до 7+.

3. Транспорт. Циклоп это гордость. Циклоп это радость владения настоящим судном.
Когда я собрал в оригинальной игре Циклопа и увидел что я собрал, то первыми моими мыслями было "о боже. у меня будет Собственная подводная лодка? ооооооо ууааау."
Мореход /seatruck это безысходность. мореход это отчаяние. 

мелочные придирки: мало растений для посадки, мало светящихся растений. гигантские растения всё так же являются текстурами, они не могут вырасти до гигантских размеров у тебя рядом с базой. Но это уже мечты о песочнице. я имею в виду что ждал больше некстгена: игровой физики объектов, более живых растений, ИИ, дистанции прорисовки, куда же без неё.

Ну и пара слов про сюжет: вы бы уплыли куда то с алиеном, наилучшей стратегией карантина которого было откровенно враждебным решением сбивать все корабли из пушки? может лучше не знаю...силовое поле, радиопередачи? удалённое отключение питания кораблей на орбите? Да я бы к нему не приблизился ни за какие коврижки. А ещё есть телепорты, которые милосердно добьют тебя холодным оружием, если ты случайно выжил после встречи с Харааа.
 А вот ГГ берёт и радостно улетает с таким Чикатилой. По сути она решает, что улететь с ним лучше, чем жить среди людей. гмм. и что люди ей сделали? Поиск фрагментов технологий это простите тупо и ничем не обосновано, в отличие от первой части.
Если сравнивать в процентном соотношении и полностью, то конечно SBZ не так плоха. процентов на 20-30 хуже. создатели не сделали игру откровенно ужасной. Плюсом им идёт благодарность за первую часть. это просто сказка, подводная сказка. 
Но  разочарование есть. От него я никуда не могу деться.
Подводя итог: оригинальная  сабнавтика должна была быть улучшена и дополнена. Но ни в коем случае не урезана.

So, I still couldn’t stand it !! comparison with original subnautica:

1. The scope of the world.
I was scared in the dark chasm of the original game. Why? I will write below. There were so many biomes .... wow! You could explore for hours. Almost every biome had its own animals and plants. The great depth was very different from the shallow water. I was looking for riddles, clues. Not a continuation of the plot! Degazi's abandoned base forced him to seek an explanation without being forced by the plot. Didn't compare the size of the map, but so far the original subnautica seems more interesting due to the huge world. The surface world of icy deserts is not interesting to me. If in the original I did not notice the absence of a map, then as soon as I started walking on ice floes (wandering and getting lost!), What the hell is not a mini-map or just a map began to climb into my head "

2. AI. in the previous game, I set up a base near a coral forest. Not without fear - I could have sailed and piled Lyuli / Kiskass Leviathan! In SBZ scripts, AI seemed to have their wings / range clipped, they became dumber, safer. It was no longer scary to plunge into darkness. It seems that the game has been downgraded to 7+.

3. Transport. Cyclops is pride. Cyclops is the joy of owning a real boat.
When I assembled the Cyclops in the original game and saw what I collected, my first thoughts were "oh my god. Will I have my own submarine? Ooooooo whoaaah."
The seaman / seatruck is hopelessness. the sailor is despair.

nitpicking: few plants to plant, few glowing plants. giant plants are still textures, they cannot grow to giant sizes near your base. But these are already dreams of a sandbox. I mean that I was waiting for more nextgen: game physics of objects, more living plants, AI, drawing distance, where without it.

If you compare in percentage and in full, then of course SBZ is not so bad. percent is 20-30 worse. the creators did not make the game downright terrible. Plus they are grateful for the first part. it's just a fairy tale, an underwater fairy tale.
But there is disappointment. I can't get away from him.
To summarize: the original subnautica needed to be improved and supplemented. But by no means has it been cut.

ps yes, I rewrote the review for the third time in a row! I was waiting for improvements!

[h1]My review after play the whole game with all achievements:[/h1]

I expected so much with this sequel, and I satisfied with what the team from Subnautica Below Zero gave to us. With a very similar gameplay but different biomes, fishes, leviathans and a new mechanic: we can walk on a freezing land!! We have have to protect us from cold, fight with creatures from those lands and investigate what happened to our sister, at the same time we have a Architect in our mind. 

For me, this game was a fair sequel for the first game. The only bad things I can say from this one are: The world is smaller, less scary and the leviathans aren't intimidating like the first game (at least, from my perspective)

This is a must play for crafting, survival and exploring game, BUT you need to play the first in order to understand this.

FINAL SCORE: 4.5/5 ★★★★✰ I'm still liking the first more, but this is not far from perfection, like the first!

Below zero shakes things up a bit with it's more story driven and land based plot but it still manages to keep the feeling of the original game all while still giving us the beautiful environments and weird fish of the first game. But it has it's downsides when comparing it to the original such as the smaller map sub par on land game play and the overall less terrifying aspect (Though for some this is all good news). Overall it is a good sequel and a good survival crafter for fans of the genre and of the series but it can't hold a candle to the original.

Subnautica: Below Zero has all the bones of the original Subnautica, with a more focused, character-driven narrative that really brings the game to life. The map is smaller but feels more organic than the original, with a wider variety of objectives and unique challenges that felt perfectly tailored to each. Unlike the first game, I never felt like I was doing the same thing twice. Many of the game's systems have been improved, most notably the land sections, which are now just as fleshed out as the underwater parts. Overall, Below Zero feels like it improved on the original in every way.

[h1]Subnautica: Below Zero - Dive into the Chilling Depths of Arctic Exploration[/h1]

[quote=author]Prepare to plunge into the frosty unknown in Subnautica: Below Zero, the highly anticipated sequel to the critically acclaimed underwater survival adventure. Developed by Unknown Worlds Entertainment, Below Zero takes players to the icy depths of Planet 4546B, where new mysteries, dangers, and wonders await. With its captivating narrative, immersive underwater world, and a host of new features, Subnautica: Below Zero invites you to brave the cold and uncover the secrets hidden beneath the frozen surface. Are you ready to explore the depths of Arctic survival?[/quote]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
Subnautica: Below Zero continues the legacy of its predecessor, thrusting players into the frozen expanses of Planet 4546B. As a brave scientist named Robin, players must navigate the treacherous underwater landscape, face new challenges, and unravel the mysteries concealed beneath the icy surface.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Arctic Exploration and Survival[/h2]
Below Zero introduces a chilling Arctic biome, complete with frozen landscapes, expansive underwater caverns, and alien creatures adapted to the cold. Survival becomes a dynamic challenge as players contend with freezing temperatures, dangerous wildlife, and the need to secure resources to sustain themselves in this harsh environment. The seamless integration of survival mechanics and exploration creates a tense and rewarding gameplay experience.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Narrative Unveiling and Mystery[/h2]
Subnautica: Below Zero weaves a compelling narrative through environmental storytelling and player-driven exploration. As Robin investigates the mysteries surrounding her sister's disappearance, players encounter remnants of alien technology, encounter new life forms, and delve deeper into the lore of Planet 4546B. The unfolding narrative adds a layer of intrigue, motivating players to uncover the secrets hidden beneath the icy depths.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]New Vehicles and Tools[/h2]
[spoiler]Surviving in the Arctic waters requires new tools and vehicles. Below Zero introduces a range of upgrades and equipment, including the Seatruck—a modular underwater vehicle that serves as a mobile base. New tools, such as the Thermoblade and Cold Suit, become essential for navigating the icy depths and protecting against the harsh Arctic conditions. The addition of these tools enhances the survival experience and offers new possibilities for exploration.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Fauna and Flora of the Arctic Depths[/h2]
The Arctic biome introduces a host of new marine life, each adapted to the frigid conditions. Encounter creatures like the Vent Garden, the terrifying Shadow Leviathan, and the majestic Ice Worm. The diversity of underwater life adds to the sense of wonder and danger, creating an ecosystem that feels both alien and captivating.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Base Building and Habitat Customization[/h2]
Survivors can establish their own habitats in the icy depths, constructing bases to serve as shelters and research stations. The modular nature of base building allows for creativity and customization, while thermal management becomes a critical consideration in the freezing environment. Building a home in the Arctic waters is not only a necessity for survival but a canvas for personal expression and functionality.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Visual Splendor and Atmospheric Soundtrack[/h2]
Subnautica: Below Zero captivates players with its stunning visual design, showcasing the beauty and dangers of the Arctic biome. The dynamic weather system, bioluminescent flora, and underwater caves contribute to a visually immersive experience. The atmospheric soundtrack, composed by Simon Chylinski, complements the sense of isolation and wonder, enhancing the emotional impact of exploration and discovery.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Early Access and Ongoing Development[/h2]
Subnautica: Below Zero initially entered Early Access, allowing players to participate in the game's development and experience new content as it was released. The commitment to ongoing development, community feedback, and the addition of features ensures that Below Zero evolves over time, offering a living and growing experience for both new and returning players.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Critical Acclaim and Player Reception[/h2]
Subnautica: Below Zero has received positive reviews for its immersive gameplay, narrative depth, and the expansion of the Subnautica universe. Players have praised the game for its unique setting, challenging survival mechanics, and the sense of discovery that permeates every dive into the icy unknown.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Subnautica: Below Zero invites players to don their diving suits and brave the freezing depths of an alien world. With its captivating narrative, immersive Arctic biome, and a host of new features, the game stands as a worthy successor to the original Subnautica. Dive in, explore the mysteries, and survive the chilling beauty that awaits beneath the frozen surface.

[quote=author]In the frigid embrace of Planet 4546B's Arctic waters, Subnautica: Below Zero beckons you to uncover the secrets hidden in the icy depths. Will you survive the cold, navigate the mysteries, and emerge triumphant in this stunning underwater adventure?[/quote]

A great sequel that holds up pretty well, even compared to the original. Below Zero inherits all the great aspects of the original Subnautica and builds up more on a few concepts as well, but isn't without flaws.

The pacing of the story felt a bit off at times, and at some moments I felt like I was a bit farther ahead then I should have been, but regardless I still was able to follow the story and moments pretty well.

Exploration, like in the first game, is extremely fun and rewarding. The map doesn't feel to small, even with the addition of the Land Segments, and I was always finding something new every so often.

The Land segments felt a bit... clunky, especially using the hover-bike. I can appreciate the attempt they made and I did have some fun exploring on land, but it very much has some flaws.

Transitioning from a Silent Protagonist to a Voiced Protagonist doesn't really bother me at all, although the major thing that comes to mind is the first game, it felt like I was the Protagonist, where as in Below Zero I'm just playing a character. Not really an issue, but an interesting observation.

Going to talk about spoilers:

[spoiler] The segment of the game with AL-AN honestly was really nice. Having him talk to me during certain parts of the game was really nice, and being able to actually SEE a Architect once I built his body was really cool. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] Also, I absolutely loved when I met Marge and realized I knew her from the first game because I had read the PDA's during my playthrough. I thought that was really neat for them to add to the game, even though she wasn't in the main story of Below Zero to much outside a few appearances. [/spoiler]

Overall, Below Zero was a fun survival exploration game that built on the original experience, albeit with a few flaws. 8/10

This game is a massive let down, with a garbage story. It ruined mechanics and atmosphere that made the original game so great.  Do not buy this unless you are a hardcore Subnautica fan.

While not offering the same sense of scale and dread as Subnautica, Below Zero still has its own charm. For starters, you're not alone in the vast ocean. You have a buddy to talk to as you paddle around in a large fishbowl. You have a slower submarine, but this is somewhat countered by the fact that you have less distance to travel. Easily the worst part of the experience is the land section, which you must traverse to complete the story and all achievements. You get a hoverbike, the Snowfox, but it's often easier and faster to just walk on foot.

The story is passable, though as a player of the Beta, I can't help think about how much better the story could have been, had the dev team stuck with the original outline. I understand some of it had to change, but they were so far along in making the original story, they weren't able to fully implement the new story without putting square pegs in round holes, so to speak. Al-an's history very much drives the story. In fact, if you ignore Robin's personal quest, the story really greatly expands on the world of 4546B, the Kharaa, and the Architects.

Base building isn't much different from the original. It's not my cup of tea to spend 60 minutes gathering resources to build a replica of Sea Lab 2020, but if you're into it, you might like it. There isn't much in the way of decoration, though. There are some environmental pieces found in the world that would have been easy to implement as buildable or placeable items, but they weren't implemented, probably due to the crunch caused by the story shift.

I don't have anything super negative to say about this game, other than "it's not as good as Subnautica." But it's still a fine game.

it is awesome
fun

If you don't like systematically scouring maze-like environments, this game is NOT for you.

There are many points in the game where the story simply stops and the only way to advance it is to find things by exploring, with absolutely no hints given to where you need to go. Often times what you need to find is through some random twisting cave somewhere, with extreme low visibility. There is also no map and no sonar for the Seatruck.

Now, one thing I can say is that most of the criticisms of this game that I've read are silly. The story and characters are good. The creatures and environments are cool. The big problem for me is just the game's over-reliance on non-directed exploration with very little assistance. I suspect very few people actually like this type of gameplay when the environments are so difficult. You won't find anything by just casually exploring in this game.

The presence of so many twisting cave systems in particular will make this game unplayable for many.

This game has plenty of cool Subnautica lore, so if you liked the original, you could pick up this game on sale, just expect to use walkthroughs often if you don't want to go insane.

Overall maybe a 3/5 from me. Some of the creature encounters are great, but the gameplay is just otherwise not very good to me. No reason to play this game unless you really loved the original or enjoy this type of survival/hardcore exploration gameplay.

Alright now that the people who haven't played the game or dont care about spoilers are out of here i'm gonna talk about how this game is bad and good, unlike the original subnautica the map is smaller than the original crater, the levithans never really made me scared because I over-researched the game. It's the thought of something like the aurora being in a deep biome like the crystal caves, murky waters, hard to see in daytime, and ever harder to see at night. The only real thing that scares me now is spike traps, they're well done by camouflaging into the area that you're in, now lets talk about the story, the story is very good in my opinion because I didn't really wanna even go like searching for the actual lore in the PDA'S that are found around the map. Basically the way that they introduce you into the story is by saying "basically ur sister is dead, go investigate because alterra said nothing about what happened" the thing is sam's (main characters sister) storyline was actually required in the beta or alpha days, but instead the whole story was revamped to be different, if you own the game it is possible to play the old storyline, the game is beautiful but it does lack the original scary subnautica charm, and the music is made by a completely different guy who did make ONE song in Celeste. now for the downsides people have stated, the map is smaller leading for less exploration, the music isn't really scary, (except for that one bonus track, and the void... the void oh god... the void.) and its not scary really, and the story is forced onto you, one problem people have is that robin talks a lot. I don't really care because this allows me to actually understand what is happening without having to watch 99 videos. Should you get this game if its on discount, Absolutely, it's wicked fun and I didn't explain THE WHOLE DARN STORY. There are some HUGE bits of it I left out. I'd give this game a 8/10. Now, there

To me this feels like a poorly though out filler sequel.

Its like Subnautica but worse in every conceivable way. 
Silent character and sense of isolation: Your character is now a blabbermouth that never shuts up and has a full on sibling story.

Awesome underwater exploration: Prepare to be lost in an icy hell land segment that never seems to end, is extremely confusing with a worm that knocks you off your bike, its not even tense, its just annoying.

Cool vehicles?: Vehicles are now mostly the Seatruck which is like the worst of both worlds compared to the sub and the small fast vehicle from the first game, don't even get me started on the Snow Fox, its like a drunk driving simulator.

Vast open underwater world?: The world is much smaller, far shallower, less secrets, less excitement etc.

Overall it just feels like a retread that makes me wonder about the future, the only real upside is it runs a lot better than the original, but they really need to lay off land exploration fully, it simply doesn't work.

TLDR = Woke trash. 

The failure of this game and destruction of all the potential for a great franchise reveals a general rule that can be applied to all things in life, as if the rule was intended by the creator himself. That rule is you can not use entertainment as a vehicle for subversion and expect to make good entertainment. There is only so much energy a developer has and if they are being asked to fill the universe with political narratives, the core of what makes good entertainment will be exhausted, in exactly the same way a parasite devours the energy of its host. A pozzed belief system introduced and forced into a previously untainted franchise will reflect the ugliness of that parasitical belief like a mirror. You can smell the subversion reflected while you play it, you can hear and see it permeating throughout the game. Everytime you catch the whiff of the developers politics you somehow feel infected by it, it is repulsive. The immersion is destroyed by the constant reminder of the degenerate and subversive ideals that drove the developers when they made this game. 

What exactly am I talking about? The best example is the main character. The noisy and intrusive main character that acts as the developers wish fulfilment. She was chosen on skin and gender to act as a vehicle for a narrative the developers wish was real, rather than as a vehicle to tell a good story based in reality. Every propaganda poster, every piece of lore found in a PDF to even the choice of voice for the altera computer system reveals the developers internal narrative, one that is founded in the delusion and insane narratives of the past two decades. Despite the sci-fi setting this is not a story based in the future. This is a story based in modern left wing politics and narratives who wish the world would reflect their internal views, but will only ever exist in the fantasies of this game, and the brainwashing of their minds.

I am leaving this review after just having a moment where I paused the game and put my head in my hands and sighed. I knew before hopping into this game that it wouldn't be as good as the original, but...

1: If you are a returning player from Subnautica 1, this game will feel extremely watered down. The leviathans aren't as scary nor dangerous. The designs aren't as imaginative. Too much of the map is completely safe which prevents those feelings of uncertainty that Subnautica 1 gives you, leading to a stale and boring experience.

2: You don't feel as isolated and alone, which was a major factor in why Subnautica 1 gave you such a unique experience. You have a couple people to talk to in this game as you explore.

3: The land exploration in this game is abysmal, and unfortunately, they decided to focus more on land exploration in this game. Anytime I needed to explore a chunk of land, I found myself wandering in circles for hours just trying to figure out where I needed to go. Ultimately, I had to look up a video guide on how to get the things I needed while on land, despite never looking stuff up in Subnautica before. I am not the type of person to get lost in video games. Remember what I said at the start of this review? I had just finished about a 5 hour trek on land finding some tiny item I needed... and then looked in my PDA and realized there's a whole other mass of land I have to explore to find something I need. Land exploration is not fun. And it seems Snow Stalkers can be killed by "the tunneler", which prevented me from ever getting the snow suit, which means I am constantly suffering from hypothermia on land.

4: While your character in Subnautica 1 is silent, Robin on the other hand talks way too much and pulls you out of the immersion.

5: The map feels very cramped because of the icebergs. The ocean doesn't feel as vast and deep as it did in Subnautica 1. 

6: The progression feels all over the place. I built my base in the lilipad zone and found myself wandering all over the place including beginning areas, with only a single plunge into the deeper part of the map so far, whereas Subnautica 1 felt like it had a gradual, consistent progression towards the deepest part of the game.

7: Below Zero should've been an expansion, or DLC, not its own game.

8: I feel like *my* exploration doesn't matter. It feels like the game is telling me what I should be doing, or else I can't progress. I hate that, because in the original subnautica *your* exploration matters. You can progress no matter how you explore. Below Zero on the other hand tells you what you need to go do and you absolutely need to do it no questions asked.

9: Last, but not least, I'm just not... interested in it anymore. I explored all over the place, built a mega base, and now I just feel like I'm being dragged across the ground to finish the last bit of the story. Subnautica presented the story in a very interesting way that hooked me in and made me want to search for more of it. But Below Zero... no.

Overall, I feel like this was just a poorly executed sequel trying to ride on the success of the original. Unknown Worlds, I loved subnautica 1, I played it off and on for 6 whole years even when it was in early access. However, I think you should try pivoting and making another game in another world, or perhaps keep the premise of subnautica but have it take place on another planet. Below Zero is definitely not it, and I'm disappointed in it. I'm still going to finish it just because I've played it for so long already, but it's starting to feel like I'm forcing myself to finish it rather than finishing it because I'm still fully enjoying it.

The game is fine I guess? Coming from Subnautica it was a bit of a letdown. As spoiler free as I can make it

Let's start with the pros:
- crafting was improved. You can now pin all parts of a recipe (so you don't have to memorize how a plasteel ingot is made, for example)
- progression was different and fresh. I didn't start with a habitat builder, for example (see also cons)
- a much more obvious story (see also cons)
- the seatruck (seamoth/cyclops replacement) was neat. I didn't really use any modules, but the concept was cool
- found squidshark eggs. swam with my little squidshark babies. life there was good
- I was looking for just a little bit more Subnautica gameplay, and if that's all that you're looking for, perhaps this is a good game for you
- I liked learning a bit more about the precursors

and on to the cons:
- the story was....kind of awful. you could complete the game without even completing what brought you to the planet in the first place. the final piece of this "optional story" is a crafted item you get a recipe for, but you don't actually do anything with it? it felt rather strange to get a recipe for something you had literally 0 use for. The characters were eh. the interaction with the friend you meet were OK, but left some to be desired. That friend's character was...also kind of OK? it had tie-ins to the first game which was a fun callback, but overall it felt very bland. 
- I felt like they gave you blueprints for some pretty critical pieces of equipment way too early. I got my PRAWN about the same time I got my first seatruck upgrade, which was maybe like a couple hours into the game? They focus so much on free diving that I found the rebreather very early, which made most of that trade off kind of a joke. 
- the voice acting is SO DISTRACTING. Contrast Riley (Subnautica) who is practically silent, with Robin, and you'd think i was playing an RPG instead of a survival/borderline-horror game. There was too much dialogue. existing dialogue was sometimes borderline horrible, and it decided to spoon-feed you the story at every turn/every wreck entered/every new area explored.
- the world is so small. what biomes there are feel quite empty. I also didn't really feel encouraged to explore. I was told if there was something cool in a biome or not (or had a map) so I didn't really have a sense of "ooo what's over here" that I got in Subnautica.
- all the biomes are too bright. even deep sea creatures you could see perfectly well in literally all circumstances and it didn't really feel like you were exploring the deep ocean
- the leviathans were poorly done. In Subnautica you had to either sneak past them, run like a little b****, get the perimeter defense module (which I didn't) or stasis rifle/knife them to death (or stasis->run). You are FORCED to interact with the leviathans 1-1 in BZ. they don't do that much damage to you (easy to repair), and once you get the perimeter defense module (I felt it was a necessity) I felt the leviathans were more of an annoyance rather than an actual threat. 
- for a game set after the bacteria is cured, there really isn't that much biodiversity? it felt like there were more creatures in Subnautica than there were in BZ. The fauna that did exist were kind of bland, in comparison, and nothing really stood out to me as "YES. This is so cool" (other than the squidsharks. the deep-ocean leviathan design was also cool, even if it was too bright for where you find it).
- I absolutely hated the land sections. Sure they gave you a cool new vehicle (I guess) but it was clunky, hard to use, never had the vast open space it needed to truly shine (maps were more maze-like with too many turns) could only be charged in one spot, and could ONLY be used on land. Unfortunately, much of the game's story revolved around land exploration and I hated every second of it
- resource scarcity was a joke, I was never afraid of drowning. never afraid of freezing. never afraid of damage. never afraid of running out of water or food. the game literally throws all of these things at you as if it's afraid that you're going to leave if the gameplay forces you to play more strategically.

I read a review before I had played the game that went something like "It's like they forgot what made the first Subnautica good", and after finishing the game this rings true for me. 

The game looks great, but is a very small underwhelming world. The creatures are very limited and less intense. The story is decently written, but the conclusions are very underwhelming, leaving a lot of the cooler alien/mysterious elements completely dead and not followed up on. The land segments and the snow speeder are fun for 5 minutes and then are an absolute chore for the remainder of time. Materials are plenty and completely unnecessary for the story and general construction. The Seatruck is okay, but is less deft/swift/nimble than I remember the Seamoth being, and as soon as you slap modules on it becomes very clunky and not that fun to drive. I would much rather pilot a submarine through the ocean. Lastly, the game starts off directing you to goals/areas to explore and drive to, but eventually stops giving you any direction, leaving you to wander aimlessly and try to dissect your PDA for leads. 

While the gameplay remains the same, the first Subnautica was a very different experience for me. 6/10

An alright sequel to the original Subnautica game. This time around the story is done very differently with much more dialogue and more cutscenes, but the game itself is much shorter and smaller in scope (original game took me 50 hours, this one took me 30). I do have some complaints that stand out in making this the lesser of the two games: 
- The map is much more vertical, less spread out but many more intricate caves that get very irritating to navigate and easy to get lost in.
- Less dangerous leviathans with dumber AI, which combined with your prior experience takes away nearly all of the fear-factor to this game that made the original so intriguing. 
- Glitches are just as bad as the original game, only this time my Snowfox (a hoverbike) got stuck under the snow which wasted a lot of my time. 

Besides these points though I believe the biggest problem with this game is it's too similar to the original. Not that that's inherently bad, but many players will lose interest because in many ways in both the gameplay and story you're doing the same thing over again. It's not a bad game by any means just a couple poor choices that make it a lesser sequel. 

If you really enjoyed the original Subnautica and want more of what you enjoyed about that game I'd give this one a chance, if you're looking for a flawless game experience this may not be what you're looking for.

By the time I had what I needed to build a proper base - looking at you, magnetite - I couldn't be arsed. The first game was about, going deeper. This one, is all tight twisty passages. For me, gameplay is more boring than in the original subnautica because of creatures, but story line is soooo good and I love ending

Upgrades compared to predecessor:
 - Better base building
 - More weather patterns
 - More landmass to explore (Although, I see it as a major negative.)

Downgrade compared to predecessor:
 - Fewer vehicles
 - Less underwater exploration (Compared to the first one)
 - Less awe inspiring moments (Moments that lets you gasp at how beautiful the areas are designed)
 - You are no longer the main character, you are playing someone else who is

Plot:
You know when you take a strip of fresh duct tape and drop it in sand, but you hope that its still usable and that it can hold stuff together? 
Thats exactly what the plot felt like.
Having played the earlier iteration of the story as well, it felt like there was no sense of direction for the story. And all they wanted to do, was push their own politically correct garbage.

Conclusion:
Sequels are supposed to be better than their predecessor. But in this case, it felt like they trimmed down what made the original Subnautica good, to try and make the game deliver a politically correct message.
HOWEVER, if you prefer base building, would recommend Subnautica 2. But if you prefer more exploration, vehicles, a better story and better underwater landscapes, I would recommend Subnautica.
Personally, I would not pick up Subnautica 2 for the full price at this point.

TL;DR: Not as memorable as the first, but still a solid experience and worth your time.

The elements that made the first game an such amazing experience such as the fear inducing open waters are absent this time around, but that doesn't mean this is a bad game by any means. A lot of the elements that made the original enjoyable are still here and expanded upon in many ways that are better than the first. There are still wrecks and caves to explore with more emphasis on free diving, creatures to discover with far more personality, and bases to build with more little additions than the first game.

The game basically exchanges the small fish trying to survive in a very big pond feeling from the first game for a more story driven narrative. It's not as memorable of an experience (especially with some of the plot holes), but it works for directing you on where to go.

Still, I highly recommend it to anyone that enjoyed exploring, scanning, and building in the first game.

Subnautica: Below Zero still employs the same mechanics and all albeit slightly altered to be more cohesive and user friendly from the battery charge indicator to other smaller changes.

This game manages to offer a familiar yet also new experience for returning players of the original from new mechanics and survival elements to also new biomes and flora and fauna. While it's sad to see the Cyclops go and the map be smaller, new options such as the Seatruck, its versatility, and more habitat building elements make up for it.

Overall, it's an improvement compared to the original from the small Quality of Life changes to the changing environment and new biomes and creatures. Would recommend buying especially during a sale.

Subnautica: Below Zero was given the impossible task of living up to the original game, but when all is said and done, I think UnknownWorlds did a great job. The biomes in this game are positively [i]breathtaking[/i], with locations [i]filled to the brim[/i] with vibrant and bizarre alien lifeforms. My favourite biomes were the tree spires, crystal caves, deep lilypads cave, and the glacial forest. Combined with the original soundtrack by Ben Prunty, the level of atmosphere some of these areas have surpasses even the original game, at least in my opinion. The only real complaints I have about the game are that the story doesn't have the same [i]level of depth[/i] than the the original game does, and the progression and exploration aspects feel more [i]shallow[/i]. I hope UnknownWorlds learns from this experience and [i]rises[/i] to the challenge of outdoing the original game and [i]blows it out of the water[/i]. Hopefully they can handle that [i]pressure[/i].

This game is in my top5 games, together with the original Subnautica. This survival/crafting game is very story driven and more about exploration. 
If you're easily distracted like me, you'll be exploring for hours and discover the beautiful world of Subnautica gradually while crafting better gear and extend your underwater sea base.

The good:
- hours of underwater adventure, this game has a lot of hours of gameplay
- beautiful designed, very aesthetic
- very good music, sometimes ambient sometimes a dubstep banger
- awesome story, just like the original game (I won't spoil anything)
- the amount of times I said "ffs this is soooo cool!!" 

The bad:
- not a fan of the voice acting of main character, she's supposed to be a scientist but sounds more like a kindergarten teacher
- it's story driven, so not as repayable as a sandbox survival game. Once you know the spoilers, you'll know where to find all the clues. The world is fixed, not generated. But absolutely worth it, maybe I'll play it again in a couple of years or if there's an update.

Is this as good as the original Subnautica? No. Is it still good? Hell. The ****. Yes.
Now, don't get me wrong. There are a lot of problems.

**SPLOILERS** YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED if you don't want them, only read the lines above. They sum up my views on the game fairly aptly.

[spoiler] I was at first somewhat pessimistic about the inclusion of a protagonist that actually talked, as it made it feel like the journey I wanted to go on was being directed by someone else. In the original Subnautica (will will now be referred to as OGS), every discovery felt like something YOU made, and every piece of the puzzle that was found was like something YOU had perceived. With Robin chiming in every now and then, especially near the start of the game where she was ticking all the boxes for insanity. I still remember how at the start of the game you receive a message about the location where her sister had been, a perfect opportunity for the PC to figure out this small hint, only for Robin to pitch in and state the answer like she's Fi from Skyward Sword or something.

Of course, despite this huge, enormous downside, I would be lying if I said I didn't enjoy some of the conversations between Robin and Al-An. That is to say, I really don't think Robin knows how to take a hint sometimes. She's so bent on proving to Al-An that the human race isn't flawed it makes the flaws even more obvious. Because we're flawed. And that's okay.

I'm also going to talk about the leviathans and enemies for a bit. I'm not a fan of the design of the chelicerate. Let's face it: it looks like an oversized prawn. In all honesty, the squidshark looks more menacing. Although, I will admit the shadow leviathan is incredibly scary, as well as the ice worm, despite the latter being a bit buggy. I also disagree with the placement of the leviathan spawns. There was one that spawned in a meagre 200 meters away from my base, which I thought was in a safe space (twisty bridges, which I aptly named the coral tendrils biome, as I think twisty bridges sounds somewhat stupid). Really made the map feel small. I also dislike how some enemies are way too clumped together, such as the squidshark and cryptosuchus. When you see these in any large number you tend to get desensitised to any danger from them. Even the sheer number of shadow leviathans in the crystal caves started to become annoying after the third one in such a small amount of time.

I know not much can be done about it since the it's the game's setting and all, but the cold temperature game mechanic really just started to wear thin after I was done exploring the glacial basin and arctic spires. I died more times to the cold than I did anything else - including oxygen and leviathans combined, two things that are probably the scariest aspects of the game to most people.

Okay, now onto resources.
So it has occurred to me that it's too easy to survive. And that's saying something in a game series like Subnautica. in OGS, fish didn't spawn in. They reproduced, just like any normal fish. This meant that the more you took from the environment, the less there'd be. So, theoretically, you could hunt a fish to extinction. Now, that would normally be fine, as you could easily satiate your hunger by just taking a little from every species so none would be overly effected too much, or at least not enough to harm their population numbers. That would be fine if there was more than one way to get drinkable water. The bladderfish, if used at the rate needed to satiate thirst, would eventually be used all up and none would be left. This forced players to find different means, leading them to discover disinfected water, a better, more sustainable water source at the cost of exploration. A good learning tool. In Below Zero, I'm not sure if the bladderfish spawn in  or if they reproduce at an increased rate but I never, NEVER, had a problem getting water. This might be partly due to the fact that so many abandoned bases had water lying around you could probably fuel an entire army. [/spoiler]

Not sure what else to say. Hope you have a good day?

Where the original felt deep story-wise and literally, this game feels much less so. Where in the original I felt motivated to go deeper and explore to further the story and my gear, this game feels much more cookie cutter. Odd to review this game after so long, but I reviewed the game when it was in EA, which it's obviously not anymore. I've noticed that this game splits the Subnautica fanbase, and the fault line is the purpose of you being on the planet. In Subnautica, you were dropped on a hostile planet and your objective was survival. The game's music and storyline emphasized that really well.

Below Zero is not like that at all. The theme feels more like exploration than survival. There are survival elements (actually, basically all the core gameplay mechanics are there, and are actually better in BZ), but the game's here to pull you through a beautiful world. It's much more serene and peaceful (though don't get me wrong, the ocean on 4546B doesn't stop being dangerous near the arctic), and you get a modular Seatruck!

Anyway, I am one of those who thinks BZ is better than the original. But honestly, just know what you're getting into. This game *is* a Subnautica game, and has the things you'd expect from a Subnautica game. But this game's feel does differ from the OG in the way I described above. With that being said, this game is amazing, and I recommend buying.

The Subnautica game mechanics are still enjoyable, but I hated the story, social politics, and felt the map fell short. 

The main story of big sister finding little sister basically fizzles out very quickly into the game. After this, there is not much reason in the story for Robin to continue other than to get some alien out of her head. 

The story was very shallow and the characters were not very likable. It would have been nice for this to be MY story and not Robins. I felt I was just along for the ride. 

I would have like to play as a chosen gender character.  It seems social politics got into this game. You play as a strong willed black woman and find every male character are either arrogant a@@holes or bumbling idiots. The woman characters are all either Marine commandos or brilliant scientists while the men are delivery guys or security. I felt the story went out of its way to put men down. This is not how I like to immerse into my game stories.  The story also had to thrown in the gratuitous gay plot-line into the story. Overall, the entire story rubbed me wrong. 

Environment - The world map is tiny compared to Subnautica. You go deep through a cave system that can be disorienting, but you don't go far in relative distance. There were several biomes were new and interesting. These were not as large and distinct as the original SN. 

Danger - There was both more and less danger. There were more creatures chasing and harassing your character, but little damage done by them. I found myself basically ignoring the creatures as there was little reason to really engage them. Even the leviathans were easily dealt with with just a push of a button. 

Summary for me: 
Overall Subnautica mechanics are still great. The story was a really turn off for me. The map and area to explore felt very confined. I hope the studio continues this line, but gets back to a bigger better game and story.

Subnautica: BZ is a claustrophobic, unpolished, nonsensical sequel, that feels like it's missing half of the content it *should* have as a follow up to the first game, and actively craps on the first game.

But!

It did *just* enough of what the first game did (despite gutting *almost* everything that made the first one good,) that I still had a lot of fun playing it, will absolutely play it again, and would even recommend it to you. For all that it does wrong and worse than the original (even as the whole fandom constantly asked them not to ruin it over the course of early access, and were constantly ignored,) the core loop really is enjoyable, and it really is a treat to get lost in. Shallow, but the water is nice.

Just don't expect another Subnautica. This dev team has Below Zero clue what Subnautica is.
