As someone who is [i]extremely[/i] skeptical of sequels to games I love, let me start off by saying that [i]Below Zero[/i] is a fantastic, high-quality sequel that I [i]still[/i] love.  While it doesn't nail the full aesthetic of the first game, it tightens up many of the core mechanics and ramps up the quality of its effects and environments.  Most of the game's core loop is so identical to the first game that it sort of ends up feeling like DLC, but enhanced with a handful of genuinely great improvements.

[hr][h3]Presentation Gets a Polish[/h3]
I personally think that [i]Below Zero[/i] has managed to improve the presentation of its world in nearly every department.

[u]Visuals & Environments[/u]
Greater saturation of exotic and beautiful environments to explore.  Nearly every biome is packed with incredible scenery and ideal building sites, so much so that you might even be paralyzed by the selection at times.  Good stuff top-to-bottom, including the new terrestrial (land-based) biomes.

[u]Music & Sound Design[/u]
Ben Prunty knocks it clean out of the park with his contribution to this game.  Prunty's style and talents are a perfect match for the setting and tone of these games, so I have to give it to him over Mr. Chylinski's admittedly stellar work from the original.

[hr][h3]Aesthetic Marred, but Still Strong[/h3]
[i]Below Zero[/i] unfortunately has a few misses in capturing the unique aesthetic of the original game, which I blame on two things:  the voiced protagonist (including fully voiced conversations with other living characters throughout the game's story moments) and the simplified delivery of its plot and story-related objectives.

You're no longer isolated on the planet all by yourself, and there's generally much more man-made (Alterra) infrastructure to be found throughout the world.  There are no more cryptic or disturbing radio transmissions that send you out into the world on a satisfying little treasure hunt for story bits and tech upgrades.  Each story-related location is sequentially marked directly on your screen, with no inclusion of puzzles or clues leading you along, while your NPC companion reveals small scraps of story at a time or rattles off some painfully cliched remarks about "your inefficient human body" or "learning what 'love' is" etc.  The side-characters featured in voice logs are still engaging and brilliantly voice-acted like those in the first game, and in my opnion more than make up for the occasional cringe delievered by the main duo.

[hr][h3]Resource Management Improves Across the Board[/h3]
[i]Below Zero[/i] has tightened up most of its core gameplay mechanics, improving fundamental aspects of the core building/gathering loop while adding a few brilliant quality-of-life features that don't break the game.

[u]Resource Nodes[/u]
A small but vital change has been made to the "resource bucket" system that governs which materials drop from the mineral resource nodes that provide the majority of the game's crafting materials.  You now have far more control over which resources you're taking in, allowing you to better manage your coffers without having to worry about throwing things out.

[u]New Features[/u]
First are the Sea Monkeys, which are passive creatures that gather minerals from your surroundings and drop them at your feet.  These guys saved my ass a handful of times out in the field when I just needed a single piece of titanium or silicon to polish off part of a building project.

Second is the Recylotron, which is a miraculous little machine that lets you un-craft nearly any craftable item into its base components, meaning you can do things like condense 50 titanium into 10 ingots (saving [i]40 slots[/i] of storage space), then recycle those 10 ingots back into 50 titanium back at your main base.  This small feature changes the game when it comes time to store and transport resources between bases, and does a decent job in making up for the loss of Cyclops storage capability.

[hr][h3]Vehicles Both a Hit [i]and[/i] a Miss[/h3]
Sadly, two of the best vehicles from the first [i]Subnautica[/i] have been removed from [i]Below Zero[/i]:  the Seamoth and the Cyclops.  The Prawn suit does return fully intact from the original, which helps quite a bit to ease the pain of so much loss.  There's also a new land vehicle called the Snowfox, which is fun to control but poorly-implemented.

[u]The Seatruck[/u]
More streamlined and fluid to operate than the Cyclops, but missing nearly 100% of the cool factor and aesthetic charm.  You can still dock the Prawn suit, and detach the cabin for Seamoth-[i]like[/i] controls, but I can almost guarantee that you'll miss the old vehicles for a while.

[u]The Snowfox[/u]
A new land-based hoverbike vehicle; great fun to control and play with, but sloppily designed otherwise and poorly-integrated into the rest of the game.  Despite having two upgrade slots visible on the bike's in-game model, you can only install a single upgrade.  This really sucks, because the ability to jump (which is crucial to having fun with the bike) takes up a slot all by itself.  Furthermore, on certain terrain it seemed impossible to avoid the attacks of the [spoiler]Ice Worm leviathan[/spoiler], which were frequently capable of stun-locking me off of the bike and preventing me from escaping until I simply packed up the bike and ran away on foot.  At the end of the day, the Prawn suit outperformed the Snowfox in top speed, agility, storage, and personal defense, so it feels like a rushed or wasted feature that could have been really great.

[hr][h3]Concluding Remarks[/h3]
As I stated at the beginning, I am a huge fan of [i]Below Zero[/i] and think it's a fantastic sequel to the original [i]Subnautica[/i].  I was skeptical for a long time, but once I got absorbed into the new setting and started getting invested in exploring and developing my bases/infrastructure, I was easily swept away by the incredible environments, music, and overall immersion factor that makes these games so special to me.  The game's ending is legitimately satisfying to experience, and (despite some tonal hiccups) an astounding amount of the original's charm managed to slip into [i]Below Zero[/i] by way of its brilliantly-voiced side characters and intimately detailed world.  Full recommendation.

For fans of the original [i]Subnautica[/i]: consider this less of a sequel and more of an expansion pack; an additional campaign from the same game.  It has all the mechanics and gameplay of the original, but with a new story and environment to play in - and different props and vehicles to play with - it also has all of the same bugs and quirks, so don't expect it to be more polished than its progenitor.

Below Zero is a much more guided experience than the original (in a good way) - the experience unfolds from biome to biome significantly more naturally, and I never felt the need to reach for the wiki in the same way that I did with the original.  It is also, however, significantly smaller - both in direct scale and because 1/3 of the map is taken-up by above-ground snowy mountains and icebergs.

The above-ground gameplay, while not quite as bad as the original, is still this game's weakest point, and I was grateful when I had served my time in those monotonous mountainous mazes and could return to the more interesting underwater environments.  

With the map being that much smaller, though, the biomes you [i]do[/i] encounter are significantly smaller and fewer in number, making exploration feel much less rewarding; coupled with the game's more effective guidance, you end-up spending so little time in each biome that they never progress beyond feeling liminal.  

The game seems to encourage you to avoid lingering, too: the Seamoth and Cyclops have been replaced with a single submersible: the Seatruck, which can be extended with a variety of modules to obsolete almost every aspect of base-building, allowing you to perpetually stay on the move.  There's no functional reason to build a base beyond recharging batteries, so that aspect of the game has been relegated to an opt-in feature for those that enjoy it.

The leviathans and fauna, too, have been streamlined - their number and variety significantly reduced, and their behaviour homogenised - this has the effect of nullifying the horror aspect of the game from quite early on, as once you have the perimeter defence system up on the Seatruck, everything will leave you alone after a quick zap.  Where each creature from the original had a distinct call that could easily be identified, these new ones all fill the soundscape and blur into one, making aural scouting nigh impossible and removing that aspect of gameplay entirely.

Below Zero is a fine game and, for fans of Subnautica, it will scratch that [i]particular[/i] itch the series creates - but it doesn't hold a candle to the original and I would recommend it only to fans craving that underwater-exploration vibe.

One of the best VR games out there! Together with it's precedessor Subnautica of course. 
You don't see VR support listed on the shop site? Well that's because the developers decided not to implement it for whatever reason! Luckily the original Subnautica had some more or less broken VR support and the engine is the same. Even many of the assets have been re-used. So in 2023 modders were finally able to fix all VR issues and also add motion controller support. The VR mod is called Submersed and you'll find it and it's BZ version on Github. Without it I wouldn't even have considered playing BZ. I played the first Subnautica without VR about as far as it was possible in the early Early Access versions and liked it. But I never finished the game when it was done. I already had the biggest and coolest submarine in the game so I wanted to resume the game when there are other submarines have been added. Turned out they didn't add any more submarines even though there was also some concept art. Modders have also added new submarines meanwhile by the way.  I tried to get into the Game in VR several times but it was too broken and using an X-Box controller it didn't feel right anyway. Also back then I had bad VR headsets with a thick cable and a bad display, But now with the PICO 4, the submersed mod opened up both Subnautica games for me, I'm so thankful to the modders who did this! Swimming and diving in these beautiful underwater worlds in VR is just awesome and unique, no other game as far as I know! I'm am about half way through BZ yet and still can't tell which of both is Subnauticas is better, I like that BZ is more focussed on exploration and there are a lot of smaller improvements to the gameplay. In the original Subnautica everything tries to kill and in a game without any weapons apart from a knife, this really sucks. So I just ended up setting the 3 biggest predators with mods on passive in the original Subnautica because I saw no point in exiting my submarine to get in a knife fight with a whale-sized shark so my sub doesn't get eaten. In BZ the fauna is a lot less agressive and you always can easily escape or evade the whale-sharks that are there. So if this is your first Subnautica and you want to explore underwater worlds in VR, I'd say start with BZ.

Subnautica.... but without most of the things that made Subnautica interesting.
[hr][/hr][list]
    [*][b] forced story: [/b]MC is talking all the time and the player is lead by the hand through the story.
    [*][b] vehicle downgrades: [/b]removed the Cyclops and replaced the Seamoth with the inferior Seatruck.
    [*][b] smaller map: [/b]there are alot of painfully complex caves though.
    [*][b] changed atmosphere: [/b]The first game was outstandingly good beacause of the silent MC and the lonelieness the player experiences. This changed entirely with below zero.
[/list]
[hr][/hr]
[b] To make it short: [/b]Original Subnautica was way more immersive and atmospheric. Below Zero gets even more surpassed by modded OG Subnautica.

[b] Please note: [/b]I don't think the game is bad, neither do I want to imply that, but below zero simply doesn't give me that feeling OG Subnautica gave me. I understand both people who hate it and also people who love it.

I played both Subnautica and Below Zero. Subnautica is way better than Below Zero.

In Subnautica we have the seamoth, the prawn suit and the cyclops. In my Subnautica review I thought that it would be nice to have more vessels but in retrospect it is a very good lineup which I missed in Below Zero.
The seatruck is slower and less maneuverable than the seamoth and with all its modules it's too big for the deeper areas. When you bump into anything you will be shaken around that it causes motion sickness.
For exploring the land sections we have the snowfox. The handling is even worse than the handling of the seatruck and for me it also causes motion sickness.

The (deep) twisty bridges and in general the whole Below Zero world looks great but the caves are tighter and more confusing than in the first Subnautica. I have definitely spent too much time to get to the right location. The land section is big and also confusing. In Below Zero I get lost very often both on land and in the water. In the original Subnautica I only get lost once in the lava area but there it was easy to get back on track.

Good. :)

Subnatica Below Zero! Or Billy Madison's favorite game because PENGUINS! It's shorter than the first game and not as good as the first ether. Took me a half a year to beat the first Subnautica. This only took me...a few weeks. But this is mostly because I got used to giant leviathan creatures especially once I get the prawn suit. I was a bigger 'bitch baby' than Markiplier before discovering means to defend myself. Even when in deathly combat with two shadow leviathans had nerves of steel when...in something made out of steel.

Like the first, it's a survival Minecraft like game in an ocean environment where you try to escape an ocean world full of beauty and terror. But this time surviving an arctic location so you could freeze your nuts off like a trip to a Klingon penal colony if not careful. On the surface mind you. It's...actually warmer in the ocean. Don't ask, video game physics is always weird and ignores real life physics.

It is much like the first. The isolation is there. Plenty of deadly creatures big and small. Have to search wreckage and abandoned bases for plans to build your own bases, vehicles and gear. Did I mention the isolation. It won't take long to suspect one of the penguins is having an affair with your only companion being a rotten arctic pepper with a drawn on face...and on a stick. "SO SORRY TO INTERRUPT!" Penguin with an island drink and cigar winking at me. I look to my Arctic Pepper on a Stick companion, "Proceed!"

But the story is different. There is one other human there too, but she's not that social. Trust me you're better off with an inanimate object as a companion still...stop smashing my pepper, penguin. Like something out of Korikatsu Sunshine when it makes that face. And you're not there by accident this time but to find your sister, no further spoilers there, and to eventually leave the planet but with a new alien companion and again no further spoilers. Okay so you're not totally isolated here, but the woman is a hardened survivalist with "get off my lawn" energy and the alien...can't spoil that. Still your best friend will be...how did you get pregnant from...nevermind.

The game does have it's cons however. While the seatruck was nice and there is now a speeder bike, I moved around the entire game with a prawn suit. Just tanked around the ocean and frozen wonderland like a Morden Soldier from Metal Slug. Why did it take me this long to recognize this suit's design from that? Seriously there is a vehicle in the Metal Slug series that's much like the prawn suit but cartoony. Think it showed up in...3? or 2 aka XX? Whatever this is not about that. Once I got the mech, didn't bother with the other vehicles. Punched or shoot torps at the leviathans when they attacked, repaired my mech when away, rinse and repeat till have to return to base for recharging. Minus the Ice Worm mostly avoided this by stuck close to the walls and NEVER travel in open spaces for too long. It did one shot my prawn when I tried to fight it.

The map is noticeably smaller. First game was huge compared to this. Not nearly as deep ether. The first was 1500m deep when at the Sea Emperor Base. Here the final area was barely 1000m or less? Whatever the real ocean's depths for abyssal plains is around 3000 to 6000m and can be deeper than this. There's a reason normally only robots or James Cameron can go down there in real life.

But the cons are minor the game is still as solid as the first but just not as good yet not at all disappointing. I'd still suggest playing the first before this being the masterpiece game, yet playing this first isn't a bad choice ether.

That's about it. Bu-Bye! The Pepper on a Stick left me for the penguin. Now I have Misses Creepvine! Wait! Do I already have a computer wife?

[h1] Fun game but couldn't bring myself to beat it[/h1]

If steam had a neutral recommendation I would put it at that, but I can't in good conscious recommend it at it's price point, and for what you get from it compared to the first game.

[h2] What it does right [/h2]

- It adds a lot of QOL changes that are very welcome that weren't in the first Subnautica like making base building much easier and broader, or adding the mineral tracker, to even smaller things like nice HUD changes that can help you out like the resource collection for crafting and what not.

- The actual design of the areas and detail is really nice and appealing. You can tell they put a lot of love into the modeling and decorating. 

- Regardless of the map being smaller, it does feel more condensed which makes travel less of a pain, and easier for finding what you need.

- The themeing/setting of it being in the arctic is really cool and the weather provides a nice atmosphere to the game.

- It's still Subnautica. it's still an underwater survival game, and I did enjoy seeing new things and ideas the devs had for it.

[h2] What it does wrong [/h2]

- The story is VERY subpar, which is sad to see as I followed this game very closely when it was still in early access. They changed the story drastically and even scrapped the whole thing at one point to re-do it. But even with all the changes, it still isn't really that good.

- It feels more like a scavenger hunt, that you can branch off and explore, rather than a whole world free at your fingertips. It's still open world, and there are no limitations like in the first game, but the fact that the game tells you what to do next instead of letting you figure it out on your own, takes away from the joy of being on an alien planet with no help but your PDA. I feel like I'm being taken on a tour rather than being a lone survivor.

- Of course, one of the biggest complaints is that the world is much smaller. roughly only 1/3rd the size of the original game, and a good third of Sub Zero is all on land which can be a pain navigating. 

- The fish are not nearly as scary as the first game, and its very sad to see. There isn't much horror factor anymore. There are definitely some areas that can get tense, but not like the first game.

-  Being on land can get very buggy and tedious. The freeze mechanic is annoying to deal with, and the Snowfox can get stuck on A LOT of things. I don't mind being on land, just make it more enjoyable. There was never a point where I said "Oh sweet, I get to go back on land." It was always "great... I have to go back on land..."

- The removal of the Cyclops really sucks. The new Seatruck is just an offbrand version, and while it's a cool idea, I liked the idea of constantly upgrading to something bigger and better along the way. Like going from the Seamoth, to the prawn suit, to the cyclops was a great feeling of progression. Having the Cyclops as a mobile base was super fun too, and you can kind of do that with the Seatruck but it's very barebones with little space.

[h2] Small Nitpicks [/h2]

- They changed the voice of the new PDA system. It doesn't sound as "robot-y" as the first game. The dialogue for the PDA also doesn't feel as snarky as the first game did. It almost feels super monotone. And the PDA has a strong accent, which just felt weird to me. It didn't really feel like an AI, it just felt like an off-brand GLaDOS. 

- The new AI companion AL-AN isn't very amusing, and honestly quite boring. A lot of his dialogue feels forced and un-intriguing. 

- In early access they added a small camera for when you back-up the Seatruck, so you can see how close you are to hitting something, and that made it super nice navigating. It broke my heart seeing it removed for the final version because that was such a welcome change.

- They removed the stasis rifle... why? -.-

[h1] TL;DR 5/10[/h1]

I enjoyed the game for sure, but over time I just couldn't bring myself to beat. I honestly just got bored... I feel like I explored the game super quickly, and I never really had the passion or want to go back and play it. I just... stopped. Overall, It's a good game for sure, has some great moments and exploration was fun while it lasted, but it got stale very quickly. Was very disappointed with the final product. Wait for a sale if you want to try it.

TL:DR - Nothing was going to live up to the first one.  Don't go in with that expectation and it's worth paying and playing.

I've done 2 solid playthroughs and will start a third.  I have such mixed feelings on this even though I do fully recommend it.  The story got worse.  Huge plot holes between the first and second game.  People that have played will know what I mean so I will keep it spoiler free.  Essentially on the timeline you have an event.  10 years later you have the first game taking place.  2 years after that you have this one.  

You're going to play the games in order.  So that's where you run into a problem.  The first game had you afraid of everything.  15 hours later you were brave enough to take on anything you saw.  Then you come to Below Zero with that bravery and that has a cost.  The original game said alot without saying anything.  It was 99% data recordings and you had no idea of any plot so everything was a surprise.  The second game took a more active approach to the plot and the story but had a writer change and a rewrite.  The story follows the dialogue of 2 characters.  One character is interesting, with terrible development, the other character is developed but not interesting.  A third character exists, but I don't know why and doesn't offer much.  I don't want to spend too much time going over all the reasons I don't like the story; I'll just leave it at the fact that it is obvious that the writer changes and rewrites suffered due to what happened.

It's hard not to treat this as a separate game.  It's not, but we do.  The cyclops doesn't fit into this region.  It's too big, too loud and and just won't work.  So you get the sea truck.  The slower than the sea moth, not as fun as the cyclops attempt at a compromise.  It's not a big issue.  I stay in the prawn 90% of the game anyway.  Had this been a part of the original and followed the same character and I sailed my Cyclops out there and saw it was worthless I wouldn't have cared.  The building is alot better in this one, so much so that they moved parts of it back into the original.

Because it's an independently existing expansion it's easy to compare them as the same game with less features, or a sequel that went backwards.  $60 for both without a sale.  I have about 80 hours total between the two.  At 30/30 the first game is a steal, and this one is on the fence.  At 40/20 it's fair pricing.  I'm super picky about story writing and character development.  I shoot for 1 hour per dollar for story driven games and I am about 4 shy before my next playthrough.  I don't hate the game.  I dislike the story.  I would still buy it, play it and moan about it being a 7.5-8/10 just because the first one hit that 10/10 mark.

This is a very fun game. I will say that the leviathans in this game felt less oppressive than the first. They were overall much easier to avoid and at times they felt powerless against my upgrades. I loved the story and would recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the first.

The story in this one was weak by comparison. The public diversity scandal while developing weighed heavy on the creators and it showed in the final game. The characters they created were all annoying at best. The story had promise, but failed. The game play had far less mystery and reward.

The game is playable. It is entertaining. But it is so inferior to the fist game I cannot give it a positive review.

Conclusion, as a random steam game it is ok. BUT, as a sequel to the best steam game i have ever stumbled upon, that kept me guessing and surprised and rewarded it does not meet expectations at all.

I feel like this is a more streamlined and linear version of Subnautica. The map seems much smaller and lacks a lot of the wrecks and mysteries that the original game had, which made it endlessly fun for me. That being said, I think the first game was absolutely amazing and I almost feel like comparing this game to the original isn't fair, because the bar is set so high. 

If you judge this game on it's own merit, you still have a great story line, new and interesting characters, an amazing undersea atmosphere with beautiful seascapes, and new mechanics and vehicles. If the original Subnautica was a 9/10, I would still give this a 7.5 - 8 out of 10. 

Yes, it lacks a bit of depth compared to its predecessor and almost feels like an expansion, but it's still worth the experience (to me at least) and I would still recommend this game to anyone that enjoyed the original.
I like this game. The story is fun so far, and there's some nice quality of life improvements over the original, though it's not a replacement, it's a separate game.

I absolutely recommend this game! I like how it focuses on exploration; the soundtrack reflects that. I am a big music person, so I get excited when a game has music that ties into the story by conveying emotions (a great example of this is Undertale). The downside to Below Zero is that it is weaker than the plot in the first game and isn't as scary. This is partially due to the fact that the original Subnautica set a high bar, and it is also just my opinion. Overall, Subnautica: Below Zero is an amazing game and it is definitely worth the money!

I've played a fair bit more and I stand by my original review; for me, it's not anywhere near as fun as the first game. It's not a bad game. It's just in its predecessor's shadow.

The main flaw for me is the feeling when you are exploring. Somehow the second game's exploration feels slower and cramped while the first game's world felt expansive and your character and vehicles seemed to move quick enough to satisfy. Subnautica has many large open biomes. It's also a darker game, (literal dark, not figurative), so there are limits to what you can see in several biomes and a whole lot of 'unknown' around you. Below Zero has very defined space where you can usually see all the "walls" around you. It is well lit the majority of the time via glowing flora and fauna. 

In the first game it felt like I was always working to improve how I survive... I don't really feel that push/accomplishment in Below Zero.  

I'm still "okay" with the story so far. I think the focus being on Sam who you don't meet in game is a bit of a mistake as I found myself not caring much. Alan was also a kinda of ho hum but I was more invested in him than Sam. Honestly though Honestly though Fred was more interesting than both Sam and Alan. I'm not nearly as invested as I was in this game as I was with a silent protagonist in the first game. It's not that I think silence is better, it's that Robin does not react/respond at all how I think most people would in the scenario she is in. Even the advertising displays this with her calmly swimming away from death without a scuba mask. Seriously. 

I think the creature designs are lovely along with the new flora. It's a pretty game. 

(If you can't handle the leviathans and that is keeping you from trying Subnautica/Subnautica Below Zero, please know there are console commands and mods that can let you play the games like they are enemy-less survival games; you'll still see them but they will ignore your existence. 'Creative' mode exists in both but that also unlocks everything spoiling one of the aspects I enjoy in regular game play thus why I mention mods/commands.)

TLDR: A solid yes - with strong caveats - if you loved the original Subnautica. Beware the horrendous Seatruck. Fuck that vehicle and give me back the Cyclops and Seamoth in a game that actually utilizes their strengths and rewards exploration; not bumper car simulator.

Beautiful enviornments are a fun to explore, but the game's biggest strengths are also its drawbacks. You will feel tense and irritated as you navigate in the mid-to-late game because each environment is isolated from others in their own complex and confusing labyrinths that do not allow for the fucking horrible Seatruck to enable your expeditions. If you were a fan of the exploration via mobile base from Subnautica OG, you will be let down in Below Zero. That said, exploration was still fun.

+Awesome new fauna and flora
+Awesome soundtrack
+Jukebox! With some really awesome tunes
+You can take the jukebox with you and play your tunes while you travel in the seatruck
+Jukebox speakers throughout your base
+More challenging early game w/ lack of Altera tech and complex starting area
+Recipe improvements from Subnautica 1
+Iconic and cute Peeper is still here! Albeit an Arctic version
+Prawn suit navigates much better. More smooth movement and less clunky
+Ore Veins are added
+Land areas were beautiful and fun
+Challenging new hostile land based creatures and Leviathans
+Seamonkeys! Albeit, they're a nuisance at first
+Beautiful environment details; however because of the increased environment beauty some barren areas seem out-of-place
+A lot more leviathans in this game. Some that are even passive/non-hostile. The big baddy is terrifying looking despite it's dumb AI.
+Great new additions to base pieces, placeables, and new recipes. Base building is very fun

+/-VASTLY more verticality than Subnautica 1. Definitely to a fault in some areas of the game. 
+/-Map feels smaller due to the verticality, but as you explore more the sense of scale vastly grows
+/-Main pretense of the story was to find out what happened to your sister. But what exactly is the cover-up? Where did all the others go? Why did Altera evacuate this part of 4546B too? Story kind of flutters out despite some heroics by your sister.
+/-(minor spoiler) Interesting dynamic discovering an alive Architect (aliens from Subnautica 1) and becoming a companion with them if you discover them early enough. Massive cliffhanger in the end though.

-Horror/fear aspect is gone/extremely diminished when compared to Subnautica 1.
-Dumb Leviathan & hostile fauna AI. Attacks you by latching onto your vehicle. Will never do a kill amount of damage, unless your vehicle is low hp, then runs away as if it never knew you were there. The camera movement in this is so jarring as it forces your camera to face the leviathan like in the first game, but then throws you back to your original camera position afterwards. This removes a lot of tension in fear, because even outside of a vehicle the Leviathans will hit you once, then run off. never a kill in 1 hit.
-Thermal recharge module is only available for the Prawn, but it's fine... you'll never really have the opportunity to use it. More efficient to carry extra power cells.
------NO CYCLOPS!
------Map wasn't designed to support the size of a vehicle like the Cyclops. Then again, it wasn't for the fucking Seatruck either.
------NO SEAMOTH!
---Many, many linear caves and areas to explore in which the entrance is also the ONLY exit. Becomes jarring and heavily punishes taking the wrong turn. You will backtrack a lot until you memorize landscapes and paths
-You will get lost; a lot due to the labyrinth-like cave networks; especially early game
-Torpedoes still suck
-Hoverfox is a nightmare to drive and motion sickness inducing. You're better off using the Prawn suit to navigate the land areas; at least this way you can easily fight the hostile fauna
-Holy bumper cars batman! You will hit terrain A LOT with the clunky sea truck. Make sure you always have a repair tool on hand with an extra battery!
-Seatruck mobility is all over the place. It's moves like a bag of bricks being drug through the water, but it can turn its axis on a dime in any direction at immense speeds.
----Never felt compelled to build another base outside of the starter area. This is because every area in which you'd need to explore or go to for specific resources are so complex in their pathways and disconnected from one another that it would only become more tedious to travel around. It was more effective and less tedious to dive down into an area for what you need, sail back up, then return to base. This is by far by biggest complaint with the game when you factor in how horrible the Seatruck is.
---Get rid of the seatruck. It's horrible. Seriously, fuck that thing. I loved the teleportation module (never needed to use it though because of linear map design, poor navigation with the seatruck, and extremely limited ion cube supply), the storage modules were fine but inferior to the cyclops, sleeping module was awesome especially for the juke box, fabrication module needed more supply.
-----GET RID OF THE SEATRUCK!
-----Even with a horsepower upgrade (base move speed increase; not a boost) you will still move slower than if you were swimming on your own when at 4 modules. This is not fun and ruins so much gameplay potential because of how frustratingly slow this is. Also, why the fuck would you want a long train like or semitruck like vehicle to use in the insane caves and claustrophobic pathways in this game? I get the point is to detach the pilot cabin from the modules, but then that defeats the whole purpose of a mobile base. Really missed the mark with the seatruck. hate it.

Subnautca: Below Zero is a full length side story set after the events of the first Subnautca. It is more story driven than the original, though you can also ignore it in this game too. While it may not be as good as the first, Below Zero is still a very good game. While people have complained about the amount of time you spend out of water, I've found that it was still reasonable. Below Zero also contains similar horror aspects to Subnautca, though if you've played the original they are dampened.

If I could give a mixed review on a game I would. BZ's main flaw is that it is a prequel to the first game, which was amazing. It does not live up to its predecessor. However, it is still a solid game by itself. I just prefer to play the first one. 

Also, WHY THE FUCK IS THERE AN ENTIRE LAND SECTION IN A GAME ABOUT EXPLORING UNDERWATER?! 

TLDR: I give it a 6.5/10. Get it on discount, but get it nonetheless.

I am a Subnautica fan, and the reason why, is because this Dev shop has figured out how to put fun in their games, and that brings me back to play their Subnautica titles over and over.  For a survival and exploration under water (and sometimes above water) game, the Subnautica IP shines.  Here is what I like about it:

 - it is immersive: the environments (biomes as they are usually known by) range from beautiful, to terrifyingly beautiful.  The graphics and colour palettes are very well designed to inspire a range of emotions in the player (from happy and safe to spooky and terrifying).  The sound complements both the graphics and the play - the music and sounds are fantastic.
 - the gameplay is excellent: whether you are a new player or a veteran from the original Subnautica title, finding rocks, crystals, flora and fauna, and mining them for materials is great because it allows you to start crafting tools, bases and vehicles to help you explore further, and deeper into the unknown.  Couple this with aspects of survival, where you have to worry about your oxygen supply, and feed and water yourself (and soon ensure you are warm enough) and you have a fantastic combination for game that will keep you coming back for more.  When you complete the game, there are other game modes that you can explore (Hardcore = one life, Freedom, like Survival but no food, water and cold requirements, and Creative = god powers that let you build and explore without fear of dying or running out of materials).

Conclusion: if you want to get an early start on the game and be part of Early Access community, and you don't mind helping to find bugs in the game, and improving its features, then get it now - it's worth it.  If you want to wait for a polished final release then wait for it, its also worth it.

I was there in Early Access:
 - as Early Access titles, you expect the bugs, but with each update (and they are very frequent) the bugs are squashed and new content emerges.  Each iteration gets better and better, and if the original Subnautica title is a baseline for what the final product is released then you as a player will get your moneys worth.
 - you have a voice in EA: both as part of the early access and final release, the Subnautica titles have a built-in feedback (communication tool) that allows you the player a voice directly to the dev team).  I attribute much of their success to this tool as it helps the title become more polished and relevant to its fans as the work is developed and after it is released.  This tool (F8 in game) allows the community of players to find bugs, especially in the early access, and make the game better as the devs squash the bugs.  It also allows the player community to voice what features they like or don't like in the game, and allows the player community to get a game that THEY like.

My absolute love for the first Subnautica absolutely influenced my review for this. 

The things they did well, Base building felt cooler. Graphics ticked up a notch....and yeah thats about it. They also did do a good job of fleshing out details from the previous game and giving a lot of answers where there were none before. So I appreciated that.

I think the devs really missed why people loved the first game. I came late to the party and both games were already out and no one even mentioned the second one. And I know these points have already been brought up but its worth reiterating. 

1. The map is a tall build. It seems like a smaller map with much deeper sections but in small caves and twisting turns. I do not consider myself a noob but wow I had to look up videos on how to get to certain places because it is not intuitive nor do you have a way to solve it in game. It also kind of takes away the vast ocean feel. It didn't feel like the first game map where you could pick a direction and explore.

2. Due to the map choices it limited that feeling of running into a Leviathan. I don't think I ever had a point where I thought "I might not survive this". That takes away a huge chunk of the experience. 

3. they made the fallout 4 mistake. You can't suddenly give your character a voice and then a deeply personal reason to care about the story. the first game I was myself trying to survive in order to go home. I even put personal pics in the game file to put photos up in my base and give a personal touch. Personally I didn't like that, some people may not care but I don't think it added anything and every time she spoke it reset my own story line for why my character was there. Its no longer your character and you're playing as someone else. personal thing for me to is that If im playing a game then I like to play as my own gender and hear that voice. That made it harder for me to care about the story line because I could never get into the character. First game I was myself and RPGed my reasons. I was expecting that for this one. Very small detail that probably only bugged me. 

4. Vehicles, once again due to the map size the vehicles were so so. I wanted a Cyclops submarine that I could move my mobile base around and explore this massive map. Instead I got a seatruck. Which I promptly named Tonka and proceeded to smash it around the tiny maze cave systems they forced me to get lost in.

5. I like the idea of some land but not in the way they integrated it. Wandering around the cold sucked and then the vehicle to use for land you can't even build until you don't really need it anymore. 

Overall I think Devs missed the mark on why everyone loved the first one so much. I'm hoping for the third one and equally am hopeful they go back to what made it such a good game. 

I did like it overall and it helped stretch my subnautica experience so I appreciated that. That said, When I play Subnautica, I play the first one and the only thing I miss is the jukebox they added in this.

Not quite as good as the original Subnautica, but that's a pretty high bar. Still enjoyed it and, whilst the main story was not great, I enjoyed some of the side story and lore.

I think the main thing which makes it worse than the original is that you feel a lot more in control. You chose to be there, you have a mission, you have a bunch of tech and blueprints. I never got the feeling of being powerless and alone that I got in the original. There's never that moment when you climb onto the roof of your pod and are daunted by being totally surrounded by an alien ocean. The environment just didn't feel as threatening. Hearing the character speak also broke the immersion for me, it made me aware I was controlling a character where in the original I felt like I was the character.

Trying to be fair here, having played the original first probably also contributed, but not feeling like I was fighting for survival with a load of unanswered questions meant I never really felt the need to e.g. set up a base. In the original I didn't know how long I would be on 4546B, or how I would escape, and the pacing meant there was downtime where carving out a little safe space in the form of a base seemed like a priority. Then later I found eggs and strange fish and new blueprints and new resources and new plants to grow, so the base naturally expanded into something quite large. That's still how I like to replay the original now.

In Below Zero I always felt like I was on 4546B temporarily and with a clear mission. I almost always had another way point I could just go straight to. There was much less uncertainty so building anything more than a basic base didn't seem necessary, let alone a base with a load of aquariums etc. so I could carry out research.

I've used base building as an example because its something I enjoy in the original but the general feeling I've described affects a lot of the game. As other examples: why should I explore, or scan flora and fauna, or figure out which species an egg hatches into when its not really relevant to my mission? When I could just go straight to the next way point? There just isn't the imperative to go deeper. Below Zero just doesn't have the magic of the original.

A couple of other things I didn't like:
- The map is a lot smaller. To compensate for this they've made large chunks of it a confusing maze, presumably to try and make it feel bigger, which doesn't really work. It robs you of some of the grandeur that the original Subnautica map has. There's less awe as you enter a huge cave or see a load of reefbacks over a sweeping slope of red sea grass.
- There's a stupid penguin robot that's really tedious to use.

I've probably made Below Zero sound worse than it is so let me be clear: if I'd played this without playing the original Subnautica I'd think it was great. However, the original Subnautica was, and is, amazing. It is my favourite game ever. And in comparison to that I find Below Zero a little disappointing.

A worthy sidegrade. It feels more compact than the original, but in turn it is also more eventful. If you want exploration and a story, try [b]Below Zero[/b]. If you want to play a sandbox survival sim, then the original [b]Subnautica[/b] is more adequate.
[list]
[*] [b] Quality of life[/b] : Everything feels so smooth. Starter tools are easy to get and right where you need them, advanced recipes cost less, resource usage is streamlined (no more lockers full of diamond and lead), items can be recycled, and the game can be paused while reading your PDA. You can have a map now!
The new Seatruck is great; The agility of the Seamoth with the utility of the Cyclops. Everything you need in a single package. Did i mention it is modular?

[*] [b] Exploration / Interactions[/b] : indubitably Below Zero's strong point. There is more to do in the different biomes now. Not going to spoil anything, but more things are happening in general. The gorgeous and everchanging Weather and the different surface sections are a welcome change of pace as well (except for the ice worms, that part is bad).

[*] [b] Thalassophobia[/b] : no, not scary. It's too compact, too clean, too well lit. Whatever could have happened, there was always a way out. I've never felt pressured. Which in turn makes for a smoother exploration, which is ultimately what Below Zero aims for. No complaints here then.
[/list]
I really like where the took the sequel to one of my favourite games! I can't wait to see where the franchise will go next.

Honestly, if there were a "Mixed" option for reviews, I'd probably have struggled a while to figure out whether I should recommend it or leave it in the mixed category. Having only two options, I would much rather recommend it than not. Keep that in mind, as I'm about to be pretty critical of the game for a bit.

First off, the content of the game itself. Where does it fall short, relative to the first Subnautica? Well, the Seatruck simply sucks in comparison to the Seamoth+Cyclops combo. Sure, it's modularity is cool in a sense, but in general it feels so much worse than what we had before. The Cyclops felt like a mobile-base, and it literally was. The Seatruck just feels shallow (pun intended) in comparison, even if it serves roughly the same functions. Then, there's the feeling of aimlessness this game provides at some point. I have way too many hours for how short the game can be, and it's because I stopped playing it halfway through like 3 or 4 times. There just comes a point where you've made a base, upgraded your everything as much as you can, and I ended up losing interest because any and all direction is super lacking. It took a fifth playthrough where I consciously forced myself to finish it.

What about the state of the game, the polish, rather than it's content? Rough, to say the least. First and foremost, this game had a real affinity for crashing on my system. And on top of that, there's no autosave function. This lead to multiple cases of losing hours of progress, until I finally drilled it into my head to save every ten minutes. Let's be real, it's (insert modern year), we shouldn't have to put up with this. Then, there were just awful bugs and unpolished stuff going on otherwise too. What's that weird looking stuff loading in? Oh wait, that's just stuff that HASN'T loaded in, and then suddenly the landscape morphs into what's actually there. Weird. Ugh, the Snowfox just fell through the map again. It gets tiring to be honest, it feels like an early access title.

Now, all that said, I'm still recommending it. Why? Well, let's first say this; if you haven't played the original Subnautica, go play that instead of this. Come on back afterwards and ask yourself, "How much did I enjoy Subnautica?" Because if the answer is "A lot," then you should get this too. Personally, I liked the environment of this game much more than the first. The icy depths and all the vivid biomes were visually delicious. And that right there is the main thing that I always loved about this series. The exploration, the atmosphere, just the setting itself is incredible. There aren't too many series or games out there that give you that feeling, making exploration such a focus. If you value that stuff like I do, grab this title too. It ended up being worth the struggle.

It's almost as if the studio did not understand what made Subnautica good in the first place.

What made Subnautica great: 

1. Map Design:

 Not only were the deep trenches of subnautica scary, but pushing into them was paramount to player progress. Facing your fears head on was rewarded with new information, materials, blueprints, and incredible spectacle. Subnautica had far reaching and wide expanding biomes that offered a lot of space to explore and even build. 

Below Zero chooses to build deep, not far. Instead of having new and interesting biomes, we have a few biomes that are filled with needlessly intricate maze like caves, often holding unique and important upgrades for your seafaring vehicles. These caves are often filled with twists and turns, and so occupied that not even your smallest vehicle can fit through without taking extensive damage. I would almost liken these to the Paris catacombs where many dozens of experienced explores lie dead due to the needless expansiveness of them. (These often hold important upgrades that cannot be found anywhere else, despite other upgrades being founds in hundreds of locations)

2. Vehicles: 

In the first subnautica we had the seamoth, prawn, and cyclops. Below zero is far too condensed and shallow to allow a vehicle like the cyclops to operate properly, so instead we have the Seatruck. The Seatruck is slower and less maneuverable than the Seamoth and even with its module add-ons it does not provide the 'moving base' aspects of the cyclops. Its 'Storage' module addition provides about the same amount as the player character itself, very clearly not worth the hit to its already terrible speed and maneuverability.  It is not the best of either world and is a general downgrade from both the Seamoth and Cyclops respectively. 

The addition of the Snowfox for the land section would have been better handled if the player could get all blueprints as soon as they reached the land section. As it stands, you must nearly reach the end of the land based section to even get the needed blueprints before spending an inordinate amount of time backtracking to the Seatruck or a base to gather the needed materials, then craft the new vehicle. An additional 3 minutes on foot would get you to the last needed area without the use of this vehicle thus circumventing its usefulness entirely, as well as a special suit that also requires the use of a machine without any explanation, and it usually achieved well after its usefulness has expired. 

 The Snowfox also has insanely poor handling. While most vehicles turn with player perspective, the Snowfox requires turning perspective, holding either left or right, as well as moving forward. It makes for a very clunky experience for something that is supposed to glide smoothly over land. 

3. Story: 

The charm of Subnautica came from the subtle humor of Alterra not caring about you or really anything on this planet that would not prove profitable. You feel the isolation, and you also feel the cold and callous approach that Alterra takes for this "rescue" attempt. You slowly gather clues that lead to a much darker and sinister history of this planet which is also directly affecting you, your health, and your rescue attempts. While not directly told to pursue a specific goal by any character it is very clear what your goal is. 

Below Zero has a very surface level story, seemingly drummed up as a flimsy pretext to get our player character onto this planet. Our character is constantly voicing her own opinions on matter and also engaged in middle-school levels of philosophical arguments with a cookie-cutter rendition of "advanced species" that has apparently outgrown us so far they can't recognize the importance of emotion to the prospect of survival.

The story is also driven through the MC's dialogue with an alien. We are no longer a voiceless character simply finding remnants of deceased passenger's logs from our ship that can guide us in the right direction. THIS MAKES BELOW ZERO ROBIN'S STORY, NOT THE PLAYER'S STORY. As soon as you force your voiced main character to have their own drivers, you remove the agency from the player. This is in direct opposition to how any successful open world story works. I want to have a good reason to explore something only because I want to, not because my stupid character does. 

There are many more reasons that this game does not succeed in its predecessor's footsteps, but I found these to be the most prominent. I hope the studio really studies what made Subnatica work well, and why it is beloved and also take a hard look at Below Zero to see where they went wrong. 

I hope below zero was just a grave misunderstanding, an experiment gone horribly awry, and not a symptom that portends the future of this studio's creations.

It's been a while since I played the first Subnautica. It might be that I already knew how to play, but I found the late stage of this one less engaging than the original. Story was still good, but I never found much of a reason to build a base beyond my first one in the middle of the map. The world felt smaller. There was less scrambling for resources. There seemed to be enough resources on land, however, that you could spend the early game there and give yourself a different experience. 

The game remains beautiful and atmospheric. The addition of character development was welcome. I'd love to see where they take the series next. The base building was more fun and engaging than I find in most AAA games.

The best way I can sum up Below Zero is "More of the same, but better". It's along the exact same vein as Subnautica 1, but it's prettier and with more story. Another way would be "A flawed gem".

[h1]Map and progression[/h1]
The map is far more vertical than the first. The first felt huge on pure area. This feels quite a bit more more cramped, like everything is within reach. But instead, each biome is deep as all hell, so there's far more verticality to explore, making depth modules and such upgrades far more valuable. There is a distinct "stepping stone" feel to progression now and it's less random which upgrades you find.

Perhaps that makes it a bit less organic and more predictable, but I enjoyed it. I also enjoyed the focus on the Architect species and their culture. 

[h1]Problems[/h1]
The complains I have about the game are mainly that some concepts are poorly explained, some story chains are disconnected and rely on luck to find and finally, the whole "on-land" section is a pain in the absolute behind. The Glacial Basin beyond the bridge is a maze that is torture to explore as everything looks identical. Add to that some VERY buggy leviathans and that whole section is actually exceptionally unenjoyable. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
As opposed to the first game, this game has several plot threads that are poorly intervowen and it feels like they're more fighting for space than complementing each other. Add the fact that some plot threads have a very unfinished feel to them and the game starts feeling unfocused and unsatisfying.

The main plot thread, involving the Architect species and the story of 4546B, is well handled, well voice acted and is without major plot holes. It also ties well into the natural progression of the game's mechanics and biome exploration.

[h2]The bad plot[/h2]
The plot involving the leviathan corpse, Maida and the deceased sister is a jumbled, unfinished mess that feels tacked on. It feels improperly tied into the game and appears to be almost an afterthought. In spite of it feeling like an afterthought, there's a lot of work that has gone into making assets for locations tied to said plot. Which makes me think the plot was something else at first and they had to rush to rewrite it or something.

There's a lot about that entire section of the story that just doesn't feel either satisfying or tight. There are many "But why?" about the story and some things straight up don't make sense at all. Like why did Sam "accidentally" kill herself with a bomb when she's been described as an absolute genius? You can speculate, based on other things, but there's so much in this plot thread that feels rushed and sloppy.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Everything else about the game is a step up from the first. The first Subnautica was an unpolished gem that was an absolute blast, and all in all, Subnautica: Below Zero is a very enjoyable expandalone to the original game. It has some flaws but they aren't enough to detract from the overall experience. The sister side-plot is forgettable, but also not required to beat the game, so it's ultimately a non-issue.

If you did not enjoy Subnautica, then you really need not bother as this is more of the same. But better.

The narrative of this game is just an awful, disjointed mess.  They had a real opportunity to tell us a cool story.

It felt like story components were missing, or that major plot points weren't hammered home enough (like what happened with the sister.)  Perhaps some voice lines or conversations just weren't triggered appropriately?  

The game world is quite a bit smaller than than the first game.  That's either a plus or minus depending on how you look at it. 

There are no real improvements in features or content from the first game.  Upgrades and resource acquisition pathways for those upgrades were essentially the same as the first game.  Go to X Depth to find Y resource, etc.  No mandatory need to use the Prawn was a weird decision.  I spent the time and resources making one and upgrading it, but I never actually needed to use it.

I might have enjoyed it more had I not hopped into it right after the first game and given myself a break.

I have greatly enjoyed playing both Subnautica and Subnautica: Below Zero. These games have a very good vibe and have a sweet spot of being both relaxing and intense.  I do have to say however, that the first game got me better. 
I missed the vehicles from the first game. All 3 (Prawnsuit, Seamoth and Cyclops) are absolutely awesome. The Seatruck doesn't quite cut it for me. The sensation the Cyclops transmits, piloting this enormous vessel with the switches and controls all over the bridge, cameras, being able to customize the interior to even make it a complete autonomous moving base... The Seatruck feels more like a clumsy long rod with weird physics. There are a couple of improvements I would give the Cyclops tho: Capability to transport 2 smaller vehicles, and a second access hatch on the top (coning tower perhaps).
What I did enjoy about SBZ in contrast, was tanking with the Prawnsuit around the dangers on dry land. I also quite enjoyed the plot and the relation we have with the Architects, although the ending (no spoilers) seemed unfinished to me, like I was expecting it to continue. Subnautica in comparison seemed very well rounded off. 
Anyways, I look forward playing a 3rd one if it becomes available, and I would very much like to get back the sensations I got with the first one that I didn't quite get with the second.

Subnautica: Below Zero (SBZ) is a wonderful exploration open world crafting game.  The world isn't as big or deep as the original Subnautica which took me 90 hours to finish.  But it still has lots to explore and discover.  

The above water part was full of exploration.  The key is Thermoses, Pepper Plants, and eventually build yourself a cold suit which gives you very significant protection from the cold.  I was amazed multiple times, when exploring a cave would open up into a whole new area. On land bases also help as you can build fabricators and plant some of your own pepper plants for both nourishment and heat.  

Underwater was equally filled with discovery and exploration.  As you find datadisks and fragments, your technology expands allowing you to delve deeper into the ocean's depths. The Sea Truck is a great addition to the original game.  It starts off with just the cab, but as you discover and craft modules it gets longer and longer, eventually becoming a mobile base of operations.  The Prawn makes a comeback and is also fun to travel around in. 

I completely binged on this game, playing for hours every night and finishing in 10 days! I loved it to pieces.

While the basic gameplay is pretty much identical to the first game, this feels very different. Without spoiling anything, you've got a lot more company now, and your player is no longer silent (rather preachy at times). There's a lot more hand-holding throughout the story and while the first game wasn't difficult this one is even more forgiving. There are many new NPCs (or PDAs with dialogue) and interesting side stories with complex relationships between all the characters (despite the minimalistic script). I like the new additions to the inventory, the small changes and the new varieties to gameplay. It's quite a lot less scary (if you can ever call it that) and the map design is very different with a lot less open spaces and in their place there's more mazes and confined spaces. The whole game hits different, though I like the first one better, because it had larger scale and was more challenging.
The voice acting is still great, with a lot more actors putting in a great performance. I'm probably going to get roasted for saying this, but Below Zero is prettier and has a better soundtrack. Overall, a lovely and fun game.

I would like to give a neutral review in this case.

I really liked the first Subnautica, but I knew that Below Zero was a dark horse. Still, I decided to take the risk.

The first five hours are pure Subnautica. Terrifying, wow-effect, flow, gameplay works, the story unfolds.

After that - it's bad. A monotonous world, with no challenge. Practically nothing new compared to the first part. Less, worse, more confusing.

The game was simply cobbled together from old assets, adding about five nauseating hours of fiddling on nauseating land (I seriously wanted to drop the game) and switching the means of transportation to a little train.

The reapers, which I was scared of even at the end of the first part, were replaced with some unclear funny shrimp, and the "scariest enemy" is more annoying than frightening and is repelled by electroshock. /Meh/

I could have a particular issue with the plot, but it's just apparent that first, there was one story, then they rearranged it, underwrote it, tacked on a second, and screwed it all up.

It was very unpleasant to watch the game move from the masterpiece category to the mediocre and, in the end, almost end up dropped and in the trash.
And the vibe from the story at many points was "I collected everything, read everything, but didn't understand the point."

After researching YouTube, Reddit, and wikis after completing the game, it turned out that I did catch the entire available story - there just isn't one.

The game itself isn't "bad". I finished it and enjoyed some parts of it. 
But the Subnautica: Below Zero could be an OK DLC for Subnautica, compressed to maybe 10 hours and reassembled story.

If you like alien world exploration and adventure PLAY THIS GAME (and the first game).

edit: pretty good

Subnautica Below Zero is a crafting/survival game. Originally planned as DLC to the original Subnautica, it eventually grew in scope and was released instead as a standlone product. Largely plays similar to the original game with a bit more steamlining I guess (you get some stuff for your base at start without needing to find it for example). If you haven't played the first game through get that instead. Below Zero is a decent game while the original is terrific.

Hunger/Thirst works same as the original but now there is a temperature meter that goes down when you're on land. Diving into artic water strangely warms you up lol. You can warm yourself when in a vehicle and on land by drinking coffee, going into caves, standing next to heating flowers and steam vents.

One issue that Below Zero has is that the game world is much smaller than the original. Swimming and the Seaglide tool speed have both been decreased to componesate. The new Leviathans are smaller that the ones from the original and are generally less scary. Levels feel overstuffed with resources and fragments. Same type fragments were often really close to each so you'd find all you'd need very quickly. Level design 

Another issue is that land sections have been greatly increased. These are largely a pain to explore, it's often very difficult to figure out where you are and are the worst parts of the game. The underwater biomes is what made the game popular. To make matters worse, there's often blizzards that limit your view making it even more difficult to navigate.

Below Zero also contains much less deep and dark underwater areas to explore. The original had truly creepy deep surface biomes to explore requiring you to creep downwards in darkness with your lights on trying to spot something below you as dangerous fishies lurk in the shadows. There's nothing like this in Below Zero. The deep areas are all in caves but these caves tend to have a lot of oxygen plants which take away some of the fear of drowning, are largely wet lit and none are as claustrophobic as the coral caves from Subnautica where you could easily get hopelessly lost. Unlike the original, you don't start off in the middle of the map but start in on an edge and can explore forwards in a cone with edges closed off with ice walls.

Unlike the original, Below Zero has a voiced MC and two other voiced characters you can meet. Some prefer having a silent protaganist and think another NPC takes away from the sense of isolation, you mileage may vary on this. The fact that [spoiler]Marguerit Maida[/spoiler] from the original survived is BS and I don't like their characterization in Below Zero. Shouldn't the [spoiler]virus[/spoiler] have killed her ages ago anyways?

There's two major storylines. One where you character investigates the death of your sister to expose evil corp-gov; this storyline largely meh, major spoilers for both games: [spoiler]Her death is her fault and the plot point of her making a cure of the virus is not good. The first game plot was about curing the virus with the Sea Emperor babies already and how does your sister casually whip out a cure for a virus that a super intelligent alien race struggled to cure!?[/spoiler] The second is to find an architect alien and after they store their conscious into yours, you search out for tech to build them a new body. Generally expands on lore of the aliens from the original and your character has young-adult sci-fi talks with them throughout the game.

The Prawn vehichle is back but Seamoth and Cyclops are gone. The Seatruck serves as a hybrid of the two. You can create modules that you can add to the truck which allows you to customize it and use it as a mobile base as you desire. More modules slow it down through and level design is very cave based so if you have too many modules you may find smaller cave sections a nuisance to explore. It's generally a nice addition, the new Snowfox on the other hand, is a terrible land based hoverbike and was a pain to drive. It somehows keeps you warm while riding it despite being open air bike. Some sections like Outpost Zero have a lot of invisible walls, largely affects Prawn with its jets.

The biomes are least are very interesting and diverse and the general gameplay loop is still good. It's just not as good as the original. BZ is like a 6 or 7 out of 10 compared to original which is easily 9+.
My only wish is that it was longer. I love this game.

Spectacular game, a big expansion of what was good in the first - massive increases in creature types, scale, biome number... It's not quite as ground-breaking as the original but this is to be expected given its status as an expansion. I find little things to be quite a nuisance (the PDA announcer was much nicer in the first game imo and there's no way to switch) but, without spoiling, there's plenty to like.

Solid 8/10: excellent work, given the magnitude of the original game that it has to live up to.

The game feels really claustrophobic compared to the original, probably because all the biomes are way shallower. Predators seem to be both more frequent and more aggressive and don't have nearly the same sense of danger as before when you can constantly hear them roaring from every direction and there isn't any deep water for them to jump out at you from. They removed the stasis rifle to stop us from just killing the predators, but they also reduced the movement speed of both the vehicles and the player so much that you can't actually run from them either. The seatruck that was supposed to replace the seamoth and cyclops is just worse than both of them in pretty much every way and really slow and unwieldy. The new PDA voice was also kind of annoying but that might just be because I'm used to the original. 

Since this was labeled as an expansion at first, I thought this was going to have a similar overall atmosphere and sense of "alien-ness" and loneliness, but it really doesn't.
I think anyone who comes in with those expectations will be disappointed.

Off to replay the original again :P

This game IS subnautica, but from the very START you instantly KNOW something is wrong.

THE PREMISE IS NOT RELATABLE
Original game: Your ship crashes. Survive on an alien world you know nothing about and try to escape.
Below zero: You incarnate Robin, a reckless woman that willingly goes on a suicidal mission to investigate the disappearance of her mary-sue sister. 

THE VIEWPOINT DOESN'T MATCH THE STORYTELLING
Honestly, whilst it would remain worse than the first, I wouldn't care nearly as much about the difference of approach if it wasn't for the fact the game is in 1st person, meaning you are supposed to INCARNATE Robin, and anything SHE says comes from YOUR (1st person) mouth. It breaks your immersion EVERY SINGLE TIME. And she speaks every time the story progresses, so in the moments the immersion is supposed to be the most important... In the end, the monologues and the interactions between characters all do a disservice to the game.

If you find yourself craving more subnautica after completing the first game (like myself) then purchasing this game is a good idea, nonetheless I personally don't believe it's worth $30, and advise you to wait for a sale. Its pretty much a carbon-copy of the first game with minor changes (mostly for the worse, the world is far too small and the vehicles reflect that) but I think the story is actually pretty nice, and does a good job of building onto the subnautica world.

All things considered, I give this game an 8/10 .

So I'm enjoying the game.  Like the first Subnautica (which you should play first before this one), the game is gorgeous.  The biomes are interesting, and this game has a good deal more variety than the first.  Whereas in the first game walking on foot felt like an afterthought, it feels better fleshed out here.  The music is enjoyable, and the updates to base building are absolutely wonderful.

I especially love the playful little sea monkeys.

But, ultimately, I feel like more effort was put into the quality for the first game than for this one.  I've come across a good number of issues -- some of which existed in the first game and really should've been fixed in that one, let alone this one.  Stuff disappearing through the floor, for example.  I was willing to let a lot of that slide since the first one was, well, the first one.  This being the second one, though, I expected to see a lot of the issues fixed.  Sure, I expected there might be some NEW issues since this game has some NEW features, just not OLD issues.

I would still recommend this game.  I don't regret buying it.  It's still very beautiful, and very fun, and very intriguing.  Just maybe save your game more often than I did, so if something goes wrong you maybe lose ten minutes of progress rather than an hour or two.

With that said, there are spoilers below.  Stop reading now if you haven't played the game yet.

Here's ten issues I had, some of which are more frustrating than others.

1. The mouse cursor is nigh invisible on the title screen.  A lot of blue on blue.  Considering the default marker color in the first game was blue, and in this one it's orange, I feel like this should've been on their radar.

2.  I got a marker twice for the initial distress call.  There are two of them in my marker list.  The second one came after I already went there and did the thing.

3. The conditions for which beacons appear isn't clear, or isn't consistent.  I basically followed the beacons and ended up at end game locations long before even getting the first hints about what happened to Sam.  This seems like a glaring oversight.  I also never got an indicator as to where Maida's greenhouse was, so I had to fumble around for that.  At this point, I don't think that marker exists.  For a game that gives you indicators and markers to progress the story, it sure seems inconsistent.

4. At Maida's undersea base, she gives you access to several snowfox fragments, but only one of them is scannable.  You have to find the particular area of iceberg where those fragments are located to find the other two.  God help you if you go to either of the other two locations first (spoiler: I went to both other locations first.)  I ended up exploring the entire iceberg in my prawn suit, and by the time I could even make the snowfox I was drowning in ion batteries.  This means I also explored those areas without the cold suit.

5.  I put my mobile vehicle bay up near the lily pads since it was pretty safe up there, and was directly above my base.  Then I made a sea truck prawn suit dock compartment, and it landed on top of the lily pad.  The propulsion cannon doesn't work on those, and I couldn't push it off myself.  There was no means by which I could force it to dock with my sea truck.  It's unretrievable.

6. Vehicular engine noise is WAY too loud, and it's grouped in "ambient noise" with a LOT of other game audio.  If you turn that down, the game becomes eerily quiet.  It would be nice if this were a separate sound category so I could turn it down without turning down ALL ambient noise.  The Sea Moth and Prawn Suit in Subnautica 1 were a joy to use, and they were so quiet.  The Prawn Suite in Sub Zero is deafeningly loud even just sitting idle.

7. My snowfox is stuck 20m beneath the surface of the ice, bobbing up and down on the water.  Y'know, cause in video games, stuff isn't solid.  There's no reason for it to be.  Anyway, right after I put an ion battery in my snowfox and tried to deploy it, it deployed inside the floor and immediately dropped down inside the iceberg.  It's unretrievable.

8.  On land, every time you exit the prawn suit, you will take fall damage.  This didn't happen in the first game.

9.  The control room only offers the ability to turn off the power to the various rooms.  If you want the lights dimmed, or off, there is no compromise.  It's off.

10.  The aromatherapy item stops glowing if you turn the power to its room off.  It's battery-operated.  Shouldn't it still glow?  What's the point of it glowing when the lights are ON?  I wanted a cool, fragrant nightlight.  =(

I haven't beaten the game yet.  I'm very worried there will be more items to add to this list before I'm done.
It's more Subnautica what's there to dislike? A lot actually but a more flawed version of my favorite game is still damn good. Give us more of the fish game Unknown worlds!

[b]Short story:[/b]
This is a good game (and thus a positive review), but I did not really enjoy playing it.

[b]Long story:[/b]
I think this game is really just an expansion, of all the same things that gave us wonder in the original Subnautica (and a very imperfect one at that for reasons that others have stated far better than I can).
It's not alright that it was marketed as a new standalone experience, essentially a Subnautica 2, but this did not catfish me, as I just bought it recently, and was fully aware of what I was getting into.

Even knowing that, it still was very disappointing as this experience feels like a game, not a living world anymore. 
Getting upgrades feels very gamey, there are rough transitions between biomes, and threats are significantly tamed. It all feels like a lesser experience, even land exploration feels worse, which I don't even know how they managed, since they significantly expanded on it!

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
This game is a lesser experience that it's predecessor, which is further hampered by a ''been there, done that'' feeling. If in doubt, my recommendation would be you play Below Zero first, and the original Subnautica after.
