this game sucks it follows the same idea of the OG Subnautica however is worse in every way and there is so much wrong with it I literally could only commit myself to doing a play through after like 5 times because of how boring it is plus the game makes a 2 - 3 hours story longer by making the story parts of the game a maze witch are annoying plus the Snow fox  is so useless just use the Prawnsuite and bring a repair tool trust me it is so much easier the leviathans are boring and weak plus everyone of them other than the land ones  are affected by the perimeter defence system meaning even if they latch on to you they take about 30% from your Seatruck plus not to mention you can get the perimeter defence system from Marguerite who you encounter before any leviathan I mean the first time I met any new leviathans I kept going back to them multiple times I still to this day am cautious of any of the leviathans in the first Subnautica but in this game they are all jokes they never got so much as a jump out of me even when I wasn't expecting them the are also tiny compared to the ones from the OG game there are many more things like the smaller map ugly bioms and more that makes this game almost unplayable especially compared to the OG also the writing is so bad it even makes plot holes in the first game along with no payoff and often times where you are waiting for the next objective and having no clue how to trigger them plus one of the mission objectives beacons doesn't work IDK if they fixed it yet but it caused alot of confusion and it wasted my time with me constantly goning back thinking I did something wrong or missed something and that doing that something right might finally trigger the next objective but it didn't this game will never be Subnautica 2 for me and will always be the DLC witch was sold as its own game
Good

Looks like devs didn't understand why first Subnautica was so successful and made Below Zero.

First, the story is complete mess, it doesn't make much sense. At start I had hopes after Al meeting, but it become such a mess.
 You can even finish the game without finding what happend to the mc's sister.
Secondly, devs decided it would be fun to explore super small caves and crevasses. No it isn't, they are super annoying. Lots of things are so hidden, so if you won't find it by accident you will give up and look for a location on the web.
Archtitects buildings with one thing to scan randomly scattered? Makes no sense - in Subnatuica you had power plant, reasearch lab, gun platfrom etc- all made sense and was connected to each other.
Glacial basin is a joke, full of boxes with water, nutrient blocks and tabs... really? 
You don't even have to catch fish anymore, there are so many diffrent fruits.
Game does really bad job at telling you where to go sometimes, like searching for greenhouse.
You have laser cutter but you can't cut the little opened doors for koppa mining because no, and yes, sea truck won't fit. You can go inside with another way, but you won't find it unless you look up on the net.
You can only have a sea truck, snowfox and a prawn suit, the prawn suit isn't even necessary.. 
Putting a few leviathans in crystal cave just to annoy you, really? They are just swimming in circles in a small space. Totally diffrent from eg. lost river in original game.
There are some small QoL improvements but not much.
There was still a bug from original game with powering base with power relay (on/off on loading save). 
The frozing weather is a joke - you counter it with salad with peppers or only peppers....
New OST is not bad, but the one from first game is better.

Overall is worse than the first game, you may still have fun with it, but really small caves and mess of a story makes it a bit silly.
constantly crashes for me, lost around 3h of play time across multiple crashes.

A lot of people say þis is worse þan þe original, but I don't þink þat's really true. It does have a very different feeling to it, þough; if you just want to experience subnautica again, þis may not be þe game for you. Þe story in þis game is a lot more direct & personal. You get actual living characters wiþ personalities, whereas in þe first game þe only proper characters & story to be found are in þe logs of long-dead survivors or environmental storytelling. Þis does, of course, vastly reduce þe feeling of isolation. 

Þe fear factor isn't nearly as prominent. Unless you have þassolophobia or related instinctual fears, you're probably not going to find it all þat scary, þough it is still *very tense* when you're in dangerous situations. 
I þink þe gameplay has a lot more to it þan þe first. Þe new vehicles are awesome, as are þe basebuilding features.

Also, and þis is more of a personal taste þing, but I þink þe new environments and creatures are even better þan in þe first game, all really beautiful and really cool.

It's subnautica lite, if you liked the first game and want to play it I guess it's worth it on sale, otherwise not missing much. The story was alright, honestly the most engaging part. Biome and creature design were for the most part good, just some bits that made no sense. Like how are there peepers and other arctic variant crater life here(Could’ve easily been fixed with a levianthan class that migrates around the ocean, like the reefbacks) And the cryptosuchus just feels all sorts of wrong. The shadow leviathan kinda sucks, it's basically non threatening if your prawn is mobile enough, not to mention it's design is literally out of a sci fi b movie. Most biome felt pretty empty, with biomes like the Lily pads pretty much only having 2-4 things swimming around. The Vent Gardens are easily one of the coolest things i've seen animal wise in games and somewhat makes up for the disappointments elsewhere, just make your base next to one and enjoy the great view.

Subnautica was one of the best games i have ever played, and when they announced subnautica BZ I was probably the most hyped i have ever been for a game! but... when it came out and i played it through I felt it was missing a certain mystical feeling that the first subnautica reveled in! as I've played it more I realized that the biggest thing bringing it down is that it has too much STORY. hear me out, in the first subnautica [spoiler] you fall out of an unknown ship that was shot by an unknown source and fell to an unknown planet. And you NEVER see anyone, the closest thing you come to actually seeing someone is when you're almost saved by the Sunbeam [/spoiler] BUT the new subnautica intro immediately introduces you two 3 voiced characters, and it also establishes that we already know the name and history of the planet we're landing on. [spoiler] an hour into the game you're introduced to the literal living consciousness of an alien from the teased alien civilization in the first game, COMPLETELY undermining all of the carefully curated wonder and curiosity the first game built up [/spoiler] I really wish they handled the story as carefully as they did in the first game.

I bought this on switch when it was on sale for $5, and then bought it on steam for sale for $10. On Switch I have 90+hours, and on here I have 3 hours. 
It's a fun game, but it gets repetitive after a while. TECHNICALLY It's infinite, but, honestly, once you hit 100 hours, your done. Only if it's on sale.

Below Zero is a good game standalone, but when compared to the original game I would say it's disappointing.

There are a few good things about it: the graphics of the biomes are really detailed and vibrant and the design of the fauna and flora are all excellent. 

However, the map is way too small imo (which also meant that no large vehicles can be constructed in this game), the main storyline is way about your sister is way too short and even anticlimactic, game isn't really scary like the original game since there a few leviathans within the crater (compared to Subnautica) and they can all be rendered useless with a seatruck upgrade. Lots of shallow areas meant it was hard to traverse and the speed reduction with the addition of modules to seatruck is way too taxing. The fact that you arrived on this planet based off your will, removes the element of survival and the introduction of Al-an made the game too straightforward to play, 

Jukebox is probably the best things that devs have added though.
Very underrated

An excellent sequel, with enough changes to keep the game fresh and interesting. 

As before, I enjoyed exploring an alien world, collecting materials, and learning how to survive and thrive. The environment is arctic rather than tropical this time, which presents new challenges. There is also a mystery or two to investigate. 

As before, I was less enthusiastic about the end game. It sometimes resembles a scavenger hunt for I knew not what, (only that something important was in the area). I scrounged and carefully mapped a large portion of the glacial basin, which was rather tedious, because it can be hard to know whether you've overlooked something. I was relieved when a walkthrough confirmed that I had already found everything important. And I still hate the leviathans, but I guess that's how it's supposed to be. 

Enjoy the fish, and I can recommend the marblemelon ;)

Not as good as the original for a few reasons, chiefly that I miss my Seamoth. The game world of Below Zero is significantly smaller than the base game but this actually works against it since there’s less places to find blueprints in. It took me forever to find the extended Oxygen tank because it’s only in one location that’s really obscure unless you know exactly where to look. Because of this, it took me about as long to beat Below Zero as the original. The plot is better, but that’s a low bar. I like the protagonist less, mostly because she won’t shut up whereas Riley knew damn well to keep his mouth shut to preserve the atmosphere. The temperature mechanic is superfluous and frustrating even in the best of occasions. Overall, I left with a positive impression, but I’m more hopeful for the next game in the series.

Below Zero as a stand alone game is fine. But, if compared to the previous game, BZ is just... weird. The story feels more streamlined and forced than the first game, mostly because there is much more dialogue in BZ than the first game. Additionally, BZ doesn't really build off of the first game vehicle and mechanics wise. Rather, BZ takes a completely different direction with it vehicles and mechanics and, in my opinion, did a worse job than the first game. 

Another thing I dislike is the atmosphere of BZ. The biomes in BZ feel more like a stereotypical alien planet similar to many other games out there. The environments of the first game were more barren, but that added to the overall atmosphere of the first game. The overfilled biomes of BZ add nothing to its atmosphere and feel forced. I guess the developers wanted to spice up the atmosphere of the game (quite literally). However, this was to the detriment of BZ.

Overall, I would say BZ is not worth getting in 2023 and beyond unless the developers release DLC, which I don't think is going to happen.

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

Subnautica Below Zero is an absolute masterpiece and a worthy addition to the Subnautica series. As a devoted fan of the original Subnautica, I couldn't have been more thrilled with this sequel. It's safe to say that the Subnautica series has captured my heart, and Below Zero only solidified its place as my favorite game series.

It builds upon the incredible foundation of its predecessor, taking us on an even more mesmerizing and chilling underwater adventure. The icy, alien world of Planet 4546B is both haunting and beautiful, offering a stark contrast to the lush, tropical setting of the first game. Exploring the depths of this frozen ocean feels like diving into a mysterious, otherworldly realm, and the sense of wonder and danger is ever-present.

The storyline is as captivating as ever, immersing you in a narrative filled with intrigue and mystery. Unraveling the secrets of the planet and uncovering the truth about your sister's disappearance is a gripping experience that keeps you hooked from start to finish. The characters you encounter along the way add depth to the story and make the world feel alive.

The gameplay mechanics have been refined and expanded, offering a more immersive and enjoyable experience. The addition of new biomes, creatures, and tools adds variety and challenge to the gameplay. The thrill of exploring uncharted territory, discovering new lifeforms, and mastering your survival skills remains just as enthralling as in the first game.

The graphics and sound design are simply breathtaking. The underwater world is a visual masterpiece, and the ambient sounds and music pull you deeper into the immersive experience. The attention to detail in every aspect of the game is truly commendable.

It manages to create an atmosphere that is both serene and terrifying, and it's a testament to the developers' dedication to crafting a rich and engaging game world. From the colossal leviathans lurking in the depths to the smallest, most intricate details, the game's beauty is unparalleled.

In conclusion, Subnautica Below Zero is a must-play for fans of the Subnautica series and newcomers alike. It continues the legacy of its predecessor while bringing new elements and surprises to the table. I was captivated, thrilled, and utterly absorbed in this underwater world. This game cements Subnautica as my all-time favorite game series. Dive in, and prepare to be amazed!

As others in the reviews may have mentioned, many consider this game more of a DLC for the original Subnautica. This is for many reasons, some of which being that the game is shorter, more story driven, easier (in my experience) etc. This game does not take nearly as long to complete at the original Subnautica did, this is partially because in the original Subnautica, the story was furthered by how much the player explored (which they do on their own terms and time), while Below zero has a lot more story quests that tell you where you need to be to further the story. Now don't get me wrong, I love the story, and am eagerly awaiting the next game (and hopefully more of our Below zero characters) and I thoroughly enjoyed every bit of this game. 
When it comes to in game play, there are a few things worth noting for those who played the original Subnautica. 1. They removed the seamoth and the cyclops, sorry. 2. They add the seatruck and a nice little upgrade that just lets you "pop" leviathans off, which honestly was pretty neat, but reduced the difficulty of the game in my opinion. (you could always choose not to use it, but it's helpful) 3. They add a larger room and some other features to build with for those who like base building. 
But no matter what changes they made from how gameplay was in the original Subnautica, I will always recommend this game as it really is a fun experience to play it.

Listen, if you crave more subnautica, its a good game. If you look at it on its own, its an even better game. It's really pretty, and the music is great. It expands well on the lore of the planet, I'd say.
But...
You may have heard tales of the story having 2 major rewrites, and... yeah, its true. The story for this game isn't terrible, its moreso the specific character writing... and the handholdiness.
Its like, they designed the game with clear intent of it being a subversion from the original game by being more story focused, but then they completely turned it right back around to try and be subnautica but again, which... yknow, I get it. people wanted the isolation and scares, but this wasnt a good move on the devs' end, imo. You can tell this game was always meant to be a heavily narrative focused game, with many living characters... and having a large part of that narratives identity stripped away... even if you add detail and quality to the remaining parts and focus on them, its still gonna leave an uncanny taste. That and GOD the main characters writing is like, actually the worst writing in any game ever? Speaking protagonists in first person survival games are already questionable, but robins exchanges with one of the few other characters that does exist? She sounds like shes pretending to be a human. Clearly deep lore /s

It's a good game on its own, if you ignore the questionable story and writing. It's a bit "go grab the thing thats over here" at times, but... eh, im conflicted. They really dropped the ball by trying to make this game conform to what people wanted a subnautica game to be, instead of letting it have a unique identity. You can probably figure out how to play early access online, if you care to experience the old story.

If you want a game to play, play it. Don't set your expectations high.

I hit 100 hours in this game, so might as well leave a review. This game is highly enjoyable. The subnautica series has such a good core gameplay loop, I always come back to these games just for that. The resource gathering, exploring and building aspects are simply fun and entertaining - even after finishing the game several times. The biomes are gorgeous in this game, and the creature design is very well done. Unlike the first game, this one features a section that's on ground, and I find that the weakest one. The difference in level of detail is huge, with the sea having all the fun stuff, and the ground being left rather plain and same-y.

The vehicles are alright. You get three. The ground vehicle, snow fox, is by far the worst and I never use it. You get another vehicle earlier that can go on land AND in water, and is perfect in every way - the prawn suit. I still make a snow fox every time, just because it's a pretty sweet lawn ornament.

The story... it's bad. I'd love to defend it because I really like this game, but I simply can't. I think it's dull and preachy, and I didn't connect with any of the characters. It's like the slightest bit of flavor over 'mega corporation bad' and that's it. The mega corporation was bad in the first game too, but at least in that one, we're allowed to laugh at it. Not here, it's Serious Time. There's a custom game option that allows you to turn off the story though, if you get really annoyed by it and just want to build a cool base.

In conclusion: Game is good. I recommend playing the original Subnautica before this, because that's even better. This game is not as scary as the first game, so that might be the only reason to play this first.

Things this game did better than the Original Subnautica:
-Color Vibrancy - The game feels like you're on an actual different planet 
-More Walking Sections - I really like how you can drive or pilot your vechicles through the ice glaciers
-Alan- Just the way how he asks the character about his kind and vice versa, it feels organic
Things this game did worse than the Original Subnautica:
-Some materials are easier to craft , thus making the game easier - F.E the Titianium Ingot now costs 5 metal , not 10 
-The depth is more shallow - In my opinion , the original was better because the time it took to get from the deepest parts of the map to your base felt more rewarding. In Below Zero the deepest part is more shallow by like what? 600 meters? 
-The Storyline - Again , IN MY OPINION , the storyline in the original game was more vague , leaving you wondering what happened to you fellow survivors. In this game its like : i need to know what happened hermm theres been a sabotage herrm who could have done that hermm.
-Playtime - I finished it two times quicker than Subnautica , but for a player focused on building and enjoying the views, i thinks you can squeeze out 200 hours of fun gameplay
Final Verdict : Should you buy it? Yeah its worth it , but it wont be like the original.

Nice game, appalling load times, glitches and general bugs. 

The devs made this game on early access business model again for some reason even though they made bank on the first one so kinda abusing the system a bit there.

Load times are still pretty bad considering it's 2023 even on a high-end gaming rig.

The game has dramatically improved since early access. There are some nice new touches to nake it stand out from the original, including a bit more narrative than the original.

Still feels kinda lazy, since so many of the items you can build in the base are cosmetic only, it begs the question why there aren't more cosmetic options. 

The truck dock is a nice idea poorly executed. If you want to change upgrade modules you have to undock and swim around the truck. If you want to change which truck modules you have to undock and do it manually. It would have been a good idea to allow both of these things to be done from inside the base since this makes things considerably more hassle, making the moon pool still the better option.

Only having one under-water vehicle to choose from is a shame. I get that the Cyclops wouldn't be practical in this map but it's nice to have options.

I don't dislike this game, it's still good fun but as a a Developer myself it's frustrating to see a game not reach it's full potential because of perceived laziness on the part of the devs.

Once you reach the end of the stable part of the game, there will be bugs. But apart from that, this game runs real nice, the storyline so far seems to be solid, and there are spooks to be had.
Buy the game, go have fun!
Edit: Game runs good now!

This game does most of what the first game does, only worse. And the new ideas it has are bad.
It has no scary elements at all, not even unnerving. All the big dangers are essensially sharks, of a few varieties. Every place is well lit. You can navigate almost anything without worrying about running out of air. No dangerous animals in any cave. Not even a humble crashfish.

The map is much smaller, both in field and in depth. With a map this small, the big submarine would be meaningless and the quick seamoth would reach the edge of the map right away. So both are cut.
The plot is very poor. It's incoherent, and poorly written. Two highly educated individuals (one of them extremely old) act, and speak like uneducated children. A third individual has done extraordinarily impossible feats to even appear in the game, but has no real reason to even be present. 
The game has two main goals. One is trivial, the other longer one is scientifically impossible and contradicts itself. The long one can be skipped, even though that is the whole reason our main character is on the planet in the first place. 

Your Survival PDA is with you all the time and is meant to inform you constantly about relevant facts. Unfortunately it sounds smug and has a really thick indian accent which makes it difficult to understand. The only real positive is the design of the biggest deep sea enemy. But it is impossible to avoid and barely injures you, which makes it just tedious again. Such a shame.

The first game is far superior. Big map, deep map. Dark, scary, dangerous places. Areas of "bottomless" sea. Simple survival setting. No tedious NPC's, only you- thankfully a silent protagonist. PDA voice is clinically effective and easy to understand, even funny at times.
Great biome variety. Unique creatures for those biomes. Frightening areas, warm areas, beautiful areas. The quick vehicle is useful, and the big sub is a great mobile base, making everything less tedious. Both are fun to pilot.

I hear a third game is in the works. I sincerely hope it's a sequel to the original game (again, properly). If it tries to build on the plot of Below Zero, I'll be deepsea disappointed.

Consider this game DLC/spinoff because as mentioned it is a lot shorter but really plays well with the continuation of 1. It's a nice closing-book to the story as a whole. 

An awesome experience - definitely play Subnautica 1 first though.

Oh, where to begin...

Subnautica is one of my most enjoyed games.
I've been playing since 2016 and completed it several times in that period. It's mostly what I want out of a singleplayer exploration game. A rich place full of things to explore, and an incredibly immersive experience.

As a player I adore the feeling of waltzing around and exploring new worlds.
Really playing the part of my character. And it helps if that world is interesting.
Which, to Below Zero's credit, it is.

The issue comes from the story.
I have no issues playing as a female character. Give them a voice, and as a guy I can just brute force them into a guy. Power of the mind and all that. It's when your story is so god awful, so unbelievably terrible, incredulously offensive. That my mind begins to slip.

Think to Subnautica, the original.
The story is told through the bare minimum needed.
Logs tell you something wrong has happened, each and every rescue pod, save yours. Has been destroyed, one of them mentions some unknown disease. Another tells you about an island. But very little more than that. Eventually you get the "Kill Transmission." You start seeing the warpers, hearing them, and you can put together the information yourself. It's very good at letting you both come to conclusions, and lead you in the direction it wants you to go.

Below Zero, treats you like a child who needs to be coddled.

And thanks to the story, you can no longer have the graceful simplicity of the first game. Now, there has to be a reason outside of "This may be my best chance for survival." Which means there needs to be a reason for me to care. I naturally cared in the original because I was a survivor looking for other people, a cure, and eventually a way off the planet.

Now? I'm some generically written woman, looking for her generically written sister, against the generically written evil corporation. I do not, and can not, care about anything that is going on. Since, I barely know anything about any of them. An issue, invited by the fact that there are characters now. I cared to visit the pinged locations because [b]I knew[/b] it would help me survive. Now I'm trying to find my sister because I'm [b]told[/b] I should care. though this isn't the biggest issue.

There was a point, where I'll admit, I said fuck the story I'm doing my own thing.
And it was so egregiously stupid, so unerringly dumb, so offensive to my sensibilities as the player.
That I was inches away from choosing to simply drop the game entirely.

[spoiler] Maud, the Degassi survivor, is alive. Alive and has a polar bear as a pet now. Which, if you remember, means that she [b]singlehandedly killed a leviathan by herself, managed to reach the top of the ocean, [/b[ and after all of that, ended up at one of the poles. [/spoiler]

This  terribly written story truly ruins the entire experience.
I can say, without a doubt. The charm that held the first game up is gone.
I respect the ambition, but perhaps what made the original so good. Was the lack of a traditional story.
At the very least, a better writer would have helped.

I checked the reviews only after finishing Below Zero, and I was sort of surprised. Folks tend to love bytchyng and hating things so much more compared to trying to find the good side of things. Total BS. The only way to get a real taste of anything is to try it yourself and avoid opinions as part of them are completely nuts and part of them are full of hate and frustration, mostly independent from the subject that they are actually speaking about. Don't listen to anyone :)

As for the game itself, it is not perfect but it still works. The biggest merit is adding some fixes and enhancements to the bag, compared to the initial game. So, if you enjoyed the game mechanics of Subnautica and just want an another Subnautica experience, it will deliver that just fine. There are many new things to keep you busy, just like the expanded surface area with a lot of odd locations. It has a smaller but somewhat denser map with a little more variation of locations. Also, there are some new gadgets and many new members of flora'n'fauna. The map is loaded with odd locations to discover.

There are things where it falls behind the initial game. Maybe, the most important one is something like the difference between Dead Space I and II. During the very first game, the protagonist doesn't say a single word and doesn't show his face at all. It has its mystique and also will put the player perspective to "me". Dead Space 2 is quite the opposite as it has a narration all over, so the perspective turns from "me", 1st person into "him", 3rd person. Less mystery. Well, the same happened to Below Zero. The protagonist of the first Subnautica game is virtually: you, stranded on an alien planet, fighting for survival. Escape room deluxe. Opposing this, Below Zero gives you a background story (a sort of investigation) and the change of perspective from 1st to 3rd person.

The other thing is, explaining the unknown is sort of unnecessary I think. Do you remember the movie Alien / Aliens? The xenomorphs were just there, as a lethal and unknown mystery. Then, remember Prometheus. Everything became explained, then the explanation became overexplained in Covenant, destroying its own roots. Well, I don't know about you, but I need no, for example, Darth Vader explained. I need no Joker explained. I need no detailed story about his positive ideas or if he is doing gardening in his leisure time or what is his favourite candy whatsoever. All I need to know about him is that he is the greatest villain in the story, period. Then, all these overexplanations destroy the mysteries around these dark characters. Well, as for Below Zero, I won't spoiler the storyline but for me, something like this happens here to some extent: overexplaination. I'd preferred the alien mysteries that were set in Subnautica left the way they were. Now I have a narrative of this game world that doesn't make sense at some points. So, the first Subnautica had a bigger ooomph for that reason, at least to me.

But does that make Below Zero a bad game? No. Is it fun? Yes. Would I recommend it? If you like Subnautica, definitely, yes. Does it have the greatest Sci-Fi stories of all time? No. Does it fall behind the first Subnautica game? Slightly. But should you hate this game for that? 

C'mon. Calm the truck down. If you can't focus on the positives, you will destroy your joy in everything.

Subnautica: Below Zero is a good, fun, and beautiful game. Though, it fails as a sequel to Subnautica in many ways. The biggest way the game fails in comparison to Subnautica is the fear.

The game is a lot less scary than it's predecessor, in large part due to the defense system of the Seatruck. Whenever a Leviathan attacks, you can simply left click using the defense system and you will stun the Leviathan taking no damage whatsoever. This removes all fear surrounding the Leviathans, and simply reduces them to an obstacle whose purpose is to be in the way. The only Leviathan that has a chance of killing you is the Ice Worm, which is more annoying than scary. The lack of fear makes it less interesting to explore the world.

The world is smaller, and more compact than Subnautica's. The game focuses a lot more on land adventure, which is boring and tedious, and the Ice Worm only helps make it annoying. I was expecting the Snowfox to be fun to drive around in, but it was just clunky and difficult to control.
I didn't feel the same intrigue exploring the ocean as I did exploring Subnautica's. Since the games take place on the same planet, Below Zero has a lot of the same environments and creatures. I wish the game committed more to the "Below Zero" theme, because most of the environments have nothing to do with ice or snow. The world is also smaller and compact, and a lot of the cave systems are cramped and difficult to navigate.
The game was also way too focused on the story, which was subpar. I'll avoid why because of spoilers, but you have to find body caches to complete the game, and they are stupidly hard to find. Also, you don't even have to finish Robin's storyline to beat the game.

With all that said, there are things the game does right, which is why I'm still recommending it. The base building is a slight improvement on Subnautica's, with there being more stuff to build. The game looks beautiful, and some of the wildlife is well-designed. And the survival aspects are the same as they were in Subnautica. There were also only a few bugs. On its own the game was fun to play through, but as a sequel to a beloved game, it was disappointing.


Overall, the game fails with the story, the smaller map filled with biomes that don't fit the snow theme, the maze-like land areas, the unintimidating Leviathans, and the general lack of fear surrounding the game. The game does a lot right too though, the survival aspects are the same as they were in Subnautica, the building is slightly better, and the game is even better looking. It's a disappointing sequel, but overall, an alright game.

tasty

In the first several hours of playing this game, I had one overriding thought - back when I played through Subnautica, I had really enjoyed the few parts of that game where you get to explore dry land, and wished there were more of them. I started to wonder if somehow my wish had come true in Below Zero, but in a somewhat "monkey's paw" fashion, as most of the dry land segments in Below Zero made me want to do nothing more than return to the water. Most of Below Zero's out of water sequences are pretty samey and stretch on for far too long. Maybe my biggest overall gripe with Below Zero is that your movement out of the water has not really been improved from Subnautica - it is wonky, slow, and you will get stuck very easily. I found the game's temperature management more annoying than tense or interesting.

Technically, as with the first game, Below Zero looks very good and runs well, though just like the first game I had issues with pop-in/LOD. I think the modeling and design work in Below Zero is maybe slightly better, with the devs learning a bit more about what looks good and what works. I did experience some early crashing which did not repeat as I put more time into the game. Weather effects look really nice in some areas, but bad in others, and most of the time you will wish they were not present as all they really do is limit your vision above water.

The story is more character-driven than the first game, for good and bad. Other people have already critiqued it extensively so I'm not going to bother beyond a brief take that's a bit of a spoiler: [spoiler]I didn't really care for the interaction between Robin and ALAN. It's all pretty trite sci-fi "alien meets human" boilerplate, which is surprising in a game that has some pretty good writing. In my opinion, it contrasts really poorly with the first Subnautica, which successfully establishes an emotional relationship between you and the Sea Emperor Leviathan with no back-and-forth dialogue and very little exposition at all. You care about the Sea Emperor because it is just a gentle giant trying to save its young, and/or you are trying to save yourself - you feel something, but what you feel is entirely up to the player. This part of the first game is so subtly brilliant that I can't help but cringe at some of the back and forth between Robin and ALAN. It's not THAT bad, but it falls way short of the first game, through no fault of either of the voice actors, who are doing the best they can with what they're given.[/spoiler]

One of this game's primary differences gameplay-wise from Subnautica is adding a new vehicle and functionally merging two vehicles into one. Unfortunately, the new vehicle (the hoverbike) is both necessary for dealing with the game's extended out-of-water sections and pretty painful to control and use. I'm not sure if it would be better or worse with a gamepad. The other new vehicle is the Sea Truck - essentially a Seamoth with modular compartments you can add to the rear. While it is more useful than the Seamoth, it's nowhere near as cool as the Cyclops and lacks some fairly important features that the Cyclops had. Some people complained that this game is less scary than the first Subnautica, and I would mostly agree. There is still some tension, but there are fewer aggressive creatures overall and most of the aggressive creatures, for one reason or another, are less dangerous. [spoiler]The lone exception might be the Shadow Leviathan, though I think I found the Shadow more annoying than dangerous, as it seems to exclusively hunt the player and seems to have less natural behavior than a lot of the dangerous enemies from the first game.[/spoiler] Below Zero however does deserve credit for adding some features which were reverse-ported back into the first game.

This game had the bad fortune to be a followup to Subnautica, which I consider to be the gold standard for exploration games. With that in mind, this game is not really a sequel but an expansion, it's not something that stands completely on its own and someone who did not play the first game would probably not exactly understand what was going on with some of the game's plot points. Despite having some additional features, it falls short of the first game in world and design, but I'd still recommend it as a solid-not-spectacular follow-up to the first game.

Welcome back to the ocean world of Subnautica, this time in the frozen arctic regions. New biomes, new gear, new wildlife, new horrors, and old friends. The much sought after squeal to the legendary first Subnautica game. I did enjoy this game, I wanted to say this up front, but in the end Below Zero was a mixed bag of improvements, alterations, and downgrades.

Gameplay: Subnautica is a survival game underwater with horror and dread elements. You build tools and buildings through blueprints and materials on the planet to survive until you can find a way to escape. This formula hasn't changed and is just as good as before, with some changes to certain recipes and some new features (like recipe pins). This time they added some new tools (mineral searcher, music box, etc) and swamped out old gear and vehicles for new ones. Some make sense (temperature based suits and snow filter system) but I find the new seatruck not as good as the seamoth from the first game. They really should've called it a seatrain as its more of a mobile base (like the sub in the first game) and leaves you without a mid-class vehicle. On the flip-side, base-building has expanded greatly with more items, options, and even music to keep you busy for hours.

Storyline: I'll try not to give too much away for those who haven't played yet. The story is the biggest change and the one most have trouble with. The first game began with you crashing after your ship crashes on an unknown water planet. You quickly find you are alone and must find a way to survive while solving the mysteries of this world. Below Zero has you playing a named character, Sam, who is sneaking to 4546B to find out what happen to her sister, who was a researcher at Alteria's base on the planet. One of the traits that made the first game so immersive was the isolation, alone with only your wits and all other contact was either through messages or PDA recordings. The sequel removes a lot of the unknown from the world (as their are multiple bases on the planet now) and all the characters have recordings and id profiles. This isn't all bad, it helps create a sort of murder mystery. The real problem is how forced the isolation element is, the reason all the bases are abandoned is never explained or explored (and with what you learn it makes no sense that Alteria would just run away). From what I learned during the early development cycles the story was YOU being one of the new researchers with the base Alteria founded after the character from the last game returned. A catastrophe occurs with you being the sole survivor and trying to survive in the frozen wastes till help arrives. I feel this might have been a better story.

The other half of the tale from Below Zero is the alien tech storyline, I found this far more fun and engaging than the 'lost sister' plot and some of the best moments of the game came from here.

Game World: A bunch of changes here as we go from the equator to the poles of the world of Subnautica, giving us new species, biomes, and resources. It helps keeping the return to 4546B fresh with enough from the first game to make it feel familiar. Two other big changes here, the game world is smaller and much of the events are more linear. This makes the story easier to follow, but reduces some of the exploration. The biomes themselves and most of the species are fantastic and fun to explore. The spot they tripped up was the larger predators, they are easily avoided mostly and sadly not very memorable, though to be fair it's hard to match the sheer horror of the reaper leviathan and ghost leviathan.

The other part Unknown worlds introduced in Below Zero is the land aspect of the tundra, some cool creatures here but it feels unpolished as most dangers are easily avoided and overcome early on. It was a novel idea, but I feel they needed to do some more work on it before they released it.

In Conclusion: The world and gameplay of Subnautica: Below Zero is still as great as the first game, if you don't compare it too much with the first game it holds up well. The story and characters were by far the weakest part with the second plot with the aliens far more exciting, giving us a great endgame and conclusion. As I said before, I like this game and enjoyed playing it and I do recommend it, though anyone who wants to play this should play the original Subnautica first, then decide how you feel about it.

My rating: 3/5 (average)

It's hard to believe this game was made by the same company as the original Subnautica. While there are  some quality of life improvements, there are several major design flaws in this game. 

For example, the story has this side plot that you can completely miss if you don't get lucky in your exploration, and even then you will also have to follow obscure hints. This side plot is actually the reason why the protagonist goes to that planet, so it's weird that you can finish the game without completing it. The main plot is strange too because sometimes it holds your hand, and sometimes it completely leaves you hanging, so it's really uneven. 

Many upgrades and equipment only spawn in ONE single place, so you can easily miss them. This is a game where you will absolutely need to use the Wiki to find your gear, which wasn't the case with the original.

The map is smaller and not as enjoyable to explore. The overland sections were also not very fun, I just wanted to go back underwater.

In terms of vehicle, I spent the whole game craving for a Seamoth. While the concept of the Seatruck seems good, in practice it just doesn't work too well. This thing feels clunky as soon as you start adding compartments, and most of them are just not very useful in practice, other than the storage one. It's useful to carry the Prawn around, but you rarely need it. It's useful to carry a Fabricator, but you will often miss components so you need to go back to your base anyways. Also, the Seatruck has no Sonar or Solar Charger upgrades, which were awesome with the Seamoth. The deeper levels are a confusing mess and that sonar would have made all the difference.

Anyways, if you want to have more fun, go play the original Subnautica.

edit: I've changed my review to positive, because despite its flaws, its a game I've enjoyed a lot and is totally worth playing. While some aspects of it were done better in the previous game, it's still better than 95% of the trash out there.

If you enjoyed the first game, you will enjoy this one. However, like most sequels, it's just not as good as the original.

Like the first game, Below Zero carries over the beautiful sound design, interesting biomes, cool creature design, and the excitement of discovering a world yet to be explored.

Where it falls short for me the most is that it lacks the fluidity of the first game, which is such an essential component of satisfying plot progression and world exploration. The first Subnautica does an excellent job of progressing you through different biomes as a natural action in progressing the plot. When in doubt, go deeper! It lays out a framework for you to explore the world, leaving enough discretion to the player to keep exploration from feeling boxed in or formulaic, but with enough guidance that you don't get frustrated and become lost.

For me, Below Zero completely lacked this framework. I realized after beating it that it is easily possible to make it to the end and miss about 80% of the game. There are so many areas that you are never directed to, never even brought close to. This disconnect is exacerbated by the fact that there are a number of separate running plot lines, which lack connection to one another and are not at all necessary to actually 'beat' the game. You can even beat the game without even fulfilling the player character's original objective!

Aside from the choppy plot lines, the other thing I missed in Below Zero was the size of the world. The first Subnautica did an incredible job of capturing the terrifying vastness of an alien ocean - Below Zero missed this. The biomes are more condensed, less vast. A lot of the biomes in Below Zero give the same energy as the shallows - close to the surface, not a lot of empty space, tons of spots to hide. That's not to say the game design isn't beautiful, but for me it lacked a real 'ocean' feel at many times.

Overall, worth playing. Not the same as the first, but I enjoyed in nonetheless. Definitely take the time to explore all of the nooks and crannies of the world if you want to fully experience it.

Update: Been poking around in the beta versions. 
Apparently Below Zero is such a disjointed mess because they scrapped the story part way through development. The OG writer left, and was replaced by a writer whose only real credit is having worked on Assassin's Creed games, which completely explains the nose dive in quality. 

The new writer started the story from scratch, while ignoring existing elements of the game. When you find yourself wondering why the bases & labs look the way they do, why certain activities are the way they are, why characters say things that don't make sense, why you keep falling into plot holes, the answer is "because of the original story." The new writer couldn't be bothered to account for the state the game was in, basically just slapped their steaming pile on top of the gutted corpse of the original, and called it good.

If I'd known about this, I would not have bought the game.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

That many hours, yet not recommended? Yeah. Sort of. This is one of those "I wish there was a neutral option" reviews. Do not buy this at full price, like I did, thinking "oh hey, more from the awesome devs of the first Subnautica! This'll be great!" It's fun, kinda, but it's also a hot mess of bad writing, failure to communicate all the controls, failure to communicate objectives, a confusing map that's hard to navigate without beacons scattered everywhere, and a nonsensical anti-climatic ending. If you're hoping to re-experience the magic of the first Subnautica, go re-play the first Subnautica. If you just want to toodle about in a wintry ocean, build a few bases, and are fine with treating the story as something to do between material excursions and egg collecting, then you'll probably be happy. So, while I do think they completely biffed the beginning and the end, the middle has an enjoyable amount of exploration, just not enough for me personally to recommend paying full price.

I started out thinking I wasn't enjoying the game because I screwed up in the beginning, literally went north (towards visible content) when I was meant to have gone south (blindly swimming out into empty open water, with no real gear). I ended up playing a large chunk of mid-game material right in the beginning (which made it way more difficult than it's apparently intended to be) before I stumbled into what was supposed to be the beginning. The more I played, the more I realized I wasn't doing things wrong; I was following the "path" the devs laid out, but that path was poorly constructed resulting in it being easy to encounter the story out of order.

The story... it's like they got bored 30% of the way through writing it, cliff-notes the middle and wrote a bullet point or two for the end. You've journeyed to planet 4546B to find out the real reason behind your sister's death. You do that, learn who is responsible and why, and do... nothing. You say... nothing. There is literally no acknowledgement that you've "solved the case". I actually traveled all the way back to an "area of significance" thinking maybe this was more out-of-order wonkiness and that some dialog would trigger if I went back to the "scene of the crime". Nope. The end game doesn't stop here though. Oh no. It veers off into an irrational cliff hanger ending.

My head-cannon is that Robin didn't survive landing, and the entire game is just her dying brain grasping at wish fulfillment.

I wanted to like it, but... I just couldn't get into it. The world feels smaller, less interesting. I was hoping to be able to continue the trend of the original Subnautica, with deeper canyons, twistier tunnels, and scarier fish, but I didn't get any of that. The map is more cramped and just as difficult to navigate while being less satisfying than the former once mastered. There were a few good tunnels that messed with my sense of direction and gave me oxygen anxiety, but they weren't balanced out by any grand, underwater caverns I was able find. Others have talked about the land gameplay, (and I'm inclined to agree) but I guess the land gameplay was still necessary because the only creature that actually gave me any fear was a land animal. Everything in the water felt squishy and underwhelming. 

There were other things, too. For example: the PDA in the original felt sassy by virtue of being a machine that doesn't mince word. (ex. "Your odds of survival have increased to unlikely, but plausible.") The PDA in this one feels like it runs on an early build of ChatGPT with custom instructions to try and be funny. (Ex. "No bed, no storage, no place to put a fabricator module, no fun.") Then there were the PDAs you find of the researchers, which tried to tell a story but were too easy to grab out-of-order, and I'm not sure if the story was all that good anyway. I screeched when I went on that iceberg and [spoiler]got jumped by Maida...[/spoiler] And then that storyline got kinda squandered, too.

It really feels like they made an absolute banger in the original, then got started on the sequel and decided to backtrack on what made the first one awesome. Honestly, just go replay that and skip this one.

Best Game Ever

Below Zero is far weaker than the first, with weird pacing, much lower difficulty, a smaller-feeling world, and content that significantly overlaps with the first. Considering how similar most of it is, its basally an expansion or new-game+ mode. That said, its still a solid pickup for those who finished the first game and want a couple dozen more hours of it.

If you liked Subnautica then this is an easy buy. It feels more like a very hefty DLC, as the mechanics and challenge are toned way down, but the new fauna and biomes (shallow as they are) provide more of the exploration thrill.

Everything feels much safer, there's nothing comparable to the hopeless dread and mystery that the original Subnautica instills from the first minute to the final hour. The developers also made some inexplicably horrible design decisions: for example, the land parts of Subnautica were always the worst in terms of jankiness and tedium. For some reason, the developers created a plot in which there's as much land-traversal as there is diving. Just one of the worst and most confusing design directions I've ever seen.

That all said, it's still more of the great undersea exploration + servicable story and endgoal that Subnautica did best. A no-brainer purchase if it's on sale.

So, after revisiting this title, I feel the need to completely revise my opinions on it. With a minor change in my approach, I was able to enjoy this game much more than before, and I feel that the issues below zero has compared to the original subnautica boil down to a single element. [spoiler] His name is Al-An. [/spoiler]


Simply put, early in the game you will find a distress signal which seems to come from an alien source. Do not investigate this source. Explore the world as you see fit besides this; if you want a good benchmark when you finish doing what Sam originally came to the planet to do before exploring this signal. I found the experience of this game to be much closer to the original when played this way, even with the aid of online resources (namely maps) for when I was stuck. I've grown a lot fonder of below zero as a result of this playthrough, and would recommend this game to anyone interested on one condition: do not, and I CANNOT stress this enough, DO NOT interact or investigate the alien distress signal near the start of the game.

The reason? Once you investigate this signal, you will have most points of interest highlighted on your screen by waypoints, which take one out of the world, and discourage exploration, instead prompting the player to just beeline it to the mark on the map ignoring everything along the way as the game basically tells you where to go for progress, rather than relying on exploration, the primary driving force in subnautica. This is fine when one wants to just end the game. It is not fine for a normal play through, ESPECIALLY a first one. [spoiler] It also brings the worst character in the game to be glued to the player for the rest of the game, and very little of value is added with his presence. Many people wrongfully point to Sam for this, but in reality, it's entirely on Al-An, who has no narrative synergy with the protagonist unlike other characters, only interacts with the main character, and also actively makes the game worse for the player. He is the worst kind of companion. [/spoiler]


Do not interact with that cave. Do not investigate the alien signal until you are satisfied with what you have accomplished in a play through. Yes, it is technically required for some progression, but trust me, you want to pick it up at the very last possible moment.

Perfect Game #65, Subnautica: Below Zero.  I loved the original Subnautica, it was scary, the environments felt unique compared to every other one, you grinded to go deeper and deeper, eventually going into the lava zone, it was perfect.  Then with Below Zero there are still different areas, but they never felt as unique as the original game.  I think the largest factor in this is the on-land gameplay.  While riding on a snowfox is tons of fun, a large portion of the map is just boring white land surrounded by cliffs.  

I wish there were more large hostile creatures as well.  When I think back to first game there was the Reaper, Ghost Leviathan, and Sea Dragon, but in Below Zero I can only recall the Shadow Leviathan.  A large part of what made the first game so exciting was the fear of not knowing what was below and then learning you could go deeper and deeper down, but that wasn't a part of this game.  I don't even think there was an area that went below 1k meters, and that's just kinda disappointing.

There are still good things to find here though.  The base building is much improved from the first game.  There is more variety  and the new base parts allow for a lot of creativity.  Though there is no seamoth in this game the seatruck is a fantastic alternative with a lot of customizability.  There is also a start-to-finish storyline that takes place through the game that I thought was handled pretty well.  I would still recommend Below Zero despite my problems with it because it did improve on the gameplay aspects of the game; I just wish that they would've kept the same level of atmosphere that the first game had.

Dont waste your time or money, this game will disapoint.

This game was unimaginably disappointing in gameplay and story. The story itself has the quality of a 5th-graders Subnautica fanfic, and the gameplay isn't much better. The map is much more small and cramped, and you're forced on land for half of the game. The story feels much more "forced" onto the player as opposed to the previous game. The game just feels like trapping the player into a subpar labyrinthine fetch-quest that leads to an ultimately unsatisfying and (imo) kinda stupid ending. The game's QOL features and graphical improvement are a welcome addition, but don't make me want to recommend the game.

[i] Subnautica: Below Zero [/i] can't quite hold a candle to [i] Subnautica [/i]. My expectations were lower for [i] Below Zero [/i] since it is an expansion pack sequel, but it was surprisingly worse in several areas.

The most glaring issue is the story. The change in lead writers was painfully obvious. The new databank entries are lackluster compared to the entries recycled from [i] Subnautica [/i] , and the dialogue is plain awful. I felt like I was listening to half-baked stories from the creatively bankrupt "Humans Fuck Yeah" subreddit. I cannot think of a single moment from [i] Below Zero [/i] that is as memorable as the ham and cheese sandwich moment, much less anything else. It didn't help that the voice acting was atrocious either. The player character always sounded like she was reading Dr. Seuss to preschoolers. [spoiler] I liked Marguerit, but her role in this game undermines the theme of the first game. In [i] Subnautica [/i] she was supposed to criticize the bloodlust-filled attitude of many players, but now she's portrayed sympathetically. How she survived the Khaara infection also isn't explained. [/spoiler]

Dialogue and a voiced player character also removed the all-pervasive feeling of loneliness and isolation that was executed so well in the first game. The terror of the first game was also notably absent.

Gameplay wise, not much changed. Everything below the surface is functional (except for the absence of the stasis rifle). The on-land segments are tedious at best; the Snowfox is pointless because it's outclassed by the P.R.A.W.N. Suit in every way. The mech suit moves faster, can mine, and doesn't fling you out of it when hit by the Ice Worm.

In short, [i] Below Zero [/i] is worse than its predecessor in terms of story, atmosphere, and several gameplay aspects. I would just download mods for the original [i] Subnautica [/i] if I were you.

It is still just like the old Subnautica in a lot of ways, with the exception of playing the role of a less anonymous character. Which is a shame as it seems to have lost something important in the pursuit of a more defined but somewhat dull story. This time it's a lot smoother with less getting stuck or relying on the grapple to pull you across rooms. I wish they had of finished the original off, as well as this. The game area I had heard was much smaller in this one but I have found it quite big enough and it's surprisingly easy to get lost in above sea areas. 

I like how you are guided around the map better in this one, although you are babied some what and a lot of the objectives are easy to reach straight off. I had also been concerned about the new Truck, but it isn't much different from the sea moth, at the start. At least it doesn't get pinched and dumped under ground like in the original game, but the snow fox can disappear under the ground when you place it.

They could have changed the environment a bit more as it seems the same as the first game, only with the surface being extremely cold. Why change the PDA voice as now 30 seconds of oxygen remaining gets very annoying and what is with all the female characters, that are hard to find any appeal with. The story is ok at best, and doesn't really go anywhere. It feels like an alternative remake of the original. the dangers from different life forms is very weak and you've got more chance of drowning, than having much of a problem with most of the sea life. It could have been a lot better but I view it as more of a remake than a progression. So it's good for those that haven't played the original or people that needed guides to find silver lol. 

So as a sequel it is disappointing as it is more of the same really without the mystery or much terror, so I can understand the negativity and I myself found that I lost interest fast. The survival mode works much better in this game... that's for sure but adds very little or nothing to the enjoyment. I hope next they use more imagination and make the story worth following.

Its a great game with loving developers. it may only be single player, but the game would be a lot less fun with friends. The idea of isolation is a core concept to the Subnautica series. Its more relaxed in Below Zero, but the player continues to feel like the only human on the planet. The addition of a companion that talks to the character is a nice touch, acting as the guide to the game without ever introducing spoilers to the story and keeping the game's mechanics simple and easy to pick up.


The above review was from before the game fully released, and perfectly captures my joyous innocence and optimism for the Subnautica series moving past the first installment. Since Below Zero's full release, I have found myself to be disappointed time and time again with the narrative direction, dialogue and gameplay. It's like they took what made the first game so successful and charming, and purposefully ignored it in order to make Below Zero stand out. And stand out it does, because it completely threw me for a curve. First of all, there is NO feeling of isolation due to the constant, and I mean CONSTANT voice lines. The "helpful" companion previously mentioned started off fine enough, but quickly grew irritating as my HUD was cluttered with waypoints and my ears assaulted by inconstant writing. The characters are constantly contradictory or just plain stupid (who in their right mind takes two food bars and a few water bottles on an arctic expedition? No clothes, no building materials). I could go more in depth about how the map itself failed to be interesting or even cause a sense of danger, since everything was so cramped that nothing could hide from you. The only slightly interesting section was the land bit, but that quickly grew tedious, dull and irritating, since snowstorms were a common occurrence and the "land" vehicle almost never works as intended. 
While I still recommend this game to people, I do not recommend going in with high expectations. If you want a fulfilling game with a SOMEWHAT plausible story, pick up the first game and forget about this one. While the first game has its narrative problems, they are far less egregious than the ones present in Below Zero. Play this game if you want, but do not expect much from the gameplay itself. Find something you enjoy doing and stick to that, weather that be cataloging the new hostile creatures (90% of them are some form of shark btw) or filling your aquariums with the non-hostile variants (funny starfish spin :) ). Make what fun you can from this game and you will have a much better experience than I did.

I played the first Subnautica and loved it, and Below Zero is a more than worthy successor to the original! As with the first one, it's incredibly beautiful, visually and aurally. Every aspect mechanically work well. It's fun, terrifying at times, but not insurmountable like the feeling that you get from many survival games. There's not much to say other than that, and I have no real gripes with the game at all. 

That having been said, I will say that I wish there was a wider variety of plant life perhaps. Also more different tech to the original, though it was nice that they didn't reinvent the wheel, because it was unnecessary. Just nit picking mostly because I would love more content for this amazing game! 

If you haven't already played either the original or this game I would highly recommend taking the plunge! They are both very much worth full price! Here is hoping for more Subnautica!

I really wanted to love this game and thus gave it 4 chances to redeem itself after the first one was a blast! (Also Natural Selection 2 was one of my favorite games of all time!)
 1. I Bought it on day one, it was in the early access mess
 2. Tried 1 year later, still early access mess
 3. Tried 2 years later, still too early, but somewhat playable. Got to 50% of the story and got bored.
 4. I Tried it now in 2023, almost a year since the last update and the game feels like a cash grab.

The story is boring and lacks depth and connection on why we do not have resources or blueprints. The pacing is terribly slow and there is no guidance on what to do. 

Do not make the same mistake of sinking 30 hours into an unpleasant, cash grab. They had so much potential when doing this one after they had so much success with the first. Unfortunately, modding community abandoned this game, since it was changed so much and most of them do not work. 

I really hope that whatever you do now Unknown Worlds, you won't fuckup your game.

its a good game.
has some good and poor points compared to the previous title.

the good
gathering resources are just way easier. I really appreciated the koppa mining site and early prawn, it lets you get alot of titanium pretty early on to do fun things like build a big base
speaking of bases, i like the new base parts (even though its not super useful most of the time) it's still awesome and rule of cool is a thing for a reason.
some people dislike the story. i dont think its that bad, i loved seeing marguerite again, sam's story, and alan/robin interactions are just plain funny. i def prefer bz's story over subog. dont even think robin is that annoying like others do lmao.

the bad
the vehicles range from meh to downright useless/unbalanced.
seatruck: for most of the game i used it in seamoth solo truckin mode because 1. i literally cannot find the modules, or rather didnt go out of my way too really, and 2. the modules you can add are pretty meh. maybe its because im a devout cyclops fanboy... i'll just say that i think the seatruck is not terrible, in fact its pretty ok considering the smaller and tighter map, but its just... boring compared to what we had, i guess.
prawn: its even more awesome, i think its better than og's because of the speedboost function and honestly it just felt way smoother to handle.
snowfox: oh god its just plain terrible. the controls are pretty bad. maybe its because i didnt try it out for more than 15 minutes, but the reason for that is because...

the ugly
oh god the pop in and bugs are atrocious. in both games, i lost a total of 3 vehicles. in og, i lost my prawn to hubris in lava zone. in bz, i lost a seatruck and a snowfox... not due to hubris, but entirely due to bugs. the seatruck was lost when i was making my way towards the mercury ii bow for further exploration, the beacon came up, I went "damn, where is it?" got out, and BAM, it popped in AROUND the seatruck and its now stuck in the bridge of the mercury ii, which is inescapable for the seatruck. the third vehicle was the snowfox, and i KID YOU NOT, 15 minutes after I got it, I picked it up, placed it back down, and it BURROWED INTO THE SNOW. LIKE AN ACTUAL SNOWFOX. which is why i decided to just do the entire land section in the prawn suit instead, which i dont think was intended. maybe if id gotten more than 15 minutes to play around with the snowfox i wouldve liked it. idk. never had these issues with glitches in og, so idk why its all happening in bz. settings are the same too.

tldr sub bz is a pretty good game if you liked sub og, just play it for fun, and be careful around the mercury ii bow. cheers.

This game as well as the prequel to this game are wonderful and beautiful! The sound design was impeccable in both the first game and in Below Zero, although in my opinion the music was better in the original game!

When considering a story aspect I actually enjoyed this game much more than the prequel. I won't go into details, since I don't want to spoil but the ending has room for a lot of possibilities, if another game is planned to be released.

It was very fun to discover the different biomes! But if you're like me you'll need to search for safe routes for the more hostile biomes, because this game can very scary at some points. 

I don't know if it was shorter because I was not that afraid of the fauna, considering I already went through the first game and thus made much faster progress but I felt like it went by way quicker. Maybe I was enjoying it more which makes it seem like time is flying by.

The biggest downside for me compared to the previous game is the map. Its smaller and it feels way more claustrophobic and empty at times. 

Anyways, if you played the original and liked it, you will definitely like this one too, since it has more diversity when it comes to blueprints and buildable stuff. In addition there is also land that plays a big role in this game unlike the other game.

Like many others, this was really average at best, its not as good as the first one on several levels.

The level design isnt quite as good, there's much less depth and exploring as the first one. The land section is a bit of a maze and the ground vehicle handles very badly which makes it a bit difficult to bear.

The water sections are good but with the narrative driven story, I often found I was kind of rail-roaded, rather than exploring things as the first one.

The story is also not particularly engaging, its trying its best to not get in your way, so often your character is silent, but not in a good way like Gordon Freeman in HL, and there isnt quite enough story to keep me interested; I feel like they should have gone all-in one way or the other.

I took a big break from the game due to events happening in real life and when I came back a few months later, I really found very little motivation to play on, so I uninstalled it, which is a shame, because I really wanted to like it, but Unknown Worlds failed to capture the same spirit of the first game.

A big downgrade not only from the first game but how it started in Early Access. If you had asked me to reccomend the game before the writing of the story completely changed, I wouldve said 100% yes - as the game stands now, however, it is just a shell of how it began.

The protagonist is now constantly quipping in and talking throughout the game - and instead of the calm, mature and flawed scientist she was in the beginning of EA, she became a stereotypical action girl who can do no wrong.

The story makes absolutely no sense and is completely pointless. [spoiler] You fly to 4546B because you dont believe Alterra when they say your sister died due to negligence. But then at the end of the mystery you find out that it was true all along. Sam killed herself by mistake by setting off the bomb earlier than intended. Thats negligence. Then you just decide to... leave to an alien planet? Not only that but your conversations with the Architect are also frustrating. Before the massive writer change, Robin's conversations with Al-An felt like she was trying her best to reason with Al-An and find a middle ground at every situation; it truly felt like Robin was being mature about every topic, even when trying to explain how humanity works to Al-An. Now, all Robin does is reply with unfunny one liners, sarcasm and anger. [/spoiler]

The map and soundtrack are the only saving graces of this game. As a Subnautica experience, it still retains the fun exploration, crafting, base building and unique environments to discover. The land sections arent as bad as some people say they are, the movement out of water is just anky, which I wish they wouldve tuned.

Overall, if youre looking for a Subnautica experience, just go play the original. This one is not worth playing unless you can bear the pain of hearing an unfunny action girl and play through a pointless storyline.

Great, immersive, fun and a bit of a step-down from the previous game.

Graphics were improved in many ways. The world continues to look wonderful, the creatures, the flora, everything looks great and detailed. The weather system adds a lot of immersion with the storms, auroras, fog, etc.

Sound effects continue to be awesome and immersive. All the voice acting is great. And the music is excellent, also the jukebox tunes are great.

Gameplay was a bit of a step-down from the previous game. Starting the game on land, and having to spend a lot of time on land during important parts of the game, in a game named Subnautica, was very disappointing. Part of the magic that the first game had was the endless ocean all around you, and the feeling that you experienced is just lost in this one, when you are surrounded with land and icebergs full of friendly penguins.
Resource gathering and basic survival stays mostly the same, although this one felt more rushed. Some of the tools and upgrades that in the first game you had to do a lot of exploration to find, in this one you find pretty fast, making some of them unrewarding and even pointless.
The fauna continues to be interesting, with new fun additions, and for the most part not that aggressive or dangerous. The new leviathans are not that scary or dangerous as the ones in the previous game.
Resource availability in general is fine, with a few exceptions that you will notice pretty early. The distribution of resources on the biomes felt a bit off, I mean, finding almost endgame materials near the first biome was a bit disappointing.
The lack of a map in this game was even more painful than then first one, mainly on the land parts, but also underwater (the lack of the sonar was really painful). I still don't understand how an exploration game have no actual map (yeah, there is a map that is just a vague image of the land, and it's pretty much useless) to discover, add points of interest, rotate, zoom, etc.
Moving to the vehicles, losing the seamoth and cyclops was a heavy blow, I loved those. The replacements, are not so great. The sea truck pretends to be a mix of the two, offering the speed and versatility of the seamoth, and adding the "customizable mobile base" component of the cyclops with the modules. But in reality, it fails to deliver both. The size and shape of the sea truck makes it get stuck in all sort of places and is slower than the seamoth. The animation to get in and out is super annoying every time that you forget to park it tilted. And most of the modules are useless. Not only, they make the sea truck slower and less maneuverable, they offer little to no benefit. Only two of the six modules are really useful. If for some reason you still decide to build them all, you can't even park them in the sea truck dock, because every time you  leave, you have to manually detach the modules. The snowfox bike is just useless, weak annoying to drive, gets stuck on everything, can't ride over water, etc. Thankfully, we have our trusty prawn suit to save the day.
The building system continues to be great. There are a bunch of new tools, a TON of beds (seriously, how many beds can you build?), a lot of new buildable cosmetics, new cosmetic options for your base and a few new and redesigned machines.

The story has so much more focus this time, with a lot of voice acting, images of the characters that speak, characters background, etc. It was nice, not that interesting as the first one, but ok. Also, the order in which you find the PDA's hurt a lot the development of the plot, and maybe even leave you saying "what? that can't be right, i'm surely missing something".

Like the first game, there are a bunch of game modes to select when you start playing, depending on the experience you want to have. If you want more freedom to build and explore, or you want the survival elements as well, or you want to customize every aspect of it, there are modes for you.

In short, great and immersive game, it still has the core parts that made the first one so awesome, but is a bit of a step-down in many of the mechanics. If you enjoyed the first game, you probably will be a bit disappointed with this one, but you will enjoy it and have a lot of fun anyway.

Its definitely not the same feel as the first Subnautica. In the first, I found the game a lot more intuitive and interesting - as the world felt unexplored but rich in biodiversity, and risk! In this game, the linear story-line felt forced - and resulted in more of a tunnel-vision, where all that mattered was fulfilling the next objective, which left all the environment building as more of an obstacle rather than something worthy of a Subnautica game. I also found the more limited choice of fabricator recipes you start off with annoying. I can see some of the cool parts of the ecosystem in this game, but if I had to sum up this game in a word, it would be 'frustrating' - the caves and land is so difficult to navigate and where in the first game I was able to swim around in caves without the need for a pathfinder tool, its pretty much a necessity in this game, plus finding certain materials - even with a material detector - is so much more annoying, plus the navigation is not intuitive at all - I would be exploring and quickly come to the void without finding the entrance to any caves of interest and without seeing very many different biomes at all. After the first games' diversity in both biomes and their ecosystems, animals and flora, this game's diversity of "surface water" biomes feels like a lot more of a let down. The game doesn't even feel dangerous - like there's much on the line. In the first game, the reaper was an absolute nightmare and even stalkers at first seemed scary - but for me at least, the predators are just...underwhelming. The first time I saw the 'giant shrimp leviathan', it wasn't even scary - it was like 'what is this shimp thing' - it was more of an inconvenience than anything else and just seemed to add to the monotony of this game. This is just my experience(/rant) though, and if you're looking for a lore-based survival game which feels very linear, I reckon this would be a game you might enjoy. I'd maybe recommend watching a playthrough to get an idea of what you're getting before you buy though.
