Its the sequel to Subnautica, all right.

With all due respect, you'd have a better time watching a review than actually playing the game. Its got a fair few issues that are partially remedied by the fact its still Subnautica. i'll list em here:

WARNING: SOME SPOILERS PRESENT

1: General difficulty is a bit of a mess. It is nowhere near as difficult as the original, which was already a fairly easy game. I'll try not to get into details outside the spoiler blocks, but you wont have any trouble playing it, aside from the storage, which is worse. [spoiler] The perimeter defense instantly stops all creatures from attacking your vessel, it doesnt go nearly as deep at the first, there are very few leviathans present, theres more stuff around. [/spoiler] 

2: The fear factor from Subnautica is mostly gone aside from some specific areas. You won't get scared nearly as often, and the devs instead decided to focus on the story, which im about to get into. [spoiler] The only area with any real scares left in it is the crystal caves, which are not required for the entirety of the game and are purely story based. There's more light everywhere, your seatruck and prawn suit are both tankier, nothing is really as big a threat anymore. [/spoiler] 

3: The story is... well, you can tell it was rewritten halfway through development. There are all sorts of odd things, weird shoehorned story bits, things that just dont make sense. Again, all of that is spoilers though. [spoiler] Al-An, your alien friend who lives rent-free in your head, is your stereotypical "i dont understand humanity" alien, despite being a biologist. Instead of attempting to explain it like Robin should be able to as a Xenologist, she just ends up in banter with him that gets old fast. You never really resolve your sister's storyarch, and the ending is nonsensical. Its just not my cup of tea, and really doesnt make sense. [/spoiler] 

4: Land. Yeah, the big thing this game has for it? Its... not the greatest. The hoverbike is a slog to use, to the point you are better off walking, and there arent any real threats aside from the ENTIRELY avoidable cold with some quick crafting. [spoiler] There is no reason to be on land aside from story bits, the land has no resources, the cold suit instantly invalidates the cold, and in general the land feels like a slog. [/spoiler] 

Now, at this point it seems like this is a pretty negative review to be labeled as a thumbs up, right? Well, one thing IS still present, and thats that it's subnautica, a master class in survival games. Even if you arent surviving quite as much as before, its still fairly fun, although you are going to be MUCH better off playing the original.  So go play that one, and if you are willing to deal with the quirks of this game, id imagine you will still have a fun time.

It's a Subnautica DLC being sold as a standalone game. It also contains many features requested by players in early access Subnautica, that were added into this game but not Subnautica. It's obvious that there was some parallel development of both titles, and at some point they said "All this stuff we were going to add to Subnautica - let's use it as content for another full priced game instead".

All in all I like the changes that they made, and I feel like the devs have learnt a lot about game and map design that allow the game to run more smoothly. Unfortunately the game is not really big enough to fully utilise the tools. This applies particularly to the PRAWN suit, which I literally did not use the entire game, because the only thing I needed it for was extra lead, and it turns out they forgot to add mine-able lead deposits. 

If you don't own either game and are considering getting one, get Subnautica. It's far bigger and will keep you entertained a lot longer. If you own Subnautica already, it could be worth picking up this game if it is on offer to experience the pre-subnautica backstory, and the other things they could have put into Subnautica if they had been a bit less greedy.

If it weren't for my graphics drivers crashing after I place things, I would actually recommend it.

I simply couldn't stick with Below Zero. After about 12 hours of trying, I gave up and watched a story summary on YouTube to see if I was missing out on anything special (and apparently I wasn't).

The OG Subnautica has my wholehearted recommendation, but something about the map and "additions" of this game just didn't do it for me this time around. There's some interesting ideas here, and I would like to say I'd recommend this to anyone who hasn't played the first one... But sadly, some of the gameplay that was introduced (and is required to progress) isn't as solid. There's a lot of time spent out of the water in this one, and those sections are frustrating and tedious as opposed to the more invigorating ocean exploration. On top of this, the narrative (especially the characters) isn't as interesting as the first time around, and a large part of me wishes they had relied on the exquisite environmental storytelling and minimal dialogue of the first game. There's a lot of uninteresting people talking a lot, especially towards the end.

I'd love to see the devs try again with this series, but there needs to be some serious additions that focus on fun, a bigger and more interesting map, and a story that doesn't make me roll my eyes.

a disappointment compared to Subnautica.
Ultimately falls short of its illustrious predecessor, being not as well designed, but it remains a pleasant experience, even though I couldn't be bothered to get to the end.

It's not bad but feels almost more like an expansion pack rather than a full game. 
- The map's perhaps denser but a lot smaller and much shallower than the OG - there's not really any of the progressively "going deeper" to find more stuff of the first game. 
- The story's pretty weak - there's not much to it, it's kind of all over the place and at least one strand feels half finished. More generally, it lacks the sense of mystery of the first.
- There's less stuff to make, you need less resources to do it, and resources are much easier to come by so you never really needed to farm or even explore that much to find what you need. It's kind of handed to you.
To put that in context, my save was 28 hours to complete everything in SBZ, whereas it was 58 hours for the OG. Steam's numbers seem completely different but still about 1/2 - 44 hours compared to 88. 

If you get it on sale, you'll get your money's worth. It is after all - largely - more Subnautica. Some of the new biomes are pretty cool, there are some pretty impressive new beasties around and it's got at least one good wreck to trawl through. I say "largely" though because a big proportion of the game - far too much in my view - takes place on land. Slightly bizarrely, the devs played to their weakest suit, rather than their strongest. I mean, it's called Subnautica not Abovegroundia.

Overall, I enjoyed it and I'm glad I played it but, whereas at the end of the original, I wanted more and stuck around exploring, farming and building, when I finished the story in SBZ I was kind of done - ready to move on to something else. It made me want to play the original again but not really spend more time on 4546B. I missed the vibrant colours of the first game, its sense of scale, all the wrecks to explore, the lost river... And I really didn't want to spend more time trogging around on land that's basically, white, pretty barren and not that interesting.

I left a review on this back in 2019 a bit after the game first came out, but back then the game was nowhere near done. I just revisited the game and finished it after playing many new and different games, and even going back to the original Subnautica to do another run through once or twice, and let me say, out of all of the games I've played from then to now, the only game that comes close is No Mans Sky, but this game is absolutely incredible.

The best part is it doesn't feel like a completely different game from Subnautica, but it feels like an extension, which is exactly what it is and should be. Many elements from Subnautica were brought into Below Zero, but they were all improved upon. Mechanics, base building is a drastic improvement, creatures, glitches, graphics, physics, all were made so much better but so subtly.

The story and side stories are also amazing, running two main story lines next to each other, making them cross often while remaining their own, so many more story elements too, and honestly a better story and ending from Subnautica.

I can only say two bad things about Below Zero. The SnowFox is really annoying to use, and honestly useless since a prawn suit is just better, and it's what I used instead of the SnowFox, and I miss the Cyclops. The Seatruck though is an amazing combination of the Seamoth and Cyclops, but I miss having a large vehicle to build inside and completely customize.

Also just glancing at the price again, for $30 this game is amazing.

Although, I will mention some of the bad too.

As good as the story is, some sections of it do lack, and feel anticlimactic, and the land sections are just mostly annoying, a bunch of twisty turns and messy tunnels and caves. However, they do have some interesting parts too.
It's not as good as the first game, but it's still Subnautica. Still miles ahead of most other survival/crafting games.

I played it to the end and mostly enjoyed it. But the things I enjoy about Below Zero are exactly the same things I loved about the original Subnautica. The stuff that's new in Below Zero is pretty lacklustre in comparison to the incredibly well crafted under water sea exploration that Subnautica already did years before. There's just not enough of the "below zero" part. The little there is is hindered by the most clunky land traversal mechanics you can imagine. You cannot jump over the smallest ledge. A pebble will make you come to a complete halt. The storytelling that was previously one of my favourite parts in the first game has now been reduced stale, uninspiring dialogue. Where's the mystery? Where's the tension? As I said, I mostly enjoyed this game and if you enjoyed the first game you'll enjoy this too. But if you had the choice between the original Subnautica and Below Zero, stick to the original.

I really wanted to like this game and do enjoy parts of it but find I'm forcing myself to play through it. 
On it's own it would be an above average survival game but due to it being tied to the first game it really needed some more time in the oven & a different story. 

Pros

- Items & base building have been updated with alot of nice touches 
- Interesting location to set the game
- Visuals are often brilliant 
- audio is mostly excellent 

Cons

- story, characters & environment often made very little sense  
- Game location is never used to it's full advantage. You're always too safe  
- Transports are weirdly implemented (can't explain in short review)
- Once you get over the 1st time fear it never comes back, you will just drive past monsters knowing it's safe and saves time. 
- voiced protagonist, some will be ok with this some won't   
- Feels like someone else's story and your thoughts \ actions mean very little 

As I said some may like this and I did enjoy the base building & exploring but I can't see past the flaws and miss the 1st games atmosphere too much .

I have only played these games in VR mode, currently using a Valve index and 4080 - this is just as good a VR experience as the first Subnautica!  

VR is using a controller, not built in support for motion controls (although it is planned, but I prefer control pad for this one anyway).


To enable VR:

Install QMod manager
https://www.nexusmods.com/subnauticabelowzero/mods/1?tab=files 

then : Native VR Support for Subnautica Below Zero
https://www.nexusmods.com/subnauticabelowzero/mods/118?tab=files - Native VR Support for Subnautica Below Zero

And, not strictly VR but EasyCraft , just for the quality of life update: 
https://www.nexusmods.com/subnauticabelowzero/mods/10?tab=files

Various comfort options are built in , like snap turning etc and disabled Y axis on controller, put I prefer to turn them off .

Runs well on my rig with the following settings:

VR render rate (in game, not Steam VR options) 100%
SteamVR video options supersampling at 120%
Refresh rate in Index set to 90.

The above is my sweet spot and I've not had any feelings of nausea or reprojection.

Getting lost on glaciers is not so great. About a third of the game doesn't worry about air or depth, so to keep it from being too easy we have to worry about going blind and freezing. It's weird to be able to name something that I dislike more than drowning, but here we are. Maybe even though a storm is inevitable, the randomness and loss of visibility makes it seem unfair, something to spoil my plans rather than part of the puzzle. If the storm above water was constant, and I could build something to cut through it and see further, that could solve it. Otherwise I guess I'd recommend other players be ready to build lots of beacons and multipurpose rooms with a bed and a window.

I bought this game a while after finishing the first one - purely because I was interested in how the story line would be continued. Now, lets get to the good and the bad.

Pros:

- Same, but different. This game doesn't completely overhaul the original subnautica, keeping many mechanics the same meaning that after playing the first, transitioning over to the second will be smooth. But they did make changes that keep the game interesting - like the new temperature gauge and new suit types - alongside the Seatruck. There is enough to keep the game fresh whilst keeping it feeling like Subnautica.
- Fauna and Flora are overhauled. Some are the same, like the good old reliable Bladderfish - but there are new plants and animals such as the Stalker. It means that you arent just filling out the same PDA from the last game.
- New storyline. The storyline is different from the original game whilst referancing the events from the first - making for a nice throwback. The events of this game also explain why the first game happened in the first place. If you feel the first games story was left on a loose end then this game will tie up some of them - whilst providing more questions that you will want answered.

Cons:

- This game is more vague than the original. There is a lot of places to go that are essential to the story that you are never told about. Most of my time here was spent on the wiki trying to figure out where to go. F1 really helps with this.
- A personal issue with this game. Your character is no longer a blank slate to insert yourself over. They have a name, a backstory and objectives that you don't really understand or want to peruse. This game is definitely more story based than the original was instead of being surivival based.
- It is a bit shorter than the original. The original took 24hrs for me to complete whilst this one took 12hrs, over half the time. 
- I want the time capsule ability back.

Conclusion:

This game is good. Its a fun experience that faithfully continues the experience of the original Subnautica. However, it does not surpass the original. Only buy this game if you have played/like the original game. Otherwise - as a first introduction to the series it would be better to just play the original instead.

Sadly, this game feels less like a worthy successor and more like a cheap DLC to the original. Instead of expanding on the concepts of the original game, they cut away what made it great: A vast, dangerous sea to explore, wrecks and secrets to uncover and meaningful lore to find. Diving Deeper into the Frozen Abyss: Exploring the Frozen Wonders of Subnautica: Below Zero

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Subnautica: Below Zero takes players on a chilling and exhilarating sequel to the beloved original, inviting them to navigate an icy underwater world filled with beauty, danger, and the thrill of uncovering new mysteries. With its stunning Arctic visuals, immersive survival mechanics, and the allure of exploring uncharted depths, the game offers a captivating continuation of the Subnautica saga.

The visual design of Subnautica: Below Zero is a triumph, plunging players into the frigid beauty of a polar environment where ice and water merge seamlessly. The attention to detail in the Arctic marine life and the frozen landscapes creates an atmosphere that's both breathtaking and immersive.

At its core, Subnautica: Below Zero maintains the engaging blend of exploration, survival, and crafting mechanics that made its predecessor a hit. Players once again find themselves in the role of a survivor, navigating a new world teeming with unique challenges and mysteries to unravel.

The sense of discovery remains a standout feature, as players dive into the uncharted waters of the Arctic biome, encountering unfamiliar creatures, biomes, and secrets that beckon them to explore further.

The narrative of the game unfolds through the player's interactions, environmental cues, and audio logs, providing a more personal and intimate storytelling experience. The journey into the icy unknown reveals a compelling story that weaves the protagonist's fate with the enigmas of the frozen planet.

The game's survival and crafting mechanics continue to add depth to the gameplay, as players must gather resources, manage their hunger and oxygen, and construct equipment to brave the harsh environment.

However, the game's emphasis on exploration and survival might not resonate with players seeking a more action-focused experience. Subnautica: Below Zero prioritizes storytelling, immersion, and the thrill of discovery.

Some players might find moments of tension and danger to be intense, particularly when encountering the Arctic's unique and potentially hazardous creatures.

In conclusion, Subnautica: Below Zero delivers an exhilarating and chilling sequel that builds upon the foundation of its predecessor. Its stunning Arctic visuals, immersive mechanics, and the allure of exploring the frozen depths create an experience that is both captivating and emotionally engaging. While its focus on survival and exploration might not appeal to everyone, those who appreciate the beauty of the frozen frontier and the thrill of uncovering new enigmas will find themselves immersed in the icy world of Subnautica: Below Zero, where every dive is a plunge into the heart of a frozen mystery waiting to be unveiled.

[h2]At best, somewhat above average; at worst, obnoxiously boring. Subnautica Below Zero suffers from an intense disconnect from what constituted the appeal of the first game, and coupled with its overall awful design choices, it makes not just a worse experience than the original Subnautica but an overall simply bad game.[/h2]

[table]
[tr]
	[th]🟩 Pros[/th]
	[th]🟥 Cons[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td] ✔️ Vastly improved base building; plenty of new rooms that work well within the much more densely designed biomes and offer decent support for above-water buildings as well.[/td]
	[td] ❌Despite each biome feeling more tightly designed, that design extends mostly into caves, which are an absolute pain to navigate. Both in a sense of trying to keep your direction as well as the feeling of being simply too tight to be comfortable for the games’ vehicles.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td] ✔️ Arguably, the biggest issues from the previous games have been fixed. Leviathans ignoring map architecture as well as the horrendous pop-in. Leading to Below Zero being a much more immersive experience.[/td]
	[td] ❌ The game is shallow. Literally. Within the first few hours of starting the game, and even before the first major story events, I managed to finish the last depth modules for my Seatruck and explore the final areas of the game. Not because I was looking for them, but because my exploration just naturally went there.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td] ✔️ The game can look absolutely gorgeous; especially during the night, BZ literally shines through its fantastic use of bioluminescence to create incredibly memorable environments.[/td]
	[td] ❌ BZ’s story is notoriously bad. Its issues range from an overly chatty protagonist to vast inconsistencies between dialogues, an overall feeling of an unfinished story, and more.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
[tr]
	[th]🟨 Miscellaneous Thoughts[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]I do think there is a place for land exploration in Subnautica. However, it seems dreadfully undercooked in Below Zero. Managing your temperature is extremely unengaging as a mechanic, and the game is still clearly not designed for movement outside of water, with the Snowfox being broadly considered by far the worst vehicle in the game.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]



[h3]Technical Issues and Performance[/h3]
Subnautica Below Zero ran perfectly fine during my twenty-hour playthrough. I experienced no stutters, glitches, or other performance problems. The biggest issue was the very occasional pop-in of some aspects of the environment, such as the "legs" of your base. Enemy A.I., while better than Subnautica, can still be a bit janky as well.

[h3]Graphics and Sound[/h3]
Graphically, Below Zero is fantastic. I mentioned the focus on bioluminescence already, which makes either the deeper parts of the ocean or the nighttime look absolutely stunning. Biomes in general are much more alien and distinct than in the previous game, even though the entire map shrank by quite a large margin. Sadly, often the game does not get to use this improvement in its visuals as BZ has a noticeable focus on tighter cave exploration, and the Glacier/Land parts are not comparable in quality either.

The sound design is decent but does not seem as impactful as Subnautica. There is something primal in the Reaper Leviathan screech that Below Zero just does not seem to be able to capture, be that through being used to the game or otherwise. Voice acting is rather bad, both through a mixture of a genuinely bad script and also through Robin, the main character, flip-flopping constantly in her delivery. In one instance, Robin repeated the same concern twice due to me hitting similar dialogue triggers back-to-back, but each time changing her intonation as if the context changed. It’s quite jarring and a constant issue throughout the story.

[h3]Story and Setting[/h3]
BZ’s story can largely be split into two arcs. You play Robin, a Xenologist who embarks on 4546B to find out the fate of her sister, who has been reported dead by the Literally-Satan company Alterra. This is the worse one. Largely because there is barely any active interaction between Robin and this story, as the only quest focused on it resolves by meeting Marguerit, another Survivor on the planet, and being broadly pointed to a research facility. From then on, the rest of this story plays out through a collection of absolutely atrocious data pads you may collect and an optional achievement, without reward, to finish her sisters’ work.

The second story and the actual story that needs to be completed to finish the game tie back into the Alien Precursor race from the first game and their involvement with local bacteria. Robin encounters one such Precursor alien and has to build him a new body to inhabit. You do exactly this. And then you leave. The rest of the story hinges on the badly written dialogue between Robin and Al-An.

It’s not the worst. And despite all the criticism of the genuinely bad writing and uninteresting setting, the player is still spared lengthy cutscenes and the like. It is bad, but it’s sparse enough to be bearable, and more so a symptom of the developers taking themselves a lot more seriously after their initial success on Subnautica. I can appreciate it for trying to be a little more ambitious, even though it made Below Zero worse in the end.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
Below Zero’s gameplay is largely identical to Subnautica, meaning a lot of your experience will carry over if you have played it. Otherwise, it is very typical survival gameplay; you’re stranded in an icy ocean, you have different crafting stations, and you need to progress through those crafting recipes, build a base, build vehicles, and dive ever deeper to try and achieve your objectives. Despite that, Below Zero feels a lot more linear precisely because the map has shrunk a lot; to put a number on that statement, while the original Subnautica bottomed out at ~1500m deep, Below Zero barely breaches 1000. The same is true horizontally, with large parts of the map being covered in actual land that will need to be traversed on foot. Sadly, there are no gameplay elements past a bike to aid in that part of exploration, leaving it woefully clunky. This has some side effects, such as Leviathans being even less threatening than in the original Subnautica, as there are only a handful of spots they even patrol and that are quite easy to memorize within hours of starting the game.

Predators are overall still not a threat, robbing Below Zero of much-needed tension. Regular enemies simply do not hit hard enough to kill you. Leviathans are still scripted to take a bite and then retreat long enough to repair any damage you may have sustained outside of one-shots when caught in the open. Vehicles are still as broken as before, even though piloting them got a lot more annoying through the sheer abundance of tight caves.

Basebuilding is vapid. More so than before, even though the interface and options have vastly expanded. While I did care to build a proper base in the original game, I got by perfectly fine with a single multipurpose room for storage, crafting, and battery recharge. If creative gamemodes are fun, there is some value here, but I don’t think that it is enough to save Below Zero.

[h3]Final Thoughts[/h3]
Originally, I called Subnautica fun through roleplaying. And the same holds true in Below Zero. It’s all a big game of pretending. If you can convince yourself that base building is fun and immersive and that it progresses your game, if you pretend that Leviathans are a threat and scary, if you pretend that anything you do actually matters, then Below Zero shines even more so through a lot of added detail. But it’s shallow. Figuratively and literally. Below Zero improved the looks. The stability. And the immersion but paid for it through an obnoxious story and a distinct misunderstanding of why the first Subnautica worked so well.

Honestly it's just missing the charm of the original Subnautica. I spent a few days playing through the original game and had a blast, but then I start this one and it's just some lightly disguised fetch quests, sub-par vehicles, and a flat story/characters. 

OG Subnautica had the Seamoth, which was fast and made me feel like an explorer in vast waters, and the Cyclops made me feel like a real futuristic submarine captain with all it's unique features. It had a story that kept throwing new things at you, and put the whole "figuring this out" thing in your hands and sent you on your way. It had characters that felt real, had real interactions with each other, and believable arcs. The lore of the game felt like it was necessary, and unavoidable since it was so intertwined with the sandbox aspect.

Subnautica Below-Zero has a glorified truck, with hugely inefficient modules and no real incentive to use any of the vehicles more than once except for the PRAWN, which is in the first game anyway. You get basically every tool within the first half hour, something that the original made you actually work up to over time. The game holds your hand from the start, sneaking inner monologue in everywhere, like "hmm, I should make this tool to go do this thing." All the characters are like that to some degree; only there to advance the progression and send you on that next mission. 
The lore, save a few parts, is almost entirely filler, designed to be plopped on some random platform with some boxes and forgotten. Where the first game had real drama and struggles in the characters, this feels more like the story was written solo, then the cast were added on top so there were actual people involved and not just ruins and random truck stops. Even the main objective of finding what happened to your sister is immediately forgotten, and replaced by a precursor AI that wants a body, so he sends you on some fetch quests with no exploration involved since you're just following a beacon. (No spoilers, this happens quite literally 10 minutes in.) All the objectives you're given either have what you need there near the finish line, or it tells you to go grab this thing and come back.

If I go on any longer I'll just end up repeating myself, so I'll end it with some notes.
This game isn't the worst I've played, and I'm certain I could get some enjoyment if I wasn't so hurt about it falling short of the original. If you have the money and you're debating between the two, the original Subnautica is the obvious choice. If you've already played the first and you're just itching for more, I advise waiting some time before jumping to this one. If you go straight from one to the next, you'll both burn yourself out and you won't be able to see past the differences, but given some rest time in between and this game has [i]potential[/i] to drag you in just like the first.

I just tried this game again (Aug 2023) and there have been some MAJOR improvements across the board from what I can tell so far. 

I played a fair bit of BZ during early access and I honestly wasn't impressed. I loved Subnautica 1, but this one felt sorta flat. HOWEVER, during this recent play it seems like the devs listened to common complaints. The music for one is vastly better, which like the first one, adds a lot of environment while playing. The start has been changed many times but I really like this new intro and the voice acting is pretty good.

I'll update this again once I've played through but from what I've seen, the changes they made turned this into a real proper Subnautica sequel.

I love the underwater exploration and the all of the cool areas. But I feel that the leviathans are a bit lack luster compared to the first game they are not as scary and you are not worried about going into their territory unlike the first game where you would straight up avoid the reaper leviathans areas.

After trying this on in Early Access I decided to wait for the release to enjoy it fully without spoilers.

I really enjoyed playing Subnautica again.

My favorite part in this was learning the story of one character ([spoiler]Marguerit Maida [/spoiler]) that appears in both games. 

The seatruck is a nice vehicle and the sea truck dock is such a great addition ! (but I missed my speedy seamoth)

I liked the new fauna and flora particularly the interactions with the sea monkeys even if it became a bit annoying when base building close to many of them but they can be useful. [spoiler]Try pinning a recipe, they might bring you exactly what you need[/spoiler]

It seems like the weather turns into a snow storm as soon as you spend more than a minute on the surface.

For some reason I didn't feel like building as much as I did in the main title game but I also didn't feel as compelled to progress the story in the first game. 

I think the story felt more organic in the first one, like you stumbled upon it while exploring aimlessly or resource gathering. In Below Zero there is more hand holding with the game guiding you to places of importance frequently.

Sadly I did not enjoy the ending that much. [spoiler]It is weird that you can finish the game without curing the disease[/spoiler]

It isn't perfect but I enjoyed the game and would still recommend it if you enjoyed the first one !

It honestly felt a bit underwhelming compared to the first game. The biomes were much less diverse, and I struggled to learn and navigate the map because everything looked the same. Mechanics like the temperature meter or whatever became real annoying real fast and not engaging at all. The story was mid and slow paced, unlike the first game. The creatures in the game were a bit disappionting as well, especially leviathons, not as many and not as interesting as in the first game. And I haven't even mentioned the countless and pointless minor changes which just made the game worse. Don't get me wrong, there are some great things that I enjoyed when playing the game, but there are just so much more negative things that just makes the good things not matter. It should've just been a DLC or something, not a stand-alone game. It feels like one as well, not as much content and playtime. If you really liked the first one and want to play this one, I would recommend buying it when it's on sale, otherwise it's not worth it in my opinion. And if you haven't played the first one yet, please play it before buying this.

Definitely a downgrade to the original both in story and map. The grind was reduced which is a welcoming change, however certain fragments are now specific to one or two spots, which makes them easier to miss compared to the original.

Summarizing: If you loved the first game, then play this one as well - even tho it's not as good it's still very much enjoyable. If you haven't played subnautica yet, then start with the original instead.

First the bad. The game is greatly unbalanced in a lot of areas. Progression is too quick which loses that feeling of stacking accomplishments from the first game. Resources are too plentiful and energy management is too simple that many base elements like nuclear energy are just unnecessary. My other complaint is a severe issue with lighting transitions that don't make sense. You look down at a scary abyss only to drop 10m and find a cave awash with golden light. I mean, I'll take an eerily beautiful cave over a black abyss any day I'm just saying. Finally, the world is too small and too shallow that the new vehicle while cool is less practical compared to the prawn suit. It's overkill to drag a slow base of sorts around with you when it literally takes no more than a few minutes to travel home from anywhere. There is more than one way to use the new vehicle though so I did take advantage of it when it was useful.

But the game gets a lot right. It's stunningly beautiful. Hard to tell if it's more or less scary because I'm so hardened by the first game that I was systematically exterminating leviathans, but I was certainly creeped out an awful lot. I'm still so terrified by the ecological dead zone that I had to quit the game when a leviathan dragged me out there. The bottom line is this game does recapture a lot of the magic of the first game, and I would recommend it for all fans.

Subnautica Below Zero is a great game. The only downside of this game is that its big brother is better. 
It's a great game, but some features feel missing after the first one and some new one are nice.

+ :
The story is great and the ending surprising.
The technology is the same and different. If you have played the first game, you will still discovered some new technologies.
The overall environment/scenery is visually great, colourful and well made.
The character's story and interaction with its environment is nice.
The new fauna/flora.
The 'above water' section.

- :
These negatives points are here because the first game exists BUT they don't make the game bad at all.

The main one that often come back is the size of everything. The map, the depth, the vehicles, the story. And it's true. 
The map is not so huge and not as deep as the first one but the depth is compensated with a new gameplay mechanic : land exploration which is "strange/ironic" for a "SUBnautica" but this part isn't a bad point for me.
Land movement feels slow and janky.
The vehicles size are made for the map and they are, in consequences, smaller, slower and a bit strange by their behaviour. The mech isn't useful because of such terrain configuration.
Some technologies are missing.
Not as terrifying. The bad fish aren't that big and scary.

It's a great game.
Play it for what it is, not for it being the little brother of the great Subnautica.

The game is good but not as good as the installation before, for me it is missing the element of fear the other game had, subnautica you don't have to interact with leviathans but you don't really grow used to them, here i grew used to them and was bassicly allready scanning one leaviathan to the next, maybe the biomes require more of a "bang" like the lillypad zone is good but i don't feel like all of them are that great, and i feel like the above part of the map, the ice pillars require more guidance or a rework or something as its just a huge anoying mess having to navigate them. Its also more story based but i care more for the previous game's sense of dread and fear, but this is also great, if the first one was a perfect this is an okay one.

I love it just as much as the first game, perhaps even more. I love the way the story unfolds through PDAs and objects you find. I love that the protagonist is a person with an emotional connection to the story (trying to solve her sister's murder) because I don't think "just try and survive" will work for a second game's story. I love finding out even more about the lore. I miss the cuddlefish, but I love the trivalve. But most of all, I LOVE THE JUKEBOX!
Great game with lots of bugs.

First I did complete the game...It felt more of chore than not by the end of it and I just wanted to rush to finish it just to complete it...The game has sooooo many bugs it's not even funny....sure they fixed some of the issues from the first game like fish swimming through my base... in the air.... but they sure as hell didn't fix others like example when i go up stairs and i have an alien containment in the above room i somehow end up inside of it when i get off the stairs...when i click the hatch to get out...it animates as me getting in....Things falling through the ground....2 snowfoxes and myself...so far.

The game itself wasn't that bad, they just couldn't capture why people loved the first one. The game lacked the size of the original. The original felt immense when you first land and jump into the water and just keeps getting bigger as you travel deeper and deeper, this one felt....small....The map is about half the size and half as deep. Sure its very "condensed" but that's not exactly a good thing, as it just feels cluttered.

The seatruck is the stupidest vehicle, I understand why they wanted something like that, due to the map being smaller and there being mazes everywhere and small holes you want a smaller vehicle that's able to get into those areas....but they could have kept the seatruck and just provided empty modules of different lengths that let people customise what they wanted. Instead they had pre-defined modules and you can only determine order and they all kinda sucked and if you didn't want to play that way well...sucks to be you....Also the storage module, why are there about half the slots in something that's larger compared to the wall storage in my base.

The snowfox....ok I stand corrected on my comment above...this is the stupidest vehicle...Drives like crap...runs into a mine-able rock on the ground (how is that even possible its a hover vehicle) ok whatever, why does the rock do about 30% damage!? and doesn't even break open! Anyways had to build 3 of those just to finish the above ground area cuz every time I put it away and took it out again it fell through the world....

Also speaking of the above ground area....wow that place is annoying...90% of the time u get the severe storm warning. Always having to deal with the cold till u get cold suit which u'll use for about an hr and never touch again as any above surface area u'll never revisit. The spy pengling drives like crap, slow as hell and can't turn....its got tank treads and drive pretty quickly forward....why can't it turn on a dime faster than my 90 year old grandma trying to do the same turn on her cane.... Also WTF is with the camera feed....I get a clearer picture from a doorbell camera on my phone and the spy pengling uses a camera how many years in the future... Also only really need to use it for literally 30 secs to get 1 item in the whole game...useless....

Conclusion...would I recommend it...sure if you've played the first one and really like it and wanted a little more, but be prepared to be disappointed. If not then go play the first one, even with it's bugs I found it to be way more enjoyable.

Seatruck's Search for Magnetite.

Okay, that's not what the game is called.  And okay, I started a sentence with okay, because all the dialog in this game has that sort of mediocre middle-Q English.  Sensa Wunda?  Sure, another exploration of biomes, a la the original Subnautica - and will there be anyone who plays Below Zero who didn't play the original?  I doubt it, and that's too bad, because they'll be disappointed.  The main character, a lady so dull I've forgotten her name, travels a long way to find her sister, and one of the first things that happens to her is a superior alien intelligence injects itself into her brain as a passenger.  The game's subdued sense of marvel at the wonders of an alien biome are drowned by this chick's - Robin, Google says her name is - Robin's tasteless insistence on proving her, and humanity's superiority to this dignified alien mind.  And when she finds out her sister has died, and the alien gently probes her grief, she starts talking about gooey caramel clusters.  She is, not to put too fine a point on it, an idiot; I've rarely hated the protagonist of a game so much.  And I've not even started on the asthmatic wheeze she makes when she runs, or the ridiculousness of half a game called "Subnautica" being set on land.  Perhaps "Nautica:  Running in Swimfins" would have been a better title.

The original game was good, verging on great in some places.  This sequel is what happens when you hand over a more-or-less finished game engine to a bunch of r/im14andthisisdeep modders.  If you really couldn't get enough OG Subnautica, you might find a few things here to interest you, but if you're on the fence: hard pass.

I think this one is a bit weaker than the original (which I absolutely LOVED)... I think the story was better told and was more interesting/mysterious than this time around, the the guidance was clearer, without being obvious... So while this is a great game overall, I prefered the last entry...

Many unfunny jokes including but not limited to an indian PDA. Kinda makes me think they combined Subnautica with Soma the way they set up the map and logs. 3 different stories that all are less interesting than the first game's. Though, speaking of the first game, (Spoilers: a survivor from the first game made it to the map of the second, and their story is honestly the most interesting.) Best thing about this game is the base improvements but some dumbie decided not to give the seatruck dock any support so it looks super silly. This can be fixed by putting multi-purpose rooms under the dock. The map and game feel very short or fast to get through, and I don't know why. I made a base larger than I needed in the first game, but I didn't even need to use 4 lockers. In the first installment I used probably 20. To compensate, they made the seatruck so slow, and the prawn doesn't work well with the terrain imo. This makes the game painful when travelling. I don't even think it's the issue that I'm skilled or anything, because they switched up resources and I took more time to finish Subnautica 1 even on my 4th play. If they added some fun things that were mods in Subnautica like a resource changer for crafting or idk, maybe they could have gave this game some replayability. Not really disappointed, but wouldn't recommend to a friend. Despite my comment about the prawn earlier, it was indeed vastly improved - especially on land. Though the land at times was just pathetic, with invisible walls and whatnot. They don't want you to leave the map, I get it, but why surround some of the bases with invisible wall? If I get a prawn and climb up the wall of one of these areas and when I try to jump down I can't because dev doesn't want me to, the game loses alot of luster. If this happens to you, don't give up though, there are little holes in these invisible walls.

Just so many strange changes that are just obviously a bad move it just frustrates me.

After I played Subnautica: Below Zero for the first time, I gave it a negative review, and it was kind of nasty.  After a couple of weeks, I realized my neg review was over the top and I deleted it.  I sat on it for a while and came back to the game and I have much more positive things to say about it.  Yes, It's a step down from the original Subnautica, but it's not in the visuals or game play.  Rather, they added too much in world-building and back story, and I say this as a writer.  Too much writing!  Some of the new biomes are amazing.  The twisty bridges, although a pain sometimes to navigate in the seatruck, are visually amazing.  I would rather an open-ended game instead of the storyline that you must follow in S:BZ (you'll see).  I hope with Subnautica 3 they find their holy grail, an open-ended game that can be played over and over, with room for much DLC.  A lot of people want to sink into what you're offering, but you've got to give them a place to stay!

The seatruck seems to be a strange attempt to combine to the seamoth and cyclops from the first game but just feels very clunky in practice, which is pretty annoying when it's your only real sea vehicle. Blueprints for critical items for it (i.e. power cell charger and moon pool) are fairly late game which is kind of annoying in terms of having to make a ton of power cells just to keep your vehicles running. I ended up with a locker full of dead power cells before having the chance to charge them, which is not really an issue I ran into in the first game.

The land portions feel very sloppy. The game was built to be underwater, and you can feel it every time you step onto land. I don't have a problem with the cold mechanic to prevent you from just camping on land all day, but movement feels just as clunky as the sparse land sections from the first game.

The story is... bad. The inclusion of AL-AN and the mech lady creates a serious atmospheric downgrade from the first game. Whereas in the first game the lack of information made sense because you were well and truly alone, in Below Zero it just feels like characters are intentionally ignoring you or withholding information. The dialogue is also grating, though it is relatively rare.

Overall not the worst game out there, but another sad case of failing to understand what made the first game so good. I worry that a third game would fall into many of the same issues this one did.

This game is a pale shadow of the original Subnautica.  It falls far short in multiple areas:

The World:
The world of the original Subnautica was vast, with a large number of unique biomes.  Below Zero’s world is smaller and feels less diverse.  I found the above-ground portions to be more annoying than fun.  I didn’t boot up Subnautica to run around in a frozen wasteland while freezing my ass off.  It’s a sea-based game where the land portions are best left as a fun change of pace, as in the original game.  The constant fear of exploring deeper is also not present.  The player of Below Zero quickly realizes that much of the world is simply not that dangerous, and most of the creatures present are not that much of a threat.  

The Vehicles:
The Prawn Suit is still here and still awesome.  The other vehicles from the original not so much.  The Cyclops and Seamoth have been replaced by the SeaTruck, which is kind of a combination of both depending on how you outfit it.  The problem is, it doesn’t perform the function of either the Cyclops or the Seamoth as well as the original did.  The SeaTruck is more prone to getting stuck on things exploring caves than the Seamoth, for example.  The way the SeaTruck interacts with the world, especially certain plants it can’t get around, was a recurring source of frustration.  It’s also too tanky.  I recall the first time it was grabbed by a leviathan, shaken around and released.  I looked at the damage it had taken afterwards.  ‘That’s it?’  Everyone remembers what it was like to be grabbed in the Seamoth by a Reaper Leviathan.  Exactly no one ever thought ‘that’s it?’ after that experience.  Which is how it should be when your little personal submarine gets grabbed by a massive predator.  Huge letdown.  

The new vehicle Below Zero introduces, the SnowFox, is a major disappointment.  It is a bit wonky to steer, but the real issue is that it is not the best option for traversing the arctic biome.  Those four-legged creatures from the trailer will chase you and cause you problems on the SnowFox, but if you just take the Prawn Suit on land, you can walk right up to them and murder them with impunity (which is quite satisfying).  The Snowfox isn't even worth the resources it takes to construct it.  

The Dialogue:
This is my biggest gripe with Below Zero.  Frankly, there is far too much talking.  In the original, the main character doesn’t say a single word.  I often wished the main character of Below Zero would take a page out of that book and shut the hell up.  Some of her conversations with the game's other main protagonist were okay, but that’s about it.  The various PDA logs are also a huge disappointment.  Most of the PDAs from the original game were relevant to the story and/or interesting to listen to.  The DeGassi logs in particular were a joy to discover, telling a tragic and fascinating story of a mismatched group of survivors trying to survive and learn the secrets of the world.  There is nothing comparable in Below Zero.  Most of the PDA logs concern inane topics such as the personal relationships of characters we’ll never meet, ‘strong female leaders’ whining about their employers and/or subordinates, or silly games the Alterra employees played with each other.  Worse still, they tend to ramble on, whereas the PDAs from the original game tended to be short and to the point.  Ultimately, I can’t help but feel that Below Zero’s PDAs are the way they are because the developers wanted to be able to say, ‘look, we have women in STEM and LGBTQ representation.  Aren’t we progressive?’  Yes, you are.  Unfortunately, you prioritized 'representation' over quality (which seems to be a recurring trend in media these days).  It is possible to do both, but if you can only do one, make sure it's quality!!!

The Ending:
The ending of the original Subnautica left you feeling immensely satisfied, like you accomplished something amazing.  The ending of Below Zero feels cheap and hollow by comparison.  Part of the problem is the ending sequence is filled with so much dialogue, which I found annoying.  Robin takes this snippy, entitled attitude with the other main character that rubs me the wrong way.  It’s awful.  

Overall, I was prepared to say that Below Zero wasn’t a bad game until the ending.  Now?  Screw it.  It is a bad game.  I’ll probably play again, but only because I’m a completionist (I played the first time on Freedom mode and feel compelled to play on Survival).  But after that I’ll never touch it again, and I will also be skipping significant portions of the game the second time.  I didn’t skip hardly anything during my second playthrough of the original game because I didn’t want to, and I fully expect to return for a third playthrough someday.  And that is perhaps the biggest difference between the two games for me.

I enjoyed playing this. It trades some of the original game's feeling of being completely lost on an alien planet and trying to survive, with a simple but well written mystery. A lot of love has definitely gone into this game, but I agree with what other reviews say about it feeling like a DLC. 

Pros: 
-I think the biomes are a lot more well thought out, and feel more "full" compared to the original. However some people may see this as a negative, as the emptiness in the original adds to the feeling of being lost.
-Cool new tools and habitat pieces.
-Cool and beautiful new creatures and biomes.
-Land biomes and a new survival mechanic adds variety
-Story is good, but cliche.

Cons: 
-Instead of figuring things out organically like in the original, this one does give you a lot more hints and markers to guide your exploration. So instead of searching out of curiosity you find yourself just going to a certain biome only because a marker has popped up in/near it.
-The seatruck is both shit and interesting. Overall it feels like a seamoth that drags a small habitat around. Cool in concept but compared to the awesome Cyclops it just kinda sucks. However I understand why it replaces the cyclops in this (see below).
-Smaller map. This is the main reason the Cyclops is replaced. The biomes are more cramped and so trying to navigate with a big sub would be impractical.
-Similar annoying glitches to the original. One all too familiar glitch for those that have played the first, was that on the rare occasion items/vehicles just phase out of the playable map and you couldn't get them back. This can also happen to creatures, leading to them either being launched out of the map, or ending up in places they arent supposed to be e.g. inside a habitat.

I would give this a solid 7/10. Buy this when on sale. If you enjoyed the first you'll have a good time playing this as well,

Good game. More story driven than the original. After a point it stops giving hints on what to do and where to go. Can get frustrating and ended up having to check some walkthroughs. The whole game can be played with a sea truck and some depth modules.

Worse than the original in virtually every way.  Would have been great as a much lower priced DLC.  As a full-price standalone Subnautica title it was hugely disappointing.

-Story is nonsensical and reads like a bad fan-fiction short story, particularly the ending.
-New/Updated vehicles feel like downgrades in every way compared to the original.  Snowfox is pointless.
-Progression feels like it just doesn't exist but at least the game world feels so small that it doesn't really matter.
-Ocean area feels way smaller and far less ominous and land segments all feel and look the same, boring.
-Difficulty is significantly reduced and the experience feels far more game-y with the addition of conveniently placed oxygen/thermal plants virtually everywhere the player is expected to explore.
-Feeling of isolation, which I would consider to be a core pillar of the original, is completely gone from the experience.
-"The base building is better in Below Zero" they say ... Um no, it's not.  The only noteworthy addition to building in Below Zero is a bunch of posters, some beds with different blankets and the control room.  Also noteworthy is that the developers decided to remove a bunch of cosmetic items available in the original such as the lab equipment like microscopes and vials.  These cosmetic items are still used as assets all over the game world of Below Zero.  You just can't scan or pickup or use them.

It wasn't an awful game.  It was kinda cool to explore even though it became clear pretty quickly that there weren't all that many places to go.  Unfortunately, as a player who just recently played Subnautica for the first time and loved it, Below Zero was an experience plagued by disappointment from beginning to absurdly bad end.

The game is very interesting, and I can't wait for it to be available in the full version. This beta test labeled 1.0 got me very excited until the game crashed, similar to Anthem. Replayed this game, first front to back playthrough - can't shake the feeling that this should've been a 2 Year anniversary dlc for lovers of the original game like myself. If you just finished the first game and just NEED MORE SUBNAUTICA this is not it, just replay the first or figure out how to roll it back so you can play it again with mods (mods killed by 2.0, rip to the true GOATs).

It's a significant downgrade, the story is only fair (6/10 in comparison to first game's 10/10) in spite of the fact that this time they actually have actors. Way buggier than the original, in this playthrough I had two game-breaking can't-escape must-reload-and-lose-two-hour moments, in addition to the expected regular "unstuck" usage. The map sucks, overland segments are too big, underwater biomes are no diversified, and you know how you hated having to spelunk through the kelp forest caves in the first game, and was so happy when that hour was over and you had all those bps and materials? Get ready for tight, lost spelunking in hazy green environments through tiny, cramped honeycomb. The biomes and map in the original game gradually become one another in understandable ways tied to the "ecology" of 4546b in the first game. In the second you will simply feel lost for hours, you'll fall through a crack and be in a completely different biome with no visible way back. I feel like the mapmaker for the original game wanted to show me an alien world, and unique horizons on that world never seen by humanity before. In the second I feel like the mapmaker wanted to really take some time off and focus on they're newfound spelunking habit, wriggle through some rocks like a worm. New creatures are boring, and I don't understand why they didn't just unify the crafting trees, since they unified the blueprints.

Also I didn't mind the munching and crunching sounds of the first game, adding much more mouth-noise and a person moaning over half the eating was super uncomfortable. It's generous or you got lost a buuunch like me if this game gives you more than 20 hours. I won't buy part 3 if one eventually exists, until I've seen that it returns to the original form.

The biggest downgrade, imo, is that the Sports Car (Seamoth) and Luxury Sub (Cyclops) have been replaced with the Seatruck (a gd 18 wheeler). It has less storage than both vehicles, and the only way to make it useful is to craft separate modules that have to be attached to your truck, making it impossible to navigate the endemic tunnels in the map. The prawn suit does make it through, but it's had the jump pack forced into it, so if you (like me) enjoyed playing with the physics in the first game to make the prawn fly everywhere be assured, the fun has been patched out! Now the limitations of the prawn suit from the first game make some segments impossible (also, don't go deep diving until you have the jump jets or you're leaving that prawn in the depths, there are spots it cannot jump out without them). 

It's like some dev on the team had the exec's balls in a vice and got to make all the design decisions. I cannot say heavily enough just play the first game again if you need more, and look up the cutscenes from this one to know what happened in this game.

an absolutely amazing sequel though not as exciting and scary as the first game but still got some of the things that makes the first game really good and more land exploration is pretty fun, i'd not recommend using the snowfox on land cus prawn suit is infinitely better, you can literally swing and fly really fast on it, i don't even know why snowfox is a thing cus its not even better for something to be exclusively on land and it got no storage unlike the prawn.

No, it's not the same experience as Subnautica 1. But it is still really good. It actually polishes a lot of things from the first game and some of the mechanics are even better here. For instance, they replaced both the Seamoth and the Cyclops with the seatruck, which is an amazing vehicle and not nearly as overpowered as the Cyclops, which makes it more balanced. The story is also much better with the introduction of more characters and a pretty good protagonist. So why is it not as good as the first game? 3 reasons:
1 - Land. The land area in this game is very boring and a major part of the game. It is very obnoxious to travel and explore.
2 - It's a much easier game and less scary. You barely ever feel threatened in this game while exploring. The leviathans are mostly a disappointment and there are way fewer and less interesting enemies to deal with.
3 - Hand holding. The first game felt like dark souls/elden ring. It was very mysterious: you had to find things for yourself, there was more and better areas to explore and it was exciting finding all the new places. Here you get markers and pointers almost everywhere while the areas and objects are way more predictable.

Still worth every cent though.

Amazing for so many reasons 9.9/10

This game was kind of a disappointment. Ignore my steam profile, I've played through the game on console already (plus watched a few playthroughs). It's just missing the magic that the first game had. Don't get me wrong, it's an okay game, but it's nowhere near as good as the original Subnautica.

Nowhere near as scary, the iconic PDA voice got changed and the protagonist is now spouting out obnoxious one-liners. Some resources are also really annoying to farm in this game since they removed certain big outcrops, which makes base building way more tedious.

The most annoying change for me was the Seamoth being replaced with a way worse and ugly vehicle, that almost reminds of a Seamoth/Cyclops merge. Now I get the Cyclops was removed, due to the map being way more shallow and narrow (which makes it less scary), but they could've at least kept the Seamoth.

All in all, Subnautica: Below Zero isn't quite a steaming pile of garbage, but it isn't great either. It has some cool aspects to it here and there, and the first bit of playing was fun since it was all new. But after playing for a while, you realize how tedious it is and you get more and more annoyed. I'd say stick to regular Subnautica, but it could maybe be worth playing this one time if you're a big fan of the series.

As a Subnautica player, My soul already lives on planet 4546B, so I’ll do my best to give you a bias-free review. 
The beginning is dramatic and throws you right in immediately giving you a direction. If you played Subnautica before, the mechanics and progression are relatively the same: find resources, avoid predatory creatures (crash fish are back), craft, dive deeper, and repeat. In terms of story, it has mystery that makes you curious to find out more, even risking life and limb to achieve that. The dangers you encounter definitely get progressively more scary, you might get Thalassophobia if you don’t have it already. The exploration possibilities are good, but lacks compared to Subnautica. You will spend more time exploring depth then horizontal exploration. However, the end is much more climactic than the Subnautica. Game time is average: about 32 hours if you put your mind to it. So if you have money to spare, this is a game to enjoy, otherwise wait for a seasonal sale.

[b] TLDR [/b]: It's just as fun as the first Subnautica. Even though the map is smaller, still feels like there's a lot of places to explore and things to do. Although keep in mind that after you beat the game there's not much replay value, so I recommend buying on a sale.

More detailed review below:

[b] Visuals [/b]: The game got a big graphics improvement since Subnautica. It just looks so gorgeous! My only complain is that some biomes are too dark and can't see almost nothing even with the light from the vehicles.

[b] Story [/b]: Not going to spoil here. But it's nice that they made some connections with the story of the first game. But is it necessary to play the first Subnautica to understand the story of Below Zero? Not really. Aside from some references, the story has pretty much no attachment to the story of the first Subnautica.

[b] Gameplay fun factor [/b]: 10/10 At the time of this review I had played 32 hours and still did not run out of things to do or to explore. So definitely recommend this game!

My only big con about Below Zero:

"Dangerous weather approaching seek shelter!" - PDA 
The frequency of the "dangerous weather" while on the surface feels like is 24/7!
This weather "events" are so annoying in the early game, and it does not get any less annoying in the late game. 

The main difference in Below Zero is that it allows you explore the surface, and the addition of a "temperature meter". This temperature meter goes down when you are out of water so you eventually freeze to death. But the draining of this meter is so fast during the "dangerous weather" that can completely kill the joy of exploring the surface.

I liked the environment in the first subnautica a bit better than this one because it felt a bit more wide open in all directions. I guess the first one had to give you more breathing room because of the cyclops. And there was the mystery and magic of the first one because I'd never played a game like it. gotta say though, the sea truck grew on me once I realized how it's modules worked. also in this one I've spent more time and had more fun building my base compared to the first one. but that probably has some to do with the fact that I was so absorbed in exploration for so long during the first game, and I avoided learning to build a base for too long because of it. whereas with below zero, like I said, I felt like the world is a bit too vertically compressed compared to the first, and exploration wasn't as rewarding or compelling as in the first, so I preferred putzing about back at base a lot. but this game does look nicer. like, I think if you randomly stop and take a screen shot, with below zero chances are you're gonna be looking at something that it eerily similar to good concept art, like the organic shapes of things look great from all angles. As for the snowfox and all the stuff you have to do on land, it's not as fun as I hoped. It felt kinda clunky. I'd rather be crawling along in my centipede of a sea truck or grappling through coral in the prawn suit rather than use the snowfox any day.

Not quite as good as the original game but still worth the time. It's still Subnautica, after all.

The Good:
- More resources, lots more. I no longer found myself scrounging for copper every ten minutes, it's everywhere. Lead, lithium, everything is all over the place. There's even a handheld scanner to help find things.

- The sea truck is a nice upgrade over the sea moth, giving it more features in a still small package.

- Penguins.


The Bad:
- No more Cyclops! While the sea truck is nice,  it just doesn't feel the same as having a huge mobile base that you can build in to suit your needs. It would have been great to have the sea moth replaced while still having access to the clops.

- Very twisty, cavernous terrain. It's far easier to get lost in this game compared to its predecessor. Take advantage of the seaglide's map and beacons. I suppose this is why they removed the sub, too big to bang around the caves.

- Map is smaller than the first game. The world lost some of the awe and mystery by being so condensed, there's less curiosity about what you'll find as you dive deeper and deeper into the sea, and the creatures/biomes down there don't get quite as weird as they used to.


Neutral:
- The story was alright but kind of forgettable. I personally found myself more interested in the B-plot than the sister thing.

Don't get me wrong, Subnautica Below Zero is not a bad game, it just isn't nearly as good as the first game. I think that the reason that I enjoyed this game so much is because it's the first Subnautica game that I played which means that I didn't have anything to compare it to. Because of that, I enjoyed this game a lot and if you haven't played Subnautica and you plan to play both, play Below Zero first. Oh, one more thing, don't spoil yourself about anything when it comes to these two amazing games.

The main differences about Subnautica and Below Zero are that the leviathans aren't as scary and they're mostly annoying, you know exactly what I mean if you've played this game. The other main issue is the map size, this game doesn't go nearly as deep as Subnautica did, in Subnautica you went 1400 meters down whils't in Below Zero, you go down to 1000 meters. That's not even the main issue, all areas feel small, hence why you don't get the Cyclops in this game, it wouldn't fit in more than half of the biomes. Speaking of biomes, almost all of the biomes feel similar to eachother, you could put someone with 200 hours in this game in an area and there's a large chance that they wouldn't know where they were. Especially since most of the biomes are just differently colored caves except for some biomes that are just giant wastelands and the map is still tiny in comparison to Subnautica.

The giant land biomes are also big wastelands that have nothing in them, the vehicle (the Snowfox) that you get is also kinda shit, the Prawn Suit is better on land than the Snowfox, I've literally never used the Snowfox in my four playthroughs, that's how utterly useless it is (I've seen it on Youtube).

One more thing that I feel like I can complain about is the fact that you aren't alone this time around, Subnautica made the atmosphere of being completely alone in a wide ocean very apparent from the start. This game however feels the need to add two characters that actively talk to you. Great job Unknown Worlds!

So... I know that I've been complaining a lot in this review but the thing is, this game is still awesome, all of the new things they added make this game so fun, for example, all the new building things, posters, music, more customization and things like that. I especially love that they added fan music.

Just a reminder, this game isn't bad in the slightest, it's just that Sunbautica is so good that it feels unfair comparing the two. I'm gonna end this review like I did with the Subnautica review a.k.a a simple version:

Difficulty: 1/10
Subnautica had a few oxygen issues but here in Below Zero, you have oxygen plants which make it super easy, barely an inconvenience to breath IN THE UNDERWATER SURVIVAL GAME.

Grind: 6/10
I don't know why but Below Zero felt way less grindy than Subnautica.

Story/Worldbuilding: 8/10
The story just feels empty in some parts, good overall but, it's just not as good as Subnautica's story and/or worldbuilding.

Graphics: 9.5/10
This game's visuals are absolutely stunning if I'm gonna be completely honest.

Scary: 3/10
I already mentioned this I feel like.

Overall: Worse than Subnautica.

This game is worse then the original in quite a few ways, especially now that one of the main edges this game had, its base building improvements, have been retroactively added to the original, that being said it is still a good game.

The 2 biggest downside for me are as follows:

The size of the map - it is much smaller. in a game about getting trapped in a vast alien world the vastness in majorly toned down.

the sea truck - while in theory it is cool, its modules and ability to shed them allows it to play the role of both a cyclops and a seamoth. but in practice it feels worse then those in both of the roles. It is much slower then the seamoth, presumably to hide the smaller map, and the modules feel less customizable then the cyclops, which enabled you to build inside of it. It was a necessary change to the seatruck due to how cramped the maps caves are but they could have just made the caves less cramped.

There are also some smaller gripes that I really cannot pass off as objective, like i do not care for the story of this one as much as the original, I find The original MC to be far more relatable due to him not stranding himself on an alien planet by choice and I also prefer the originals OST, this one is still good but I think nostalgia might be at play, but I cannot help what I feel. I also found the original PDA to be better written and funnier, I do not think I laughed at a single of this PDA's jokes. But these things are relatively minor and do not detract from the experience of exploring the alien world.


OVerall S:BZ is a good game, But I feel like it would have been better if it was a DLC for the original, and I do recommend it if you were desperate for more subnautica, but if you are new to the series I recommend playing the original first and only getting this one if you want more. While my review doesn't seem very positive for a reccomend I want to note that the only reason I have so many bad things to say about this one is because the original is just so good. If this was the first one I would be praising it to the heavens and back.

Subnautica: Below Zero is a captivating and immersive survival-adventure game that builds upon the success of its predecessor, Subnautica. Developed and published by Unknown Worlds Entertainment, Below Zero takes players on a thrilling journey to an alien, frozen underwater world.

The game's storyline revolves around a researcher named Robin, who sets out to investigate the mysterious disappearance of her sister on Planet 4546B. Unlike the lush tropical environment of the original Subnautica, Below Zero introduces us to an icy, harsh landscape filled with unique biomes and treacherous creatures. The attention to detail in the game world is outstanding, with stunning visuals and realistic water effects that enhance the sense of depth and immersion.

One of the standout features of Below Zero is the seamless integration of exploration and survival mechanics. Players must manage their oxygen levels, hunger, thirst, and body temperature while delving into the unknown. Crafting and building play a crucial role as players gather resources to create tools, vehicles, and shelters to survive the harsh environment. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenging gameplay and rewarding progression, keeping players engaged for hours on end.

The diverse marine life in Below Zero is both fascinating and terrifying. From adorable penguins to colossal leviathans, encounters with the various creatures evoke a sense of wonder and fear. The game cleverly uses sound design and atmospheric cues to heighten tension during encounters, making exploration an exhilarating experience.

The storyline unfolds through well-crafted audio logs and in-game dialogue, further immersing players into the protagonist's journey. As players uncover the truth behind the planet's secrets, they'll find themselves emotionally invested in Robin's quest for answers.

--CONS HIGHLIGHTS--
However, Below Zero is not without its minor flaws. Some players might find the pacing a bit slow at times, and occasional technical hiccups can briefly disrupt immersion. Such example would consist of the times where you find yourself without a specific material and be needed to explore different biomes in order to find what you require. Sometimes it may become repetitive, but it will make the player better consider what they need to craft an item. Moreover, some movement bugs should be taken into consideration by the developers, for example, entering a cave or a room can often be accompanied by an inadequate collider that slows down player's pace, as well as going up a stair case. Yet, the developers have consistently provided updates to address these issues, showcasing their dedication to the community.

--CONCLUSION--
In conclusion, Subnautica: Below Zero is a remarkable sequel that successfully expands upon the strengths of the original game. With its enthralling storyline, stunning visuals, and engaging gameplay mechanics, Below Zero offers an unforgettable underwater adventure that will keep players hooked from start to finish. Whether you're a fan of survival games, exploration, or simply seeking an immersive narrative-driven experience, Subnautica: Below Zero is a must-play.

Very fun new experience. Has all of the fun that made the original game enjoyable and includes enough of a spin and new content to make it feel unique and worthwhile.

Pros:
- I LOVE the custuomizable modular nature of the new vehicle
- The land aspects are new and interesting
- The story takes a different approach and introduces a lot of new insights into the game's lore while tackling different themes that give it a different mood than the first game. I'm interested in learning more about this universe and how human society functions. Spoilers aside, this story does some New Stuff
- As others have pointed out the map is much smaller, but I think that's a plus because it's more navigable. I spend more time exploring and less time holding W in a submarine. Embarking on adventures is less stressful because I don't have to worry as much about overpacking or forgetting something because the travel times aren't huge

Cons:
- A lot of the wildlife feels too familiar. In a way the map can seem more like a DLC than a game of its own
- Game's progression feels rugged. It was fast and almost overwhelming at first with the amount of signals I had to go to explore--then that transitioned rather quickly to having very few new things to explore and feeling very limited
- Map exploration is less linear. I feel like the first game had a great setup where you progressively went deeper and deeper and could predict where endgame was taking you; you could see the next progression areas ahead of you and had to work towards it. This game feels like it throws you in random places and I'm going back and forth rather than linearly moving deeper. Progression is often found in random caves scattered across the map that you can coincidentally come across sooner. Many biomes are visited once and never again, leading to many recipes being missed because I never return to the area their fragments are found. I unlocked the Prawn Suite Depth upgrade before the Prawn Suite
- I feel like there was less attention to detail. For example, bullseye shrooms exist, can be farmed and the PDA says they're used in crafting, but afaik no recipe uses them and they're useless. They're just a remnant of the first game. There's a land plant whose PDA analysis says it can be harvested for food but it can't. The alien structures are small, scattered and less awe-inspiring.

All in all this game has a really great concept and setup but then I feel like it lost steam partway through development. I wouldn't be surprised if this was due to covid or other developmental issues. Nonetheless it's a unique experience with a great synopsis and I think it's more than worth the price for Subnautica fans
