I hear a lot of people don't like this game cause it was not like the original. Just ignore them cause this is also another amazing master piece of this series. There is just something so captivating of swimming around underwater discovering the environment and creatures.

There is some new and fresh content in Below Zero, the new creatures and biomes are welcome additions.

Unfortunately it adds more bad than good. Part of what made Subnautica so special was the immersive experience of trying to survive an alien world. The player is driven by curiosity to progress the tech tree and uncover the story. In Below Zero your character is voiced, not silent, she is obnoxious, the dialogue is infantile.  Who thought it would improve the experience for the player character to have marvel style quips reacting to the world "SO, THAT just happened." "Woah now this is... different!" "Umm, guys, you're gonna wanna see this". The dialogue is cringe and there's too much of it. What happened to whoever wrote the lines for the PDA in the first game? The PDA used to be funny. In this game they give it a thick indian accent for some reason and the 2 jokes I heard it say were painfully unfunny.

Additionally the story itself is nonsensical and contradicts itself constantly, it simply makes no sense and it is really perplexing how such terrible dialogue and such a bad story shipped. In addition the land/snow portions of the game are boring, buggy and borderline unfinished. It's simply a huge missed opportunity and I cannot recommend it, instead I recommend playing the original Subnautica, and when you've beaten that, try the mods. Forget about it for a few years and then play it again lol.

Good, not great. The original Subnautica is excellent and sets the bar for similar games, while Below Zero, while a good game, is a step back. The story was good, but again, just good. It didn't wow me or keep me guessing. 

The underwater exploration is still great, but the huge portion of the game set above sea level is underwhelming and becomes tedious. This is due in part because the game is designed to be underwater and the above ground movement and feel is still clunky. The smooth, fluid control underwater instead feels like a poorly designed FPS when on land. 

Because of so much of the game being above sea level, there wasn't as much underwater, the best part of the game. The original Subnautica kept the land and ship exploration to relatively short, but important areas. Minimizing the game's weaknesses for dry land exploration. Making nearly half the game above the waves limited the game's core content, underwater exploration. Also, outside of a couple of areas, Below Zero didn't capture the wow factor of being in an incredibly deep, dangerous area. 

The vehicles also underwhelmed. The Seatruck, while being modular and utilitarian, was not exciting. If my job was to perform tasks underwater, I'd want a Seatruck. But it was far from fun to operate, and when at its largest size, clunky and slow. The impressive size and looks of the Cyclops or the speed and agility of the Seamoth is just not there. I ended up using the Seaglide most of the time, using the truck as an oxygen and storage stop. 

I hope the Subnautica returns to its underwater roots and keeps the exploration the ocean depths the main focus.

I've never played a sequel that somehow took everything from the first game and just did less in the way this one does. It was originally going to be dlc and BOY does it feel like it.

Almost every biome feels unfinished. Literally the only new assets were the sea truck, a few new fish, and literally only two new base components. 

When I beat subnautica 1 I felt triumphant. I was elated and wished I could have more. In Below Zero, I felt absolutely nothing. I finished it more out of obligation to my addiction to sunk cost fallacies.

If the game had fleshed out more about the architects I might have liked the ending but what they were obviously going for felt totally unearned. I thought the ending was so cool on paper but was executed so poorly. 

The whole game is a buggy mess. The entire ending where I'm supposed to be in awe I was distracted by the leviathan that clipped into the facility and was swimming in mid air trying to get back out. 

I spent an hour walking around a suspiciously flat frozen wasteland wondering what I was gonna see before the game world ended because the devs never anticipated that I’d use the prawn suit as a land vehicle and ended up where I wasn’t supposed to go. And the reason I was USING the prawn suit was because the hover bike they made look so cool is an absolute piece of junk that handles like it uses the same mechanics as a submarine but they just removed the ability to maneuver on a y axis. And I had to make two of them because the first time I tried to deploy it, it clipped through the terrain and fell through the world and I had to hide its map marker so it wouldn’t clutter the screen (had to do the same thing after my first sea truck got hopelessly stuck and I had to abandon it).

Oh and get this… the bugs were so bad that I had to look up console commands to trigger story beats toward the end that somehow didn’t and I had to spoil the ending by looking up walkthroughs to figure out why it wouldn’t progress. This meant I also stopped getting achievements since I had to use console commands to even finish my playthrough.

This game might have worked as DLC as originally intended. As a new game they owed us a renewed reason to come back. This game was the same price as the first one but it’s far less. When you consider the smaller environment, the very very few new assets and features, and the amount of stuff they cut out that was in the first game like the cyclops and sea moth, this game absolutely fails to justify its own existence let alone charge the same price as the first game that did so much more. 90% of the effort went into a very narrow sliver of this game. 

I’m genuinely sad that I was so let down. And since they’re moving on to the “next game in the subnautica universe” there won’t be any more substantial updates. And if they go in the direction I think they’re going to with what’s teased at the end of this game, I am permanently checked out on this franchise and this developer. I have no reason or desire to play Subnautica Below Zero again. 

Like the Star Wars prequels, the saddest thing about this is that it can never be undone. It will always exist to sully how good the original was by being adjacent to it.

Overall I recommend Subnautica:  Below Zero, though not as much as the original Subnautica.

[b]Pros:[/b]
In short, it's more Subnautica goodness in terms of gameplay.  If you enjoyed the first game, you'll likely enjoy this one.  I particularly appreciate the "Freedom" game mode, where food & water requirements are removed - I've always found those annoying in games, so it's nice to be able to focus on other survival & exploration aspects!

Some people seem to hate the Seatruck, but I like that you can customize it for various roles.  And you have a "quick disconnect" option to drop the additional pods if you need speed & maneuverability.  Once you get the upgrades, I found the speed was suitable enough for the size of the map.

[b]Neutral:[/b]
The map is definitely smaller, though I didn't have a problem with that.

A lot of the creatures seem less "alien" than the first game.  Looking through pictures of the creatures, you can probably guess which are fairly harmless and which are a threat.  And most of those threats are minimized if you're in a vehicle (especially with the [spoiler]Seatruck Perimeter Defense Upgrade, which makes even leviathans back up off you[/spoiler]).

[b]Cons:[/b]
The main character is annoying, and makes me miss the "silent protagonist" of the first game.  Her sister died, and she's determined to find out what "really" happened.  I got a kick out of the reverse-twist (it was surprisingly a non-surprise), but the whole "corrupt dystopian corporation" thing seems forced.  I'd prefer in future titles if Alterra was actually a decent company, just dealing with events (and personnel) as best they can.  I was actually more interested in the story of [spoiler]the Mercury II's crew and their attempts to escape in the past[/spoiler].

I did *not* like how much land portions the game had, especially with the obnoxious Ice Worm.  As far as I could tell, there was no way to dodge it (at least with no modules on the Snow Fox).  Continually getting knocked off my vehicle made me want to get that part done ASAP, rather than exploring.  Fortunately that's a very small portion of the game.  I appreciate the devs were trying something different, but I feel there needs to be more tweaking of gameplay on land (since this isn't the game's core mechanic).

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
I'd give Below Zero a "B+" rating.  It has some unique differences from the original without breaking the core gameplay that made the first game so compelling.  There are some annoying parts of the game, but not so much that I didn't want to finish.  I recommend picking it up on sale; the full retail price is a bit steep compared to what you get in its predecessor.

Below zero is not inherently a bad game but it is a very sub par follow up to its predecessor. 
My main gripe with it is frustrating biome design (all are a form of windy narrow caves and passages) and the very "gamey" feeling of it. 
One of the cool aspects of the original was the fact that equipment and game progression was tied to exploring the crashed ship. It made logical sense and therefore was very immersive. Sadly in Below Zero you end up finding random bits everywhere seemingly without any logic why this piece of equipment would have ended up there. There is distinct lack of danger from the wildlife as well and consequently the need to properly prepare and be cautious is gone. 
There are some great QoF improvements but with a smaller map, frustrating biome design, lack of challenge and really poor story line it is a very inadequate follow up. 

Despite this I am looking forward to the sequel and in the meantime I recommend to play subnautica one and buy this one to support the development of the 3rd instalment.

Okay, please don't hate me, I already left a review for Subnautica and talk about Below Zero at the end of it, so it is attached after I say a little bit more about this "take two" on Subnautica. First of all, if you LOVED Subnautica from start to finish you may like Below Zero (anything's possible right?). But if you were starting to get worn out by the end, or if it ever felt tedious, do yourself a favor and skip Below Zero! Seriously, this could ruin both games for you!

Everything that made Subnautica a slog just seems worse in Below Zero, and that despite obvious attempts to streamline this second chapter. If you love swimming around in disorientating caves searching for blueprints that may, or may not, have spawned so you can get the gear that you (think) you need to proceed in the game, then -look no further-! This is the game for you, you can waste countless hours wandering in circles while fretting over you o2, thirst and hunger levels! Yes, all the things that make your daily life a frustrating challenge without any of the reward (sorry, as much as it's reassuring to hear the player take that big gasp of air after nearly drowning, or crunch crunch crunch on some salted fish, I am not vicariously enjoying any of these experiences).

But that's not the best of it. The best is that Below Zero is buggy! Yup, get off your hoverbike and fall -through- the glacier into the ocean below. Did I mention that this is a very large glacier? Good luck swimming to the edge before you drown... dummy, why didn't you plan for that? Okay, you used the "unstuck" feature to survive that death trap... now you're in the middle of the glacial ice fields, and the only way you can survive is by using your hoverbike to stay warm. Now there are ice worms that knock you off your bike periodically, no problem, but whoops, meant to get back on your bike but you picked it up and put it in your inventory instead. No problem, I'll redeploy this vehicle and escape this frozen hellscape lickity split... except the hoverbike just clipped through the glacier to the ocean below... okay, how are you gunna survive that one dummy? To be fair, I didn't notice a lot of penalties to dying, actually got me back to my seatruck faster... maybe I missed a valuable game mechanic... just get the components I need, then die... voila! Like free teleportation. Gotta love it.

Another gripe, and I'll lose some of you here. But I think this game might be woke... No seriously, I read comments about the new player character being a BIPOC female, but that didn’t throw me, she’s completely normal throughout the game. But the new PDA voice has a thick Indian accent (google it, I’m not the only one scratching their head)? Okay, that's a little off putting (and difficult to understand sometimes), but the commentary is bizarre. “In the control room, you can change base lighting and colors, rename your base, and see information about power and structural integrity. But not the integrity of societal power structures.” Wait, what?! That one stuck with me, but there are some other strange “jokes.” Then there’s this alien database where they’re talking about their “replication,” because they can “copy themselves as many times as they want,” and “perpetuate themselves forever,” or something like that, but “that would be shameful, and any architect inclined to do that should just delete themselves.” Wait, what?!?! I’m taking it these guys aren’t pro-life…

Okay, obviously I didn’t like that game. Below is the review I wrote for Subnautica, if you’ve played Subnautica you’ll probably get an idea from it as to whether you will agree with me about Below Zero.

Okay, nevermind... My review is too long, Steam won't let me post it. You can probably find my review for Subnautica if you look for it. My guess is that no one will care enough to do so (my guess is very few people are still reading now, but if you are, thank you. You are very patient, you might actually like this game). I will try to clip the part about Below Zero from the other review and paste it here (please excuse the repeated story):

"It got way worse in Below Zero though. They added a bit more "quest prompts" and some other characters to interact with too, but the game is way buggier than the original subnautica. And now we have freezing to add to the survival mix (I turned hunger and thirst off, no way I was going to play through that again). So on one occasion I deploy my hoverbike (which keeps you warm) and whoops... it just fell through the earth. I don't have a hoverbike anymore... Please excuse me while I run around wildly and freeze to death. Or the blueprints for the quest item that don't appear Margeurite's desk after she tells you to pick them up. I didn't know anything was wrong until I spent 3 hours wandering the world trying to figure out what I missed. Then I googled it, found out this was a common bug, submitted a bug report, then went back to Margeurite's and... okay, they're on the table now? They weren't there before, and that's not the desk where she told me to pick them up... but cool... I guess? At least I finished the quest. 

Then I started searching for the leviathan cure. Spent a few hours wandering around the glacier with a map that looked like it was drawn by a child (in the future everyone is far less competent than they are today... I didn't know that was possible...) and finally I got so bored I just looked it up on youtube, Oh... I have to swim under the glacier... Well THAT wasn't on the map. After that I got fed up and looked the rest of the quests up on youtube. 20 hours was WAY TOO MUCH time to give that game.

What a waste. I wouldn't call this a game. But if you don't have a real life that needs attending to I suppose you can engage with a very frustrating "alien planet survival simulator."

A simple review below.

PROS:
Addictive survival-ish (far too easy to be termed 'survival') game play with excellent base building, finding the right place for your primary base is a joy. The environment and creatures this time are somewhat improved over an already very good approach in the first game.

Great voice acting, particularly with Alan and a decent approach to having other characters in game though it was a bit confusing (see below).

Graphics are OK for the game's purpose, but its a curious thing that pop in is so bad which breaks immersion.

CONS:
Being essentially an add-on to the first game I am very confused why this game went into early release. Bugs and issues still exist to this day going on being a decade old. Either this team does not care about quality or is unable to code their own game remains to be seen. The story is just nonsense, with Sam's demise remaining confusing and Robin being 100% OK with an lien who misled her and was largely to blame for the catastrophic events, her response was well I make mistakes too.

Most players of the first game complained the map was too small and yet this map is five times smaller, great listening from the developers here. The map this time uses even more maze like architecture to try and create a false sense of difficulty, miss one turn or cave entrance and you will be lost until you re-orientate. The player can construct a nuclear reactor, yet struggles with an O2 tank to last longer than some can hold their breath while also dying from starvation or thirst in twenty some odd minutes. Creating false difficulty is a sure sign of weak game mechanics.

The writing and 'science' behind the game world feel like they were written by a twelve year old and are  not passable by any standards. The addition of temperature being a prime example. Cold? jump in the frozen waters or use the heat plant that grows for no reason along your exact line of travel. Rudimentary writing and science are completely abandoned.

CONCLUSION:
The game just feels like the team was lazy, not listening to feedback and certainly not addressing something like 50 bugs/issues still present in game. I hope they actually try for the third attempt. If the third game goes to early release that will be a pass for me. As it is I got both games for a steal and would never pay full price for what is essentially an incomplete poorly designed and written game.

I am giving it a thumb's down as it receives far too much praise and we are stuck with Steam's binary rating, but I would give this game a 5 out of 10 mostly because of the team's laziness and lack of integrity in putting out a decent game based on an excellent framework of base building and resource gathering.

A glorified DLC. Not as good as the original in most aspects. MUCH smaller map, muted horror because of the small map size and kind of lame sea monsters, uninspired soundtrack (different composer), lame and pointless story (you drive around the ocean aimlessly looking for precursor sites, all of which are pretty sparse), low creature variety, and boring vehicles (the seatruck is just a commuter bus). 

Honestly this thing sat in early access for almost 2 years (maybe more?) and I waited until 1.0 to play it. I got bored after about 10 hours.

If you haven't played the original, do so. If you have, dont waste your money on this stale re-fry.

Potential Spoilers Ahead!

[spoiler]Subnautica: Below Zero (or, more accurately, Subnautica: Part II) is not, and will never be Subnautica, the original. But, I'd argue that was never really the point. Any attempts to copy the original would've resulted in a game I believe I would've enjoyed far less. Where Subnautica laid the foundations for an exceptional and stunning universe: a technocratic, corporatist dystopia unlike any other games, where corporations on the scales of whole governmental bodies exist, where the Human race is a space-faring species with the power of teleportation and nano-construction, but one that restrains their autonomy by the use of the corporate straitjacket, Below Zero expands it. To not expand upon this universe in Subnautica: Part II would've been a disservice.

The tales of Subnautica are, to me, a love letter to the indomitable Human spirit. The highs and lows of human perseverance, ingenuity, compassion, morality, sorrows, our hopes and dreams. To realize our ambitions of exploring the final frontier and the tragedies that inevitably follow. This game explores this dream universe turned into a nightmare, and the power behind our actions. Our power of curiosity. Of justice. Of individuality and of our freedom.

Consider my review of Subnautica: Below Zero to be incomplete. This review really depends on what happens in Part III. I and many others will be awaiting the release of this trilogy with the anticipation and curiousness that makes our whole species. I will be waiting for the return to this intriguing, complex, technological marvel of a world they have created, hungry for the next course.[/spoiler]

TLDR: No excuse for you not to get it. Stop looking at the reviews and play it. Expect not the same as Subnautica I, expect it instead like a spin-off. You're going to have a lot of fun.

I keep seeing a lot of thumbs down....but then in the review it says the game isnt bad? well anyway here's my take after playing both back to back.

TLDR: if you thoroughly enjoyed the first, you will also enjoy this one and like it for its own qualities.

Pros:
- the underwater biomes are absolutely stunning and feel more unique compared to the first
- the creatures are more detailed and seem far more diverse
- the caves are far more "twisty" so it feels like deeper exploration instead of just...go under rock, big open room under rock, which the first was like.
- resources feel more abundant and crafting feels slightly more streamlined but more or less the same as first

Cons:
- map is smaller than the first, so the extent of exploration feels smaller, however there arent repeated biomes so you dont travel through kelp forest in 5 different areas like in the first or 2 mushroom forests etc.
- progression of the game is not very straight forward compared to the first and often feels random going back and forth
- above water missions didnt really add much to the experience for me with a couple exceptions, and I would've preferred more ocean to explore.
- story is more narrated which isnt bad, however the story just isnt as interesting as the first in my opinion.

For me its hard to say which is better, because where one of the games lack, the other does it better. so I have them tied for different reasons. I lean more towards the original mainly just due to the progression feeling better with gradually going to deeper and deeper locations that were quite large etc. and the story was more interesting.

I really enjoyed exploring the ocean in below zero much more than the first. the creature designs were very well made. the cave systems were awesome to go through. exploration was just a lot more interesting. However progression felt super weird and non linear. it felt like there was much less of a clear path of progression compared to the first. also, although the below zero biomes are beautiful, i often felt like there was not much to discover in them.

the story was fine/meh in below zero, and the above water stuff was pretty average.

Just go play the original tbh. Below Zero is less than 1/4 of the size of Subnautica with an awful and often nonsensical story, immersion-breaking overly-chatty protagonist, and almost complete lack of what made Subnautica great in terms of biome/creature diversity and atmosphere. 

This is no longer an exploration-focused experience about surviving on a hostile alien world. It is more akin to a walk through mostly-harmless, incredibly linear pathways where everything is given/told to you explicitly while the dumbest "scientists" you've ever heard wax philosophical about the human condition with about as much critical thinking as that one kid in high school that thought they were super deep.
As beautiful as the first game, and the same amount of terror! Love how much this series has grown, and can't wait to see what's next!

I cannot say I am happy playing this. I was happy and some what excited when I first had played. The first few hours were extremely fun and scary, but then, as it progressed, it lost that factor. Many things that were implemented for you early game became useless. For example, the Snow Fox and whatever suit upgrade you get for the cold, are rather useless. While the SF is fast and the suit maybe handy, you could negate their necessity with the PRAWN suit. It keeps you warm, and much safer, and even a threat unlike the SF as well. The Ice worms are disappointing. I was able to hop away from them in my PRAWN in all encounters, in effect, making thumpers useless. The leviathans aren't scary and I found myself being annoyed with more than anything. I actually chased one down (again in the PRAWN suit) because I got so pissed at it. Leviathans are not scary, only 1 that I encountered looked cool and even then was just in the way. The other Leviathan, the Chellirate (idc enough to spell it right) was far from a threat. I had to approach it and bump into it to make it attack me, it dealt little damage and then ran away. The sea truck is slow, annoying, and vastly inferior to the Sea Moth and Cyclops from the original game, however the map design makes me more understanding, however it still makes me loath using it. Fauna is very limited, the standard preyfish, some leviathans, but very little in between like Subnautica 1 had (sand sharks, bone sharks, stalkers, etc). The travel is boring cuz distances between important locations are so far apart and the sea truck is so slow. The sea truck is easy to damage and destroy unintentionally. Biomes seem more limited, and it overall seems more barren and empty (granted its in the arctic of 4546B). The story is less compelling, and I found myself trying to force myself to finish the game. I looked it up and the amount of travel back and forth I'd have to do to finish the game just hurts to think about so I've quit. Maybe I'll be back just to say I've finished it. Its not a bad game despite my rant, but having played the original Subnautica, it just feels like a worse game. It lacks the mystery and intrigue of the first game in my opinion and it just feels meh. It feels bland, and like a less content filled reskin with a few tasks. I want to finish this game. I have forced my self for a few days now prior to this review, and I can't. I won't. It just bores me to tears. All I have left is the grinding and the travelling. I know where everything is, but even thinking about having to sit through nothingness filled travel. This game is not bad, but its overpriced in my opinion when its not on sale. I'm very happy I didn't spend 40$ on this game. It's not bad, it's just that Subnautica 1 is better in every aspect. I'll being going back to Subnautica 1 and mod it. It has most of the fun or interesting content that BZ has in it's 2.0 update anyways. BZ, not a bad game. Subnautica 1, an amazing and memorable experience that I will keep going back to.

I want to be on an alien planet and think my own thoughts about things. I really like this game but I don't love it.

Solidly mediocre on it's own, and a pretty big disappointment after playing the first.

Overall, it definitely feels more like a DLC to the first game and not a standalone sequel. It is much shorter, smaller, and worse in basically every way. They made a couple attempts to innovate on the first game. None of those attempts went well, and universally hurt the experience.

The best thing I can say about the game is that if you liked the first game and really, REALLY want more then this is more. It has the same basic structure where you explore to find things to craft gear to help you explore.

As for the bad, first and foremost the protagonist talks! They made an attempt to shoe horn in a more direct narrative, which completely missed how the first game worked. Subnautica OG took a dogshit barely existent story and stretched it out masterfully. You were constantly alone with your thoughts, and the drip of story was just enough to remind you of what was happening but never distracted from the game. Sub BZ's protagonist comments on everything. Once you have Alan in your head you have constant "banter". There are several instances where you're exploring and trying to listen to audio logs and the protagonist and Alan CONSTANTLY interrupt to quip about what is happening. It is maddening how badly they misunderstood what made OG great.

The biome design is just pathetic compared to OG as well. There are far fewer biomes and they are less differentiated. It is nuts to see the same resources just randomly copy pasted across half the biomes when OG had such consistent theming for the biomes. The biomes are visually uninteresting, mechanically uninteresting, they're just dead inside. This causes the entire game to falter, since the whole game is about exploring cool shit. OG also felt very intentionally designed. It felt like it guided you to certain locations very naturally, to the point where I felt manipulated when I realized what the game was doing. BZ feels hacked together. Tons of paths have dead ends, and none of them naturally lead you to the next area. You just bumble around until you accidentally advance. Many important areas also only have 1 or 2 entrances, and because they aren't very well designed it can sometimes be easy to miss them. It made exploration feel like a chore.

The positive:  I think if you're at all tempted, you should play this game.  It's beautiful, exploration is compelling, and it feels like a nice extension and expansion of the first game.  When you're getting into new areas and seeing new things, this game can be exhilarating.  And while a lot of the items and mechanics are similar to the first game, it changes up enough that it doesn't just feel like a rehash.  Also, I appreciate that I don't feel blind 80% of the time walking around in the prawn suit like I did in the first game.  I don't know if that's because the headlamp on the prawn suit are better, or if the lighting in general is friendlier, but I like it.

As for the negatives:  This won't be a surprise if you've played the first game, but it can be incredibly frustrating when you're lost and looking for something specific.  This is especially true in the large above ground section which has multiple important locations, but they're separated by sections that look almost identical.  It is so easy to get turned around and go in circles.

Also, the plot stuff is a little too hands-off at times, despite the game having a more active plot than the first game.  There were a few times while playing where I had something I needed to do, and for every other situation there would be a signal to follow that would nudge me in the right direction, but for whatever reason I had no signal or no guidance to get me there, so I ended up looking it up.

And that's the thing.  I get the design choice to not have a map or minimap in these games.  But ultimately it ends up sending me to wikis and guides to try to find things after spending hours searching and getting frustrated.  I think I'd like it more if the game had internal ways to track this sort of thing.

All that being said, this game, along with the original, were a really fun time.  Very engrossing.  And I very much look forward to any follow-up on this series.

If this game was not the sequel to Subnautica I would likely be giving it a positive review.

To start with the good, the base building is improved with several new set pieces and quality of life features. It's still as fun as ever to build out your base and I spent my fair share of time doing so. The vehicles are good (except for the Snowfox), and I actually found the Seatruck to be a comfortable medium between Seamoth and Cyclops, even though Cyclops is still cooler. New tools like the mineral detector are a lifesaver and are appreciated. Some of the new creatures are cool, like the sea monkeys who find stuff for you.

Unfortunately, nearly every other aspect of the game is a step backward. The main story they tried to tell in this game is an interesting concept, but is just not told in an interesting way whatsoever, and the plot is full of more glaring holes than Swiss cheese. None of the characters introduced are very compelling at all, and half of the main characters' dialogue is extremely eye-rolling and cringey. What made the first game so great was the simple concept - you crash on an alien planet, now survive and escape somehow. You played as a faceless, mute protagonist (I know he does have a name/face, but it is barely mentioned in-game), which allowed it to feel like your own fully immersive survival story.

Most people point out that the world is much smaller in this game, and it's true. There are plenty of areas in the game that look amazing, however the biome variety and individual identity of each just feels lacking overall. A good portion of the map is on land areas, which are frankly a slog to get through. After finishing the game, I felt no desire to go and further explore any areas I felt I hadn't fully seen yet, which is the opposite of how it was for me in the first game. Also, the game spoon feeds you too many way points throughout the story, which eliminates a lot of the experience of organically finding something cool, or analyzing a clue to figure out where you need to go. That aspect is still present at several points, but about half the time it seems the game just wants to throw way points at you to say "go here next". 

Ultimately, I wouldn't recommend this unless you have played the first and really want to scratch that Subnautica itch again. Just know you will not be getting the exact same experience that made the first game so special.

I'd say its not as good as the original Subnautica, however it's no where near a bad game. Still a very fun experience, and I think it gets a bad rep because of how good the first game was. It doesn't feel as lonely as the first game which can be viewed as a bad thing or a good thing, but for me it really doesn't matter. One issue I have is that the leviathans aren't as scary as they were in the first game, and instead are just kinda annoying. Another issue I have is that it's hard to see where you are on the non existent map. In the first Subnautica, you could see where you were by going to the surface and looking at how far away or what direction the Aurora was. In Below Zero there is none of that. Instead, when you peak your head out of the water, you see mist, and unfortunately nothing else. My last issue with the game so far is the Sea Truck. Now I actually quite like the Sea Truck itself, and was very excited to see how you could attach modules to it, and that it was basically a mix of the first games Cyclops and Sea moth. The problem comes when you realize it's the ONLY vehicle in the game that goes under water, and i'm not counting the prawn suit. You also get the Sea Truck very early on which made me think there would be another vehicle, but no. The Sea Truck is still very cool, but it could've been handled better in that regard. With all that been said, this game is still very fun and has some great moments. However if the 3rd Subnautica game follows the same route Below Zero did, I don't think the franchise will last long. So in conclusion, Below Zero is a great game, the big problem is that the original is much better.

And even after finding it, i spent almost 2 hours getting lost there cause its build like a maze. Add weather and night, 2 phases where you cant see shti and its just awful. I would throw frost in there too, but the snowfox saves you from it.

Map: Its smaller and somehow still worse to navigate through. 

Vehicles: Seatrunk is an interesting idea but in the end worse than everything from the first game. Prawn Suit still rocks tho.

Story: Worse than the first game IMO but the architect part was interesting atleast. 

i respect the developers for trying out new things to expand the game but for me, most of them just made the game slightly worse than the first. 

All in all, its still a decent game and i could recommend it, if its on sale but i just finished it and im still very tilted from running around Phil station for way too long.

First of all... WOW. This game sure was an experience, possibly one of the greatest games I have ever played.
Gameplay-wise, the game expands the original Subanutica with more mechanics, a large amount of quality of life improvements and additions and a different yet somewhat similar overall feeling.
The gameplay is really well executed and polished and the amount of features is great without being overwhelming. I really enjoy that they have expanded on features that are useful when playing on land.
Graphically, the game is quite similar to the first game although I would say much more polished and with less rendering issues.
The story is the strongest part of the game I'd say. It goes in depth about a lot of things and has a lot of worldbuilding. It blends perfectly with the gameplay and the ending is really satisfying.

Overall one of my favourite games of all time, I wouldn't really give it a 10 but I'd say it's a solid 9/10.

To start things off I had purchased both games while they were on sale which was the only time i'd be willing to pay for it and not full price. The original Subnautica was an absolute masterpiece and I loved every moment of it. The map on the original was so vast and mysterious and had so much to explore. But sadly this next installment did not fall through in those regards. The map is so much smaller and does not carry that excitement that I had with the first. Below Zero also really lacks in horror aspect of exploration. Exploring into the deeper and darker parts of the ocean should carry higher risks with higher rewards but yet it feels like it was missing something. I missed the chills of hearing reapers in the background and having the feeling like I am in real danger. But with Below Zero I felt like there was no real danger's throughout my entire playthrough. Also, the vehicles in this one are god awful. Why would they take a step back and remove the seamoth and cyclops?! I was so turned off after realizing that both of them were never brought over. The sea truck is by far the worst vehicle I have ever used in a survival game. On terms of story I believe that was the only thing I actually liked and the only reason anyone should consider buying this game.  Do NOT buy at full price!

When playing the original Subnautica, this game was set already high on the "want to play"-list. Was not disappointed: With a different main character we are able to explore one more time the bottom on the ocean of Planet 4546B. The stunning graphics, well made dialogues and great game mechanics make this as enjoyable as the original Subnautica. The player will find out more about what is going on on the planet, about the Architects and about the story of the main character (who this time is not being belittled by his colleagues).
The only this i was missing was the Seamoth from the first game, but the Seatruck is a great addition when it comes to versatility. Only small glitches, which CAN cost you a vehicle or two when exploring areas, you are maybe not supposed to explore in the game. Great game, stunning visuals, nice and harmonic soundtrack and not having to shoot enemies all the time. This describes Subnautica Below Zero in brief. Runs smoothly even on older gaming gear - never crashed during my gameplay. Strongly recommended not only for Subnautica fans.

Mechanics, graphics and world are better than the first, but the voice lines and story lack. It's overall a phenomenal game, and I would definitely suggest it to anyone who likes this genre.

Is it as good as the first? I don't think any game released could ever live up to the first. But that doesn't mean that this game is stunningly beautiful, fun to play, and terrifying in the best way possible. This game adds so much onto the original, while still be good old Subnautica. New base parts, new creatures, new vehicles, and new lore. Not to mention quality of life changes.

A main complaint about this game, is that it looses some of the charm that the first had. This game feels less isolated, something the first one did great. But personally, I'm glad they took a different approach on this one. I like the interactions between Al-An and Robin, and learning more about architects first hand. The game does spoon feed you occasionally, but if you're the type to explore a lot (like me), you will often find stuff before they're marked by Al-An. 

Building is back, and better than ever with the new large rooms, Multipurpose/large room roofs, control room, and so much more. Will you build solely for survival or will you decorate. Perhaps a bit of both? There are so many customization options, and parts to find. My favorite new edition is the large room, so much space for activities!

The theme for life and biomes is this game is pretty.... self explanatory. The first game had a more tropical theme, being on a volcano and all. But despite that, this game just feels more lively to me. There's more fish to catch and eat, new creatures that are vastly different than the ones encountered in the first, and deadly new threats. Of course, some fish from the first are still here, like the peeper and bladderfish, but all of the larger creatures have been replaced. Keep an eye out for the Chelicerates, the reapers of this game.

Yes this game is supposed to be underwater for the most part, but I also enjoyed land travel in this as well. The added aspect of keeping your temperature in check is annoying, yes, but it is still a good survival aspect to the game. A well prepared adventurer can easily bypass this issue by bringing coffee, warm fruits, or a certain salad that can be unlocked through Marguerit (the snow suit also helps). The ice worms are horrifying, no matter how many times you encounter them. 

There are two stories occurring in this game. The first one introduced is about your sister, Sam. Sam has disappeared, and Robin not trusting what Alterra says about her disappearance, goes to 4546B in order to uncover some secrets. Through this, you learn a little bit about the people who worked/studied in this cold environment, and a little bit about Alterra's schemes. The second one, which is the one I looked forward to the most, has to do with precursors/architects. This story line can be initiated at anytime, but it is required to reach the ending. Through this, you learn a little more about how the architects lived and interacted with each other, as well as how some of their technology worked and a little bit more about the Kahraa bacterium. I have not personally reached the ending, but I will here soon.

There's a lot more I could talk about, but I feel as if I hit some of the major ones. This game is awesome, and definitely worth buying, especially for it's price! I hope Unknown Worlds keeps up the amazing work.

I got the same first experience as I did in the first game- which is hard to match! More building options, different vehicles and more of an emphasis on survival on both land and sea. The only thing I would say is not as good as the first game is the map itself, as it is smaller and not as complex as the first game. However, the above sea-level portions make up for that and more with new map mechanics and vehicles.

In short: doesn't meet up to it's predecessor, after playing the first game this disappointed me. Might still be worth it if you're into this type of game, when it's on sale.

Reasons why:
- Dialogue is awful. Detailed character backstory is awful. In the first game you could truly immerse yourself in the experience without having to worry about a mouthy protagonist instructing you how to feel. To add insult to injury, the protagonist is written like an annoying teenage girl misquoting plato. Dialogue removes mystique and grandeur from what should be mysterious and grand. Cliché physical presences prevent you from being on your own, surviving, like in the first game. All this ruins the mood of the game and reduces it to a treasure hunt instead of an experience.
- The ice worms are annoying as hell. The ghost reapers are annoying as hell. It's scary if you see it once and it instantly kills you. If you know you can survive it and you just have to step out and repair your gear each of the few hundred times you see one, it becomes a chore. In the first game, you were able to avoid the big monsters. In this one you are forced to face them again, and again, and again, until, again, the mood is thoroughly ruined.
- While this sequel does have some nice areas, the design overall doesn't feel as thought out as the original. It feels like the design team took half of the first game, half assed the rest, and got lucky one or two times. Maybe overconfidence, maybe an attempt to cash in on the success of the original, maybe both.

After finally finishing it months after buying, I only have one word.
Wow.
Wow, the visuals and especially cutscenes are amazing. The animations of Al-An and Marguerit give a whole new immersion to the game, not to mention the insane detail and quality of the cutscenes, especially at the end. I loved the way the game looked!
But also, Wow, another cliffhanger? All this time since playing subnautica for the first time years ago I wondered if the Precursor race survived Kharaa... And we STILL don't get to know?
For the gameplay, I think it is generally better than Subnautica. Some stuff is less overpriced to match the available resources (for example titanium ingots getting cheaper, since unlike Subnautica there is not millions of metal scrap laying around), and new stuff like the seatruck being an actual portable base and the deconstructor/recycler allowing for us to undo accidents are great additions. What bothered me about it though was the lack of novelty, but I guess thats almost inevitable when you make a sequel to a game. A lot of stuff just felt familiar, and while the balance between new and familiar in a sequel is hard to find I think it didn't go very well in below zero. I missed the handholding; In subnautica, you didnt always have a quest running, but once in a while you got stuff happening like other pods or the sunbeam to nudge you into the right direction, while i spent a full 5 hours of gameplay with no new beacons like alien artifacts, so I ended up just using the wiki to find locations of seatruck fragments just to have SOMETHING to do. I also felt like the terrain was less interesting. The variety of biomes in subnautica felt stronger and more interesting.

Overall, the game is great, but for me it would probably have been more enjoyable if that balance between novelty and familiarity I mentioned would be better. I doubt we're getting another subnautica game, and I probably don't want one either. A prequel would be interesting, but then again we already know what happened; A sequel wouldn't really work since, how are they gonna make a full game on the alien planet that still resembles subnauticas unique feel?

If you're a subnautica fan however, the game is a must have. The storyline is very tightly connected to the one of the first game which is really cool.
If you're new, I do still recommend playing the first game though otherwise you'll meet a lot of spoilers in Below Zero.

Subnautica: Below Zero is an absolute masterpiece that flawlessly builds upon the original Subnautica, pushing the boundaries of immersive storytelling and exploration. Brace yourself for an awe-inspiring adventure set in the icy depths of Planet 4546B, where every corner holds secrets waiting to be unraveled.

From the moment I submerged into the crystal-clear waters, I was instantly captivated by the game's stunning visuals. The developers have outdone themselves, delivering a breathtaking underwater world filled with vibrant biomes and awe-inspiring creatures. The attention to detail is simply mind-blowing, making each dive feel like a journey into an alien wonderland.

One of the game's strongest aspects is its narrative. The storyline, accompanied by exceptional voice acting, hooks you from the very beginning. As the protagonist, you find yourself entangled in a web of mystery surrounding your sister's disappearance. The carefully crafted plot unveils itself through environmental cues, audio logs, and encounters with other survivors. The emotional depth and sense of urgency to uncover the truth kept me on the edge of my seat throughout.

Exploration remains the heart of Subnautica: Below Zero. The vast underwater world is teeming with life, and every dive offers a unique and thrilling experience. Whether you're marveling at the luminescent flora or carefully evading the deadly predators, the sense of wonder and danger never wanes. The addition of new biomes, such as the hauntingly beautiful Glacial Basin and the treacherous Twisty Bridges, keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting.

To aid your survival, the game introduces a range of new tools and vehicles. Crafting and upgrading equipment is as engaging as ever, adding a satisfying layer of progression. The Snowfox hoverbike, in particular, injects a thrilling sense of speed and freedom into underwater traversal. Seamlessly blending exploration and survival mechanics, Subnautica: Below Zero strikes a perfect balance that will captivate both new players and veterans of the series.

The sound design deserves special mention, as it amplifies the game's immersive experience to new heights. The haunting melodies and underwater ambience envelop you, evoking a palpable sense of isolation and discovery. The attention to detail in every soundscape is impeccable, enhancing the overall immersion and making each encounter feel alive and authentic.

Furthermore, the developers have exhibited a commendable dedication to post-release support and updates. They have actively listened to the community's feedback, addressing issues promptly and providing regular content additions. This commitment to quality has further solidified Subnautica: Below Zero as a shining example of how to nurture and evolve a game post-launch.

In conclusion, Subnautica: Below Zero is an absolute triumph, pushing the boundaries of what a survival-exploration game can achieve. It combines breathtaking visuals, a compelling narrative, and enthralling gameplay to deliver an experience that will leave you in awe. Without a doubt, it deserves recognition as a must-play title on Steam. Dive into the frozen depths and prepare to embark on an unforgettable journey!

[RATING: ★★★★★]

Subnautica: Below Zero tries to be more than its sequel, but due to poor understanding on what made the original game good, it falls flat on its face. 

On first glance, the game looks pretty great. The ocean is still beautiful as ever, and your expectations are high at this point. 

1.  The Story

The first thing that slaps you in the face is the writing and dialogue. They are some of the blandest, generic and cheesiest scifi-nonsense I ever ever had the misfortune of hearing. In my opion, this is by far, the biggest problem in this game.  In the first game, you only got very brief snippets of dialogue and the story was mostly told via journal entries you could read at your own pace. However, in Below Zero, the story is constantly showed in your face, making the replayability extremely poor.  

2. The Map Size

To have a game about exploration, it feels almost criminal to have substantially reduced map size. The ocean
biomes are laughably small, and a big portion of the map is wasted on the land areas. It was easy to get lost in the vast sea of the original game, yet after 30 minutes of Below Zero, the world already feels cramped.

3. The Land Gameplay

It's terrible. The land areas are just nothing but vast empty fields of ice and snow, without any interesting terrains feature. They are horrible to walk trough, not only because of the annoying freezing mechanic that constantly slows you down, but also you get a fun "mini-game" of avoiding the Ice Worm creatures that just randomly pop-up. They are pretty scary when you first encounter them, but become a regular nuisance afterwards. You can construct a janky hover vehicle, but with horrible controls, it doesn't help much.

4. The Endgame

Remember how awesome it was visiting the alien facilities in the first Subnautica? How you descended down to the Lost River with Ghost Leviathans and then to the lava area each with very different ecosystems? Well congratulations because this game has none of that. There are two biomes you must traverse to get to the 'final base', which by the way is the only big alien base in the game. And guess what? Apart from the color, the biomes are EXACTLY the same thing, with the same Leviathan creature in both of them. 


5. The Submarine

One of the best parts in the original game was finally constructing the Cyclops after finding the required blueprints. It was so awesome to have this huge submarine with you could descent into the deepest areas of the game. Well the devs apparently decided that it was too fun, and removed the whole thing. Now you get this Sea Truck vehicle, that even by name sounds ridiculous.  The modules you get are almost useless, and it is extremely slow and cumbersome to drive, considering it's basically a glorified Seamoth.

Graphics 4/5
Story 0/5
Gameplay 1/5
Atmosphere 2/5
Music 3/5
Price 0/5

I loved Subnautica, but this extension has me worried. Worried about the direction the devs seem to go to, worried they either can't build on or even understand what made the original game so good. 

First off, the map is much smaller. It would not be as much of an issue if it were also denser, with richer and more interesting biomes, yet the opposite is true. Some of the new creatures are genuinely interesting, such as penglings and sea monkeys, but they are a minority compared to the reused assets from the base game, and can't make you really feel like you're exploring a new environment. The Leviathans feel all the same, and represent no credible threat because you see them so often (for real, the end game zone is crowded by them). You'll get used to avoid them by driving straight. At worst they'll take a bite out of your sea truck and leave you alone.

Talking about the sea truck, it is now your main and really only means of transportation. While I enjoy the concept of a more "utilitarian" sub, it's attachments do not reflect it's function as a logistics vehicle, with almost no cargo space forcing you to multiply resource gathering trips while building a base. It's resilience on the other hand, nullifies any threat leviathans would pose to your character. There goes the fear element...

All of those issues compound with another HUGE letdown of BZ: the promised new survival mechanics. Indeed, the game is set in the arctic region of the planet, and thus a temperature system was added. Well, it already existed in the original. But this time instead of the burning heat of the Lava Zone, you'll have to deal with the freezing cold of the Arctic... Or will you? Because FOR SOME REASON cold is only a problem on the surface, leading to some incredibly stupid situations when you will dive in the water to avoid dying of hypothermia... Indeed, the cold only serves as a replacement for your oxygen meter when exploring the surface, and only up until you acquire the Cold Suit which solves it entirely.

And why bother? The surface is a chore that you will have to endure, with the worst vehicle I've seen in a game for a long time: the Snowfox. An Unwieldy land speeder with a tendency to clip through the ground and disappear below the map when you deploy it. So what is the reason to use it? Simple, it is the only way to progress the story, if like me you make the mistake of trying to complete it.

BZ was advertised as a step towards more direct story elements, the protagonist is now voiced (don't worry, the dialogues are awful) and you encounter NPCs. Two of them, and together they'll manage to be less impactful and way more annoying than the Emperor in the first game. The original reason of your presence in Sector Zero will end up as an optional objective, meaning the protagonist can leave the planet without ever learning about her sister's fate. And honestly I can't blame her considering how boring and anti climactic this whole plot was...

Below Zero was a full downgrade when compared to Subnautica, and I don't recommend anyone, including new players to buy it. Play the original, it does everything much better, and for the same price.

I was obsessed with the first game, but this was a horrible sequel. Not the worst sequel I've ever played but to summarize, the biomes are overly cramped and lit way too well so there's approximately zero spookiness, plus they overdid it with the gas sacks making it effectively impossible to suffocate so why even bother with an o2 system? Just say Alan reprogrammed your lungs to breathe underwater. It would fit pretty well with the rest of the 3rd grade writing.  

The seatruck is mid, and there's no cyclops although I can see why, there's basically nowhere to go with it. The snowfox is an actual joke. It has to be. Why would I use a vehicle that just...ejects me every time an ice worm appears? I truly, unironically thought this was a bug. I haven't been this baffled by a gameplay design choice since the legendary Peter Molyneux.

Bottom line, if you loved the original Subnautica then you'll either be moderately disappointed or outright offended by this sequel. If you're starting with this game, it might be like a 7/10...

I liked this game. Not as good as the first but still entertaining. 

I do have  critiques with the shallow story, the music that isnt as good as the original, and overall small map and lack of actual deep biomes to explore underwater. It did seem like this game was less horror-inducing than the first, but that could also be due to vast majority of areas feeling less open and claustrophobic. The game also felt like the difficulty was waayyy tuned down compared to the first. Not only are there significantly fewer dangerous leviathans but even the freezing part seems really hard to die from as long as you build a snowfox or a snow suit or salads. Additionally, i found resources much easier to find (with the exception of magnetite) but that could also be because the map is smaller.

That being said I actually enjoyed the idea of the Sea Truck and found the base building better in many ways than the original with the possibility of complex hybrid sea-land bases. Additionally, I also also enjoyed the increased land masses, although i felt there were some underutilized mechanics attached to land exploration.

I found the gameplay still fun albeit this game felt more like an expansion or DLC, rather than a true sequel. Buy it on a discount.

I wish I could give this a more granular review than a thumbs down.  The game is not bad by any means; the main problem is that it exists alongside the original, and it does everything just a little bit worse.

The main loop of the game is the same as in Subnautica: explore, gather resources, find clues to the mystery, craft upgrades to be able to get to deeper, more dangerous areas, repeat.  It's still a beautiful world and accomplishing your next goal is still satisfying.

The problems:

- The map.  It's smaller, more cramped, full of distinct caves and small twisty areas that lead to the next milestone, and those milestones are often marked by HUD waypoints.  I admit this was probably to address the original game's problem of not knowing where to go next at times, but the result felt less like I was exploring and more like I was completing a series of video game levels.

- Land: The overland areas were not engaging in the least.  The temperature mechanic was a non factor due to the abundance of heat sources, the creatures were never threatening, and the movement out of the water was clunky whether you were on foot or in a vehicle.

- The Vehicles: This has been run into the ground, but the Sea Truck was all the downsides of the original vehicles with none of the upsides.  In the original, the Seamoth zips you around faster than anything, and getting the Cyclops for the first time is a major milestone - it gives you such an amazing feeling (even if piloting it wasn't the easiest thing to do).  In BZ, you get the seatruck early, and that's what you have to use to make progress past a certain point, and if you have to travel across the map, bring something to read.  In the original, there's a choice depending on what you want to do.

Let's not forget the snowfox, which controls like you're drunk and adds nothing except the ability to ignore the temperature mechanics entirely (more than you already were, I mean).

You still get the Prawn Suit.  It's the same Prawn Suit.  You arguably don't need it as much as in the original.

- Tools.  A minor point, but the tools are a bit worse in this game.  Notably, they removed ultra glide fins for some reason.  If you want to go fast, you have to use the Seaglide, the end.  The mineral scanner is a nice addition, but the range is extremely short - if you're looking for a particular mineral you're going to be swapping between it and the seaglide constantly, which is, again, clunky.  The rest of the tools are extremely optional and none of them are particularly interesting.

- Story and Characters.  In both games you are solving a mystery, they're both somewhat interesting but nothing amazing.  The first game had very few characters, as you are a silent protagonist and collect the occasional audio log or transmission.  This game, you have a voice and there are other voiced characters you can interact with in real time.  There are no dialogue options - not inherently a bad thing, but all of the real time (non audio log) dialogue is completely inane.  The "banter" between the two main characters is awful, and about as subtle as a brick through a window. It's by far the worst part of the game.  I don't need a silent protagonist in my atmospheric exploration game, I just wish the dialogue that is there had been revised a couple more times.

If Below Zero were the only Subnautica game, I would have recommended it.  As it stands, the original is better in just about every way, and I highly recommend you purchase and play that one instead.

Did a 6 hour session (first time playing since it was early access) just to have the game crash, and receive a painful reminder that the game has no autosave. Yes, in the year 2023 ( the game received an update in January so I'll qualify that) there are still developers who don't put such a basic & required feature in their game.

Do I recommend the game in it's current state? No. Do yourself a favor and install an autosave mod before playing it. Save yourself the pain. I'm going to sleep on this loss and see if I'm in the mood to start over again tomorrow.

Update: Now that I've installed an autosave mod I've started over. Receiving a comforting "auto save" lag spike every 20 minutes is well worth it so an ADHD person like me doesn't have to worry about manually saving.

And like others said: If you can't get enough of the formula: go and play this as well, but be prepared for some disappointments and frustrations.

Why is that? 
First of all: When I play a game ike this, being subnautic is what I crave. Not getting lost in some mad freezing and overwhelmingly huge landscape. So far, the above see level parts are something to suffer through for me.

Second: Maybe I am mistaken, but I think in the first part I never missed a crucial blueprint, because you either had multiple opportunities to find them or they were scattered along some story related locations anyway. Not so in the second part. Here I gave up after 20+ hours and looked up the coordinates for the first O2 tank upgrade. Because there is just the one place to find it. And nothing important nearby.

Also the story here doesn't catch me nearly as much as the first one. The bits and pieces of what happened at the locations (PDA messages) are a little bit too long and uninteresting for my taste.
On top of that, this one lacks the subtle guidance that helped decide on where to go next.  Here it is a clutter of possibilities across the screen, while I am not even motivated to visit most of them.

Lastly: moth and cyclops :,( 
Having no storage on the truck by default is such a pain. Being a loot monster and not a fan of prawns is not a good combination...

---

I can't remember if I already reviewed this or not. So I'm here to make my voice heard.

The TL;DR is that I have 600 hours in the original game, but only 150 hours in this mess. I have played through the original multiple times, I never even played this all the way through... although my wife has. This game just feels like the wish.com version of the original.

1) Sequels should be bigger, more elaborate in some way. They should expand the universe. This does not. The world feels much smaller. Some say the map is actually smaller, I don't know for sure. But it doesn't encourage you to explore. The game might as well take place in a hallway. You go from here to there, then yonder. You never get that "what's over there?" feeling.
2)  It feels like there's more of a time crunch than the original. Subnautica definitely had a ticking clock. But this feels like you've been given a hard deadline from your boss.
3) There's too much talking!!!! The number one thing that I hate about this game is that they decided to add chatty, canned dialog. This completely destroys the vibe of the game. It makes it more like an interactive cartoon than the immersive experience of the original.
4) Related to #1, too much rehashed content. Basically, slap the word "arctic" in front of the name of creatures from the original. The whole game feels copy/paste.

What it boils down to is that the devs thought they knew what we wanted from a sequel, but they were completely out of sync with the fans. There was real tension and uncertainty in the original. You actually felt like you were trapped in an alien ocean. This has none of that. Instead, it feels like pandering. "Here's that cute fish we know you liked from the first one". "Hey, remember that character?"

I don't know if they're planning a third game. If so, I hope they bring back the aura of the original. No talking, no confining plot... just plop me in the ocean and let me find my way.

The original Subnautica was easily one of the best games I've ever played.  The gameplay of Below Zero is essentially the same as the original, but the story line leaves a lot to be desired.  In fact, the story has a lot of plot holes and doesn't really make sense in general.   Unlike the first, this game just never captured me.  Even the monsters don't seem scary this go around.  If you can get this game super cheap, then pick it up and get a few hours of moderate entertainment out of it. Otherwise, I'd say pass and so you don't spoil how much you loved the original!

Although more like an expansion, and less like Subnautica 2, this is still a good game.  It isn't nearly as scary, nor expansive  like the first.  It does offer more quality of life improvements, but also feels a bit diluted without a real sense of danger the first provided.   (I have since edited this review to reflect the excellent changes from updates including being able to triple the danger and aggression from predators...as well as darken the game)

I'd rather there wasn't a voice for my avatar.  I don't mind playing a female character at all.  But there was a sense of self being stranded in the first that is missing here.  Also, sometimes Robin's thoughts spoken aloud can be a bit jarring, taking me out of the immersion.  It's not as bad as some make it out, and isn't all the time however.

I love the jukebox.  I love the UI tweaks and character portraits.  The music you find for the jukebox in game is not so great though.  Downloaded some free Celtic harp music for peaceful times in my base or sleeper cabin in the truck.  



***edited to endorse after update.  Having options now to make the game darker, more dangerous, and more of a scary challenge in general is game changing.  I can now make predators do more damage and behave more aggressively while also playing with the spawn rates modestly.  This makes all the difference since the regular game before the major update was far too easy and not very frightening.  Now it is scary again.  The seatruck perimeter defense system is not overpowered anymore either.  Plus now there is the seatruck dock and it's wonderful.

Subnautica: Below Zero is often criticized for being "only more Subnautica". That is unfortunately not true.

Below Zero is Subnautica, but worse. Worse in most of the aspects that made the original Subnautica such a masterpiece. (The following contains mild spoilers for the predecessor but I try to keep them minimal. Go play that instead if you haven't yet!)

[list]
  [*] [b]The map is TINY.[/b]
Because Subnautica is about being lost in a vast open ocean - you don't get that here. (It's about a third of the size and you can feel every missing square meter.)
  [*] [b]Low creature variety.[/b]
Meaning the few biomes this game has are even less distinct from each other.
  [*] [b]Precursor sites are insultingly barebones.[/b]
I spent hours looking for the greenhouse location because I couldn't believe that what I had already found was supposed to be all there was.
  [*] [b]Bad story.[/b]
It is nonsensical and collapses in on itself after the first third of playtime / the beginning of the supposed 'story arc'. The dialogue is without choices and feels very sterile. Most of the potentially interesting aspects end up abandoned, unexplained and unresolved.
  [*] [b]Poor atmosphere.[/b]
The horror elements don't work properly for lack of open water. And because you're walking around Alterra sites, you're not exploring anymore - only "re-exploring".
  [*] [b]Bad vehicle.[/b]
I loved the Seamoth. I liked the Cyclops. The Seatruck is an unholy amalgamation that manages to combine the worst features of both without tangible benefit. Slow, loud, unwieldy and with no noteworthy storage or food/drink capacities. (The seatruck dock at least looks cool, though.)
  [*] [b]The land section is pure pain.[/b]
It is big, it is empty, it is bland and only exists to annoy you with unavoidable, random iceworm encounters while the jittery snowfox "glide" makes you nauseous.
  [*] [b]It's the same price as the original?!?[/b]
Really, that's not just rubbing salt into the wound, that's pouring gasoline over it and setting it ablaze.
[/list]

You can skip the next list if you want because those are much smaller problems by comparison, but I still wanted to write them down:

[list]
  [*] The music and sound design are uninspired and much less unique. It's hard to keep BZ's generic roars apart while the looping, biome-specific soundtrack quickly becomes obvious.
  [*] You can not stop sea monkeys from stealing your tools (until spoiler stuff happens, but by then you've already murdered most of them, let's be honest). Also, for some reason they don't rotate when diving diagonally which looks really weird.
  [*] Lots of reused fish swarms. This one boggles my mind because BZ actually has a bunch of new fish designs, you just rarely see them and especially the swarms which are the most prominent form in which you're going to see fish are mostly the ones you already know from the original. Just ... why?
  [*] The new build options are cool but the small map size strongly discourages base building.
  [*] The creature attacks are directly copy-pasted from the original, drawing unfavorable comparisons instead of bringing something new to the aquarium. Furthermore, this might be a weird thing to note but many critters feel much less ... alien than the original designs do. The shark-things look too much like a shark, the shrimp-things too much like a shrimp etc.
[/list]

It pains me to write this because there have been some good QoL changes that were thankfully backported. But this only reinforces my conclusion: What started as a DLC, should have stayed a DLC. I would have loved / would still love to see all of BZ's building options in the original game.

The amount of wokeness thrown into this game during late-beta releases was way too much. I am even an LGBT person and its not cool in my book. For example, they changed the race of your character from a white woman, to a woman of color. And you are now on this planet to learn about your sister having a gay relationship that was unknown to anyone. None of that was part of the story before the game was officially released. But because this game was released during the height of the woke madness, they shoehorned in as much as they could before release. They even changed the voice of the PDA which used to be the same as from Subnautica to give it a woman of color accent. It just screams "lazy and unoriginal" at me. The pre-release alpha and beta versions were legit and are the true colors of the developers. If they had stuck with the original intent they had, it would be a 8.5/10 game for me.   Not everything has to be woke just to be woke. Imagine watching a woke Tarantino film. It would make even the best concept trash on its face. Which is what happened here.

If I spend a majority of a game thinking about how much better the previous game did pretty much everything, I can't really recommend that game. Is it completely awful? Not really. Is it good? Not really. Does it live up to the previous game? Absolutely not. The original Subnautica is an amazing game and it feels like they intentionally tried to take out everything that made it good to make Below Zero. I guess I could recommend if you're really itching for more Subnautica game play but I was that way and now I regret it.

For this one, story takes a huge focus. That can work if you actually write a good story. Apparently somewhere in the games development the story went through a huge rewrite and it really shows. It really reads like poorly written young adult novel. A presumed dead character returns and is a "huge kewl badass", your incredibly dumb protagonist gets a quirky alien in her head who acts as a foil to her personality, and (this one bugs me the most) where did everyone else go? They just left I guess? It's literally never explained. It ruins the atmosphere and feel that really helped carry Subnautica, the loneliness of being trapped in an alien ocean is just not there when you're not alone at any point.

The map is so much smaller and focuses much more on small caverns that are not fun to navigate. You never really need to go to different places to find basic resources because its just everywhere. I never had actual fun exploring. Then the arguably worst part of the first game, the land sections, are heavily expanded upon. And they're way longer and worse! I was close to giving up on the game while exploring the bland and frustrating tundra. 

This point is more personal opinion to be fair but I found a vast majority of the sea life much less interesting, especially the hostile leviathans. The Reaper was this hulking, threatening beast while whatever the Below Zero one was called is just a big shrimp with a vagina face. The Shadow leviathan was kinda cool but by the time I ran into them they were not a threat at all, just one click with the shock module I got for free and he'd let go.

Missing the Cyclops kinda sucks but it makes sense given the tiny map. There felt like no reason to exclude the Seamoth. I will concede the Sea Truck is great though. I hope to see it modded into Subnautica so it can enjoy swimming around a much better ocean and game.

A smaller Subnautica with the removal of everything that made it good with the addition of forced identity politics and a voiced protagonist that everyone wishes she would shut up. Why do we have to play as a character that relates to nobody nor is interesting to be around. If the first game was paid 30$, this one would be 7$. It is only worth bare-bones. Half the game is on land, most of the ocean is void of life and incomplete. There's just a small chunk of biomes that are awesome, even could be better than anything in the first game.

Hearing the development, they paid more attention to how the playable character was meant to be a black bitchy female protagonist with a lesbian sister instead of finishing the base game. Why does Unknown Worlds never bother to finish games before moving on to the next project?

An improvement on its predecessor in nearly every way. The character writing/voicework is wonderful, the plot is even more emotionally touching than the first game, the tech advancement plays better, and it looks stunning. The one thing the original has over this one is the feeling of survival against all odds in an unfamiliar environment. Maybe it's because 4546b isn't as unexplored, maybe it's because I as a player was already familiar with how to survive, or maybe it's something to do with the focus of the plot. Whatever it is, this game doesn't have quite the same "Iceberg Hermit" vibe that the original does. (It still managed to set off my thalassophobia in true Subnautica fashion though.)

None of that is to say that it's worse in any way, just different. And I think those differences lead to a much stronger story. Over all, highly recommend.

If you loved Subnautica, you're going to like this game a lot. It's got the same gameplay loop in a different part of the planet. There are new creatures to meet, new biomes to experience, and the added challenge of dealing with the cold. The exploration, soundtrack, and base building are every bit as good as the original.

If you liked Subnautica, you'll have some fun with this but you probably want to wait for it to go on sale. It's not quite as strong as the original.

The later part of the game drags a bit, though, and moves above water. This was an interesting concept but ultimately felt a little boring. The Snowfox is an awesome idea for a vehicle and I was really looking forward to speeding across the glacier on it, but driving it is annoying and frustrating, and it comes at a time when the game itself gets a little annoying.

What truly holds this game back, though, is the story and how "chatty" it is. Al-an talks at you ... a lot, and it takes away from that feeling of "I'm alone on this planet and I need to figure out what I'm doing" that made the first game so great.

All in all, this is a really, really good game. It's biggest drawback is that you can't help but compare it to the original, which is one of the best games of all time.
