FIRST OFF! I ATTEMPTED TO 100% SUBNAUTICA BELOW ZERO AND THE GAME BUGGED OUT ON THE LAST PART AND HALTED PROGRESSION. HENCE I DID NOT GET THE ACHIEVEMENTS BUT FINISHED THE GAME USING ANOTHER SAVE FILE AND USING CONSOLE COMMANDS. (84% Achievement Completion, Lost 2 Story Achievements coz of the bug)  - Update - I got the last two achievments after playing it again.

Here is my unbiased spoiler free review: 

Gameplay - Same as the predecessor.. Really cool exploring the snow regions and new biomes, we got new creatures, new variations of some recipes, new vehicle etc. The gameplay is the same, but now you got temperature added into the mix as well, so.. that's something you would have to worry about only on land. It plays out decent, and in the beginning, there are markers, but later, there is nothing.. So exploration is key.  I feel that this game was just.. not captivating enough like the first game. The first game was intense! This game? Not so much. Also gonna point out that you can literally completely skip certain areas and also skip many items in the game, making this game not even close to the first game. But ok, I will keep this like a standalone experience. I felt less threatened in this game. I want to feel scared when I am exploring the ocean. The ocean is scary! And also given the fact that the places just do not feel good at times. I think when I first beat the game I was actively seeking out areas and all and even then I missed a few areas. The 2nd time, I basically, again! Missed those areas AND found out that you can completely skip certain aspects of the game which just makes this so bland of an experience. 

Soundtrack - Pretty good. You can build a jukebox and look for discs for soundtracks of the game, or import your own custom music into the game and play it through the jukebox and blast it throughout your base.

Story - The story is bleh at best. It makes 0 sense in the subnautica universe and I feel that there was more potential. Not as good as the first game's story but I'd be fine with this. I feel this story had 0 purpose and was just there for the sake of being there. Plus add in the voiced protagonist with a bleh storyline, it just makes this a boring game (in terms of story).

Now for the worst part of my experience (THIS IS NOT GONNA MAKE ME NOT RECOMMEND THE GAME COZ IT'S JUST 1 THING WHICH MESSED THE WHOLE GAME UP AT THE END, IDK IF OTHERS ENCOUNTERED THIS OR NOT, BUT THIS IS MY PERSPECTIVE)

BUGS - The game.. literally is underwater exploration.. right? Yes, you say.. but guess what? SOME PLACES HAD NO WATER. I didn't use cheats on my original save file, I swear it. The water would just disappear, which made me literally walk on the ocean floor.. I couldn't get into my sea truck, I couldn't parkour to get into my seatruck, I reloaded the save, nothing happened, restarted the game, nothing happened.. Then I restarted the game after an hr and it was fixed. Next, I made it to the end game stuff (I won't say where, but REALLY DEEP for the story stuff) and my game broke once again, this time, literally not letting me progress in the story. I couldn't interact with what I had to interact with to progress in the story, which pissed me off.. Nothing worked.. I couldn't do anything and that caused me to not get my achievement. I couldn't reload my save coz it was already saved when  I bugged out. So, I went and started another save file and enabled cheats, and warped to the locations and finished the story.. And it was literally the final 30 mins of the game!! I can't restart the game for getting back to where I was just to get the achievements and all, which were disabled coz I used console commands on my other save file. I finished the game using cheats on my other save profile and I feel bad that I couldn't do it without cheats. The game was broken which forced me to use cheats and it hampered my achievements. It is so sad that a really good game can be completely destroyed by 1 or 2 bugs. I still will not place a negative review because this game was good. This section will affect the game's score.. Sorry Subnautica Below Zero. 

If the bugs didn't hamper my progress, it would have gotten a 7/10 - GOOD

FINAL SCORE - 6/10 - GOOD

Subnautica: Below Zero is an expansion of the popular underwater survival game Subnautica and offers a fascinating new adventure in the icy deep sea. Despite being a standalone story that takes place parallel to the events of the first game, Below Zero still stays true to the core of the original and offers players a rich and immersive experience.

One outstanding feature of Below Zero is undoubtedly the breathtaking game world. The underwater landscapes are beautifully designed and filled with vibrant fauna and flora. The developers managed to create an icy and mysterious atmosphere that will make players feel like they are in a completely different world. The visual effects and creature design are impressive and add to the immersive nature of the game.

The story of Below Zero is gripping and full of surprises. As a player, you slip into the role of a scientist who investigates the mysterious occurrences on an icy alien water world. The characters are well written and the dialogue is engaging. The game creates ongoing excitement and curiosity as you uncover the mysteries of the environment while fighting for survival.

Below Zero's gameplay mechanics are solid and offer a variety of activities. From exploring the underwater world to gathering resources and building new gear, there's plenty to do. The crafting system allows players to upgrade their equipment and base to better withstand the harsh environment. There are also a number of missions and tasks that advance the gameplay and give the player clear goals.

However, despite all the positive aspects, there are some minor criticisms. Game loading times could be faster, especially considering that it sometimes takes multiple loads to get to different areas of the map. Performance on certain platforms could also be improved to ensure a smooth gaming experience.

Overall, Subnautica: Below Zero is a remarkable expansion on the original game. With its compelling story, immersive game world, and diverse gameplay options, it offers a rewarding experience for fans of the underwater survival genre. While there are some minor flaws, the positives far outweigh the negatives. Dive into the depths of Below Zero and be enchanted by its fascinating world.

It's a great game. It does have a different feel to Subnautica though. The first game is vast and has no map boundaries so it's inherently scary to travel further and further from your life pod. This game has walls on 3/4 sides, so you don't feel that same endless expanse pulling at your sense of scale. I think many areas of the game are less dark and less murky too. These aren't necessarily bad changes, it just means that Below Zero feels more like an adventure/story game than a tense "one mistake and you die" survival game. Part of this may also be due to the Sea Truck being very durable and making for a good battering ram to take out leviathans. It's quite an early vehicle and you feel very safe in it. More safe than I did in the last game's cyclops even. This game does have more complex cave systems though, so oxygen management is more of a concern in this game than it was in the original. The oxygen plants placed throughout the cave systems seem to make it a more enjoyable experience. Instead of exploring a bit and then making sure you get back to the surface in plenty time, you can push ahead and swim between oxygen plants to buy time and explore without feeling like you're on a short leash. 

The story is very different to the last game too. Instead of finding hints and uncovering stories an audio log at a time, this game has characters that talk. None of that is really an issue though as the characters themselves aren't bad. It does make you feel much less alone though, which again removes a bit from the "stranded and desperate" feel the first game had. In that game you'd be left swimming through dark waters with a thudding heartbeat-like track being the only sound. In this one there are rarely moments like that and the frequent chatting with other characters means there isn't time enough for that feeling of isolation to set in. 

Besides the characters, I feel like the story itself is torn in two, and neither is really finished. On the one hand you have Sam's story, where you're trying to find out what happened to her, the whole initial driving plot of the game. This seems to be quickly forgotten though once you discover an alien ruin. You can still kinda follow that story line and finish the work Sam was doing but you never actually find Sam... Or find out what happened to her, I'm pretty sure. Your main character seems to forget about her sister though when she meets a new character relatively early in the game (usually, since it's in the area right next to the life pod location). 
At that point the game becomes more about the ancient civilisation again. Exploring and trying to find their ruins, put together pieces of what happened and find alien blueprints needed to access the end of the game. At which point it's implied that our player character joins the archaeologist character on exploring alien ruins across the universe, apparently having completely forgotten about her sister by that point. 
Of course, I'm leaving out key details and being a bit cryptic to avoid spoilers but personally I feel like the game would have been better off focusing on one of the two stories. Your character could have been sent as a rival corp agent to discover what's going on with Altera's new research outpost, since they seem to be streaking ahead of the competition all of a sudden, for example. Or perhaps they could be a rebel journalist, intent on finding out what secrets Altera is hiding. Or they could be just searching for their sister who's mysteriously gone missing/radio silent after taking work with Altera and being sent to a strange alien planet. Each of the stories is individually compelling but they're not linked in the game. Sam was never involved with the alien ruins, for example. And the alien ruins never had anything to do with Sam's research/work that we end up finishing. Which means you can't have a complete ending since one will have to be a 'soft' ending to that story and the other a hard ending to the whole game. You can't do a climactic "the story lines come together and there's a big epic ending" because the story lines can't come together. 

Anyway, I'm going on too much about the stories, which are honestly a relatively minor part of the game, much like in the first game. The setting is good and it's a lot of fun to explore. Even though the story is weaker and the atmosphere is more "exploration" than "survival" I'd put this game pretty much on par with the original Subnautica. Plus there's a lot more 'on land' parts now. Which not everyone likes but I think it adds something to the game.

TLDR: If you are looking for more Subnautica and more beautiful environments, I'd pick this up, but definitely on sale. This feels like really phenomenal DLC rather than a standalone game. Its size and scope are much more limited than the first, so I don't really feel they should have put it at the same price point. And like the first one, it's better if you go in blind (but I'm going to leave my thoughts anyway).

I will start off saying that overall, I really enjoyed the game. There were some aspects I even found to be an improvement over the original. The story in particular was far superior in my opinion, and I liked the voice acting (though I've seen other reviews saying the opposite, so YMMV). I also loved the seatruck, though a couple of the modules felt fairly useless. It was also nice having more land-based exploration, though that probably could have been implemented better. The new base buildings and the new wetsuit were welcome additions as well. Finally, some of the new creature designs were excellent. I especially loved [spoiler]the shadow leviathans and vent gardens, and the... puffin things with lots of legs[/spoiler].

So the biggest problem, to me, was how limited everything was. There's just a whole lot less to explore, and a whole lot less to find. I mentioned that there's more to explore above ground now, but there's not much variety to the landscape up there. A lot of the surface just felt like filler. The [spoiler]spy pengling[/spoiler] also felt under-utilized. And then underwater, the map has a tendency to just stop. I don't think it's actually the case, but It [i]felt[/i] maybe half the size of the original's map, both in diameter and depth (though perhaps not if you include the surface areas). Further, there was quite a bit of technology I just never used. There were three seatruck modules I never built, and I never used the propulsion cannon. There was also a lot less on which to use the laser cutter. In the original game, my hub base was expansive and had an absolutely huge storeroom full of all sorts of resources, and it always felt like there was some reason to use them. In this game, none of my bases grew very large, and I never felt a need to stockpile resources. I don't know why they even included large kyanite crystals, except maybe to look pretty? There also wasn't as much of a sense of dread in this game. I never really felt like I was in major danger, though I did get spooked a couple of times, of course. [spoiler]I also found it odd that they actually included another living character in this game, and then proceeded to do practically nothing with her.[/spoiler]

The other major problem was progression. They did not balance technological progression well at all in this game, so I often found myself way ahead of where I was supposed to be, and unlocking tech way too early. This on its own didn't cause too many issues, it just made some things redundant, or sometimes I'd have to go back and find some scraps I missed in an earlier area. However, this totally threw off the story. Like I said, I enjoyed the story, but I unraveled it all out of order. And what was meant to be the climax of my sister's story (which I found halfway through the chronology of the story) felt oddly... hollow? Weightless? It had very little impact. The other story was done much better, I felt, and the ending was very satisfying.

Again, I really enjoyed this game, and I hope they continue the series (especially given the ending of this one). But in some ways, it just felt unfinished and unbalanced when compared with the first game. And although I love the seatruck, I still really miss my cyclops ;_;

Would I recommend this game, absolutely. It is still a great game....but... I declared my profound love for the original Subnautica game a while back. Subnautica, the original, is a superb game. And this one, Below Zero, just did not hit the same for me. All the things that made the original game sooooo good were literally eliminated in this one: the utter lack of dialogue and other characters which gave you that deep sense of loneliness, the amazing diversity in biomes -not one looking like the other-, the fun with a seamoth and a submarine which you could turn into a floating home away from home, playing the overall majority of the game under water, the amazing and diverse sea creatures, fun base building....no more.  I did not enjoy base building as much in this one because it was a PAIN to find areas where you could easily build a large base.  There was a clear lack of diversity between the biomes and sea creatures, everything looked alike. The twisted roots quickly became old and annoying, same for the horror that is your new underwater ship. You cannot play with it as you could with your submarine, it is hugely impractical and the parts are annoying to connect. The ice areas and worms...nah...totally unnecessary and destroying what set the original game so apart: the skill do make a good underwater game. And the dialogue...oh my ...it completely killed the entire Subnautica vibe. Completely. As much as I am in love with the original one, this one...no...it felt rushed and incomplete and the devs tried too hard to make it maybe more accessible and easier to play but it destroyed the heart and soul of the base game. But ...again....it is still a great game and if you have not played Subnautica 1 you will enjoy this for sure. For my part...I hope the devs revert back to the roots for the 3rd instalment because I so want to fall in love again with this game.

Review: Subnautica Below Zero

Rating: 5/5

Subnautica Below Zero, the highly anticipated sequel to the original Subnautica, takes players on another thrilling underwater adventure. Developed by Unknown Worlds Entertainment, this open-world survival game offers a captivating and immersive experience that builds upon the success of its predecessor. While it retains the core gameplay elements that made the original game so beloved, Below Zero introduces new features and an intriguing storyline that keep players engaged from start to finish.

One of the standout aspects of Subnautica Below Zero is its stunning visual design. The underwater environments are beautifully rendered, with vibrant colors, detailed textures, and a sense of depth that truly makes players feel like they are exploring an alien world. From the shimmering depths of the ocean to the icy landscapes of the arctic biome, the game excels in creating diverse and visually appealing environments.

The gameplay mechanics in Below Zero are similar to the first game, focusing on exploration, crafting, and survival. Players must scavenge for resources, construct tools and equipment, and manage their oxygen levels as they navigate the vast underwater world. The addition of new biomes, creatures, and resources adds depth and variety to the gameplay, encouraging players to further explore and discover the secrets that lie beneath the surface.

One of the significant improvements in Below Zero is the introduction of a more engaging narrative. Players assume the role of a scientist investigating an alien planet, uncovering the truth behind a mysterious corporation and their activities. The story unfolds through voice logs, data terminals, and encounters with NPCs, creating a sense of intrigue and discovery. The characters are well-written, and their interactions provide emotional depth to the overall experience.

The survival mechanics in Below Zero strike a good balance between challenge and accessibility. While the game presents threats and dangers, such as hostile creatures and changing weather conditions, it never feels overly punishing. This allows players to focus on exploration and the gradual progression of their equipment and base building without becoming overwhelmed by constant threats to their survival.

One aspect that some players may find lacking in Subnautica Below Zero is the overall length of the game. Compared to its predecessor, the main story is relatively shorter, taking around 15-20 hours to complete. However, the game makes up for this with its high replayability value, offering multiple endings, side quests, and hidden secrets that encourage players to revisit the game and uncover everything it has to offer.

In terms of performance, Subnautica Below Zero generally runs well, but it's worth noting that there have been occasional reports of minor bugs and optimization issues. However, the developers have shown a commitment to addressing these concerns through regular updates and patches, ensuring that players have the best possible experience.

In conclusion, Subnautica Below Zero is a worthy successor to the original game, building upon its strengths while introducing new elements that enhance the overall experience. With its stunning visuals, engaging narrative, and immersive gameplay, it offers a captivating journey into the depths of an alien world. Despite its shorter main story, the game's replayability and attention to detail make it a must-play for fans of the survival genre and underwater exploration.

Having played and beaten both Subnautica and Subnautica: Below Zero, this one was just "ok" in comparison to the first one. 

As far as story goes, it felt very short and lacking. Not to say that I didn't have fun on the journey to the end but it definitely felt less emotional than the first did for me. During parts that should have been emotional, it felt very rushed and just like "Okay, that happened. Moving on!" so that was kind of a bummer. 

As far as gameplay goes, it was as to be expected from a Subnautica game. There were plenty quality of life improvements that I enjoyed more in this one than in the first (although they did update the first one to add some stuff from the 2nd game into the 1st so that's awesome!) but overall, if you played the first one, this one is super easy to figure out and learn right out the door. 

The ocean felt smaller. It also felt emptier but not in that scary way that the first one felt where you felt alone. This one felt more like we needed more fauna to populate the ocean. Speaking of population, there IS one specific enemy in the game that you meet pretty early on and without spoiling anything, I truly feel that they should have taken the "less is more" approach with those ones specifically because you end up seeing them so often that they no longer really become scary.   

Overall, I still think I enjoyed Subnautica better than Subnautica: Below Zero but it was still a fun experience overall.  I'd say if you're on the fence with this one, wait for a good sale. I got mine for $13.99 I believe? To me, that was worth the price. If you're a bit iffy, you may want to hold off until it is a bit cheaper. 

Having said that, play both of them, and enjoy the journey.

I find Below Zero more appealing than the first game, which might not be a typical view. It's important to know that Below Zero isn't identical to the first game. They're set in the same world, but the experience is quite different. Below Zero is more story-driven and less focused on scares compared to the first game.

That doesn't mean Below Zero doesn't have scary moments - it does, but there are fewer than in the first game. Also, the map in Below Zero is smaller. This isn't a drawback though, as it allows for more details to be included. And in Below Zero, there are a lot of details.

In short, Below Zero is very different from the first game. If you enjoyed the underwater fears and surprise elements in the first game, you might not feel the same about Below Zero. Still, I recommend giving it a try. If you weren't a fan of the scary parts of the first game, but liked the overall idea, I strongly recommend Below Zero.

Actually just as good as the first game if not better in some ways, not to mention that they finally introduced a map, not an interactive one, but a map nonetheless! 

I actually really liked the smaller map since it had more meaningful exploration, it was easier to get lost in the first game which ultimately just wasted time. I also like that the main materials are easier to find when needed, the addition of mineral detector was insanely beneficial early game too.

That being said, the starting experience such as being thrown in the world forcibly (not by choice like in BZ) and seeing the destroyed starship in the distance was definitely better in the first game, but in BZ it was exciting throughout the game until the very end. 

In the end, they both were awesome games which convinced me to try other survival games. Such a great franchise.

Let me start with some of the good parts:
-Story, engaging 
-Soundtrack, good
-Exploration, great (maybe even more fun than in the first game)
-land segment, nice to explore
-Visually, amazing
-No bugs on my playtrough

But it is not all good news sadly. 
The story, while engaging, I found to be lesser then the first game. The ending was a bit boring and the motivation of exploring is questionable at best form a story perspective. 
It is also much shorter. This could be because I know the gameplay loop now, but it took me about 15 hours less than the first game.
The base building is good, but because of the shorter nature of this game, I didn't find myself needing the base so much. 
The seatruck is nice. It is a mix between seemoth and cyclopes. You can have a mobile submarine, or a big one. Up to you. Modules however were very difficult to find, and not really needed. Outside of the debt module, I beat the game with no additional help.
The game seems easier, I died less. More sources for air were around and animals were not that dangerous.

Other thing to note:
This is not a bad thing, but the game is not scary (just like the first game). I have no idea why others find it scary. I often punched big fishies because they were nibbling on my seatruck (which is not cool :p).
I love the new ice setting. I recommend it for all those that enjoyed the first game. Environmental mechanics are different due to the cold.

I played since early access, and I've enjoyed it from start to finish.
First, I loved the first game and I love the genre, They did many QOL improvements and added enough variation that it no longer feels like a copy of the first one.
That being said, I dislike the story. The original story they had in mind during early access was much more interesting to me, I was curious where they were taking it. We'll never find out, since they changed almost every part of it. The current story works better, but is far less interesting, engaging, and feels almost completely unnecessary. I'm so glad they let us turn it off now in the custom worlds.
Going into it without expectations or knowledge of the other storyline, it might be a bit better. Overall I only recommend playing with the story on to get achievements.

Great game, as good as the first Subnautica, albeit goes in some distinct directions. It's more story-driven, and the story and characters are better developed. For me story was as good (or better) than the first one, but it seems that many people complain about it. I hope the fact that the protagonists are all strong women has nothing to do with this...

The world itself is smaller, and exploring for the sake of it less enticing than the original, so in the end it's a shorter game. However, the twist of having large land areas with actual gameplay is great. Temperature adds another survival layer to these parts, although there are so many ways to deal with it that it becomes less relevant than it could be. Nevertheless, running around looking for shelter and avoiding threats, I had the only moments in Subnautica where it feels like a true survival game.

I played it just after finishing the first game, and the game loop still felt interesting. Being focused in story and exploration, there isn't much replayability (same thing for the original), but what you get is totally worth the price.  In conclusion, this may not appeal to who didn't like the first game, but it's a no-brainer for anyone that enjoyed it (just don't expect EXACTLY the samen thing).

[b] I love Subnautica. I love [i]the hell[/i] out of Subnautica. [/b]

But as I wrapped up my final session of Subnautica: Below Zero and watched the credits, I just didn't feel like it gave anywhere near the same energy and thrill the original game did. I've read many reviews saying that while it wasn't as good as the original game, it was still good. And for the first few hours, I'd agree with that statement. But progressing through and putting more time in, it felt like an entirely different [i]game[/i].

Let's start with the land exploration. The original Subnautica had a bit of exploration out of the sea - it was a  nice change of scenery from the underwater portions, but a miniscule part of the player's overall journey. Below Zero implements its 'temperature' mechanic this way. Being on land will tick away at a temperature gauge, and if it drops to zero, you die of hypothermia. It's understandable to have a mechanic related to heat in this game, but here's the kicker - there's A LOT of land to traverse. I have some qualms about the temperature mechanic itself but what's so irritating is that the land segments seem to overstay their welcome long before you're finished with them. If you built the Prawn Suit for these sections, you're all good, these segments can be traversed without much worry of temperature or injury. But if you're a player like me and traverse these areas without one, the cracks begin to show in the land-based traversal. Your character gets hung up on multiple things, whether they be tiny ankle-high obstacles, scattered materials, or perhaps most confounding, elevation changes. I found myself on multiple occasions leaping around trying to find the spot that would allow me to progress, and this was especially frustrating when I was simply trying to climb a snowy hill or walk towards a vent to warm myself back up. This is interspersed with multiple PDA warnings that hazard 'dangerous weather' and to 'seek shelter'. Thing is, dangerous weather almost seems to be the standard - I'd hear one of these warnings every few minutes when navigating on foot and it made it irritating to navigate the areas where shelter wasn't an option or I'd just left a safe space, although the weather changes themselves didn't seem to alter much. Walking isn't this game's strong suit and as I navigated these areas I found myself desperately wishing to be back in the water.

And while I thrived in Below Zero's initial routine, I found that being in the water here wasn't what it was in the past. Environments seem to have no semblance of connecting with one another - I navigated from a lush green environment full of seaweed and fish to a barren landscape devoid of life, then continued on to find [i]another[/i] flourishing landscape full of lilypads and moss. It's even worse in the late-game areas - what awaits you below are long mazes cramped full of environmental hazards that damage vehicles and lend no semblance of where you are going. Getting lost almost seemed to be part of the game at this point - there are multiple areas that appear to be ways to climb upwards or descend downwards that instead lead the player into a dent in the landscape instead of a tunnel. Why make navigating these areas so irritating to accomplish and so dull to be in when the endgame areas from the last game [spoiler]like the Lost River and the Lava Zone[/spoiler] were so thrilling to find and explore?

This frustration is compounded by one creature[spoiler]- the Shadow Leviathan[/spoiler]. These pricks are found weaving through the tight narrow areas deep under the water's surface, and they take every opportunity to engage the player. Once it makes visual contact, it lets out a roar and weaving and diving through the environment or trying to find a hiding spot is useless at that point - it will find you and it will engage you. They lock you in a grapple animation if you're in a vehicle, and you have to tediously wait as it takes its time munching on whatever you're piloting until it gets bored and spits it out in an entirely random direction. What's worse, by the time you repair your vehicle or heal up and point towards the direction you were initially headed, you could very well get spotted and have to go through the same process all over again. I spent 30 minutes and 2 batteries on an endzone run making my way to where I needed to go between repairing my Seatruck and moving a few feet before it stuck me into yet another attack animation. Remember the Reaper Leviathan animation from the first game? It was horrifying, specifically [i]because[/i] I remember it locking my Seamoth in its maw. From what I recall this happened only once to me but it established it as a major threat, and even though it never happened again I knew to steer clear of the Reapers. And the other threats, like the Ghost Leviathans, had no animations that I experienced at all - they'd glide by you mouth agape and deal their damage in passing, establishing them as dangerous without having to push the concept in your face. Instead, this creature comes out annoying and tedious to deal with after 10 minutes in the landscape they occupy because you can expect to get grappled frequently - AND THEY'RE ALMOST IMPOSSIBLE TO AVOID. The fact that this enemy takes so much time away from the player and insists on being so aggressive pulls a lot of the wonder away from exploring the late-game environments since the longer you spend down there the better chance you have of getting attacked again.

I couldn't complete a review without bringing up the game's lack of direction, either. When you start, the game highlights a few areas of importance and... that's basically it, that's all the guidance you get. From a few highlighted areas on your map, you have to navigate without so much as a map to help guide you to where you're supposed to be going. I don't need handholding, I managed to get through the original game just fine, but in some of the objectives [spoiler]like finding Al-An's body pieces[/spoiler] you are given such little direction on where to go you may not know how to progress. I resorted to using a light walkthrough with little guiding hints instead of outright step-by-step directions and I cannot emphasize how much it made the experience more enjoyable simply because it finally felt like I knew what I was doing again. But that job shouldn't fall on fans - if the game is done right, a walkthrough shouldn't be needed at all.

There are so many other things I could comment on - the reduced vehicle count (the Cyclops and Seamoth are removed, replaced with the Seatruck), the multiple useless blueprints (the pathfinder tool, the repulsion cannon, the thumper and multiple vehicle upgrades all felt like more trouble than they were worth investing in), stockpiling of materials that meant nothing (I had over 10 ion cubes stored in my locker since I found only one blueprint that utilized them in any meaningful way), lack of direction on where to find different materials (I didn't know where to find root pustules, for example), one of the late-game materials being nigh-invisible compared to the rest of the environment... (looking at you, Nickel - and yes, I used the mineral detector) I won't deny that I had fun playing Subnautica: Below Zero, but I would be doing a disservice if I didn't also say that by the very end I was also dying in frustration to complete the game and finish it so I could uninstall it. If you're looking for more Subnautica, I recommend modding the original with content the fans have released instead of trying to relive it playing this, as by the end all I could feel was relief that I could finally stop exploring this game centered on the concept of exploration.

Reading the reviews, many of them praise the first game whilst criticising this one when the same issues they bring up also apply to the first! Strange. Without being a vassal for [insert famous YouTuber's name here] opinion, here's my review.

I abandoned the first Subnautica due to the grind and poor guidance on 'where to go next' but enjoyed elements of it. Unfortunately, in what could have been a huge improvement over the original, they improved little, and even worse: the dev team outsourced the voice of the adviser! Cheapskates.

The problems I have with both Subnauticas:
- Little guidance on game mechanics. Tips at the beginning would be handy.
- Poor or no guidance on progression and where to go next.
- Resource management can be a pain
- Grind
- The base-building mechanic is a little dodgy: they take considerable effort to build, which wouldn't be so bad if the game hinted at where to place them.
- Annoyances. Do creature attacks and traps really do anything other than annoy the player?

How they can improve:
- Solid guidance
- Get rid of the base-building - it's not necessary
- The player's submarine is the base! The player should get a submarine from the start or early on.
- There should be a scanner on the submarine, which would help to locate tech and story progression.
- A 3d map, showing all areas the player has seen
- Beacons should be able to be placed on the 3d map.
These are but a few, but even implementing these would massively improve Subnautica.

I very much believe that only the sweatiest of sweats can complete the Subnauticas. They really are frustrating games and I doubt I'm alone in saying this. It's as though they created the game for co-op play but the guy/gal/thing responsible for the netcode secretly spent all his/her/its time watching cat videos, so they released it for single-player instead.

One more thing: I could only find 2/3 parts of the laser cutter in Below Zero and even went back to search the site with better tech later. It's a bit silly that it's hard to find the parts for a (presumably) important item such as this, especially considering there's lots of areas that you can only access with the laser cutter.

The Subnautica franchise really knows what it is doing -- just the right combination of anxiety-inducing situations with interesting backstory, character development, plot, great building and design challenges. Amazing game with incredible immersive visuals and sound.

This game both *is* and *is not* Subnautica. While it shares the game mechanics, underwater exploration, crafting, resource hunting and open-world design, it is a different game. It is much more story focused, less scary and much less grindy. This was right up my alley and I enjoyed the ride from the moment my pod crashlanded on the planet up until the ending.

That being said, there are couple gripes - where the first game holds your hand and by careful rationing of messages, depth limits and area design guides you to the next tech or base or point of interest, this game lets you pick up the trail of breadcrumbs on your own, which can often times lead to frustration because you missed a key tech or PDA. 

However don't let that discourage you! Once you get used to the way the game talks to you, it all falls in place and you will enjoy a wonderful adventure!

Subnautica: Below Zero - A Chilling and Captivating Dive into the Unknown

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐ (4/5)

Subnautica: Below Zero takes players on a captivating and immersive journey into the depths of an alien underwater world. With its stunning visuals, atmospheric soundtrack, and a sense of exploration and discovery, Below Zero offers a unique and chilling experience that builds upon the success of its predecessor.

One of the standout features of Subnautica: Below Zero is its breathtaking underwater environment. The game presents players with a frozen, otherworldly landscape, filled with vibrant marine life, mesmerizing biomes, and haunting depths. The attention to detail in the game's visuals, from the shimmering ice formations to the unique flora and fauna, creates an atmosphere that is both beautiful and foreboding. The underwater setting truly feels alive, offering a sense of wonder and mystery that drives players to explore further.

The storyline in Subnautica: Below Zero adds depth and intrigue to the gameplay. Players take on the role of a scientist investigating the disappearance of a research team on an alien planet. The narrative unfolds gradually, revealing secrets and unveiling the truth behind the mysteries of the planet. The engaging characters and well-paced storytelling keep players invested in the journey, while the addition of audio logs and environmental storytelling adds layers of immersion to the overall experience.

Exploration is at the core of Below Zero, as players navigate the treacherous underwater world and uncover its secrets. The game offers a variety of biomes, each with its own unique challenges and resources. From the frozen tundra to the eerie depths of dark caves, there is always something new to discover. The inclusion of new vehicles and equipment expands the player's abilities, allowing for deeper dives and more efficient exploration.

The survival mechanics in Subnautica: Below Zero add an extra layer of challenge and immersion. Players must manage their oxygen, food, and water supplies while fending off dangerous creatures and navigating hazardous environments. The sense of vulnerability and the constant need to gather resources and craft essential tools create a compelling gameplay loop that keeps players engaged and motivated to explore further.

The game's audio design is exceptional, contributing to the overall atmosphere and immersion. The haunting and atmospheric soundtrack perfectly complements the underwater setting, enhancing the sense of isolation and mystery. The sound effects, from the eerie calls of distant creatures to the gushing of water currents, further immerse players in the alien world, creating a sense of tension and wonder.

However, Subnautica: Below Zero does have a few minor drawbacks. The game's performance can be inconsistent at times, with occasional frame rate drops and glitches. The survival mechanics, while adding depth, may feel repetitive or grindy to some players. Additionally, the game's early access nature during the review may mean that some features and optimizations are still being developed and refined.

In summary, Subnautica: Below Zero offers a chilling and captivating dive into an alien underwater world. Its stunning visuals, immersive atmosphere, and engaging storytelling make it a worthy successor to the original Subnautica. Whether you're drawn to the game for its beautiful underwater vistas, the thrill of exploration, or the intrigue of its narrative, Below Zero offers a unique and compelling experience that will keep you hooked from beginning to end. Dive into the unknown and uncover the secrets that lie beneath the icy depths.

I've come across numerous negative feedback for this game, typically from players who had previously experienced the original Subnautica. However, my perspective differs greatly because Subnautica: Below Zero was actually my first introduction to the series. Approaching it as a blind playthrough, I found immense enjoyment in the game. After completing Subnautica: Below Zero and subsequently starting the original game, I was pleasantly surprised by how much I appreciated them both. It's worth mentioning that while the second game didn't diminish my enjoyment of the first game at all, there were a few spoilers about it.

If you haven't played any Subnautica titles yet, I'd recommend starting with Subnautica: Below Zero to experience the joy of a blind playthrough, and then diving into the original installment. However, it's important to note that this is just a personal recommendation based on my own experience.

A good game. Gameplay and controls are just as solid as its predecessor and the new frozen setting is graphically appealing and fun to explore (bonus points for having the devs use area designs in this game that were scrapped in subnautica, like the twisty bridges). Below Zero also introduces quality of life features which are overall nice to have. What bugs me however, are the new vehicles. The snowfox is cool but basically just a seaglide on land. The cyclops and seamoth have been removed in favour of the seatruck, which is a good way of integrating the "mobile base function" in a smaller map, however the iconic status of those 2 makes the loss a bit bitter. While the new fauna is uniquely designed and interesting to scan and learn about, what i am missing is the scare aspect of fear. The new leviathan designs are intimidating but there arent enough of them. There are also less deep dark zones like the bulb zone or the lost river. Everything is brighter and less intimidating. 
Verdict: Smaller scale than the first game, beautiful environments and rock solid survival mechanics.

Another Great game by the same developers!, - 10/10 - 

- The design of the creatures and fauna are well put together,
- Lots of dialog in this one game than in the first game,
- I mentioned in the review in Subnautica - This takes patience and time and effort instead of using some sort of teleportation to get here and there easily and beat the game quicker (once you discovered the area you go to),
- I like how I can design my base and decorate the interior though having a pet that isn't stuck in a aquarium  or outside in the ocean but can move around the base would be a great addition to Subnautica and Subnautica Below Zero, but the Trivalve pet will have to do - You can have multiple with is great (2 Yellow & 4 Blue), better then having one in the first game or a chance to get another in a time capsule.
- Sea monkeys are my favourite since they bring you items.

- DO NOT GO IN THE DEAD ZONE!, it isn't like the first one where you have time to escape, no, the Void Chelicerate will be right on your trail without time to think,

  - SPOILER -

If there will be a third Subnautica, which I hope that there is, I hope that they will continue the story of Robin and AL-AN on his home planet on his search of any survivors of his kind and get to explore the planet that I saw in the ending cut-scene, Because to be honest the whole game-play and story-line felt like an intro to something bigger and more greater.

and also being able to going to the void where you see nothing but darkness and just a guide to maybe to scan some items for your base or PDAs to discover or even to discover a new part of the map that other researchers or survivors have discovered before your character got arrived - it would be a great addition to the game since it would increase the scare factor & all.

It would also be cool if you go deeper than 2000 meters with more deadly leviathan class creatures.

 - END OF SPOILER -

I enjoyed it. I enjoyed it less than Subnautica, but I enjoyed it. I miss the Cyclops (never was a fan of the prawn suit, so I never made it, so carrying things on the back of the seatruck didn't matter for me). I don't care as much as others for the forced narrative, but I did prefer just "I am here. Why? What is going on?" VS having two storylines. This is sadly the only game which I believed I would enjoy, but was severely let down by. The experience of the game is very much the first trailer. Not exactly afraid, just mostly mildly annoyed that you keep getting attacked by different sea monsters.  It's not like the first game, at all. The plot feels super shallow, and I completed the game in a quarter of the time it took me to complete Subnautica. The above ground sections were annoying because of the cold meter and how large the areas were, but all of that goes away the instant you find the snowfox, and then the areas are over in 2 seconds. The normal map is super small, with every 200m or so being a new biome with just a large ravine that goes super deep inside it. At only one point did it feel like Subnautica, and that was exploring the underwater Altera mining site, and that was very brief. There's nothing really to the story, you sort of arrive, find some alien stuff, find some more, and leave. Honestly the main point you're on the planet, your sister's death, feels like a subplot. The main character really doesn't do anything significant at all, except optionally finish what their sister was trying to do. If someone else was trapped on the planet, it would change absolutely nothing about what happens. Sorry, but this one missed the mark on interesting plot, horror, and survival game. 3/10, only play if you really want just want some DLC areas to explore after finishing Subnautica.

Please someone tell me why the developer who struck gold with a unique underwater based game, in an industry where literally every other company is making survival games on land. Thought what "SUBNAUTICA" needed was a labyrinth of a small, monochromatic, boring, ice, wasteland. One that you have to go around checking useless cave after useless cave untill you find something meaningful.

What I liked about this game is that there is so much to explore on the planet with many different biomes and creatures. I also liked that the game didn't just revolve around being on the waters all the time like the last game. In this game you get to be on land too where you explore caves made of ice. The best part of the game though is the ocean animals and the large monsters hidden in the depth of the waters. I recommend this game to people who love survival and enjoy exploring Alien planets but would not recommend this game to people who want to have a multiplayer experience because there is no multiplayer mode in this game.

Having played through the first game multiple times, I decided to return to Below Zero again. I had remembered fans of the first game having disliked Below Zero and didn't really understand all the hate the first time I played the game through. After finishing (not completing, but decidedly not returning to) my second play through, I can safely say that I get it now.

Here's everything wrong with the game:

1. Progression - Progression in Below Zero is completely uneven. Maybe twenty minutes into my run, I had found Outpost Zero and scanned several blueprints that would be considered mid-late game in the original Subnautica. I don't think I even had a Seaglide yet, let alone a builder tool. This phenomenon continued throughout the game, and I often felt simultaneously over and under geared.

The depth mechanic that facilitated progression in the first game is pretty much non-existent in Below Zero; you can comfortably navigate about 80% of the (meaningful) map with a basic Seatruck, Seaglide, and Oxygen plants. As a result, there's no real order in which you gather blueprints and experience events, and it makes the whole experience very disjointed.

2. Characters - one of the biggest changes from the original is greater focus on characters and dialogue. This wouldn't be an issue if the characters weren't all unlikable, childish, one-dimensional caricatures. The writing is absolutely awful, and I felt embarrassed for the voice actors every time I listened to a recording. I completely understand Alterra's decision to stick all of these people together out in the middle of icy nowhere.

Robin is a whiny, jaded know-it-all, and her conversations with Alan sound like something out of an undergrad philosophy dormitory common room. I don't even know the name of the protagonist from the original game, but after a few of these conversations I thank him wholeheartedly for keeping his mouth shut throughout the first adventure. Love that guy!

3. Large Areas - While many of the new biomes are great (Twisty Bridges, Lily Pads), there are some infuriatingly large, empty areas that the game forces you to slog through. The two overland areas essentially serve to be as annoying as possible to get all the way through, just to grab the one thing you need and never return. They are large seemingly for the sole purpose of being time-consuming and confusing to navigate; that's the challenge. There is an alien gateway shortcut in one of these overland sections that literally takes longer to utilize than just walking to the end destination - what?!

Don't worry though - large, useless areas aren't just limited to the land. The end-game deep biomes are just as huge and empty as the overland areas. Subnautica's Lost River was undeniably huge, but despite it's name I never remember actually getting lost. The tunnel does a good job of guiding you to the end of the game. The deep areas in Below Zero are twisting networks of interconnected caverns that all look the same, and I found myself going around in circles until I managed to get lucky and find the tiny little area the game had me looking for.

4. Boring, Annoying Leviathans - the Reaper put Subnautica on the map, I don't care what anyone says. There are areas in the first game I still haven't been to after maybe a dozen playthroughs because those things are so terrifying (although pretty manageable in the end). Leviathans in Below Zero are the opposite. Save for the Vent Garden (that thing is awesome, maybe the best five minutes of the game), the new Leviathans are all unintimidating and incredibly frustrating to manage.

Remember what I said about the huge, empty deep zones? I forgot to mention that, while cruising around in circles looking for the next place to go, you're going to get grabbed by the Shadow Leviathan roughly every thirty seconds, spend the next thirty seconds repairing your ship, travel maybe 100 meters, then rinse and repeat. ALL THE WAY DOWN! Unlike the Ghost Leviathans, the Shadow Leviathans can pull you out of any tiny crevice; there is no escape.

In the end, this is what killed my playthrough. I got to the last area deep down at the bottom of the map, only for the game to inform me that I needed to turn around and brave the onslaught of Shadow Leviathans again to collect the wide variety of resources I'd need to complete the game. It was at that point, having re-experienced Below Zero to my (dis)satisfaction, that I decided to power down and call it quits. I can only pray that Robin stays in that deep dark cave at the bottom of the sea and never has a chance to run a power drill between another player's ears ever again.

Subnautica Below Zero is a fantastic expansion of the original game that takes place in a new, icy world that offers an exciting and challenging experience for all players. The game introduces new mechanics, creatures, and an enthralling storyline that is sure to keep players hooked from start to finish.

One of the best features of the game is the high level of immersion it provides. The game's graphics are stunning, and the icy underwater world is full of surprises and dangers that make it a real joy to explore. The game's attention to detail and its unique sense of atmosphere makes it a truly captivating experience.

Another great aspect of Subnautica Below Zero is the integration of new gameplay mechanics, such as the ability to ride on some of the game's creatures and the introduction of new vehicles. These mechanics add even more fun and variety to the already enjoyable gameplay.

The game's storyline is also a highlight, featuring a thrilling narrative that has multiple surprises in store for the players. Each new discovery and revelation is a testament to the game's excellent writing and fantastic world-building.

Moreover, the game's sound design is truly superb, with ambient noises and sound effects that perfectly capture the atmosphere of the icy underwater world. The game complements this with a mesmerising soundtrack that will leave you impressed.

In conclusion, Subnautica Below Zero is an excellent expansion to the original game that offers a challenging and enthralling underwater adventure with breathtaking graphics and an immersive atmosphere. If you loved the first game, or are looking for an engaging and unique open-world exploration game, Subnautica Below Zero is absolutely worth checking out.
Everything the original had, but more story-line, and less to frustrate the average player. All in all, a most enjoyable experience :)

I wouldn't buy this unless you're a die-hard Subnautica fan that is dying for a new experience. Otherwise, just play the first game.

[b] TL;DR: Even without the novelty the first game provided at launch, Below Zero manages to give a solid experience. I recommend playing, preferably after playing the original one. [/b]

(+) Below Zero improves in some areas relative to the original game: better overall visuals, less glitches, way more varied environments.
(/) It preserves the stressful aspect of discovering new biomes while not being sure where danger may lurk, though the effect will likely not last as long if you already played the previous game.
(-) It overall has a much smaller variety of underwater obstacles (including enemies) and a story that often feels like an afterthought and may be hard to follow (specifically what is expected of the player).

In general, while the world is significantly smaller than in the original game, it is also more focused while attempting new things (more importantly, a few new building blocks for bases, and a new exploration feature which sees the player surviving the cold on land). After spending almost 30 hours in the game to finish all the "quests" at a relatively rushed pace, it doesn't feel like a DLC at all, although the first few hours may give such an impression considering how the game's foundational mechanics remain similar.

Accessibility-wise, the difficulty settings let you customize a preferred experience properly. Not necessarily being a big survival-game player myself, I chose the Freedom difficulty setting, which removes the thirst and hunger mechanics, and at the very least, I can say I didn't feel like I missed much of the game. I'd recommend the setting to people who prefer exploration over survival anytime. 

On the other hand, not unlike the previous game, the way forward is not always clear, especially during the last third of the game, where clues only appear when you happen to get very close to where you are supposed to go. The lack of a conventional mapping system, a tendency of vagueness within dialogues and logs, some specific items being surprisingly easy to miss (nickel ore for example) as well as a tendency to design very labyrinthine biomes can make progression difficult without a guide. You might at least want to follow one on the side if you absolutely don't want to do backtracking: the game has a mildly frustrating habit of halting progress by having you suddenly need to build something using resources you probably didn't think of bringing with you, considering the limited inventory space.

In summary, it expands very well on the original game, offering a more limited in size but a much more visually appealing world. In fact, if you are more into exploration games than survival/horror games, you might even prefer Below Zero. Don't be ashamed to look at a guide occasionally if you're lost, don't want to miss out on important stuff, or want to limit backtracking.

Я наиграла 16 получается часов, чтобы в итоге дойти до предпоследнего глубоководного биома, который в ней есть, и понять, что больше чем, что, я уже видела, я больше в игре не увижу. И это был момент глубочайшего разочарования, потому что я надеялась что вот-вот игра все-таки чем-то меня удивит.

Имхо, они разрушили все, что делало притягательной Subnautica. 
* Несмотря на то, что многие говорят, что игра стала красивее, я бы поспорила, что большинство подповерхностных биомов выглядят особенно блекло и скучно. Игра улучшила освещение, стала выглядеть чуточку "реалистичнее", но потеряла в в какой-то красочной стилизации. Есть, конечно, несколько биомов, штуки может быть 4-5, которые действительно выглядят сочно, но в целом игра никакая.

* Карта невероятно тесная. Я так и не нашла привлекательное место для построения большой базы. Абсолютно отсутсвует ощущение масштаба, как в оригинальной игре.

* Новый введенный транспорт - отвратительно ужасный. Seatruck, который пытается быть и Мотыльком и Циклопом с треском проваливается быть и тем и другим. Медленнее и менее маневленный, чем Мотылек, и менее функциональный и кастомизируемый, чем Циклоп. И еще он уродливый. (вы только сравните его дизайн с транспортом первой игры!). Snowfox имеет абсолютно неотзывчивое инерционное управление, и  с ним так колбасит камеру, что вообще вызывает укачивание. В итоге из юзабельного только Prawn Suite, которому еще и улучшили вертикальный подъем.

* Главная героиня - неприятная личность, которая умудряется проигрывать в харизме немому протагонисту первой игры (браво!). Типичная сильная независимая женщина без каких-либо запоминающихся черт или мотиваций, а ее разговоры с компаньоном лишь заставляют побиться головой об стол от их тупости.

* Из предыдущего пункта вытекает проблема с сюжетом, который заслуживает звание максимум функционального, но точно ничем не захватывает и не вызывает интереса. Говорить про сюжетные дыры даже не хочется.

* Атмосфера страха неизветстного - основная фишка оригинальной игры - порушена на корню и тут полностью отсутствует.

Скажу игре в плюс, что Unknown Worlds подтянули техническое состяние игры и я вроде бы не натыкалась за свои 16 наигранных часов на что-то вопиющее. Оптимизирована она тоже лучше, чем оригинальная Subnautica. Хотя проблема с подгзрузкой на глазах кажется была решена уменьшением дальности видимости, что не есть гуд и прибавляет к ощущению тесноты игры.
Итого, я не вижу реально причин тратить время и деньги на Below Zero. Лучше просто еще раз пройти Subnautica.

[b]TLDR verdict: Play it if you're itching for more Subnautica, but lower your expectations going in.[/b]

Below Zero is pretty much classic Subnautica with some QoL improvements, a new story and my two least favorite elements -- setting the entire game in an arctic area, and requiring the player to spend a substantial amount of time out of the water.

Underwater gameplay is Subnautica's hallmark and it does oceanic exploration better than any game I've played. It's the primary strength of the franchise. While the Snowfox is pretty cool, surface gameplay just isn't as much fun.

Mostly you'll spend time zipping through mostly featureless arctic landscapes and trying to negotiate tight caves, which the delicate Snowfox is not well suited for. There's also an incredibly annoying bug that has the Snowfox sinking into the map, much like the Seamoth did in the original Subnautica. If you pack up your Snowfox, save the game before you redeploy it, otherwise you're going to find yourself trekking back a long distance on foot, hopping between thermal vents to stave off hypothermia.

Then there's the Cyclops, or lack of it.

While the Seatruck does have some good utility, it lacks the wow factor of the Cyclops, you can't customize the interior and two of the modules are pretty much entirely aesthetic. (The sleeper module and the aquarium, which gathers fish for your base aquariums. The sleeper does offer a small amount of additional storage space, but it's negligible.)

By removing the Cyclops the devs took away a fan favorite toy, and they also made the map more compact with a greater focus on vertical exploration instead of horizontal. While I do like some of what they've done, much of it is claustrophobic and the biomes lack the wow factor of areas like the Lost River from the first game.

If you're a Subnautica fan, you'll probably like Below Zero despite its flaws. I find I'm losing interest in the extended time spent on the surface. Here's to hoping a third game gives us a huge ocean without snow or ice, a proper submarine (perhaps the Atlas?) and the kind of biome, plant and fauna variety of the first game.

This game does not stand well as a sequel. 

Starting with the positives, it is a beautiful game a visual improvement over the first. There are more special interactions with some of the wild life not simply floating or biting. The base building improvements are good,

Now for the negatives, biggest was the ambiance, gone was the feeling of terror when diving into the sea. The map is smaller, even including the land zones now included. Instead of a vast ocean you will encounter tight spaces and winding corridors. The almost all of the "enemies" in the game lack any sort of uniqueness, almost all are just grab and bite. The story makes little sense and the main objective at the start of the game can be completely ignored, this makes progression feel convoluted when compared to the stream lined progression in the first game.

You can skip this sequel in my opinion, there is not much it offers that the first subnautica cannot.

The Dev's didn't give you a Subnatica sequel (Freeguy Referrence).  If I understood the story this appears to take place after the alien gun is shut down.  I found 2 or 3 wrecks which offered back story, immersion and great places to explore.  If you were expecting the game to hand everything over like it did in the first.  Your going to be disappointed.  Its hunting season.

I enjoyed the game.  I played the first and jumped instantly into this game.  I think world, challenges and change in approach kept the game feeling new.  I didn't feel like it was a remix of Subnatica.  So fear one can be removed from the list.  Lets tackle the next fear.  Did they remove the underwater aspect for land?  Yes and No.  I would say there is a bit more land mass (possibly, it was hard to judge the same) than the first but it was not a place I spent the most time.  I spent hours in my seatruck exploring unlocking, following the story.  They added new challenges I felt were fitting for changes in the game.  The flow was different but fitting.  The map size I (not positive) was smaller but they didn't waste any space which really made adventuring super fun.

I had no crashes in the game.  Adventuring was great.  Biomes were interesting and fun to explore.  They added way more stuff to make (I didn't use half of it).  Since this was not subnatica they continues on their tradition of building a world and filling it with life / history.  Just like the first exploring was really rewarding and you can see the foot prints of Alterra.  I love the fact they build off alien experience from the first.

Thank you Dev's for delivering a really cool experience.  If the rumor are true and you are in production of the next game and releasing it on unreal.  I really look forward to what you give us.  If you have played the first I recommend this game for you.

"How bad can it be?" I thought, as i read the reviews. Let's just say I hope this game doesn't kill the series - Subnautica 1 was brilliant but just about every change made in this game is a downgrade. They are building on their past success but the design decisions were bad. I have replayed the first game a few times, want a third game to be made, but I will never replay this one. Issues:

-The zippy transport and strong sub you had before is replaced with a slow, clunky long vehicle which is basically a moving base instead of an exploration vehicle. Takes too long to move around, can't evade anything, gets stuck. Jack of all trades, master of nothing. I swear, I might even have liked this game if I had a seaglide, but they just deleted the damn thing.

-Huge portions of the map are on land, and there is less underwater area to explore than before. The land section is a big gimmick and has nothing to do with the rest of the game. Hey devs: this is a game about being in the ocean. 

-Scary biomes are replaced with bright and colourful biomes. They look nice, but I no longer get the same feeling of dread/terror from the first game. There are also too many parts where you enter a linear cave system with a completely different look to everything else and it feels way too 'designed'. Like I just swam into a piece of concept art instead of a natural cave system.

-Characters and voice logs are dull. No one is stranded and so everyone is just talking about penguins and shit. I hate everyone in this game, and I don't care about anything they are talking about, even if the penguins are cute.

-The story is a patchwork mess, no longer a fight for survival it is a quest to find your sister and then talk to an alien or something. The simple and primal motivation of survival works so much better in a survival game.

I enjoy the base building, which is mostly the same as before, and it is still fun to explore new places. Only worth it if you replayed the first game and just want a bit more to explore.
god

The logical evolution of the original Subnautica. Everything is tighter this time around, including the map, for better or for worse. The bugs and performance issues of the original Subnautica have been wholly squashed, and any tedium of the original gameplay loop has been addressed. Ultimately, it's more of the same of the first game, in a slightly smaller, denser package.

Subnautica Below Zero is a great game in itself but can look bad when compared to its predecessor 'Subnautica' which is arguably one of the best survival games of all time. This is because it goes on a different approach in the survival genre to subnautica, where instead of having a lonely scary vibe it feels more bright and happy. This is mainly because both you and other characters in the game talk (unlike subnautica where the only character in the whole game doesnt even talk). 
I would highly reccomend this game to any past subnautica fans who would like a bit more from the series or new fans of the series who would like a (slighty) less terrifying version of the original.
Overall I would rate this game a good 8/10

Subnautica Below Zero

Subnautica: Below Zero delivers an immersive and enthralling underwater adventure that will keep you hooked from start to finish. Set in a frozen alien world, this standalone expansion to the original Subnautica offers a fresh and thrilling experience that builds upon its predecessor's success.

The game's visuals are breathtaking, with stunning environments that beautifully portray the icy depths and diverse marine life. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the shimmering ice formations to the intricate designs of the underwater flora and fauna. Exploring the vast and mysterious underwater biomes is a visual treat that never fails to impress.

The storyline of Subnautica: Below Zero is engaging, introducing you to an intriguing narrative filled with mysteries waiting to be unraveled. As you navigate through the chilling waters, you'll encounter a range of memorable characters and uncover the secrets of the alien world. The progression feels natural, and the game strikes a good balance between providing guidance and allowing for personal exploration.

Gameplay mechanics are solid, offering a mix of survival elements, resource gathering, crafting, and exploration. The underwater setting introduces unique challenges, such as managing oxygen levels and dealing with dangerous sea creatures. The addition of new vehicles and equipment expands the gameplay possibilities and enhances the sense of discovery.

One of the standout features of Subnautica: Below Zero is the sense of atmosphere it creates. The ambient sound design, coupled with the haunting music, immerses you in the depths of this frozen world. The moments of tension and awe blend seamlessly, leaving you with an unforgettable experience.

While the game does a fantastic job of captivating players, it is not without a few minor drawbacks. Some players may find the pacing a bit slow at times, and certain areas might feel repetitive. However, these issues are overshadowed by the overall excellence of the game and its ability to keep you engaged throughout the adventure.

In conclusion, Subnautica: Below Zero is a worthy addition to the Subnautica franchise. It combines stunning visuals, a compelling storyline, and immersive gameplay to create an unforgettable underwater journey. If you're a fan of exploration, survival, and captivating narratives, this game is a must-play. Dive in and prepare to be captivated by the wonders and dangers lurking beneath the frozen surface.

The alpha version is only available to patreon supporters. You will have access to the Alpha version when you become a patreon supporter at the address below. As a Patreon supporter, you will continue to have access throughout the entire alpha process, even if you don't renew your membership.

The mod is free and will always be free. The purpose of the mod is not to make money. Patreon is only for motivation and to cover the costs of the mod. Only the alpha version is accessible to patreon users. The beta and all other subsequent releases will be accessible to everyone.

This is better that the first Subnautica in some aspects, worse in others. Better in that you get more tech to play with and that there's new, more interesting environments to explore, worst in that the progression seems kind of... off. For example, in the whole game, there's only one Rebreather piece of tech. If you miss it, the rest of the game gets exponentially harder because you can't spend more than a few seconds outside when you go to depths below 100m. You also had more clues on where to find bases and alien facilities in the first game. In this one, the clues are very vague even when they give you a map. Then, there's the boring surface section where there's a weather event that forces you to seek shelter every 2 minutes. It is nuts!

All in all, it is an okay game and if you liked the first Subnautica and want more of the same with some questionable design decisions, then get this.

It's a good game but the first one was much, much better. The land exploration on this one is super confusing and annoying... Maze-like map design that you have to go through with almost no vision due to constant storms and without any kind of guidance except your crappy compass that doesn't really do much.

They removed the original vehicles that in my opinion were the best thing about Subnautica. They were replaced by the Seatruck, a modular vehicle that again... doesn't give you any sort of guidance. The only tool you can use for underwater navigation is your Pathfinder tool or Seaglider and for that you need to keep exiting your vehicle in order to check your position. 

So yea... if you enjoyed Subnautica 1 expect a lot of disappointment from this one. It's still fun but mostly annoying.

Be warned - this review contains spoilers.
[hr][/hr]
I enjoyed playing this game thoroughly. From the very beginning to the very end, it was just like diving into the known gameplay of Subnautica enriched by new environments and things to do! It really sucked me right in and I could not stop thinking about this game [i](to my boo's annoyance lol!)[/i].

I did however find certain bits of the game frustrating. (TL:DR – There are annoying bits in the game, but it’s still FLIPPIN GOOD, and you better go get it and cherish it <3)

Cons:

[spoiler]- Operating Snowfox was difficult. I think I would've enjoyed the on-land bits of the game more if Snowfox was easier to manage.

- No Cyclops broke my heart. I loooved operating Cyclops in the first Subnautica game and sneaking around with the silent mode running and freaking out because it was draining my power cells like crazy, but I had to get past this leviathan in the cavern! Seatruck was excellent idea with the mix-and-match solutions, but I found operating it a bit more annoying and it did not leave any possibility really to sneak past all the aggressive fauna. Just running through everything on high speed because there is no other way for one to do it was certainly less enjoyable to me. I missed the planning, the sneaking...

- I think the aggressive fauna sounds were a bit overdone. Every time I was out the sounds the varied sharks made were [i]freaky[/i], but... At some point, and quite soon at that, they became too much. I got used to them to the point when an actual leviathan was nearby screaming, I would just ignore it because I got so used to the freaky sounds of much more common aggressive creatures. Imho having too much freaky sounds in the game diminished the very specific fright of encountering one of the truly scary things out there.

- Sometimes I was feeling very lost in the game and what am I supposed to do. It might be me missing some important bits and clues in the gameplay, but I think the first game had much more guidance to let you know where to go next if you want to progress the story. In Below Zero sometimes I would sit in my base and just google things on my phone because I had no clue what to do next. But again, that could just be me, I'm not the sharpest bulb in the shed.[/spoiler]

[i]And yet...[/i]

[spoiler]- I was absolutely captivated by the story. Learning what happened to my sis, learning the dealio with the frozen leviathan, learning all the corp bullshit! Putting all the pieces together was awesome! <3

- Spy Pengling will forever have a place in my heart <3 And its lil dialogs <3

- Al-An! OMG Al-An! I'll forever be simping for Al-An, especially after learning their story and their vulnerability, their desire to put things right. My babe <3

- Marguerit! When I first time heard her voice, I was simply gobsmacked, and then when I actually met her out there, I was squeeling like a teenage fangirl! I loved her from the PDA recordings in the first game, and I loved her in Below Zero <3

- Jukebox <3

- New plants <3

- Playing a character that actually talks <3

- Freaky alien shit <3

- Sea monkeys <3[/spoiler]

Subnautica and Subnautica Below Zero are two of the very best survival games in existence. The artwork behind the graphics is quite beautiful, this is the only game that has even tempted me to consider paying big bucks for VR. There is the perfect amount of mining, exploration, story and building alongside moments of tension and 'jump'. They are different enough to be unique and similar enough so that you can seamlessly move from the first game to the second. I am FAR more excited by the possibility of a third in the series than I am about almost any other franchise (possible exception of a new Witcher game), It would be interesting to include small RPG elements about decision making and skillsets but other than that, I am not sure this developer could do much more to make these games better. They both score high 90s/100 for me and my 7 year old son who loves them very much, especially creative mode, scores them 100/100.

Below Zero really had a promising start. It seemed to be taking things in a slightly new direction but still had elements from the first game that make it so fun. Slowly as you keep playing though, the problems start to seep in. The story is the biggest downfall of this game. There are so many contradictions in the story it isn't even funny. Not only that but the motivations and logic behind the actions of the characters in this game are slightly silly at best and laughably bad for the worst examples. One of biggest missteps this game takes is being way to hand-holdy. I want to explore and see what the game has to offer but it feels like every time I reach a new biome I'm told "There is something important here go look!". It totally ruins the feeling of uncovering something and just turns into a guided tour that it really didn't have to be. Initially I appreciated some of the dialog but quickly it got old how often it would pop up and tell me something that I could have figured out on my own. I'm glad they added some cool new base parts and tried out some new vehicles. However apart from a few new things,  some basic quality of life problems still remain in the game. The palpable tension and atmosphere from the first game are greatly diminished. If you are coming into this game fresh, and haven't played the first one, it will probably be a decent experience as it is still better then many survival games out there. However, I would generally say give it a pass and just play the first game. It is a much better game in so many ways. They both have problems but in Below Zero almost every new addition feels like 1 step forward and 3 steps back. It hurts to write this because Subnautica is so close to my heart. You can really see the cracks starting to shine through with the direction they are going by aiming for a more story focused experience. I will definitely be weary buying into another game made by UWE.
