Ah, Subnautica. The best survival game I have ever played and definitely one of the best games I've ever played. Playing through that game was an absolute joy, heavily bolstered by its open-endedness, sheer terror, and the oddly compelling, dangerous curiousity to swim even deeper, and deeper, and deeper into the abyss than ever before. The brightest moment of that game for me was, ironically, exploring the deepest, darkest parts of the map, expertly crafted by Unknown Worlds, all by myself. The isolation was the cornerstone of Subnautica. It's part of what makes it so freaking good. I struggled to go even deeper than even 50m for the first 10 hours because of the sheer terror I felt exploring, but I forced myself to do it anyways because it's just so much fun.

I have nothing but fond memories from the original Subnautica. I still play it to this day. Very few games have the honor to be replayed by me regularly. And even fewer games have mastered the feeling that the fear of the oceans gives you, the fear of the unknown.

So, you would think that the sequel to such a well-beloved game would be just as good, if not better, right?

Well, you thought wrong.

 Subnautica: Below Zero is nowhere as bright as the shining star that was the original Subnautica.

What's the quote again? "Wide as an ocean, but deep as a puddle"?

The world is about 1/5th the size of the original's world. So, with that in mind, you would expect for Below Zero's world to go even deeper than the original, and be the exact opposite of that quote?

Small as a puddle, but deep as an ocean. 

Ha, you would think, right?

Below Zero's world is as wide as a puddle and shallow as one. The world doesn't get very deep at all compared to the original Subnautica. and there's not anywhere near as many places to dive in. There's not very much underwater biome variety as well. In fact, about a 1/3 of the world is covered up with walkable terrain. And guess what? The walking is awful. Everywhere you walk, even in your bases above and below the sea, being stuck on a random object isn't an uncommon ocurrence. A massive shame such a large portion of an underwater survival game is spent exploring above the sea level, and you can't even have a bug-free time doing so, eh?

Speaking of going underwater, Below Zero is nowhere near as scary as the original. The devs just brightened everything, took away all the cool leviathans from the first game and replaced them with gimmicky creatures and plants designed to piss you off (cough cough Sea Monkey) or make the game boring as crap (oxygen bubble plants. the inclusion of these actually takes away all incentive to use vehicles.).

All that brilliantly paced tension: Gone. A major tool for Subnautica's succes: Gone.

Below Zero has a prewritten, voiced protagonist, a woman named Robin, as well, but the story is very poorly written, illogical, and very handholdy to the point where it makes Mass Effect Andromeda's story look enticing, taking away one of the best aspects of the original: The freedom to do whatever you want, to go wherever you want, whenever you want as whoever you wish to be. 

The original Subnautica also had a prewritten protagonist as well (a man named Riley, I believe), but that protagonist was silent, so it makes the game even more impressionable as you become more and more immersed in the world. You start playing as Riley, but by the end of the game, you are playing as yourself. 

A quick explanation of what I mean:
The original Subnautica was about your personal journey. Your adventures. Every action you take is your own. 

Below Zero is about Robin's journey, not yours. It can't even tell Robin's story well, unfortunately. Robin's story is entirely made from her and her sister's negligence, how the hell is that compelling, Unknown Worlds?

And now, the soundtrack. 

The soundtrack of Subnautica has morphed, from tense, but futuristic electronic music, absolutely dripping with atmosphere with every sound, every note. A perfect blend between technologically mystifying ocean exploration and bone chilling horror.

Simon Chylinski knew what he was doing, man. (I'll post links for both Subnautica and Below Zero for comparison.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tOJVtMtSLpw

 ..to generic underwater exploration music that sounds like something from Spore. The new composer, Ben Prunty thought a national geographic album would be more appropiate.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SyNiDh7fEYE&list=PLDisKgcnAC4Te0v8NH5Ddy-tcBKBtryhR&index=5

A travesty, really. 


So, because of these shortcomings (and more I haven't mentioned), Below Zero absolutely destroys every aspect that made the original game so compelling:

To see what's beyond the murky, pitch black depths.

To go where no man has gone before.

To recognize and overcome the primal terror of looking directly at the abyss and having it staring back at you with malicious intent.

To explore an alien world as if you personally inhabited it yourself, as if you were the protagonist.

That was what the original Subnautica stood for. That was what made it so successful in the first place.

So, why the sudden change in direction for the series after such a massive success?

Look at Unknown Worlds, what do the devs have to say about this?

UW actually fired the OG Subnautica's composer and sound director, Simon Chylinski, (which explains why the sound design is this game is so bland) over making a mild joke about an Attack Helicopter (shortly before Subnautica's release, I believe.)

I've also noticed that during the early access period for Below Zero, the story was remade about 6-8 times. The game was fundementally changed several times throughout the early access period. The original voice actor for Robin was changed as well.

I've never, ever seen any early access game pull changes that drastically in my 15+ years of gaming, so that leaves me a few questions:

Did Unknown Worlds have any sort of solid plan for Below Zero? 

Was there any sort of infighting going on between the dev team at Unknown Worlds?

Why were they having such a hard time deciding on one idea and sticking with it?


I sense [i] somebody [/i] (gestures directly towards Unknown Worlds) is having a Bioware moment and throwing away all sorts of talent foolishly and trying to recapture lightning in a bottle without the capabilities to do so.

Because of these actions that the devs have been doing a lot as of recently, and because of the bad product they've shipped out as Subnautica: Below Zero, I really can't recommend this game in any good faith.

In fact, dare I say, I don't have any faith that Unknown Worlds' next project is going to turn out well. I expect Subnautica 3 to be a disaster.

Subnautica: Below Zero, for me, is a 4/10. Below Zero is a major dissappointment for me personally, which really depresses me since I was a massive fan of the original Subnautica. That game changed me, made reconsider what kinds of games I should play.

If you want to venture into the wondrous, aquatic alien world of Planet 4546B, I highly recommend playing the original Subnautica and completely ignore Below Zero entirely so you don't soil the memories you get from playing the original.


TL;DR: 

Subpar: Below Average isn't worth your time.

They had to hire a different voice actor (and less talented in my opinion) near the end of development, the map was so much smaller compared to the original, the game didn't have the same vibe when entering places meant to be horror based, and most of the vehicles they introduced barely served a purpose or was over prepared as if it was made for a much bigger game. I bought this when it first was released in development some 2 years ago now.
The fact that the Maida is alive turned me off the game completely.
Why?
1. Killed by Leviathan(s)
2. Killed by Kharaa
3. Starved/thirsted to death
4. Froze to death
5. Drowned.
Maida was a survivor. She had the skills to pull of surviving 4546B, she proved that when she dragged the Torgals along with her. But planet 4546B killed her all the same. Poetically, the very survival instinct she possessed drove the into a slightly earlier death than anticipated. Earlier death, but not avoidable. They were infected and going to die no matter what. Because they didn't find the sea emperor and hatch her babies.

Subnautica zero ruined that by reviving a dead woman and plopping her to a place she had no business being. For the last two years I had hoped that the developers would compare the story line between and realise the deus ex machina they were committing. But alas no.

I hope you enjoy the game, I sure didn't.

What I wish is that there were just as many subnautica's out there as there were first person shooters.

Below Zero lacks the charm and engagement of the original game on just about every level save one.

First, the map. The original's map was expansive and interesting. The one here feels kind of samey, being in some areas too mixed and without the same degree of layered exploration. In the original exploration felt very layered. Like every time you went deeper you were moving into a new world with a sense of fear and wonder which magnified as you found new strange locations such as the Lost River and below. Below Zero it lacks that. Instead they all just kind of merge together and the layout just comes off as bland. The closest they have is the surface exploration which, while not bad, is feels divorced from the core game play loop and is set up into this mess of canyons that just adds artificial challenge.

Second, the vehicle progression. In the original you work your way up from the Seamoth to the Cyclops. There was a sense of progression. In Below Zero you build the Sea Truck and just bolt new pods to the back and give it upgrade upon upgrade. And using the Cyclops vs. the Seamoth felt like a trade off in places. The cyclops was a mobile base, but it moved like a pregnant cow. The Seamoth was speedy and agile but weak and limited. You could bring both (at least until you got to the lava chamber) but that would mean leaving the Prawn behind. There were trade offs. 

Third is the plot. In the original you were a simple survivor and the plot is discovered largely by vague hints and stumbling around blindly. You discovered it for yourself. It wasn't handed to you, you had to discover and explore and figure out what was going on for yourself. In Below Zero you immediately start with an annoying generic 'strong female protagonist' (not that anything is wrong with female protagonists, as long as being 'strong', 'female', and 'the protagonist' aren't the only memorable aspects of the character, like some soulless, self-propelled inclusivity checklist) who basically skydived naked onto an alien death world for 'reasons'. The plot is driven by an endless stream of poorly written exposition that manage to be memorable in only how annoyingly it can kill your immersion and coupled to 'helpful' way points that remove much of the impetus to explore.

One thing to note about the plot is that it was completely scrapped and rewritten halfway through development. It's one of the reasons the story comes off as so disjointed. The reason that everyone mysteriously vanished from the planet was because in the original plot the planet was abandoned after a meteor storm caused everyone to evac to an orbital station but Robin was left behind, but the station was severely damaged meaning that they couldn't go back down for her and it went from there. The current plot was shoe-horned into existing map assets, like a DLC of a DLC, and it shows. You can see this because the game has two stories that are not only completely disconnected, but one of them which was the reason you came there to begin with seems to drop off the map 30 minutes into the game and it's almost too easy to miss it due to the second feeding you a series of breadcrumbs that leads to the endgame.

In general, they missed the simple factor that made the first game great. It wasn't Ryley the Protagonist's story. It was my story. It was your story. It was the players story. The voiceless  blank slate character was simply a vessel for the player's experience. Below Zero is Robin's story, not the players, and frankly, she really ain't that interesting.

Then you have the creature designs which compared to the original are largely uninspired, drawing far too much from earth lifeforms to the point they seem less like strange and exotic alien lifeforms from a distant planet and more just strange and exotic prehistoric earth creatures. For example, you have the alternative to the Reaper Leviathan, the Chelicerate. It doesn't feel like as alien, instead its just kind of a giant death shrimp. Then you have the penguins. I mean 'pengwings'. Which are penguins.

Even most insulting is the fact that they actually had plans to add some well designed creatures to the game but chose not to because they cut a biome and thought that people didn't need excess creatures. The Ice Dragon Leviathan (check the wiki) would have been infinitely more interesting than the mega-shrimp we got.

The only improvement over the original is base design, which is largely due to the addition of some additional rooms and decorative elements. A very welcome addition but it kind of falls flat when combined with the everything else. 

In general, this is an all around inferior product that shouldn't be bought for full price. If you find it for half off, loved the original, and don't mind being lead around the nose by Lady Generica and her boring sidekick, go for it... but don't pay full price. It's not worth the money.

Update: The game being finished does nothing to change my opinion.

Note: Having thought about it, I'd almost like to say the theatrical trailer manages to be both a case of gross missadvertisement and the game they should have made. No bland voiced protagonist, just some poor sap trying to survive on a planet that seems hellbent to making them suffer. Wouldn't even have had to of replace the character model as I find absolutely nothing wrong with the idea of an everywoman protagonist...

Subnautica: Below Zero is such a let down in comparison to the original. The world/map feels suffocating with massive ice walls surrounding 2/3 of the world edge and labyrinth like underwater caves to find your blueprints. 

The Sea Truck is slow, janky and gets hooked on everything causing you to be disorientated. No other underwater vehicle option except the prawn suit which is rendered useless as the truck can go almost as deep as the prawn. On land sections are vast and empty with nothing of interest except running around for HOURS trying to find one alien base. The story is strange that you are searching information on your sister's death yet for the 20 hours I played this game, Sam (the sister) was almost never mentioned. The monsters of the game lack scare factor and the ocean is not as terrifying as the original.

The positives are that the most of biomes are bright, alien and resources are mostly plentiful. Equipment progression is relatively easy compared to the original. I dragged myself through 80% of the game to just put it down because its making me miserable. Overall, I am super disappointed in this game and really wanted to enjoy a similar experience to the original but it fell short.

Subnautica: Below Zero is an epic adventure that will transport you to an icy and exotic world hidden beneath the ocean's surface. Developed by the awesome folks at Unknown Worlds Entertainment, this standalone expansion of the original Subnautica takes the excitement to the next level!

Get ready to be blown away by the stunning graphics and immersive sound design that bring this world to life. With a gripping storyline that builds upon the original game and introduces new characters, plot twists, and exploration opportunities, you'll be hooked from the start! And the best part? The game's progression is perfectly balanced, so you'll never feel overwhelmed!

But what really sets Subnautica: Below Zero apart is the amazing world-building. You'll dive into an immersive underwater ecosystem, encountering weird and wonderful creatures as you explore a variety of new biomes, like icebergs and frozen caves. And with a range of cool tools and vehicles at your disposal, you'll be able to navigate this mysterious world like a pro!

The crafting system is also super impressive, allowing you to create all sorts of awesome tools, vehicles, and equipment using resources you gather from the environment. With so much to discover and explore, you'll never want to leave this captivating world!

In a nutshell, Subnautica: Below Zero is an incredible survival game that takes the original to new heights. With gorgeous visu

After having played through and completing Subnautica i was overjoyed to see there was an expansion.  I just finished Below Zero and while I feel like it was not quite at the same level as the first one it is still worth playing through.  The game environments (mostly) are again beautifully done along with all the details of each biome, however, i have a few critiques...  

First off the overall size this time seemed much smaller, maybe its because there is more top side land in this one to navigate, but with all the great things they did underwater the top side just felt uninteresting.  I only ventured on the surface just long enough to accomplish a few mandatory tasks before returning to the depths to never again set foot topside until the end of the game.  Oh and the "snowfox" was more like "snowFAIL", absolute garbage vehicle and the ice worms were just annoying!  I will give props to the dynamic weather this time, though, annoying sometimes... i do enjoy a good weather system in play.  Secondly, what is the deal with the no maps thing!? Again with trying to navigate around with nothing more than a compass and beacon's... I can make all this cool shit but i can't plot out a map? seriously? ugh...

The story was cool, the alien tag along was a new and different experience.  Some folks found it poorly done but i thought it was a nice touch overall.  I was wondering exactly how the game would end but I didn't think it would go the direction it did.  

Lastly i thought the base building was more constricted due to the size of the map, i didn't feel motivated much at all really to expand out for a 2nd base and i only utilized the pop-up scanner base a couple of times...  I was disappointed to see it would not pick up on wrecks or alien sites considering the navigation difficulty.  I accomplished everything i needed with a fairly small base and i never had the need to use a nuclear reactor or a thermal gen...  Between 1 solar panel and the bio-reactor i never had a want for more power.

Overall it was a pretty good play through and is a must if you have played the first one already.  I definitely got my money's worth out of it.  Great game!

To preface this, Below Zero is good game, I feel, but it's not *as good* as the original Subnautica.

My play time is a bit fragmented, I got really close to finishing it, but got stuck for whatever reason and quit without finishing it.  After getting back into the original game, I tried to give this another shot.

There's a bunch of design decisions that are different from the original game, mostly because BZ is a standalone expansion rather than a full fledged sequel.  Some of these decisions were great, others I think stemmed from a misrepresentation of what players liked.

Let's start with the good.  The developers are masters of creating underwater alien landscapes.  Glowing purple rocks that regularly "pop" into flame jets.  Lily pads that are attached to chunks of rock at their base.  Massive icebergs with caverns inside.  Deep underwater mushrooms that spit out spores that float in the water.  All of it feels alien and you'll always be amazed at the environment.

The progression system does two things: it allows you to slowly acclimate to the environments around you while letting you grind out some resources for your next project, and there's always at least one or two resources that will force you to go out of your comfort zone to search for new materials.  For example, to make a certain material, you need mushrooms from a deep cave.  Your vehicle likely won't be able to reach all the way, so you'll be forced to do at least 100 meters or so outside the safety of your seateuck.  You'll also rarely feel like you need to grind.  The system from the OG Subnautica was changed so that each outcropping now has 1 special resource, or titanium (a general crafting resource for most things and base building) instead of having nodes carry 1 of 3 different resources that was completely random.

As for the bad, the story just isn't as intriguing.  S1 had a story of a mysterious crash landing, and you slowly put the pieces together of what happened, and how you'll escape the alien planet.  You're also a silent protagonist, so you're alone with your thoughts and the occasional informational and sometimes snarky PDA.  SZ has a voice protagonist and eventually an alien in your head.  I don't hate this, but it creates a very different vibe than the original.  The game also gives you your objectives almost straight away (find 3 specific blueprints, craft them, then bring them to a certain place, and also find out what happened to your sister).  S1 didn't, you just survived and slowly got introduced to the gravity of the situation you were in.  The character animations for people are also just... Weird, like they couldn't do stop motion so they all feel like cheap canned animations from the early GameCube era.

Land areas are too much and Subnauticas engine leaves a lot to be desired.  There are a few neat moments, but for the most part they just feel like a slog.

Lastly, I don't like the Seateuck and it's modular design.  I get why the Cyclops from S1 wasn't included, because of the map size, but there's no point to getting all the Seateuck mods.  Half of them are useless (sleeping quarters and aquarium), and the more modules you add, the slower you get.  The Seamoth was a perfect early exploration vessel and there was no need to remove it from BZ.  The Prawn suit is back because I'm sure the fan base would've rioted if they scrapped it.

Overall I think it's still a fine game and if you liked the exploraion of S1, you'll find something you liked in SBZ.

There are no multiple saves and the developers disabled cloud saving some time ago (no idea why), so if you encounter a game breaking bug or a corrupted save there is zero (below zero perhaps) ways to restore to 5 minutes before or even an hour or two before where you were.

This type of game really needs strong save game code because progress is all about long distances, searching random spawns, dangerous situations etc.

For example the second tier oxygen tank blueprint is in exactly one location, and if you miss it, or as in my case think you got everything from that location, you are going to have a bad time.

Builds on the story a lot more than the first game did, and it actually started to feel like a sci-fi adventure rather than an ocean game. The game for me was overall shorter with less in it as a whole, but its still a worth it play for subnautica lovers. I did notice less bugs than the first game, but a few non gamebreaking glitches were found in my casual playthrough, just menial stuff like hail falling through the ceilings of a cave, nothing like getting flung around at mach speeds in a prawn suit that I experienced during my playthrough. I do wish the game was longer, my first subnautica playthrough lasted 48 hours with this one lasting only 18. I had tons of fun playing, but it really leaves something to be desired. One downside is the map construction felt almost constricted. In the first subnautica there was a vast and open ocean in all directions, except this time around theres shallow waters with small biomes and often times "Deep" versions of them, which are mildly different. Do be careful, though, as if you avoid going deep in some places you'll miss a whole new biome, so just be on the lookout. I would have liked a more vast and open map similar to the first game, as an example of what I'm talking about, I found the seatruck hard to maneuver in most areas with anything more than 2 "trailers".  I can say, however, that the story was very comprehensive and it was easy to find out what to do next without the use of a guide, unless you missed something. With that being said, a bit of advice would be that if you get a major piece of information, and then find nothing important, and the story grinds to a hault aside from small things, you may need to revisit some places if you don't want to look at a guide to see what you missed. 

I recommend buying this game if you catch it on sale.

TL;DR: the first game was longer and had tons more content, but this game adds tons onto the lore and was still an enjoyable gameplay experience. It felt lacking in terms of the whole map, and didn't deliver as much as I would have liked. 6.5/10

I would have recommended it if I had reviewed this game before finishing it, now I'm glad I waited until then.

The worst part of this game is the story. The story is very cliche, and Rail-roady. The mystery that was offered in the first game was interesting and mysterious. In this game, it's very annoying and tedious. The characters have very little depth and the story doesn't change much at all from the beginning. It's a big corporation exploiting the khraa, again, and they even demystified the Architects. In the first game the story made you want to explore more Biomes and go deeper into the sea. In this game, most resources are 0-450m deep. There's really no reason to go deep except for curiosity or because the game forces you to. There aren't many benefits to going deep like there was in the original game. Also, the Arctic Biome was, barren. Not just literally but also of content. And the Worms? kind of a rip off of Dune without much story to them as well. I don't mean to get attacked by SJW's but all of the important characters were female. That's fine, but it feels forced and obvious, like the storyteller was trying to make a point.

Exploration was fun, if not short-lived. I was excited to see the new Biomes and Build my bases, but the fun quickly faded. There wasn't a lot of new content in the new Biomes, maybe about the standard amount for Biomes less than 450m deep, less that standard at deeper levels, and almost none than absolutely necessary in the arctic areas. What's with base building as well? just put in a Bio-reactor and an Alien Containment (although this was hard to find), using too much energy? Build two Bio-Reactors or build a Nuclear Reactor. There wasn't much motivation for going any other way, like Thermal or Solar. Maybe Bio Reactors and urananaite should be harder to access, or there should be another way to incentivise toher power methods. 

Lastly, I liked having the SeaTruck, but I hated only having the seatruck. The Submarine in the previous game was  awesome and it would have been nice to at least have that option again, if not even more options.

Did a pacifist make this one? In the first game you needed teeth for enameled glass and now you don't need to harm any predators to finish the game at all, why not instead offer some amount of combat and creative awards for fending off squidsharks and leviathans? Rewards could be crafting material or even a guardian you need to beat to get access to an area. Oh and maybe add a skin ability to leviathans to shake off grappling arms if you do implement combat. Killing Leviathans is too easy with the old grapple and drill method.  

Lastly, but least likely to be implemented, if the game were at larger and included multiplayer, that would expand the player base a lot, but would probably require a much larger budget.

TL;DR This game is limited compared to the first, the story was much tedious rather than mysterious. The combat was even less than the first game (essentially only defensive). The exploration was slightly less than the original in terms of depth, and base-building was about the same, minus a few new, small changes. This game was also a lot easier than an original. I cannot recommend it in good conscience.
Every time that I play this, I take an Pengling to my base to start my own family
great love it one of the best games i have ever played
fun
Good game. Doesn't quite capture the same feelings as the first game, but looks even better and runs much better. Recommend.

You're probably wondering if Sub Zero is as good as the original Subnautica, and unfortunately the answer is no. I appreciate all the things they did to distinguish Below Zero from the original Subnautica, and most of them are fun additions to the game. However, Below Zero does lack a certain je ne sais quoi that made the first game so special and memorable. If you finish the original game and find yourself jonesing for more hot Subnautica action, Sub Zero will fit the bill, but don't expect to be blown away like you were with the first Subnautica.

fun game, just like its predecessor except this one is more forgiving= safer starting point, land you can build bases on where you don't need to worry about hull integrity, monsters are easier to kill with exception of the big ones, those are okay to grapple to but they have MASSIVE HP pools: you will find yourself detaching and repairing then go back at it for a couple of times but once you kill it it never re-spawns so the reward is creating a safe zone for yourself, starting point protagonist is a female I am a male so I cant immerse in it 100% but it stops mattering due to content, like the fact that you can eventually carry a prawn suit on your sea-truck which can have a defensive hull taser if a monster gets a little too romantic with you. all in all greatly balanced, the scary factor is still there but decreased due to available tools if you take your time to prepare. Story is neat and jumping from freezing land to seas with monsters back n forth is never boring even if the map is tad smaller than first game

Smaller area to work with and some glitches still remain, such as getting stuck in rocks and fragments being inside rocks when you ping them with the scanner room, and not very obvious how to get to some waypoints, but still keeps the essence and thrill of Subnautica!

O melhor entre os dois subnauticas. Realmente chegou em uma maturidade interessante o jogo. O sistema de construção de bases é tranquilo, e dá para fazer muitas coisas diferentes. A história também é um prato cheio para os gêneros de sci-fi, bem como as resoluções. O único contra é ficar perdido no meio de um mundo gigante, moendo o tempo enquanto crafta e monta a base. Os mapas e sistemas de navegação são bastante rudimentares e não ajudam nos pontos de labirinto. 
Mas para quem terminou a história em 1 semana, realmente o joguinho me prendeu. 
(não vou revisitá-lo. As bases e crafts eu montei durante o jogo, e estou satisfeito com o final)
fun

I haven't finished the game yet, so take this what you will.

The first game is much better overall. All I know about the development of this game is that it was originally going to be DLC for the first. IDK how that would have worked, but it IS nice to see them make a whole game of it. What IS NOT nice is that it doesn't live up to the first game. Call it high expectations, but you should really only get this game if you just want more Subnautica. Don't expect a full sequel to the first. Zombiebutt already summarized it pretty good in his review.
I say go play the first, but I'm surprised a game released in 2018 is still $30 at full price. Get either game on a sale, I can't recommend any at full price, but, if you feel inclined to do so, get the first game.

Edit: The actual save, doesn't seem to work anymore. Many articles online with others claiming the same issue - but I'm not finding resolutions.


I love this game, but I could do with 'some' kind of autosave. 

The last time I played I had an error that made it so I had to terminate. Didn't just lose the progress since the previous save, but somehow even lost the hard-save from earlier that day. Resetting me 12 hours of gameplay to the night before. I went from fighting a massive lategame creature to having just built my seatruck.

The voice acting is really good, but if you have to do it all over again due to weird save issues, it's less interesting the third and fourth time.
Awesome game and a great successor for the first game. Really excited where the story goes next!

Just like the first one this game is insane and definitely worth full price. I am so hyped for what the devs give us next - whatever it is, I hope for some elements from both games to make a return.

The game has minor bugs. My worst bug encounter so far was when I fell through the ground once, however I eventually managed to climb back up.

The game has many very different situations, which all feel like they are hardly the same game. For example I would argue, there are at least 3 very different on-land areas to explore, one has a Leviathan, one a lot of scary things, and the rest is a lot of lore. In the water there is just as much gameplay variety. Thus, the game requires you to build a lot of bases and explore a lot, which is great! Just be aware though, that once the story is complete, there is no endgame goodbye. It just ends. That made me quite sad on my first playthrough.
really good game could play for hours.

Thumbs Up from me as a stand alone Game. Together with Subnautica felt like, there was more to explore and more magical moments and mystery in the first one. Plus the map felt smaller then last time, but i could be wrong.
The addition of land excursions was great and would not mind if the Studio played with the Idea of Alterra as a backbone for another game, but this time different environment. Not below, but more land, air or all things together. Different discoveries of different team on different worlds, could be an interesting story/franchise.

its like the first game but it feels almost soulless i feel like this game lost all the original charm that the fist game did also like the first its to easy and there are really no practical uses for the sea truck add ons besides maybe the storage

Personally, I think the sea truck is better than the cyclops in terms of functionality. Aesthetically, it's like the human centipede of vehicles. Map is smaller than Subnautica but they have an above-ground grappling-hook-friendly area which is the tits. I highly recommend you play the original first.

Great game, love the Subnautica franchise. The first and second game have a lot to love but I still love the first game more than the second one, I think the overall fear of a new area and a sense of dread is what makes the first game better. Base building is great and the Seatruck is great but I'll always love the big submarine from the first game... Especially when being attacked and the disco that ensues. Overall a great game this time round but lacks that 'something' from the first game. Equally worth playing however... Subnautica 3? I hope so!!!

Game crashes 3 hours in, boot back up and the save file has just vanished, googled it, apparently lots of people have this issue and have to resort to manually backing up files in case it get's corrupted. Playing on GFN that's not an options for me, so basically it's unplayable, as even if i started again, i could get 20 hours in, game crash and lose all progress again.Last time i had this issue was in the 90s, come on, seriously.

I have mixed feelings about this one. After playing the first game multiple times, I finally had enough and wanted the newer, fresher experience which I hoped I would get with Below Zero. First impressions were good, better graphics, more detailed environments, smoother performance, all good. Now the story thread through the game is interesting and nicely told overall, but I never really had the feeling of the first game. The sense of exploration that kept me on the edge of the seat in the first playthrough. I understand that it is near impossible to get the same feeling with a similar game or in this case the sequel, but it was present the whole time somehow, this was a different experience. I just wanted to get through the story and finish the game, so I could get on with it. Nevertheless I had a good time playing it and as you can see it took about 40 hours. Got all achievements and didn't rush it, so I consider it worth my money (did get it on a sale though). Will I play this multiple times like the first Subnautica? Probably not. Tldr.: I recommend

Absolutely great game! Backstory was smooth and solid and the lore was so interesting. This game definitely fills in those gaps and just extends your enjoyment with cool new features. Would highly recommend to play this game!

A lot of reviews have made comments about how they think the story of this game as well as other aspects are a downgrade from Subnautica 1. I honestly just cannot agree… really at all. I think this game was a fine successor to Subnautica 1 in most every way. The environment, base building, creatures, terror, etc. were recaptured very well in Subnautica 2. The story is not all that bad in my opinion and I liked the interaction between Robin and Al-An. I was expecting throughout for Al-An to turn on Robin and become evil but I was pleasantly surprised in a subversion of expectations way when Al-An never did and he and Robin finally made it to his home world in search of his people. I think for most people, if they enjoyed Subnautica 1 they will enjoy 2 as well.
